webTitle: Burma junta resorts to ridicule as Suu Kyi camp digs in

fields.headline: Burma junta resorts to ridicule as Suu Kyi camp digs in
fields.trailText: The United States has denounced Burma's treatment of its opposition leader, Aung San Suu Kyi, as the country's military junta steps up its campaign against her.
fields.body:
The United States has denounced Burma's treatment of its opposition leader, Aung San Suu Kyi, as the country's military junta steps up its campaign against her.

Ms Suu Kyi has been camped in a suburb of the Burmese capital, Rangoon, since August 24, when she was blocked from driving further in defiance of a ban on her leaving the city.

The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, said she was appalled that Ms Suu Kyi had been denied the freedom to travel within her own country.

"Her work gives voice to the long-suffering people of Burma whose hopes for a democratic society have been crushed by a repressive regime," said Mrs Albright. "Her voice will not be silenced."

But in Burma the only voice being heard is that of the junta, which is combining ridicule with threats against Ms Suu Kyi.

She had now become an "enemy of the people", the junta's official website said yesterday. It argued that she is "constitutionally disqualified to stand for elected office" because "[her] bloodline remains only in Britain."

Ms Suu Kyi's late husband was British and they have two sons, but she has taken care to maintain her Burmese citizenship.

Earlier, Rangoon published photographs with satirical captions suggesting that the encampment of Ms Suu Kyi's small group in the suburb of Dala was just a pleasant outing. One picture shows her car next to a hut and a tent, with the caption: "Daw [Ms] Suu Kyi and her travel companions continuing their stay in the new rest camp at Dala."

Other pictures show members of her party, the National League for Democracy (NLD), "going for an afternoon dip" in a nearby river and "visiting a Chinese noodle shop".

Ms Albright's criticism of the junta was backed on Thursday by the US vice president, Al Gore, who said that "each day the Burmese authorities restrain [her], Burma's isolation from the international community deepens".

Yesterday the UN high commissioner for human rights, Mary Robinson, expressed her concern for the safety of Ms Suu Kyi and urged Burma to resolve the standoff "in line with international human rights standards".

"I urge the two sides to engage, as soon as possible, in a substantive political dialogue" she added.

The standoff comes at a very bad time for the junta, said Dr Peter Carey, a family friend and south-east Asia historian at Oxford University.

"It is split between different factions, and the economy is at a low ebb," he said yesterday. "China is still an ally but there are limits to the open cheque."

But the NLD is also in a weak position. The party is struggling to survive outside Rangoon and Ms Suu Kyi's attempt to link up with party members beyond the capital is important, said Dr Carey, "to add substance to her claim that it is still functioning".

The junta's propaganda offensive this week has portrayed Ms Suu Kyi and the NLD as uninterested in dialogue and preferring to indulge in "symbolic gestures".

It hints that the country's universities, which have only recently reopened after being shut down in 1996, may be closed again if there are more political protests. Ms Suu Kyi was attempting a journey to meet members of the NLD's youth league when her path was blocked at Dala.

U Maung Maung, a tea-shop owner from central Rangoon, is quoted saying that his customers "are concerned about their children's education and some have even suggested [a law] to prevent students from participating in party politics".

webTitle: Mexican officials want to expel settlers from protected forest

fields.headline: A burning issue of farmers and rebels
fields.standfirst: Mexican officials want to expel settlers from protected forest. But they are wary of taking on the Zapatistas
fields.trailText: Mexican officials want to expel settlers from protected forest. But they are wary of taking on the Zapatistas
fields.body:
In Mexico's most important area of tropical rainforest the jaguar prowls, a type of red macaw found nowhere else in the world makes its nest, and the only swamp crocodile known to live above 800 metres has its home.

But, the authorities say, the ecological balance of this global treasure of biodiversity called the Montes Azules biosphere reserve is under serious threat from communities deep in the interior, most of whom say they will not leave without a fight.

"They can come and get us if they like, but we live tranquilly here, everything grows so easily and we don't want to go," Don Mariano, whose link to civilisation is a river four-hours' walk away from his village, San Francisco. "We think they want to kick out the poor so they can sell it to the rich."

San Francisco is one of the 14 "irregular communities" who have vowed never to leave the rainforest, their determination strengthened by their link to the Zapatista rebels hiding in the jungle.

Another 12, non-Zapatista, communities are similarly reluctant to leave such fertile soil, and similarly suspicious of the authorities' relocation programme.

"If the government was really so worried about the environment they would have solved the problem long ago," said Porfirio Encino, who represents seven communities which have agreed in principle to negotiate but in practice have made it clear that they are unwilling to go.

"No, this is not an ecological problem, it is a political and military issue," he said. There are rumours that relocation is a pretext to facilitate an attack on the Zapatistas.

"And there is oil in the area, and a wealth of biological resources bio-prospectors would love to exploit."

"History has taught them to mistrust the government," said Roman Perez, an official at the reserve. But if they did not leave, he said, ecological disaster could be as little as five or 10 years away.

The reserve covers 331,000 hectares (827,000 acres) in Chiapas, near the Guatemalan border. It was created in 1978 in the heart of the Lacandon jungle, which was then shrinking at an alarming rate as prospectors thinned out the valuable trees and the advancing frontier of farming levelled its edges.

The need to actively protect its integrity was largely ignored until a series of forest fires two years ago damaged about 30,000 hectares and focused attention on the increasing number of communities set up within it.

The authorities accept that there there is little they can do about the two dozen well-established villages on the perimeter which have legal titles to the land, so they are concentrating on the more recent settlers.

"The biggest risk is fragmentation," Mr Perez said.

Although the irregular communities are small and dispersed, they threaten to break up the unity of the ecosystem.

The danger is greatest in the dry season, when the settlers burn off the vegetation in preparation for planting, posing the threat of uncontrollable fires.

"The most logical thing to do would be to send in the security forces to evict the irregular communities, but that simply is too politically delicate a thing to do, because of the Zapatistas." he said. "Realistically, a long-term solution to the problem will not be possible until that conflict is resolved."

"We didn't want to move from that blessed land, where things grow on their own," Enrique Perez said, standing in front of his new concrete house and surveying the five hectares he has been given in a heavily farmed area 50 miles west of Montes Azules. "Sure, there is the road, but what good is the road when we have nothing to sell? I am thinking of going back."

Those who have yet to move are also reconsidering their decision to go, in the light of the recent presidential and state governorship elections victories by candidates committed to peace talks with the Zapatistas.

The word spreading through the jungle is that the new authorities will be anxious to defuse the tension that the relocation drive has created around the rebels' safe havens.

webTitle: Residents ordered to flee volcano Japanese island

fields.headline: Leaving home
fields.standfirst: Residents ordered to flee volcano island
fields.trailText: Japanese authorities ordered the evacuation of all remaining residents from Miyake-jima island yesterday after experts warned of the possibility of massive volcanic eruptions.
fields.body:
Japanese authorities ordered the evacuation of all remaining residents from Miyake-jima island yesterday after experts warned of the possibility of massive volcanic eruptions.

Most of Miyake-jima's 3,800 residents have already left the island, 125 miles south of Tokyo. Over the next three days the remaining 900 will be ferried to the mainland, where they will be given food and accommodation.

The evacuation order came after experts from the meteorological agency said Mount Oyama, at the centre of the island, was in danger of unleashing huge pyroclastic flows - very fast-flowing frothy lava.

Residents on the island have suffered a summer of disruption, with a series of powerful earthquakes and minor eruptions followed on August 18 by Mount Oyama's biggest eruption since 1983.

Last week, more than 130 children and their teachers were evacuated after another large eruption.

Although they are unable to predict the timing of an eruption, the experts were concerned by evidence that rising magma was coming into contact with underground water, a process that has potentially catastrophic consequences.

Shintaro Ishihara, the governor of Tokyo, said the island faced " a danger greater than anything we have experienced so far".

About 600 officials and emergency workers will remain on the island during the daytime to monitor volcanic activity and check gas and water supplies. They are likely to spend the night moored offshore.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Ruth Lea, the head of the policy unit at the Institute of Directors, has asked us to make it clear that she took part in the debate on page 2 of the Saturday Review, August 26, on the understanding that she was arguing against the proposition that men should have paternity rights equivalent to the maternity rights of women. She would certainly not have replied "No" to the question posed in the headline, "Do women lose out at work because of maternity leave?" We are sorry for any misunderstanding and consequent embarrassment.
fields.body:
Ruth Lea, the head of the policy unit at the Institute of Directors, has asked us to make it clear that she took part in the debate on page 2 of the Saturday Review, August 26, on the understanding that she was arguing against the proposition that men should have paternity rights equivalent to the maternity rights of women. She would certainly not have replied "No" to the question posed in the headline, "Do women lose out at work because of maternity leave?" We are sorry for any misunderstanding and consequent embarrassment.

Contrary to what we said in our front-page report about the retirement of George Carman, August 30, it was in the context of a libel case brought against Channel 4, not The People, that the South African journalist Jani Allan made the remarks attributed to her. Ms Allan was suing over Nick Broomfield's documentary of 1991, The leader, his driver and the driver's wife. She said of Mr Carman, who was representing Channel 4, which won the case: "Whatever the award for libel, being cross-examined by you would not make it enough money."

Sharon Manitta, the freelance conservator mentioned in our report Museums in crisis, page 8, August 29, is not a founder member of the Institute of Conservators. She is, however, a member of the United Kingdom Institute for Conservation of Historic and Artistic Works.

fields.headline: Spelling out the benefits
fields.trailText: When Dr Johnson fixed our spellings he may have promoted the destruction of "the previous free choice in English spellings" (Letters, August 31), but he was promoting a more valuable kind of free choice, by instituting a useful and widely welcomed set of conventions, by means of which anything can be clearly expressed and easily understood.
fields.body:
When Dr Johnson fixed our spellings he may have promoted the destruction of "the previous free choice in English spellings" (Letters, August 31), but he was promoting a more valuable kind of free choice, by instituting a useful and widely welcomed set of conventions, by means of which anything can be clearly expressed and easily understood.

Try reading the stuff produced by the pre-Johnson writers. It is doubtless an art form and intriguing, but if you want to know what they were trying to say, you have a struggle on your hands. There is a pay-off between writers and readers; the more conventional the presentation of the writer's message, the easier it is for the reader to grasp it quickly.

It is surprising how much people who can't spell suffer and the limitations which the problem imposes on their lives. This is not widely understood as, naturally, they don't talk about it much.

Susan Greig
Hannington Wick, Wilts susangreig@cwcom.net

 There's little point in going into the niceties of spelling: soon all communication and transactions will be via speech-operated/recognising/synthesising computers. These technologies will engender greater social change than the advent of printing.

Peter Rowland
London PeterRowland@compuserve.com

 John Mullan (Law of the letter, G2, August 30) says "Spelling reformers would solve everything forever". The New Fowler says "forever" in this sense is an American usage for "for ever".

Edward Holroyd
Eversley, Hants

fields.headline: Full dish
fields.trailText: BSkyB's Julian Eccles (Letters, August 31) is selective in response to my criticism of a standard Sky digital system. A Sky-approved tuner cannot be programmed for anything other than the Sky transmissions.
fields.body:
BSkyB's Julian Eccles (Letters, August 31) is selective in response to my criticism of a standard Sky digital system. With cheap installation and "free" satellite tuner, many are duped into a diminutive dish that is useless for anything other than the predominantly Sky transmissions from one isolated satellite. A Sky-approved tuner cannot be programmed for anything other than the Sky transmissions.

In contrast, my installation - which costs little more - is looking at 12 satellites, allowing me to install, with my German tuner, 500-plus free-to-air TV and radio stations from Europe and the Middle East, including the new ITN 24-hour news, which is unencrypted, in contrast to the BBC's. By opting for a Sky digital system, the viewer and listener is drastically narrowing options for the future.

Reg Williamson
Kidsgrove, Staffs regwilliamson@beeb.net

webTitle: Leader: Racism is on the upsurge in Germany

fields.headline: Echoes of the 30s
fields.standfirst: Racism is on the upsurge in Germany
fields.trailText: Germany is experiencing another disturbing wave of racially inspired violence and murder. At various moments in its post-war history the country has seen neo-Nazi groups winning, and losing, support. Now they are on the upsurge again with a series of killings among blacks and other minorities as well as arson attacks on asylum-seekers' hostels. A few of these incidents can be put down to drunken hooliganism by individuals, but there is mounting evidence that they stem from an organised sub-culture of racist nationalism and homophobia.
fields.body:
Germany is experiencing another disturbing wave of racially inspired violence and murder. At various moments in its post-war history the country has seen neo-Nazi groups winning, and losing, support. Now they are on the upsurge again with a series of killings among blacks and other minorities as well as arson attacks on asylum-seekers' hostels. A few of these incidents can be put down to drunken hooliganism by individuals, but there is mounting evidence that they stem from an organised sub-culture of racist nationalism and homophobia. Much of it can be traced to the nationalist party, the NPD, and particularly its youth wing. Headquartered in western Germany, it has made a big effort to recruit in the east, where social alienation and youth unemployment have remained high since unification a decade ago. The NPD youth wing's papers specifically call for the setting up in eastern Germany of "free spaces where we practically take power and can administer punishment to deviants and enemies". The technique, they say, is to mount shows of force through street demonstrations which go unchallenged.

Echoes of the 1930s are all too alarming and it is right that Germany's establishment has begun to take the issue seriously. The life sentence given this week to the leader of a group of youths who kicked a Mozambican to death sends a powerful signal, as do the nine-year terms for his 16-year-old accomplices. Chancellor Schröder's visit to lay a wreath at the murder site was equally significant. In democratic countries politicians frequently fail to join the fight against racism, arguing that it is best left to the courts. This may be acceptable when racist acts are rare, but when they become frequent and widespread it is vital for governments to give a political lead. By the same token the German government is right to have started talks with the other political parties for an approach to the constitutional court to ban the NPD and its youth wing. Bans should be a last resort. They pose major civil liberties problems and can drive groups underground without weakening them. But the evidence is that Germany's racists rely on street activity for their recruitment, so that prohibition would have an effect. The debate provoked by court hearings on a constitutional ban would also help to remind Germans that racism is no marginal matter. It needs to be fought, not ignored or wished away.

fields.headline: Swiss role
fields.trailText: First you serialise the gross inaccuracies of Norman Finkelstein's The Holocaust Industry and now you publish the astonishing revisionism of Tim Luckhurst (The plucky Swiss, September 1).
fields.body:
First you serialise the gross inaccuracies of Norman Finkelstein's The Holocaust Industry and now you publish the astonishing revisionism of Tim Luckhurst (The plucky Swiss, September 1).

He writes that Switzerland "did not persecute or deport Jews". Yet under Dr Heinrich Rothmund, director of police, practically every Jew illegally entering Switzerland during 1939-44 was pushed back across the border, arrested by the waiting Gestapo and dispatched to their deaths. In 1942, only 9,150 foreign Jews lived in Switzerland, just 980 more than in 1931. Rudolph Kastner's negotiations to save some Hungarian Jews were in 1944 - after the government reversed its policies. By then, tens of thousands of Jews had been expelled and murdered. The Swiss kept their money.

Tom Bower
London

fields.headline: Musical elite replies
fields.trailText: Stephen Moss's assertion (Drop the labels, August 31) that "music is the least intellectual and elitist of the arts: it appeals to the heart not the brain" is both manifestly wrong and a clear symptom of the dumbed-down culture on which Sir John Drummond has rightly turned his blunderbuss.
fields.body:
Stephen Moss's assertion (Drop the labels, August 31) that "music is the least intellectual and elitist of the arts: it appeals to the heart not the brain" is both manifestly wrong and a clear symptom of the dumbed-down culture on which Sir John Drummond has rightly turned his blunderbuss.

You can't really get to terms with Beethoven's late quartets or Sibelius's Seventh Symphony listening to snippets from Classic FM on the car radio or in the bath. And the operas of Puccini offer far more interesting rewards than just a repertory of vocally sensational set-pieces.

Serious music demands a continuously focused mind, together with a degree of emotional surrender that accepts shocks and surprises as much as comfort and contentment. True elitism in this domain springs not from disparities of opportunity as defined by class or wealth, but from well-developed cultural perception: which means not treating wallpaper music, such as Lloyd Webber's, as on a par with Holst or Britten; or not imagining that rising stars are automatically worthy of accolades when encouraged by record companies to dress like punks or nymphettes. Drummond, the very last person to deny ordinary people access to the best in the performing arts, deserves praise for his defence and encouragement of such connoisseurship.

Meirion Bowen
London knot.garden@argonet.co.uk

 Opera does not appear to be outrageously elitist because of its cost. I pay between £11 and £15 for three hours of wonderful musical and dramatic experience in excellent company, courtesy of Opera North. This seems to compare favourably with 90 minutes of tribal entertainment at Elland Road for about twice the cost.

Stephen Morley
Roundhay, Leeds stephen@ayresome.u-net.com
fields.bodyText: Stephen Moss's assertion (Drop the labels, August 31) that "music is the least intellectual and elitist of the arts: it appeals to the heart not the brain" is both manifestly wrong and a clear symptom of the dumbed-down culture on which Sir John Drummond has rightly turned his blunderbuss. You can't really get to terms with Beethoven's late quartets or Sibelius's Seventh Symphony listening to snippets from Classic FM on the car radio or in the bath. And the operas of Puccini offer far more interesting rewards than just a repertory of vocally sensational set-pieces. Serious music demands a continuously focused mind, together with a degree of emotional surrender that accepts shocks and surprises as much as comfort and contentment. Drummond, the very last person to deny ordinary people access to the best in the performing arts, deserves praise for his defence and encouragement of such connoisseurship. fields.headline: Cross-channel skirmish
fields.trailText: Is it such a surprise that the French people should view the protection of a valued industry from a short-term economic variable as of more importance than the convenience of British holidaymakers (French deal ends channel blockade, September 1)?
fields.body:
Is it such a surprise that the French people should view the protection of a valued industry from a short-term economic variable as of more importance than the convenience of British holidaymakers (French deal ends channel blockade, September 1)?

Unlike most Britons, French people are engaged in politics. They have a sense of society and civic duty rooted in their constitution and a general high-mindedness lacking in our own contemporary culture, with its meaningless monarchy, political elitism and slavish capitulation before business interests.

They support Europe on ideological grounds, in sharp contrast to the "reasons why Emu will make you better off and make your holidays cheaper" stance of our own government. If British people find this so distasteful, then perhaps they should holiday more within their own country (as the French do). This will spare them the sight of a robust democracy in action.

Chris Laing
Paris chrislaing10@hotmail.com

 Having had the end of my holiday spoilt by the fishermen's protest, I have decided, after 20 years of holidaying in France, to boycott the country next year. If enough people felt of a like mind then perhaps their tourist industry may feel Frenchmen blockading Britain is not a good idea. The sight of French police looking on and doing nothing may then be difficult to explain.

Geoff Poole
Prescot, Merseyside Gpoole@btinternet.com

 The media slant was that this was an exercise in union muscle-flexing, linking the dispute to the "dark days" of pre-Thatcher Britain - despite the fact only 14% of French employees are members of a union.

In France, industrial relations are an equal partnership between worker, employer and government. Unlike the UK, where the government seeks to extinguish working-class politics at the first sniff of globalisation, in France, the constitution seeks to look after the French and not exploit their citizens for an extra bottle of Coca-Cola.

Rob Roweth
Botcheston, Leics robroweth@hotmail.com

 Dump the pump v the French fishermen: one has been running for months with absolutely no effect, one lasts less than 48 hours and results in immediate concessions. Instead of criticising the "misbehaviour" and "unruliness" of our French neighbours, we should perhaps be looking to learn from them. The complainers are right when they say "it would never happen in Britain", just as the government here would never respond to the people's demands.

Dave Whyte
Manchester dave_whyte@email.com

 Tourists and traders run the risk of becoming entangled in any social problems of the country they are travelling in. Instead of demanding to be compensated, us Brits should cease to practise mindless apathy in the face of escalating social problems in our own country.

Emily Hall
London

 Why is it always the Channel ports and Eurotunnel that are blockaded by French fishermen, farmers and any other group that wants to protest about government policy? The price of marine fuel is presumably just as unpleasant to Mediterranean fishermen, so why don't they blockade Med ports? Why don't the farmers blockade rail lines to Belgium, Germany, Italy or Spain? Let's have égalite of misery across Europe.

Simon Hunter
Brookmans Park, Herts

fields.headline: Carnival's parade of arts
fields.trailText: I cannot share Margaret Mallett's enthusiasm (Letters, August 30) for the photograph of revellers at Notting Hill carnival (August 29). It is attractive, but you do not identify the mas band (costume group), its theme or the designer.
fields.body:
I cannot share Margaret Mallett's enthusiasm (Letters, August 30) for the photograph of revellers at Notting Hill carnival (August 29). It is attractive, but you do not identify the mas band (costume group), its theme or the designer.

The masqueraders are anonymous and we are not told the costume section in which they are playing. This, sadly, is typical of the way carnival is reported in Britain.

It is a unique art form, combining costume design, dance and drama, and has a rich cultural history, yet it is portrayed merely as a colourful street party with added crime statistics. Notting Hill carnival is surely the largest cultural manifestation in the UK, involving about 75 mas bands, a dozen steel orchestras and about 20 calypsonians. Every year I look in vain for an informed assessment of the costume designs and their stage presentations.

Where is the report telling us that SW Storm, singing the beautiful Thank you T & T, was beaten into second place by Kerwin Du Bois at the Calypso Monarch finals? Did any reporter attend the Steelbands Panorama to see Ebony's nine-year run of victories broken by Mangrove Steel Orchestra? Acres of newsprint chronicled obscure acts at Edinburgh, yet not one paragraph could be spared to review the astonishing marriage of art, engineering and performance at the costume gala held in the Millennium Dome the weekend before carnival. Few who attended will forget Masquerade 2000's extraordinary altar tableau, Mahogany's vast swirls of fabric, or South Connections' attention to detail.

I live in hope that one day carnival will take its rightful place among the reviews in the arts pages.

Stephen Spark
London stephen.spark@ciria.org

fields.headline: Easter: fixed or floating?
fields.standfirst: A centuries-old debate may be revived
fields.trailText: One snag with the plan to have six school terms a year is what could be done about Easter, which may crop up at any time between March 22 and April 25. The commission which reported yesterday suggests that Easter should be ignored. Terms would run between the same dates every year; sometimes Easter would fall in term and sometimes in the holidays. Some church opinion dislikes that, believing that it would detract from the solemn importance of Easter; though given Good Friday shopping and falling church attendances generally, the observance of Easter is not what it was.
fields.body:
One snag with the plan to have six school terms a year is what could be done about Easter, which may crop up at any time between March 22 and April 25. The commission which reported yesterday suggests that Easter should be ignored. Terms would run between the same dates every year; sometimes Easter would fall in term and sometimes in the holidays. Some church opinion dislikes that, believing that it would detract from the solemn importance of Easter; though given Good Friday shopping and falling church attendances generally, the observance of Easter is not what it was.

At present the date is fixed by a formula of such awesome complexity that, fortunately, it cannot be summarised here. But it has to do first with the vernal equinox (the word Easter derives from a pagan celebration then) and the Jewish feast of the Passover. It is also linked with the moon, though the moon in question is not the one in the sky but a "hypothetical moon" related to it. Unsurprisingly, the "correct" date has been regularly disputed ever since the council of Nicaea in 325, when a group called the quartodecimans lost out to the quintodecimans and were declared heretics.

That Easter should be fixed rather than floating was proposed, and defeated, as far back as 1582, when the Gregorian calendar was adopted. You might think a modernising parliament would by now be tempted to legislate. In fact it would not need to do so. In 1928, parliament passed the Easter Act, setting the date of Easter as the Sunday after the second Saturday in April. This has never come into effect. An order in council was needed to activate it and the law required that regard should be had to opinions expressed by any church or other Christian body. Most were hostile. But the act is still on the statute book. Note too that parliament is required only to "have regard", not to take instructions. Perhaps the time may be coming to wake the Easter Act from its 72-year sleep.

fields.trailText: Whilst seeking to add to this serious debate (Labour hit by race row August 31; Letters, September 1) may I ask how many of these black and Asian MPs (men and women) should be disabled people?
fields.body:
Whilst seeking to add to this serious debate (Labour hit by race row August 31; Letters, September 1) may I ask how many of these black and Asian MPs (men and women) should be disabled people?

David Barker
Durham

 As Labour MPs are carefully selected to be Blair clones, does it matter whether they are black, white or Asian, male or female, or straight or gay?

Paul Flewers
London

 Do Tony Blair's proposals for DNA testing (Report, September 1) include Euan?

Mark Walker
London

 Now Portillo favours cheap energy (Comment, September 1), the Tories will have to decide between the gas guzzler and the beer guzzler.

Dr Martin Juckes
Oxford

 Theresa Villiers (Letters, September 1) says cross-border transactions "remain 17 times more expensive than domestic ones". Use of cash machines in Euro countries is free to users of Nationwide debit cards, as in UK, and the conversion rate is competitive.

Tony Aldous
London

 Three cheers for FIFA (Football transfers to be scrapped, September 1). At last the likes of Beckham and Keane will be able to receive the rewards they deserve, rather than struggling on today's paltry sums.

Dave Hanson
Hull

 Your two racing tipsters nominated nine different horses to win the six races at Ripon on Tuesday. Not one of these nags came in first. A couple of seconds and thirds, but I got a second myself, just by choosing a quirky name. How am I going to mend the roof if your experts keep picking lame ducks?

Rev Fr Alex Mitchell
Ashton-under-Lyne

webTitle: EU on warpath over US proposed tax breaks

fields.headline: EU on warpath over tax breaks
fields.trailText: The threat of a trade war between the European Union and the United States moved a step closer yesterday after the EU said proposed US amendments to a multi-billion dollar tax break scheme for exporters still contravened global trading rules.
fields.body:
The threat of a trade war between the European Union and the United States moved a step closer yesterday after the EU said proposed US amendments to a multi-billion dollar tax break scheme for exporters still contravened global trading rules.

Yesterday's rejection of amendments to the US's Foreign Sales Corporation scheme raises the prospect that Brussels could seek World Trade Organisation permission to impose sanctions on American exports. The bill could run to billions of dollars, dwarfing the $300m of sanctions which Washington is imposing on EU goods in separate disputes over beef and bananas.

The WTO ruled earlier this year that the FSC scheme was an illegal export subsidy, and gave Washington until October 1 to change it. US trade officials proposed a reform plan in July.

EU trade commissioner Pascal Lamy told deputy US treasury secretary Stuart Eizenstat in a letter on Thursday the proposed changes to the FSC scheme "fail to render it compatible with international trade rules".

But a senior US official insisted the proposal complied with WTO rules and said the Clinton administration would ask Congress to approve the plan by October 1 in spite of EU opposition.

"We're left with no choice," the US official told reporters. "It is critical that the US move forward [with its FSC replacement proposal] by October 1."

The existing scheme covers hundreds of billions of dollars of exports and provides US companies, including multinationals such as Boeing and Microsoft, with up to $4bn a year in tax breaks.

If the United States presses ahead with the proposals, EU sources said Brussels could return to the WTO after October 1 to seek a ruling against the reformed scheme. If the WTO agreed with Brussels, the EU could then seek permission to impose trade sanctions on US goods totalling billions of dollars.

That could spark a damaging confrontation between the world's leading trade powers in the lead-up to the US presidential elections in November.

This case was the first major victory for the EU at the WTO, after a succession of rulings in the US's favour.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Sat on the edge of Thorne Moors, soaking up the sunshine, watching dragonflies hawk up and down on old peat cuttings, the world of politics, business and capital seems a million miles away.
fields.body:
Sat on the edge of Thorne Moors, soaking up the sunshine, watching dragonflies hawk up and down on old peat cuttings, the world of politics, business and capital seems a million miles away. Yet we were here to meet the media, to publicise the latest step in a long battle to halt intensive peat milling on these magical and important sites.

Despite proposals to designate both Thorne and Hatfield Moors as special areas of conservation, the peat extraction will continue. That is, at least until the planning permission which allows it is reviewed, found to be damaging the nature conservation interest and revoked. Which is where the politics, business and capital come in.

It will be argued that the sites are already damaged, and that a bit more exploitation won't matter. It will be claimed that thousands of jobs are at risk, although the notion that people will stop gardening simply because they have to use the perfectly good alternatives to peat is absurd. It will be argued that peat bogs can be restored, despite being dried out and the peat reduced to a fraction of its original depth.

The politicians will need the resolve to withstand intense lobbying from commercial interests. It is worth remembering that last week's proposed special areas of conservation sites are the UK's second list to be put forward. The European Union criticised us for the lack of peatland sites in its first list, proposed in 1995. Why were Thorne and Hatfield Moors left out then? Still, this latest move is good news. Peat milling should end as a result of special area of conservation designation.

Black darter dragonflies, blissfully unaware of the efforts being made on their behalf, defend their territories vigorously against intruders, while bees busy themselves amongst the ling and cross-leaved heath flowers. A male brown hawker dragonfly lands on my trouser leg and we look at each other for almost a minute. I'm wondering how I can gently dislodge it onto a plant and photograph it. He is simply soaking up the sunshine.

webTitle: Business: Wickes succumbs to Focus Do It All

fields.headline: Wickes succumbs to Focus Do It All
fields.standfirst: £289m cash offer accepted three months after rejection of hostile bid
fields.trailText: £289m cash offer accepted three months after rejection of hostile bid
fields.body:
Wickes, the do-it-yourself chain, yesterday accepted a £289m cash offer from rival Focus Do It All - only three months after seeing off a hostile takeover bid from the same company.

Bill Grimsey, chief executive of Wickes, said the Focus offer represented a good price for the business. Focus already owns a 40% stake in Wickes, built up during its earlier bid battle.

Mr Grimsey said that the DIY industry was undergoing a restructuring, with companies such as Homebase and Great Mills being put up for sale or seeking new partners. But Wickes' attempt to take part in the restructuring had been frustrated by the large stake held by Focus.

Mr Grimsey led a management team which took control of Wickes four years ago when it was bankrupt and its shares were suspended. He said his Wickes shares and share options meant that he stood to receive about £1.5m as a result of the new offer.

"It has not been decided whether we will stay with the company," he added.

He said he was not disappointed that Wickes was losing its independence. "I am very pragmatic. My job was to do the best for shareholders."

Since the first Focus bid lapsed, Wickes had returned £70m to shareholders. Now it had secured a bid worth £289m. "I think we have done a great job for shareholders," he said.

Wickes and Focus are the third and fourth largest home improvement chains in the country, though Wickes concentrates on the heavier end of the market. The businesses combined will have a 10.7% market share.

Bill Archer, chairman and chief executive of Focus, said: "The combination of Wickes and Focus Do It All will bring together both light- and heavy-end DIY product offerings.

"It will create a business with the scale necessary to compete with the larger industry players in an increasingly competitive and consolidating industry."

Neither company would comment on possible job losses. Wickes has 4,400 employees and Focus 7,000.

Wickes's 131 stores, which are in the middle of an ambitious revamp, sell goods such as kitchens, tools and lighting whereas Focus' 200 stores sell traditional DIY, craft and pet products.

Mr Grimsey managed to defeat Focus' original two month long takeover attempt by winning the support of leading institutional shareholders who backed his plans for restructuring Wickes.

The main shareholders in privately-owned Focus are its management and funds managed by Duke Street Capital. Wickes' shares closed 75p higher at 487.5p, just below the 495p-a-share offer price.

fields.headline: Microsoft suffers a $1m rebuke
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
Special report: the future of Microsoft
fields.trailText: After a summer break from its legal battles, Microsoft found itself back in trouble yesterday when a US judge ruled that the company had engaged in "wanton, reckless" and deceptive business practices.
fields.body:
After a summer break from its legal battles, Microsoft found itself back in trouble yesterday when a US judge ruled that the company had engaged in "wanton, reckless" and deceptive business practices.

The Seattle-based behemoth was ordered by a federal judge to pay $1m in punitive damages to Bristol Technology, a tiny software manufacturer. The award is the largest to be imposed in Connecticut for violating the state's unfair trade practices act.

webTitle: Business: Standard Chartered pushes into Asia

fields.headline: Standard Chartered pushes into Asia
fields.trailText: Standard Chartered further severed its ties with the developed world yesterday, selling its UK consumer finance business to Lloyds TSB and extending its foothold in Hong Kong with its second-largest acquisition this year.
fields.body:
Standard Chartered further severed its ties with the developed world yesterday, selling its UK consumer finance business to Lloyds TSB and extending its foothold in Hong Kong with its second-largest acquisition this year.

The London-based bank also placed new shares with investors to raise £450m in order to help pay for the buy and boost its regulatory capital.

Lloyds TSB paid £627m in cash for the Chartered Trust business, which has been up for sale for some time and is involved in consumer finance and contract hire in Britain and the Channel Islands.

Standard Chartered in turn paid $1.32bn (£850m) for the Hong Kong retail banking business of Chase Manhattan of the US to make it the biggest credit card provider in the former British colony.

The move is part of Standard Chartered's aim to extend in emerging markets. The acquisition of the Chase business is just a few million pounds short of the $1.34bn Standard Chartered paid for Grindlays Bank, which boosted its presence in other emerging markets - particularly India.

Rana Talwar, the chief executive of Standard Chartered, described the acquisition as a perfect fit.

"Hong Kong consumer banking is our most important market. This move adds to our existing strength and builds our consumer franchise."

The bank's shares ended 9p higher at 963p, despite the placement by UBS Warburg and Cazenove at 915p.

Lloyds TSB's shares fell 20p to 628p, although analysts said that was unrelated to acquisition of the leasing business and more a sign of a gentle move out of banking stocks.

John Davies, managing director of Lloyds TSB's asset finance division, said the acquisition would allow the bank to consolidate its position as the leader in motor finance.

webTitle: Swiss bid to run unloved UK rail lines

fields.headline: Swiss bid to run unloved rail lines
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The clockwork accuracy of the Swiss could be imported into the rail industry, following the announcement yesterday that Swiss Rail is making a bid to take over a slice of commuter services into Paddington and Waterloo stations in London.
fields.body:
The clockwork accuracy of the Swiss could be imported into the rail industry, following the announcement yesterday that Swiss Rail is making a bid to take over a slice of commuter services into Paddington and Waterloo stations in London.

The firm, which is owned by the Swiss government but operates as a separate trading company, joins the French and Dutch, who are competing to retain or win new rail franchises serving the capital.

The company is joining Laing Investments, part of the construction firm, John Laing Group, to bid for the Thames Trains and Wessex franchises.

Swiss Rail has a reputation for quality and punctuality, and is one of Europe's most highly used railways, all electrified. The company has been successful in attracting people to use rail for a higher proportion of journeys than most other countries in Europe.

Its boast is that it provides passengers with the same timetable each hour, 365 days of the year, with no disruption from engineering work. Railtrack could not come close to matching that, although unlike the Swiss, it is not responsible for operating services.

Laing was also attracted to the Swiss because the state-owned railway ensures that trains connect with each other at the same time every hour - and with trains, buses, trams and ferries in the same way.

It issues tickets which can be used on every form of public transport and rail cards that are used by more than half the population. The company also provides a level of customer service unheard of in Britain and 99% of its daily 750,000 passengers are satisfied. In Britain, some 2m people use the rail network each day - and less than half the travelling public has expressed real satisfaction.

The Swiss network incorporates Advanced Train Protection, the safety system on trains still to be introduced throughout Britain's network. It has been fought off by the industry here because of its high cost. All main line stations in Switzerland have luggage check-in facilities.

Laing's subsidiary company, M40 Trains, already owns Chiltern Trains, which last month had its franchise extended for another 20 years. It is the first of its type to be awarded by the shadow Strategic Rail Authority.

Andy Friend, managing director of Laing Investments and Benedict Weibel, chief executive of Swiss Rail, enthusiastically welcomed the new partnership. They said it was dedicated to providing passengers with "a quality of rail service that has never previously existed in the UK".

They said that the franchise would be at the heart of an integrated transport network, which would provide a real alternative to the car.

Governmment figures issued yesterday showed that £2.2bn of private money was invested in the rail industry last year, almost double the £1.3bn government subsidy.

Lord Macdonald, the transport minister, compared this to the heydays of the 1950s, although around £2bn came from Railtrack alone.

webTitle: Manufacturing industry fights off sterling effect

fields.headline: Industry fights off sterling effect
fields.trailText: Activity in Britain's hardpressed manufacturing sector picked up slightly last month, according to the latest snapshot of the sector from the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply.
fields.body:
Activity in Britain's hardpressed manufacturing sector picked up slightly last month, according to the latest snapshot of the sector from the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply.

Manufacturers continued to report better performance in export markets, despite sterling's strength against the euro. Firms said much of the recent improvement was due to the pound's fall to a seven-year low against the dollar.

City analysts said the survey contained encouraging signs of recovery in the fragile manufacturing sector without sparking inflation. "The overall tone is still firm enough to suggest that the worst is over for the sector," said Jeremy Hawkins at Bank of America.

The latest report tallies with the Confederation of British Industry view last week that orders were low in August but were expected to pick up slightly in future months.

"Exports are likely to continue to be supported by strong euro zone growth and the weakness of the pound against the dollar and the yen," said Neil Parker, UK economist at the Royal Bank of Scotland.

Fuel and raw material costs are rising at the slowest pace for nearly a year, according to the Institute, which might persuade the Bank of England to keep interest rates on hold at 6% next week.

The report said that the pace of job-shedding seemed to be slowing among companies.

webTitle: Business: Monster toys that ate your child's pocket money

fields.headline: Monsters that ate your child's pocket money
fields.trailText: Pikachu, Vileplume, Mankey and other members of the Pokémon menagerie will invade the Millennium Dome this weekend for a funfest of games and adventures.
fields.body:
Pikachu, Vileplume, Mankey and other members of the Pokémon menagerie will invade the Millennium Dome this weekend for a funfest of games and adventures.

It is a suitable setting for a children's craze which will probably be swept away within a few years by something new.

Remember Cabbage Patch dolls and the tamagotchi electronics pets? All the rage one minute and forgotten the next. But during their brief appearance, pocket money was gobbled up and parents were driven to distraction.

But Pokémon has been a nice little earner for Nintendo, the Japanese video games group, even though it shares the rights to the name with two other companies, Creatures and Game Freak. Pokémon, short for pocket monster, started out as a game for Nintendo's Game Boy. It is now a $5bn (£3.4bn) franchise industry encompassing T-shirts, cameras, bikes, a film and a television series.

The avidly collected cards featuring Pokémon characters are a throwback to Nintendo's 19th century roots.

Small roots

Nintendo was founded in 1889 by Fusajiro Yamauchi as a small business making highly decorative Japanese Hanafuda playing cards and selling them from a shop in Kyoto. Within 10 years, the firm was making conventional playing cards, initially for export and then for sale in Japan.

Renamed the Nintendo Playing Card Company in 1953, it started to mass produce plastic backed playing cards. Sales soared in 1959 when it started to make cards featuring Walt Disney characters for children. The seeds of Pokémon's later success were sown.

But Nintendo's most significant change came in the 1970s when it added electronic toys to its range of games. Its target-shooting Beam Gun, which used opto-electronics, went on sale at the start of the decade. It is thought to be the first Japanese toy to incorporate electronics.

The company later developed a laser-based clay pigeon shooting system which it hoped would fill former bowling alleys standing empty following the game's decline in Japan. Then the company started making amusement arcade games. Within a few years it replaced the 16mm film used in its coin-operated arcade machines with an electronic video player which it developed with Mitsubishi Electric. The two companies then used the system to make arcade games for home use.

The founder's grandson Hiroshi Yamauchi, who is now the company's autocratic boss, faced a crisis when one of his arcade games, Radarscope, flopped. He signed up a young artist, Sigeru Miyamoto, to quickly convert it into something that would sell.

Smash hit

Miyamoto, who was to become Nintendo's star games designer, decided to break away from the "shoot-'em-up" games that were all the rage. He created an adventure game, Donkey Kong, which involved a small carpenter having to find a way to rescue his beautiful girlfriend from a gorilla with attitude and humour.

Nintendo salesmen were horrified. It would not sell, they said. But it did, becoming Nintendo's first smash hit.

The group's US business, Nintendo of America, was struggling to survive. Its small staff also thought Donkey Kong would go down like a lead balloon. Also before they could sell it, they had to produce English text for its opening scene. They named the central character after their landlord, Mario, who had interrupted their deliberations to complain about unpaid rent.

Mario, transformed into a plumber in later games, was to become Nintendo's first super-hero. Donkey Kong and its successors sold like hot cakes, the American business was saved, and its parent made a fortune.

The US entertainment giant MCA Universal sued Nintendo. They claimed that Donkey Kong infringed Universal Studios' King Kong rights. MCA lost its action in the US Supreme Court. It ended up having to pay Nintendo $1.8m.

Yamauchi tried to dominate the home video games market by producing cheaper hardware than his competitors and supplying more exciting games. He told wholesalers that while they might make a loss on the games machines, they would more than recoup it through sales of the games' cartridges. He preferred cartridges to CD-Roms because they were difficult to copy. However last week the company announced that its Gamecube, to be launched next year, would use an 8cm optical disk.

Nintendo has kept an iron grip on the creation, production and marketing of games which can be played on its machines. Christoper Stamper, one of three brothers who run a British games software company called Rare, spent six months working out Nintendo's key technical specifications through reverse engineering. Rare's first game for a Nintendo machine impressed the Japanese firm which later brought a 25% stake in the business. The company has since developed many Nintendo games.

Fight for space

The video games industry has always been a battlefield in which the players have tried to use new technology to make faster machines capable of handling ever-more complex graphics and games play. Many companies have pulled out, collapsed, or switched to making pure computers, leaving Sony, Nintendo and Sega to fight it out among themselves. However the scene looks likely to change: Microsoft is to enter the arena next year.

Home games machines were initially plugged into televisions. Then, in 1989 Nintendo introduced the Game Boy, the first portable hand-held video game system which played different games stored on cartridges.

Nintendo is now established as the world's second largest video games company, trailing just behind Sony. It has moved so far from its playing card roots that it has had to licence the making of the Pokémon cards to other firms.

webTitle: Business: Byers faces crunch over PO bank

fields.headline: Byers faces crunch over PO bank
fields.standfirst: MPs press for rescue of network
fields.trailText: Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers faces a crucial meeting with the main clearing banks later this month over the Post Office proposal for a universal bank.
fields.body:
Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers faces a crucial meeting with the main clearing banks later this month over the Post Office proposal for a universal bank.

He will be under pressure from his own backbench MPs to persuade the banks to back the scheme because failure could lead to the closure of almost half of the post offices in their constituencies.

The National Federation of Sub-Postmasters said that without the Post Office-run universal bank up to 8,000 post offices - nearly half the network - would no longer be viable. So far the banks have opposed the idea because they would have to subsidise it.

The PO submitted its final business plan for the new bank to the Department of Trade and Industry yesterday.

Post office closures, running at about two a day, are forecast to accelerate rapidly over the next year unless the banks and the government agree to fund the universal bank, which is to be given a new name to prevent it being dubbed the poor people's bank.

The new bank, which would offer a very basic account without overdraft facilities, is an important part of the government and PO strategy to replace the £400m that branches will lose when benefit payments start being paid direct to bank accounts in 2003.

On average there are 30 post offices in each constituency. If the 8,000 post offices at risk were to close, the constituency number would be halved. Government plans to privatise the PO or reduce its 16,500-branch network have met with public opposition in the past.

The preservation of the branch network is seen as crucial at a time when the big banks have been closing branches in rural areas.

Already a number of banks, including Lloyds TSB, the Co-op, Barclays and Alliance and Leicester, have arranged for post office branches to provide basic banking services for their customers.

The government wants the estimated 3m people without bank accounts to be drawn into the banking system so it can go ahead with its plan for direct payment of benefits.

The Treasury would like the banks to introduce their own no-frills accounts, whereas the DTI would prefer the universal bank - not least because it might halt the attrition of the post office network.

The plan for banks to install cash machines in 3,000 post offices over the next 18 months appears to have been shelved - even though it was welcomed by the government when announced in February.

The banks, which would have to pay the £50,000 installation cost for each machine, have gone cold on the idea since they were forced to drop plans for charging customers using them. Only about a dozen machines have been installed.

webTitle: Notebook: Market forces versus golden shareholders

fields.headline: Market forces versus golden shareholders
fields.standfirst: Notebook: A thorn in the corporate flesh
fields.trailText: It is getting on for 20 years since the then energy secretary, Nigel Lawson, devised the concept of the golden share as a way of soothing fears that a privatised Britoil might fall into "unsuitable" - that is, foreign - hands.
fields.body:
It is getting on for 20 years since the then energy secretary, Nigel Lawson, devised the concept of the golden share as a way of soothing fears that a privatised Britoil might fall into "unsuitable" - that is, foreign - hands.

In the event, the Britoil golden share came back to haunt the government when the company came under seige from BP in 1987. Although BP was hardly an "unsuitable" owner, the ownership issue was particularly sensitive because Britoil was regarded as Scotland's most important company and opinion was pressing the government to use the golden share to ensure control of Britoil remained in Scotland.

Occasional political embarrassments, however, have not discouraged the development of the golden shares. They have become common currency in privatisation programmes - both in the UK and elsewhere.

Purists might argue that the concept of the golden share sits oddly with the philosophy underpinning privatisation. Where is the logic in governments deciding organisations are better suited to the private sector but then retaining ultimate say over ownership? Then again, when have governments put logic ahead of political expediency?

Despite the passage of almost two decades since Mr Lawson came up with the idea, the golden share is not a matter for economic textbooks.

The UK government, for example, retains golden shares in a number of con cerns. This week the Portuguese government made it clear that it will retain a golden share in Portugal Telecom when it sells off its final stake in the firm later this year.

That might prove irritating for an ambitious telco which might have fancied entering the Portuguese market via a bid for Portugal Telecom - especially if the said telco was one of those which has had to shell out billions to European governments for third-generation mobile telephone licences.

But Portuguese caution cannot be dismissed or seen solely in terms of old-fashioned domestic political preoccupations. Some of the telcos which might come knocking on Portugal Telecom's door have market capitalisations not far removed from Portugal's gross domestic product.

Portugal is not the only country concerned about the growth of corporate power in areas regarded as politically and economically important. On Thursday, Belgium's energy minister, Olivier Deleuze, expressed his anxieties about the prospects of a link-up (subsequently denied) between German utilities group E.ON and France's Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux.

No wonder. The latter has a huge presence in Belgium's gas and electricity market through its ownership of Tractebel. Mr Deleuze said: "I am concerned about the future of Tractebel and that the promises given to maintain Belgian control over decision-making don't seem able to resist market forces."

Shades of Britoil again: a combination of E.ON and Suez Lyonnaise would have a market capitalisation of about 25% of Belgium's total output. In such circumstances the Belgian government may well be concerned about its ability to in fluence events that will have an impact on its citizens' lives.

There are those who would argue that globalisation means corporate power - to paraphrase an 18th century House of Commons motion about the crown - that it "has increased, is increasing and ought to be diminished".

In 1992 - albeit in a slightly different context - the British authorities found, like Mr Deleuze, that market forces were difficult to control as sterling was ejected from the European exchange rate mechanism. Others would suggest that if big corporates are to be confronted it must be by big governments - although the current travails of the euro suggest that size is not everything.

B ut where does all this leave the ordinary citizen? The flippant answer these days might be "watching Big Brother". It may not be a bad starting point, odd though that may seem to those who believe such goldfish-bowl television is an ill-starred mismatch of Crossroads and the Roman method of deciding the fate of defeated gladiators.

The crucial point is that however much you may dislike the concept on which the programme is based, viewers feel involved. They are drawn into what is happening and then vote on what should happen next. They are part of the decision-making process not every five years but every week.

Nor is their participation being sought by those who too often give the impression that the whole thing is an unfortunate necessity but by those who use the very level of participation as a yardstick of success.

It should be worth considering how the postive aspects of such a series might be adapted for rather more serious purposes than a programme like Big Brother. No doubt if some one does, our governments will want a golden share of that, too.
fields.bodyText: It is getting on for 20 years since the then energy secretary, Nigel Lawson, devised the concept of the golden share as a way of soothing fears that a privatised Britoil might fall into "unsuitable" - that is, foreign - hands. In the event, the Britoil golden share came back to haunt the government when the company came under seige from BP in 1987. Although BP was hardly an "unsuitable" owner, the ownership issue was particularly sensitive because Britoil was regarded as Scotland's most important company and opinion was pressing the government to use the golden share to ensure control of Britoil remained in Scotland. Occasional political embarrassments, however, have not discouraged the development of the golden shares. They have become common currency in privatisation programmes - both in the UK and elsewhere. Purists might argue that the concept of the golden share sits oddly with the philosophy underpinning privatisation. Where is the logic in governments deciding organisations are better suited to the private sector but then retaining ultimate say over ownership? Then again, when have governments put logic ahead of political expediency? Despite the passage of almost two decades since Mr Lawson came up with the idea, the golden share is not a matter for economic textbooks. The UK government, for example, retains golden shares in a number of con cerns. This week the Portuguese government made it clear that it will retain a golden share in Portugal Telecom when it sells off its final stake in the firm later this year. That might prove irritating for an ambitious telco which might have fancied entering the Portuguese market via a bid for Portugal Telecom - especially if the said telco was one of those which has had to shell out billions to European governments for third-generation mobile telephone licences. But Portuguese caution cannot be dismissed or seen solely in terms of old-fashioned domestic political preoccupations. Some of the telcos which might come knocking on Portugal Telecom's door have market capitalisations not far removed from Portugal's gross domestic product. Portugal is not the only country concerned about the growth of corporate power in areas regarded as politically and economically important. On Thursday, Belgium's energy minister, Olivier Deleuze, expressed his anxieties about the prospects of a link-up (subsequently denied) between German utilities group E.ON and France's Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux. No wonder. The latter has a huge presence in Belgium's gas and electricity market through its ownership of Tractebel. Mr Deleuze said: "I am concerned about the future of Tractebel and that the promises given to maintain Belgian control over decision-making don't seem able to resist market forces." Shades of Britoil again: a combination of E.ON and Suez Lyonnaise would have a market capitalisation of about 25% of Belgium's total output. In such circumstances the Belgian government may well be concerned about its ability to in fluence events that will have an impact on its citizens' lives. There are those who would argue that globalisation means corporate power - to paraphrase an 18th century House of Commons motion about the crown - that it "has increased, is increasing and ought to be diminished". In 1992 - albeit in a slightly different context - the British authorities found, like Mr Deleuze, that market forces were difficult to control as sterling was ejected from the European exchange rate mechanism. Others would suggest that if big corporates are to be confronted it must be by big governments - although the current travails of the euro suggest that size is not everything. B ut where does all this leave the ordinary citizen? The flippant answer these days might be "watching Big Brother". It may not be a bad starting point, odd though that may seem to those who believe such goldfish-bowl television is an ill-starred mismatch of Crossroads and the Roman method of deciding the fate of defeated gladiators. The crucial point is that however much you may dislike the concept on which the programme is based, viewers feel involved. They are drawn into what is happening and then vote on what should happen next. They are part of the decision-making process not every five years but every week. It should be worth considering how the postive aspects of such a series might be adapted for rather more serious purposes than a programme like Big Brother. No doubt if some one does, our governments will want a golden share of that, too.

fields.headline: Peter Gladstone
fields.standfirst: Wildfowl expert who created a magical oasis among Lancashire's cabbage fields
fields.trailText: Peter Gladstone, who has died of a heart attack aged 71, was one of the world's leading authorities on wildfowl, and turned his expertise to remarkable practical use. He made the duck in all its peculiar and colourful forms an unlikely symbol of spreading knowledge, in the process having fun and encouraging non-comformity in a number of elite British institutions.
fields.body:
Peter Gladstone, who has died of a heart attack aged 71, was one of the world's leading authorities on wildfowl, and turned his expertise to remarkable practical use. He made the duck in all its peculiar and colourful forms an unlikely symbol of spreading knowledge, in the process having fun and encouraging non-comformity in a number of elite British institutions.

He designed, created - from a huge rubbish dump - and endlessly fund-raised for the Wildfowl and Wetlands Trust's reserve at Martin Mere near Southport. It became one of the trust's six centres that followed on from the famous Gloucestershire reserve at Slimbridge set up by Peter Scott in 1946.

Scott had poached Gladstone from 20 years of teaching at Shrewsbury School in 1971. He went on to win over a sceptical and sometimes hostile local farming community while creating a magical oasis among the cabbage fields of coastal Lancashire.

Although an expert shot and latterly laird of a Scottish estate, he was a pacifist and a stranger to social dignity which others tried to enforce. Hugely enthusiastic - he was often as ruddy-faced and dishevelled as some of his birds - he bounced along among the pink gins as naturally as he did with inner city school tours of Martin Mere.

The great birds which now wheel and form their arrowhead flights over Martin Mere had their predecessors on the lake at Hawarden Castle in Flint; Gladstone's celebrated name was the real thing. He was the great-grandson of the 19th century Liberal prime minister William Gladstone and he had the run of the old stately home. The silver spoon went further; Gladstone's father was an Eton College housemaster and Peter was brought up at the school.

In 1946, he joined the Palestine Police and saw terrible things - a grenade lobbed into a school bus, for instance. It sealed his loathing of war and bullying.

From 1949 to 1952 he was a student at Christ Church, Oxford, graduating in biology. In 1952 he rowed for victorious Oxford. Then came his 20 years at Shrewsbury, teaching biology and other science. This coincided with a heyday of irreverence among both a minority of staff and pupils, which included the entire founding staff of Private Eye as well as Paul Foot and Michael Palin.

At Shrewsbury his duck pond, a large area of mud inhabited by odd birds and Gladstone's hideous Irish water spaniels (a sort of super-poodle), became its own outpost of non-conformity. Gladstone also revived Shrewsbury's rowing reputation and saw school VIIIs take the Princess Elizabeth Cup at Henley in 1955, 1960 and 1961.

He was ever on the trail of wildfowl, hunting the pink-headed duck in Tibet in 1998 - in vain, but discovering a different and previously unknown species.

Recently made a fellow of the Royal Geographical Society, he is survived by his wife Jeannie, a daughter and two sons. They formed the sort of household he hoped that others - particularly those in trouble or distress - would one day enjoy.

 Peter Gladstone, wildfowl expert and teacher, born October 16 1928; died July 25 2000

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Fiona Banner
fields.trailText: Fiona Banner
fields.body:
The artist Fiona Banner was born in 1966 in Merseyside. She is best known for her 'wordscapes', in which she handwrites films from memory. Her 1,000-page text flick-book, The Nam, is made up of descriptions of six Vietnam war films. She has shown extensively across Europe and the US, at London's Tate and Hayward galleries, and at the Venice Biennale. Her work appears in Centre Of Attention magazine, a new limited-edition art publication. She is single and lives in east London.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Total freedom.

What is your greatest fear?
No freedom.

Which living person do you most admire?
Bob Dylan. He reinvented the love song.

What is the trait you most deplore in yourself?
Messiness.

What is the trait you most deplore in others?
Boringness.

What has been your most embarrassing moment?
Killing a small dog on my bicycle - its lead got caught in my wheels.

What vehicles do you own?
Very old red Nissan Patrol jeep, blue racing bike.

What is your greatest extravagance?
Losing things.

What objects do you always carry with you?
Swimming costume, mobile phone, book, lap dog, unsent letters .

What makes you depressed?
Queuing.

What is your most unappealing habit?
Snitching. Snatching. Stealing. Spitting in the street.

What is your favourite word?
Ricochet, spunk, daffodil.

What is your favourite fantasy?
Coo wee, wkjfregnb naeebvdefbjcbh gcxj twrtqdcsweie - that's in code.

Should the Royal Family be scrapped ?
They're doing it for themselves.

Do you believe in monogamy?
Serial.

What do you consider the most overrated virtue?
Confidence.

How often do you have sex?
Twice a day. More at weekends.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
A doppelgänger.

How would you like to die?
Airplane crash.

Do you believe in life after death?
Yes.

How would you like to be remembered?
As someone who could express love.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
Don't shit on your own doorstep.

fields.headline: Dulcie Domum: O sole mio
fields.standfirst: 'Harriet tells me that having a gay parent is cool - in fact, she wishes I was'
fields.trailText: 'Harriet tells me that having a gay parent is cool - in fact, she wishes I was'
fields.body:
We are in Umbria, but I have forgotten my dictionary. We are staying with Fred, a bisexual landscape painter. Freddo means cold, I remember that much, and dolce (nearly me) means sweet.

I wonder if we will ever make beautiful Viennetta together. I think not, somehow. On our first night out, I distinctly heard Fred tell the waiter, "I don't want Dulcie." Or was it pudding? There is little difference these days.

Fred has no time for dalliance. He is preparing for an exhibition. He is busy with frames and labels. We are chaperoned, in any case, by our children. Fred's son has been tactless enough to bring his girlfriend, Emma. Harriet hated her at first, but soon discovered that she was more fun than the boy, who is blond, thickset and humourless. He is the fruit of Fred's early liaison with a Dane - female, presumably, which means that Fred must once have fancied a woman.

This gives me no hope, though I wouldn't mind a bit of elderly adultery. Of course, 100% organic adultery is not possible, as I am not married. I am, however, co-habiting in celibacy with my ex-spouse. He saw me off, glowering with disapproval. So if I were to co-habit in celibacy with Fred for a week, that would be a sort of infidelity. Not a very satisfying sort, though. A bit like low-fat yoghurt.

Try not to notice how handsome Fred is. A healthy Chopin. An older, more emollient Paxman. A smaller Jonathan Miller - say, size 10. Grey curls, a Roman profile, as upright as a meercat on sentry duty. But what will this paragon of male maturity want with me? I can only offer the jowls of a bulldog, the breath of a blowtorch, the pot belly of a Vietnamese pot-bellied pig.

I drift around in capacious dresses and chew gum, in order not to revolt him too much. I would have no hopes of attracting him even if he wasn't gay. As it is, my moustache, deep voice and interest in cricket might go some way towards compensating for my lack of a penis, but if Julian Clary's innuendoes are to be heeded, not nearly far enough.

Fred's party have taken over the ground floor, while Harriet and I lurk upstairs. We have our own tiny balcony, from where we survey the rolling fields, blue hills and campaniles of Umbria.

Goldfinches twitter in the pines and wood smoke mingles with the odour of sanctity. St Francis is the big star round here, but they also have St Rita. She was married before she took to praying for such long periods that her knees wore away the stone. I expect she found it a lot more relaxing than housework, however.

Becoming a saint after being a housewife must be rather like becoming gay after starting out as a paterfamilias. Fred is tender and effusive with his son. I am informed by Harriet that having a gay parent is meant to be cool - in fact, she wishes I was, though I'm privately convinced that beatification is more likely.

Fred takes the kids off to the lake. I decide to wash a few socks. Am hanging out the clothes in the sacred Umbrian sunshine, when an ancient lady (probably five years my junior) peers over the wall and laments, in a thick Etruscan voice, that Fred and the others have left me home alone. Or she may have been recommending Rinso, for all I know. Wish to assure her that I enjoy solitude, but get in a tangle with sole and sola, and suspect I have informed her I would rather be a fish.

Escape indoors from the sun (sole - again) muttering what I suspect is, "I must try and keep out of the fish." Enter dark bedroom and collapse on to bed with all the grace of a factory chimney being dynamited. Drift off into light doze, but I am woken by a step on the threshold. A figure stands there, but without my glasses, I am not sure if it's Fred, St Francis, or possibly a friendly local serial killer.

"I've finished my work now," says Fred's voice softly, "and the kids are OK for the rest of the day, so how about a bit of Panicale?" Wish, increasingly urgently, that I had packed my dictionary.

fields.headline: How to iron
fields.trailText: Irons have three settings - two for women and one red-hot one for men, who just can't conceive of operating any tool on less than full power.
fields.body:
Since the 50s, Britain has seen a steady decreasing in creasing. However, creases have never entirely gone, because a small proportion of the population can't say what they want to say about themselves in a drip-dry, non-iron, synthetic bag.

Irons have three settings - two for women and one red-hot one for men, who just can't conceive of operating any tool on less than full power. That's why delicates end up looking as if they've had a once-over with a blowtorch and soldering iron. Generally, though, men are quite sensible about ironing: if they really want something to look sharp and neat, they buy it that way and then wear it straight from the wrapping.

Mothers know that boys have a problem with ironing, and have therefore evolved a cunning trick to get them started. They wait until boys are old enough to want to look grungy, and then they start ironing razor-sharp creases in all their trendy gear. Naturally, boys don't want to go out looking like a Victorian sailor on shore leave, so they have to spend half an hour ironing out the creases and returning the trousers to the desired laundry-basket state.

Work shirts take about 15 minutes to iron, as the manufacturers have contrived to put every ironing challenge into one item of clothing: collars, double cuffs, ruff sleeves, flared yokes, etc. Unless you like to spend your weekends at the ironing board, the best way to cope with this is to iron the front of your shirt and keep your jacket on all day.

Pants don't need ironing. If you've got to the stage where a stranger is seeing your underpants, then the obligation to impress them is probably past. In fact, the last thing you want is to be almost finished ripping each other's clothes off and then for everything to come to a grinding halt while you try to explain away the neat little creases in your Y-fronts.

Some items claim to be easy-iron, but this can't be right, as anything that involves grappling with an ironing board can't be easy - in the competition to design the deckchair, the losing team went on to design the ironing board. For a quick insight into the world of slapstick comedy, simply try erecting an ironing board with one hand while keeping your dignity intact.

Bizarre as it sounds, some people love ironing. It really all depends on what kind of person you are. Some people look rumpled even when they are wearing a starched bib and tucker, while others manage to look sharply creased in the nude. The general rule is: the more you look like an ironing board, the more you enjoy their company.
