fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck laments the end of the summer's special offers.
fields.body:
There was a time when the mark of a gentleman and a wine scholar was his knowledge of the dates of the great French and German vintages and of the names of particular vineyards. But no one, outside Alan Ayckbourn plays, flashes this sort of knowledge around any more.

Nowadays, it is not years and châteaux that the smart wine drinker needs to retain in his or her head, but particular days of the month allied to particular supermarkets. Thus, it is jolly useful to remember Morrisons and September 10, Tesco and the 12th, and Safeway and the 17th. On those days, at each of those retailers, the summer special offers come to an end, so you have until then to make the most of the prices that follow.

Tesco has Taruso Ripassato Valpolicella Valpentena 1997 (16.5 points, out of 20, on offer at £5.99). From Italy, this marvellous red exhibits wild strawberries, cherries, licorice, almonds and sweet lushness tempered by smooth tannins that will permit it to age with distinction for a further five or six years and become even lovelier (and, perhaps, reach 18 or 19 points). With its plumpness and depth, it will ride along with even the most robust of dishes.

Tesco Chilean Merlot Reserve 1999 (16 points, down to £3.99 ) has superb balance and lingering, leathery fruit with a meaty edge. TerraMater Cabernet Sauvignon 1998 (16 points, offer price £3.79), also from Chile, develops graduated rivulets of flavour that linger and refresh, enliven and delight, and create a gorgeously gluggable cabernet.

Buzet Cuvée 44 1997 (15 points, on offer at £3.99), from France, is stuffed with generous tannins and savoury fruit, and makes a terrific casserole red. TerraMater Chardonnay 1999 (15.5 points, offer price £3.79), likewise from Chile, is deliciously textured and plump, has a fruit mix of subtle dexterity, and a calm, cool finish of class and precision. And, for a truly delightfully sparkling end to summer, it is worth considering a rosé of real style in the shape of Lindauer Brut Rosé, from New Zealand, which rates 15 points and which has slumped in price to £6.49. Personally, I find this rosé infinitely preferable to many a more expensive liquid from Rheims.

At Morrisons, there is a charming Aussie pair: Lindemans Bin 50 Shiraz 1998 (14.5 points, now £3.99) and Lindemans Bin 65 Chardonnay 1999 (16.5 points, now £3.99). The shiraz has kiss-me-quick, sunny, holiday-romance fruit; the chardonnay, which is more substantial and elegant, can be taken home and introduced, with profit, to one's relatives. Inycon Chardonnay 1999, from Sicily, is down to £3.99, and this superb 16-point wine parades rich melon undertones to its slightly smoky fruit, and finishes clean and fresh with an undertone of minerals and lemon. Also from Italy at Morrisons is the politely fruity Di Notte Pinot Grigio 1999 (14 points, down to £2.99), which offers subtle apricot sensations to accompany - even, dare I say, richly to enhance - fish and chips.

At Safeway, Rosemount Estate Chardonnay 1999 (16 points, £5.99) can consider itself one of the most stylish whites on this retailer's shelves, while Lindemans Cawarra Chardonnay 1999 (15.5 points, £3.49) is one of its biggest bargains. The Rosemount has a touch of warm butter and is finely textured. Cawarra, more playful, goes from ripe melon to dusky pear and lemon.

Sauvignon Blanc Cuvée Réserve Vin de Pays d'Oc 1999 (15.5 points, £3.49) is a rich softie, and is not the classic dry style of sauvignon. fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Dress to impress, part two
fields.trailText: Dress to impress, part two
fields.body:
The subject
Oil and vinegar, variations on a theme.

The basics
The standard salad dressing contains three parts oil to one part vinegar, plus salt and pepper. That's nothing to be ashamed of, but why not experiment with . . .

The details
Oil: take your pick. Extra-virgin olive (natch), sesame, hazelnut, walnut, citrus, pumpkin-seed - anything short of Castrol is fair game, but use high-flavour oils in moderation.

Vinegar: the choice is even more awe-inspiring. Basic, straight-ahead, industrial wine vinegar is the saladier's mainstay. But for more character (and a higher price), think balsamic, Champagne, varietally specified (eg, cabernet sauvignon), sherry, rice, etc. I'd stop short of Golden Whisk Smoky Lap-Souchong Chinese Tea Vinegar (www.specialtyfoodsnet.com), but it's a free country.

Moderation is advisable here, too. Best of all, when you feel like getting fancy, what about these optional add-ons, which make dressing salad an adventure. For another layer of flavour, think lemon or lime, soy sauce, Worcester sauce, dry vermouth, fino sherry, yogurt, etc again. For solid matter-wise, choose between alliums, mustard, herbs both fresh and dry, blue cheese, Parmesan, morsels of olive, gherkin, capers, tomato, capsicums, anchovies, ginger, etc yet again.

For extra body, think mayo, cream, ricotta, crème fraîche, leftover gravy, heavily reduced meat stock; more etcs. Let your imagination run wild through the larder. Dieter's tip: oil-free dressing never reaches divine status, but sieved ricotta is a reasonable facsimile. Everyone's tip: think of basic salad dressing as a canvas on which to apply layers of flavour.

Where to buy
The Knowledge's preferred mail-order source for anything oleaginous or acetic is The Oil Merchant (020-8740 1335). Otherwise, a swanky food shop is your best hunting ground. One such, Harvey Nichols (020-7235 5000), sells around 100 oils and 35 vinegars. Not a bad start.

The easy way out
Bottled dressing? Anything they can do, you can do better.

fields.headline: Get fresh
fields.standfirst: Green genie
fields.trailText: Green genie
fields.body:
A gorgeous-looking drink, glistening greeny-gold with a frothy mousse on top. It's fun to drink, too, because it plays tricks on your senses. The limey-pineapple nose promises the Tropics, but once in the mouth the mellow sweetness of the apple balances off any zingy acidity. Then, just when you thought you'd identified all the elements, the celery kicks in, giving it a long, savoury finish.

It also delivers a good whack of vitamin C. The enzymes in the pineapple aid digestion. Celery makes you pee, which is not useful if you're stuck in a traffic jam, but very good for reducing blood pressure and dealing with stress. Both celery and apple promote detox, speeding up digestion and benefiting anyone with a sluggish system (constipation) or joint problems. Can't be bad.

In a juice extractor, pulverise: one large stick of celery (green for preference), half a lime, peeled, a quarter of a medium pineapple, skinned, and one large or two small apples. If you haven't got a juicer, whizz up the whole lot in a liquidiser or food processor. Makes one medium-sized glass.

fields.headline: The joy of misery
fields.standfirst: The 'defensive pessimist' who is preparing for a speech should imagine tripping over the microphone cord and having a coughing fit
fields.trailText: The 'defensive pessimist' who is preparing for a speech should imagine tripping over the microphone cord and having a coughing fit.
fields.body:
More than six months after I made the very point on this page, American psychologists are beginning to recognise that moaning and whingeing and being generally pessimistic about things can actually be beneficial to the individuals concerned. This is quite an admission in a society that has long believed passionately in the virtues of positive thinking. Most Americans still do. They think that cheerfulness and optimism are the keys not only to success in life and in business, but also to a person's health and well-being. But at the annual meeting of the American Psychological Association, in Washington last month, a group of psychologists started to question the absolute truth of this article of faith.

At a symposium entitled The (Overlooked) Virtues Of Negativity, they did not deny the usefulness of positive thinking in most circumstances, but they verged on heresy by agreeing that cheerfulness could sometimes be taken too far. Perpetual pressure to be upbeat made some people feel worse instead of better, they said. According to their most forceful representative, Dr Barbara Held, the author of Stop Smiling, Start Kvetching (which is Yiddish slang for complaining), many Americans are suffering because they are not allowed to feel bad. "Life is very hard," she says. "If you're having a hard time with something, it can make it harder to cope if you feel pressure to act okay when you're not."

The symposium heard about research showing ways in which negativism could be helpful. For example, some people, whom psychologists call "defensive pessimists", like to set unrealistically low expectations for themselves in order to cope with a challenge. If, say, a "defensive pessimist" is growing increasingly anxious about a forthcoming public-speaking engagement, he doesn't try to persuade himself that it will all be fine on the night, but instead imagines tripping over the microphone cord, dropping his notes, or having a coughing fit.

This may sound like a recipe for disaster; but according to the psychologist that conducted this bit of research, the "defensive pessimist" responds to such a nightmare scenario by taking steps to prevent it happening, like putting the microphone cord out of harm's way before beginning his speech, or by placing a glass of water on the lectern. "This mental rehearsal tends to make defensive pessimists feel less anxious, and so they actually perform better," the psychologist says. Conversely, "strategic optimists", as their opposites are called, do equally well by banishing all thoughts of possible mishaps and anticipating triumph.

Other research presented to the symposium undermined the widely-held belief that positive thinking makes people healthier. "There's some reasonably compelling evidence to suggest that when people are falsely peppy and upbeat and chipper, it's not very healthy," reported Dr James Pennebaker. Nervous, unhappy people, prone to chronic complaining, were no more unhealthy, no more likely to visit the doctor, to develop high blood pressure, or to die, than cheerful, bouncy ones.

The psychologists did not deal with the main point I made in my February column, which was that moaning and whingeing is what confers dignity and independence and a sense of freedom on even the humblest wage slave. That was why I objected to Greg Dyke's ultimatum to his staff at the BBC that they should either stop moaning or leave, for I regarded this as an attack on basic workers' rights. But these psychologists have nevertheless made a small contribution towards the great task of emancipating the shy and the gloomy and the miserable, who presently are the main victims of discrimination in the US.

Anthony Holden, the British journalist and writer, announced in last Sunday's Observer that he is going to settle permanently in the United States because of his weariness with Britain's stuffiness, conservatism and racism, and his admiration for America as "a nation based on the simple, pure intent of seeing if all the peoples of the world can live and work together, side by side, in mutually supportive harmony".

His article included a long and bitter whinge about Britain (for which I do not blame him: he should write as he feels); but now that he is converted from "defensive pessimism" to "strategic optimism" and living in the nation he likes best, I hope he'll be tolerant of those in his adopted country who feel less than happy with their lot. According to one study presented to the psychologists' symposium, such gloom-mongers are predominant among Asian Americans, who are more pessimistic than Caucasian-Americans and more likely to use pessimism as a way of coping with life.

fields.headline: Do you really trust him?
fields.standfirst: I like the idea of aggressive, rampaging sperm and of my duty as a healthy, modern, selfish woman to evade them at every turn
fields.trailText: I like the idea of aggressive, rampaging sperm and of my duty as a healthy, modern, selfish woman to evade them at every turn.
fields.body:
Yippee skippee! According to doctors at Edinburgh University, we may well be looking at a safe, effective and commercially available male Pill some time over the next five years. Why, then, does my heart not skip a beat in sheer molten gratitude, as the men in white coats believe the hearts of all sexually active women across the nation should?

Lots of reasons, actually; let's start with the ignoble, demeaning cliche. Are women, who are notoriously better at remembering things than men, really going to gamble with their hard-won controlled fertility on the backs of a breed who can barely remember one birthday and one anniversary a year, let alone to take a pill more than 200 times during it? And, at the risk of sounding like an Anthony Trollope novel, Do You Really Trust Him?

I know well from talking to my younger friends that these days it is often the male half of a couple who yearns to hear the patter of tiny trainers, while the distaff side desires nothing more than to concentrate on her career before she comes anywhere near having that greasy stuff smeared on her stomach so they can give her a scan. Take one broody man, one woman with an irrational prejudice against abortion, stir in the male Pill and voila! - a liar's charter.

Not only does the male Pill hold the possibility of making your man into a liar, don't you think that, even supposing he remembers to take it and you remain childless, it makes him a bit of a daddy, too? Your daddy, that is: there is something rather unwholesomely I can't-handle-this-nasty-contraception-thing-look-after-me-please about handing responsibility for your sexuality over to someone else.

And it works both ways; not only does he become The Boss, but you become a Good Girl, rather more so than is good for any romantic relationship. If you're handing over contraception duties to him, your husband/boyfriend's going to trust you a touch too much; if there's no chance of anybody but him picking them apples, they're going to start looking not half as juicy.

This is not to say that actively attempting to make your spouse jealous is anything but pathetic. But on the other hand, what he imagines you getting up to on your nights off is nothing to do with you. Many studies show that the stronger the suspicion that his gal is not altogether dead from the waist down where other men are concerned, the more your average man makes a big effort to be good in bed. The old chestnut "Treat 'em mean and keep 'em keen", always the fastest way to become catnip to boys, mutates into "Keep 'em sure and be a bore" when we imagine a male pill.

Then there's the fact that I like a quiet life, as I'm sure you do. After two marriages of (to paraphrase Living Doll) screaming, squawking, keening, sulking hysterics, I am now lucky enough to be going steady with a young man of almost unbelievable sweet temper. Long exposure to such sunniness has rendered me, too, extremely easy-going and barely recognisable as my uptight 80s self, and I have no desire to return to this tormented state.

One of the main reasons for marital discord is, I believe, the mad, modern desire to share everything, from household tasks to bank accounts. The key to domestic harmony, on the other hand, is to divide everything, so that each has his job and doesn't interfere with the other one. Hence I would no more dream of letting my boyfriend drive my fertility than I would dream of trying to drive his car. Stick to what you're best at, and happiness will result.

Let's face it, romantic relationships are full of arguments just waiting to happen, and sharing rather than dividing tasks is the quickest way to end up in a whirlwind of resentment and martyrdom; it also leaves women wide open to that eternal dirty dig of "nagging". And there's worse. If you get pregnant through your own miscalculations or poor memory skills, you're going to breathe a quick "Ooo! Stupid cow" before booking that lunchtime termination. If he gets you pregnant through his own inefficiency or idleness, the potential for relationship-wrecking fights is limitless. You're not going to forgive him quickly, if at all.

Then again, it's political. Women fought and died and worried their brains in order to help you gain control of your one and only body. Are you really happy to hand yours over to a man, no matter how benign, just because bothering with contraception is a "drag"? Yeah, voting's pretty annoying, innit, having to drag yourself down to the polling station - I know, why not let your husband vote for you, too? Then you'll have even more time to spend at the hairdresser.

As politicians are always telling us, you can't have rights without responsibilities. If this is so, it's very likely that the reverse is true, too. Let a man share responsibility for your reproductive system, and before long he is going to feel that he has rights over it; in short, he is going to become one of those men you hear of in America who burst into the operating room just before aforementioned lunchtime abortion and start screaming scary crap about it being his ickle baby, too!

My last reason for being sceptical about a male Pill is the most embarrassing, and the hardest to put across without sounding as though I have swallowed one too many Black Lace books, but bear with me. I actually like the idea of aggressive, rampaging sperm, and of my duty as a healthy, modern, selfish woman to evade and frustrate them at every turn.

Day in and day out, the sexually active woman who refuses to obey Nature's dictat that she becomes a walking incubator once a year for 20 years scores a near triumph against the tyranny of biology: if the man's firing blanks to begin with, it does rob us of our victory somewhat.

In the eternal battle between sperm and ovum, I want to be Bette Davis, walking all over the opposition in Fuck-Me shoes; I don't want to be Jennifer Aniston, muddling meekly through with a lot of help from her friends. And while I may be an extreme case, I feel that for a lot of women the merest likelihood of conception makes sex more exciting; I've only known one girl who was married to a man who had a vasectomy, and whereas before she had been perfectly faithful to him, within three weeks she had run off with an imperfect stranger she met at a party. Mind you, the dumped hubster was a sexually repellent premature ejaculator, so that might have had some bearing on it.

Phew, that's better. But to get back to basics, I would suggest that if a woman is so loathe to organise something as fundamental as her own fertility, it could be a sign that she isn't that interested in sex anyway - "He wants it so much, let him arrange it!" - in which case, perhaps you simply shouldn't be doing it at all. Now there is a revolutionary thought.

Let a man share responsibility for your reproductive system, and before long he is going to feel that he has rights over it; in short, he is going to become one of those men you hear of in America who burst into the operating room just before aforementioned lunchtime abortion and start screaming scary crap about it being his ickle baby, too! My last reason for being sceptical about a male Pill is the most embarrassing, and the hardest to put across without sounding as though I have swallowed one too many Black Lace books, but bear with me. I actually like the idea of aggressive, rampaging sperm, and of my duty as a healthy, modern, selfish woman to evade and frustrate them at every turn. Day in and day out, the sexually active woman who refuses to obey Nature's dictat that she becomes a walking incubator once a year for 20 years scores a near triumph against the tyranny of biology: if the man's firing blanks to begin with, it does rob us of our victory somewhat. In the eternal battle between sperm and ovum, I want to be Bette Davis, walking all over the opposition in Fuck-Me shoes; I don't want to be Jennifer Aniston, muddling meekly through with a lot of help from her friends. And while I may be an extreme case, I feel that for a lot of women the merest likelihood of conception makes sex more exciting; I've only known one girl who was married to a man who had a vasectomy, and whereas before she had been perfectly faithful to him, within three weeks she had run off with an imperfect stranger she met at a party. Mind you, the dumped hubster was a sexually repellent premature ejaculator, so that might have had some bearing on it. Phew, that's better. But to get back to basics, I would suggest that if a woman is so loathe to organise something as fundamental as her own fertility, it could be a sign that she isn't that interested in sex anyway - "He wants it so much, let him arrange it!" - in which case, perhaps you simply shouldn't be doing it at all. Now there is a revolutionary thought.

fields.headline: Top seeds
fields.standfirst:
In the first of a new monthly series on spices, Jeremy Lee recalls that heady day when 
he first fell in love with cumin, corianders and all their relations
fields.trailText:
In the first of a new monthly series on spices, Jeremy Lee recalls that heady day when 
he first fell in love with cumin, corianders and all their relations.
fields.body:
It was a rather awful kitchen, but the food looked fantastic. It was probably the first time that the smell of those heavenly dishes almost came wafting out of the television set and into the home proper. The show was Madhur Jaffrey's Invitation To Indian Cookery, and there was Ms Jaffrey giving graceful and precise instruction in the extraordinary cooking of the vast and varied land that is India.

The end-result of this was that an indulgent mother stood back as her number three teenage son set to peeling garlic and ginger, picking coriander and laying out spices measured in teaspoonfuls on to a plate. Then the real fun began, as a small pan was placed upon a high heat, and the whole spices were tipped in and moved around, as they change so very quickly. The reaction was almost immediate - the scent of roasting cumin and coriander seeds wafted through the house, all heady and marvellous. Once roasted, they were ground, releasing an aroma that intoxicated us with the promise of something delicious.

I have been hooked on spices ever since. Their variety and range of uses weave a mesmerising path not only through the dishes of India, the Middle East, China, Spain, Italy and even dear old Britain, but through the history of cooking itself. This is the first in a monthly series about spices. In each article, two spices will be linked together, which should make for more interesting reading and more interesting recipes. More than one spice may be used in a recipe, but only one will be the hero - or heroine.

Cumin and coriander are ancient spices that predate Christianity, and were used widely in the Middle East and India. Cumin is indigenous to Egypt, so it is not surprising that its use spread to other Middle Eastern countries and beyond, to India and Europe. The seeds were valued as an aid to digestion and anti-flatulence, and Pliny the Elder recommended smoking them to produce a scholarly pallor. Its culinary qualities were appreciated as a substitute for pepper, and the Romans made a paste from its seeds to spread on bread.

Cumin crops up so often in Indian and Middle Eastern dishes that you might call it a staple spice. When you think of the old silk routes and the caravans that trekked along them, bringing to the west all those magical ingredients, it is extraordinary that they have now ended up in little glass jars under fluorescent strip-lighting in the class acts that are our modernday supermarkets.

Coriander, on the other hand, is a native of southern Europe and the Middle East. I had better make clear that I am talking about coriander seed here, not the leaves, which come from the same plant. The flavour of coriander seeds has been likened to orange peel by two not inconsiderable authorities, Elizabeth David and Tom Stobart. It is a very good comparison, but in truth coriander is spicier and more complex than that, having a slightly bitter, minerally edge to it. It has a long history in British cooking, albeit on and off: late Bronze Age tourists brought coriander with them to add a bit of zip to their barley gruel, and there is mention of it in Elizabethan herbals; however, it has been predominantly used in pickles, brines and chutneys. Coriander has always been an important flavour here, prized as highly as cloves, nutmeg and cinnamon.

Somehow, we have lost our forefathers' passion for cooking with spices at home. We can apparently whip up Thai curries with the ease and familiarity of making a milkshake, yet still regard cooking with real spices through suspicious eyes. We hand over great wads of cash to eat the food termed "fusion", yet mutter under our breaths if Indian restaurants get smart or charge more than £10 a head. This is a nonsense. Go buy a coffee grinder, and have a stab at making a food that needs to be looked at again as something other than a convenience. All recipes serve six.

Grilled pork chop with spiced quinces

The quinces are a preserve and keep well, but there is no rule that says you can't eat them within a day or two of the making. When served with pork of fine descent, it makes you wonder why this fabulous fruit appears so rarely at British tables. I know why, but for some reason a pound to a pint always makes a better preserve than a litre to a kilo.

8 quinces
1 heaped dssp sea salt
Water
White sugar
Very good white-wine vinegar
Coriander seeds
Cumin seeds
1-2 pork chops per person
Black pepper

Wipe off any fluff that covers the fruit, then peel and core them. Cut the fruit into eight or so pieces, place them in a pot, cover with water and add the sea salt. Bring the pot to a boil and simmer for 10 minutes or so. Strain the liquid from the fruit, reserving it for later, and return the fruit to the pot. Measure the cooking liquid in a jug, and for every pint add a pound of white sugar, a quarter pint of vinegar, a teaspoon of gently roasted coriander seeds and a half-teaspoon of gently roasted cumin seeds. Pour everything into the fruit pot, and simmer until the fruit is tender.

With a slotted spoon, transfer the fruit to scrupulously clean and dry jars. Continue cooking the liquid for a further 10 minutes, until you have a thick, flavourful syrup. Pour this over the quince pieces and seal the jars.

The breed of pig you buy will decide whether one or two chops is required per person, but once this decision has been made the only other things you need are sea salt and a fully-charged pepper mill. The bold may wish, when roasting the cumin for the chutney, to cook a few more teaspoons of seeds, then add these to salt and pepper, and rub this into the meat. Cook the chops over a flame, under a grill or in a heavy-based frying pan, though do not let the pepper over-blacken and so turn bitter.

Chickpea pancakes with cumin

Though it may not be traditional, these go wonderfully with many Mediterranean dishes, as well as Indian ones. If your local shop does not stock chickpea flour, try an Asian grocer.

2 medium-sized ripe tomatoes
8 spring onions
225g chickpea flour
1 pinch cayenne pepper
1 tsp salt
1 tsp cumin seeds
Vegetable oil, for frying

Bring a pan of water to the boil, blanch the tomatoes for 30 seconds, then peel, seed and chop finely. Trim and thinly slice the spring onions.

Sift the flour and cayenne pepper into a bowl, and slowly pour in 300ml of cold water, whisking furiously as you do so (chickpea flour is so fine that it tends to form lumps easily). Add the salt, cumin, chopped tomato and spring onion to the batter, mix thoroughly and leave to stand for half an hour or so.

If you have a trusty griddle or pancake pan, then use accordingly, though I must confess that I prefer the ease and pleasure of a non-stick frying pan. Heat your pan of choice, pour in a thin film of oil, stir the batter with a ladle, then lift enough batter into the pan to cover its base. Cook until lightly browned on the bottom, then flip over and cook until the other side is also lightly browned. Repeat thus, piling the pancakes on a plate, covered, to keep them warm. Serve with a few salad leaves and some spiced beans (see below).

French beans and potatoes with cumin and fennel

I find this delicious, hot or cold, with any amount of fried or grilled meats. Make lots of it, as it is really good the next day, too.

300g waxy small potatoes
1 small onion
2 cloves garlic
1 thumb-size piece ginger
3 tbsp vegetable oil
1 tsp cumin seeds
1 tsp fennel seeds
450g green beans, topped and tailed
1 tsp ground coriander
1 tsp ground cumin
1/2 tsp turmeric
1/3 tsp cayenne
Sea salt and black pepper
60g chopped fresh tomato
1 big handful coriander leaves, chopped

Scrub the potatoes (only peel them if you really want to - it's not at all necessary), boil them until cooked through, then drain. Peel and finely chop the onion, garlic and ginger. Heat a large, heavy frying pan, add the oil, then the whole cumin and fennel seeds, and stir for a few seconds only. Add the onion, ginger and garlic, and fry for a couple of minutes until lightly coloured.

Tip in the beans and the cooked potatoes. Add the remaining spices, mix everything together, then pour in 120ml of boiling water and leave to simmer, covered, for eight minutes or so. Add the tomato and coriander leaves, and simmer for a few minutes more, until the beans are fully cooked.

Cauliflower fritters with coriander chutney

In the cooking of India, these are called pakoris and are quite delicious.

For the chutney

1 large handful coriander leaves
1 small red chilli, chopped fine
300g good plain yoghurt
1 lemon, juiced
? tsp salt
1/3 tsp ground black pepper
1 tsp roasted cumin seeds, ground

For the fritters

125g chickpea flour
Water
1/2 tsp salt
1/2 tsp turmeric
? tsp ground cumin
1/2 tsp baking powder
1/3 tsp ground black pepper
1/3 tsp cayenne pepper
1 large head cauliflower
Light frying oil, such as groundnut

First, make the chutney, which can be done earlier in the day, and refrigerated. Wash the coriander, put it into a liquidiser, along with a tablespoon of water, and blend to a paste. Add the remaining ingredients and mix well. Decant into a bowl, cover and refrigerate. Put the chickpea flour into a bowl and slowly whisk in 200ml of cold water. Err towards having batter with a thicker consistency, so that it will fully coat the cauliflower. Add the spices and seasoning, and mix until smooth.

Cut the cauliflower into florets of roughly 2-3cm in length, rinse it free of any sleeping caterpillars and the like, then dry thoroughly. Heat a deep-fat fryer according to the manufacturer's instructions, and when you are ready dip the florets into the batter and drop them carefully and gently into the oil. Cook only a few at a time, so that the fat remains hot and the fritters do not stick together. Drain, and repeat the cooking process until all are done, then serve on a cloth along with a hearty dollop of chutney

Technical Tips

 Buy your spices whole, only in small quantities and often - they lose their fragrance if kept for more than three or four months. Ready-ground spices lose their freshness even more quickly.

 Store spices in airtight jars out of the light: light is a great enemy to spices (as it is to herbs and olive oil).

 Grind the spices only as and when you need to use them. It is worth buying a coffee grinder just for this purpose (they cost around £10).

 Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, London SE1.

fields.headline: The net addict
fields.trailText: Tanya exorcises the ghost of Ann Widdecombe, and ends up gaining a religion
fields.body:
I was really intrigued by the email about www.beautyspy.com: exclusive products from Milan, New York, Beverly Hills and Munich that have a loyal following among multi-millionaire celebrities and models such as the Princess of Saudi Arabia, Madonna and Gwyneth Paltrow, are now accessible in the UK.

Eager for my beauty to exorcise the ghost of Ann Widdecombe from Migraine Alan's sexual drive, I checked the range. I noticed Zirh: 'This vitamin-rich formula teamed up with soothing macadamia nut oil and strengthening ginkgo to bolster the skin's defences, leaving post-shave skin smooth and soft.' I was stunned. Do Madonna and Gwyneth shave? Does The Princess need to, behind all those veils?

I decided that, since we are going on holiday, I shouldn't worry about such conundrums and enjoy my dream holiday on the yacht. To make it perfect, I chartered a private jet, through www.flylea.com, to fly to Monte Carlo.

As we boarded the Princess Tanya, an enchanted world of marble, mahogany and round baths unfolded before us. After a candle-lit dinner served by divine men wearing jackets and gloves as white as their teeth, Migraine Alan and I idled about the moonlit deck; the wind pressed my sheer gown against my taut, yearning body; I could see his eyes burning with lust.

My breathing became faster, but so did the wind. In no time at all, it turned into a howling gale! The yacht climbed waves as monstrous as those in The Perfect Storm (watch the trailer on www.reeldemand.com - don't bother with the film). I clung on to the rail for dear life. During a brief pause in the unforgiving tempest, I opened my eyes. Oh, God, where was Migraine Alan?

Desperate to pray, I switched on my WAP mobile in search of www.beliefnet.com but a cruel wave soaked the phone. 'Man overboard!' I cried...

tanya@ gorgeoustanya.co.uk

www.gorgeoustanya.co.uk

webTitle: John Turturro: Someone to lean on

fields.headline: Someone to lean on
fields.standfirst: If there's one thing you could say about John Turturro, it is that he is not afraid. He has played all kinds of creeps and villains on screen - far from his actual persona, as Suzie Mackenzie finds
fields.trailText: If there's one thing you could say about John Turturro, it is that he is not afraid. He has played all kinds of creeps and villains on screen - far from his actual persona, as Suzie Mackenzie finds.
fields.body:
I met John Turturro in New York, in his beautiful Brooklyn brownstone, which may once have housed five families but which is now the home for himself, his wife the actress Katherine Borowitz, their son Amedeo, and soon-to-be child due in December.

Later, in a midsummer monsoon, he drove me back to Manhattan. He was on his way to a meeting with the producer of the television drama The Sopranos; there is a part that they'd like him to consider.

"Somehow I don't see John in The Sopranos, do you?" Katherine had said.

Driving, he explained: "He is a powerful man. And in this business you have to be polite."

Following the meeting, he was going back to Brooklyn to stay the night with his mother, take her to hospital the next day for a cataract operation, probably stay with her that night, too. "I'll call to let you know when I'll be home," he told his wife. Then slung a few clothes into an overnight bag, put on a full length plastic windcheater, tied up the hood and went round the block to fetch the car. There is a modest ease about this man. Which is not to say he's not intense. There is a kind of tension in his very bearing, 6ft 1in and densely packed - a former athlete, a great dancer - that translates on the screen into a powerful, visceral presence. It's not difficult to imagine that he could be hard work. But what he's not doing is hiding.

In the car he had told me about the time he was rung by Stanley Kubrick. "He wanted me for a part in Eyes Wide Shut." Turturro was interested. He chooses most of his parts according to who the director is. "But I was busy directing my second film, Illuminata, and couldn't be free for six months, and that's not the way that Kubrick worked. He wanted total commitment from the beginning."

Afterwards, when he saw the film, he was glad not to have been in it. "It was so childish, stupid. The idea that a man can't handle his wife's fantasies. Everyone has fantasies, everyone is tempted. It's part of all our experience. It's how you act on those fantasies."

And, as he says, it happens all the time in movies, actors falling for each other. It happened to him once. Once in the 20 years that he and Katherine have been together he fell for someone else. "That was hard for everyone." In the end, nothing happened. He didn't act on it. "Because I know that an action can hurt a person, really hurt them. And when you know this and you love someone, you can't do it, even though you may want to do it."

Funnily enough, this is the subject of Illuminata, previously a play entitled Imperfect Love written by his good friend Brandon Cole, and adapted as a screenplay by Turturro. Somehow, without knowing it, and simultaneously, he was working on the perfect antidote to Kubrick's cloying sentimental drama, making a film "about staying in love rather than falling in or falling out of love - that middle period, the one we're all involved with".

The film hasn't had a release in Europe. Go see it, he said, before you leave the States. "It has a lot of me in it. It will tell you a lot about me." Where is the lie, the film asks. In falling for someone? No. Where is the hurt? In admitting it - to yourself, to another? Some hurt maybe. But the far bigger lie, the bigger hurt is in concealment. Because how can you love when part of you is hidden and, more to the point, how can you be loved if you don't allow yourself to be seen?

Translate this into his work, which he also loves - I don't think I have ever met an actor so passionately critical of his job. How do you remain faithful to an idea of acting that you had as a scholarship kid at Yale Drama School before you became a movie actor, when idealism was the air that everyone breathed. It was easy then, a couple of off-off-Broadway plays a year - Ibsen, Ionesco, John Patrick Shanley - everyone in the same boat, broke, filling in time teaching or working on a construction site. Then, if you took a bit part in Exterminator 2, it wasn't you that was involved, it wasn't your heart - it was more like a high school date, something you did to pass the time while you waited for the real thing to come along.

He got typecast early on in movies. "Violent, volatile characters and stuff", like the character of Heinz in Tony Bill's 1988 film 5 Corners, a psychotic who throws his mother out of a first-floor window and kills his girlfriend Jodie Foster's pet penguin. The suave accomplice in Michael Cimino's The Sicilian. The pool hustler in Scorsese's The Color Of Money. But since these were the films that got him noticed, he's loyal to them. "After all, there's a humanity in violence, in brutality."

Then he got lucky, his word. I don't know if that's what's happened to him, his film [Nil By Mouth] was great. But there is only so much of that stuff you can do and then people start to see you differently. George Clooney, he says, has cracked it. Clooney he has just finished working with on the Coens' O Brother, Where Art Thou?, a hillbilly romp and a musical, with Clooney as a kind of Ulysses figure, an escaped con, trying to find his way back to his home and the woman he loves. Turturro plays one of his two accomplices. "George is a nice guy, very talented and very smart. He knows where he's at and he's made the system work for him. He made his money in TV and now he can do what he wants in films. He's still learning about film; he's come from TV, he works very fast, he wants everything done in one. When Turturro talks like this he is not being covertly bitchy. The Coen Brothers put it better, and more revealingly - certainly in terms of the actor. "It's amazing how he allows himself to be humiliated in front of the camera." Humiliation is a tricky word, with its connotations of self-abasement. This kind of humiliation is Bernie Bernbaum pleading for his life, instead of taking the bullet like a man, as his macho world insists. The ability to do this, to expose yourself at will and in public, is acting - anything else is simply playing at acting.

Turturro has said that he learned everything he knows about acting from his father, who was an Italian immigrant construction worker. An honest guy, "to a fault", extremely physical, tough, and violent. He frightened his three sons. Turturro is the middle child: "Always in the middle, always juggling, that's where I stand in life." And no doubt he frightened his wife. He used to hit her, "not a lot, but it did happen", and it was always John who intervened. "For some reason my older brother was more afraid than I." His mother, he says, always knew "I'd hit my father if he went too far".

He taught him some good things - about passion, about loving work. "He was never sloppy, never lazy." And about a kind of immersion, of personalising things. As a kid he took all the responsibility, "just about all of it", and that's continued into his adult life. "I'd do anything I can to help. I have no qualms about being the one that can make things better - give them money, buy them something. I'll lie, be inventive if I have to, if there's something I can do for one of them. When they're okay, then I can do my stuff." His elder brother has had drug problems: "He was always fragile. Probably he needed help when he was young and he didn't get it. By the time he did it was too late." His younger brother s an actor: "He has a lot of talent, but I don't know if he's ever going to get out of himself all that he could." As he says, there are repercussions.

He gets emotional. "But emotion is not depressing." I think at one time he wanted to make it the main character, I think he would have... but he didn't." They are still good friends. "He just hasn't had that much for me recently. You know, you work well with someone, you think you'll work together more. But then, no. That's how it is. When my friends have roles for me I am thrilled to do it. I love it."

He has three films opening shortly: the Coens' O Brother, Sally Potter's The Man Who Cried, and Dutch director Marleen Gorris's The Luzhin Defence, from a Nabakov novella, in which he plays the lead. It is not his best film. "There are a couple of things I am disappointed about, little things that didn't make it in." But, as he says, it's a hard book and hard to adapt - movies have to simplify. "Favourite things go as you try to make it more understandable. Really, I have to see it a couple more times before I can say."

It's far too explicit, the introduction of a demonic character, not in the book, over-simplifies. The ending is so compressed as to be unrecognisable. But it doesn't matter. Turturro is wonderful as Luzhin, a grand chess master who comes to the Italian lakes to play the tournament of his life and falls in love. It is impossible to imagine anyone else in this role, except maybe Pacino before he played The Godfather. So, impossible, in other words.

Nabakov wrote it as the story of a man who can't get outside his own head. Chess, the only thing he knows how to do, and consequently the only thing he loves, will kill him, and yet he can't survive without it. "I have seen that with people I have known and it is a tragedy." In Turturro's portrayal, you see the man he could have been, if only. It is Chekhovian in that way, or maybe Russian in that way. A kind of Vanya, but years younger before he became cynical. Luzhin, trying so hard not to lose sight of himself, can't see anybody else. He tries and he fails.

Watching it you find yourself thinking that in other hands it could have been a great film. The definitive role for Turturro, a culmination of so much work that has gone before. The cowardice of Bernie. The egotism of Barton Fink. The kind of felt but never integrated physicality of his father in Mac. Plus a kind of modulated elegance, when he dances, when he is making love to Emily Watson, that I have never seen in Turturro before.

All he has ever wanted of film, he says, is to be able to develop, not to repeat himself. Imperfection is his element, he learned it early on, and it is, to use one of his favourite words, his humanity. There was a time, he tells me, when he was young and so embarrassed by the size of his nose that he'd sit in class with his hand covering one side so that the beautiful girl on his left couldn't see it. "A whole year I did that, maybe more."

In Illuminata, he wrote these lines for the leading lady, played by his wife Katherine. "I am imperfect... Born imperfect, educated imperfectly... moulded in my formative years by imperfect hands... If you look for someone to love you imperfectly, look no further."

There's a lot of me in that, he had told me. There is a lot of all of us in that

Nabakov wrote it as the story of a man who can't get outside his own head. Chess, the only thing he knows how to do, and consequently the only thing he loves, will kill him, and yet he can't survive without it. "I have seen that with people I have known and it is a tragedy." In Turturro's portrayal, you see the man he could have been, if only. It is Chekhovian in that way, or maybe Russian in that way. A kind of Vanya, but years younger before he became cynical. Luzhin, trying so hard not to lose sight of himself, can't see anybody else. He tries and he fails. Watching it you find yourself thinking that in other hands it could have been a great film. The definitive role for Turturro, a culmination of so much work that has gone before. The cowardice of Bernie. The egotism of Barton Fink. The kind of felt but never integrated physicality of his father in Mac. Plus a kind of modulated elegance, when he dances, when he is making love to Emily Watson, that I have never seen in Turturro before. All he has ever wanted of film, he says, is to be able to develop, not to repeat himself. Imperfection is his element, he learned it early on, and it is, to use one of his favourite words, his humanity. There was a time, he tells me, when he was young and so embarrassed by the size of his nose that he'd sit in class with his hand covering one side so that the beautiful girl on his left couldn't see it. "A whole year I did that, maybe more." In Illuminata, he wrote these lines for the leading lady, played by his wife Katherine. "I am imperfect... Born imperfect, educated imperfectly... moulded in my formative years by imperfect hands... If you look for someone to love you imperfectly, look no further." There's a lot of me in that, he had told me. There is a lot of all of us in that  The Luzhin Defence opens on September 8, O Brother, Where Art Thou? on September 15.

fields.headline: The last word on   Trifles
fields.standfirst: Men trip not on mountains, but on stones  -  Hindustani proverb
fields.trailText: Men trip not on mountains, but on stones - Hindustani proverb
fields.body:
According to received wisdom, the month just ended deserves its sobriquet of "the silly season" because the absence of major news - by which is meant political stories, most party leaders being on holiday - leaves news organisations groping for matter. What they find is invariably seen as trivial.

The year's latest offerings, all published last week, include a story about a human head found inside a giant cod, the remodelling of Barbie dolls to reflect the "fuller figure of Australian women" for sale at the Sydney Olympics, and a London man's world-record burp of 118 decibels.

A student of the news media might point out that this fare is the staple of the tabloids all year round, and it only becomes worthy of comment when broadsheets and broadcasters resort to its like in the dog days of August. But dismissing such stories as trifles misses a point. Trifles are the texture of history; in minutiae lie truths, and there can be more significance attached to events unobvious or apparently mundane than to single grand upheavals. As Manuel Gonzalez Prada said: "The displacement of a little sand eventually changes the deepest river's course." Arthur Conan Doyle made this observation a key component of Sherlock Holmes's art of detection. "It has long been an axiom of mine," the great sleuth told Watson, "that the little things are infinitely the most important."

There are at least two senses in which something can count as a trifle: one, by being small or unobvious; the other, by being ordinary, familiar or mundane. In both cases it requires observation to single it out and see it for what it is. "It is only the dullness of the eye," observed Pater, "that makes any two things seem alike."

The small and mundane might be lost to view in the world's sheer multiplicity because ordinariness always confers invisibility. To be able to see such things in their own right is a special talent, but it is one that can be acquired by mindfulness and attention. The ability to see the small and ordinary in their full particularity brings the tex ture of the world alive, and surprises one because it shows that small things can be large in meaning, and that, after all, barely anything is ordinary.

Pliny the Younger remarked that people travel far to see things which, if they were under their noses, would lie neglected and unconsidered. That suggests one should inhabit one's life like a traveller, curious and alert, looking for the strangeness in things in order to see them afresh.

To survive the blunting effects of time and habit on our sensibilities, we do well to remember the rousing claims of Carlyle, who said that the meanest object is a window into infinitude, and Rilke, in his remarkable Letters to a Young Poet, who said that if the world does not appear magical, "blame yourself; tell yourself that you are not poet enough to call forth its riches".

There are less exalted reasons for giving little things their due. They can give peace, and consolation, just as they can give distress out of proportion to their scale. The greater part of most ordinary biographies are records of what was individually set in a minor key, and there is not much space between those apparent trifles that engender dissatisfaction and a sense of defeat, and those that yield recurring pleasure, giving the quality of life a positive cast. In saying that "trifles make up the happiness or the misery of human life," Alexander Smith was voicing a cliche no less true for being one, and no less worth remembering.

If one sees the importance of small things, one is better able to judge the importance of their opposite. "For the person for whom small things do not exist," said Ortega y Gasset, "the great is not great." Such a person has no sense of proportion, and this is a terrible deficit, because the ability to measure things is essential to judgment, and to the task of living well. If only for this reason it is well that there are silly seasons, because they exercise our sense of perspective, and help us calibrate the material of experience.

fields.headline: More musical mortalities
fields.trailText: Wonder at the deaths of famous musicians. Which should keep you busy as far down the Ball's Pond Road as Dalston.
fields.body:
My reflections last week on the sad deaths of artists have produced a ripe crop of further examples, most of them new to me. ER Carter of Ventnor has sent me what he modestly calls a "little list" of musical deaths, and an incomplete one, but it seems quite a big one to me. In chronological order, these are the cases he cites:

Jean Baptiste Lully (1687) used to conduct by stamping a staff on the floor. One day, no doubt while trying to inspire a crescendo, he put the staff through his foot and died of the subsequent gangrene.

Johann Schobert (1767; not to be confused with the rather more eminent Schubert) died with his household after eating poisonous fungi. Grove's musical dictionary says that one small child survived.

The pianist/composer Alkan (1888) died when a wardrobe fell on him.

César Franck (1890) died after being hit by a shaft of a horsedrawn omnibus, which brought on a fatal attack of pleurisy: this is one of two cases in this fresh bout of evidence in which transport was involved.

Eduard Strauss (1916), brother of the more famous Johann the younger, and a conductor rather more than a composer, fell off a rostrum after a brain haemorrhage.

Granados (1916) and Mrs Granados died when their ship encountered a German torpedo.

Alban Berg (1935) died of blood posioning after a bee sting; and Anton von Webern (a famous case, this one) was accidentally shot by a US soldier who mistook him for a black marketeer in 1945.

 Then there is the death of Thomas Love Peacock. In a book called Famous Last Words, compiled by Jonathon Green, it is stated that Peacock was burned to death while trying to save his library from a fire. His last words are said to have been: "By the immortal God, I will not move." A friend has lent me a life of Peacock by JB Priestley - not your obvious Peacockophile: too dour: but his book is deeply enjoyable - which does not quite confirm this story. According to Priestley, Peacock, then 80 and something of a recluse, had a morbid fear of fire, and did indeed utter this cry of defiance when a fire duly occurred. But these would not have been his last words; he survived the fire - only to fall into a fatal decline.

 And what (you must surely be asking by now) about the death of Alexander Zemlinsky? Apart from the date (1942), Grove has nothing to tell us here. But what's clear about Zemlinsky, as Dr RF Carter of Putney points out (what a great week for Carters! I hope to hear more from more Carters in future) is that he is always being traduced. Traduced, that is, if you call it traduction to be assigned to the second Viennese school by people who seem think that it practised relentless cacophony. Dr Carter singles out for especial disdain a columnist in the Observer who suggested that Zemlinsky was unlikely to figure on Vladimir Putin's list for Desert Island Discs - thus implying (Dr Carter suggests) that Zemlinsky was a) a blight on the ear and b) Russian rather than Austrian. Knowing nothing of Zemlinsky, I borrowed a disc from the record library and can now confirm Dr Carter's view that his music is no more rebarbative than, say, Mahler's. The work I heard was quite Brahmsy and pretty Wagnery. He may have been Schoenberg's father-in-law but demanding he certainly wasn't; if anything, a bit on the soppy side.

A pedant writes: There is no such word as traduction. I think what you mean is traducement.

Smallweed responds with a lascivious sneer: If it's all the same to you, old fruit, I think I shall stick to traduction. When you were last seduced, did you not call it seduction?

 The final test of the England-West Indies series may be over by now, so perhaps it is time for a word on the much-praised Channel 4 coverage - so much better, people keep saying, than the lazy old BBC's. Smallweed cannot entirely agree. I like some innovations, especially Simon Hughes's subtle analyses from his dungeon. But I find the sudden switches from cricket to ads unsettling. A generation is growing up which will come to think of cricket as a game in which, as soon as a bowler has bowled his sixth ball, someone tries to sell you a Renault.

 Someone has pinned on a noticeboard not far from Smallweed's head a cutting torn from something called The Sinderwood Stroll, by Bob Footslog (maybe a pseudonym?): "Above all, do not lose your desire to walk. Every day I walk myself into a state of wellbeing, and walk away from every illness; I have walked myself into my very best thoughts, and I know of no walk so burdensome that one cannot walk away from it; but sitting still, and the more one sits still, the closer one comes to feeling ill - thus if one just keeps walking, everything will be all right." That is Kierkegaard. I shall ponder it in a moment or two as I stroll the length of the Balls Pond Road to the point where it meets the A10 at Dalston. It's suggested that one of the ancients - it's not clear which one, but no doubt some Carter or Carters will know the answer - summed it up rather better in the words: solvitur ambulando. But that's hardly enough to keep one going all the way down the Balls Pond Road.

 More unfinished business. The allegation that "step change" derives from the practice of marching armies has been challenged on various counts. It relates to the thrills and spills of the world of accountancy, having to do - according to a correspondent clearly well versed in these matters - with the way costs are laid out in graphs as production increases. And the alias under which TE Lawrence signed up for the RAF under the watchful eye of the creator of Biggles was Ross, not Shaw: he changed to Shaw later, having been rumbled. And how did he die, you may ask? In a motorcycle accident.

 smallweed@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Way to go
fields.standfirst: On why obituaries are a business in the US and an art in the UK
fields.trailText: Elaine Showalter: On why obituaries are a business in the US and an art in the UK
fields.body:
American journalists have specialised in reporting birth and marriage as significant news events, but since the 18th century, with its gazettes and Gentleman's Magazine, British newspapers have excelled at the journalism of death. Indeed, James Ferguson in The Penguin Book of Journalism (1999) says that in Britain, death itself "is simply the occasion for an obituary; the cue for publishing a small biography".

While American newspapers treat obituaries of public figures as occasions to record historical facts, British newspapers in the past 15 years have increasingly used the obituary as an interpretation of the life and career of the deceased, often written in the first person by someone who knew him or her.

Since 1988, all obituaries in the Guardian, as in most of the other broadsheets, have been signed, and regular readers of the pages have their own favourite examples of the genre, including the commentaries, addenda, corrections and even letters to the editor that they generate. High on my own list would be Braham Murray's fond tribute to the biographer, translator, and bon vivant Michael Meyer, which ended: "I expect that up in heaven now, Ibsen and Strindberg will be saying thank you, the chefs will be quaking, and it will certainly be a more fun place to be."

American obituary writing has definitely been influenced by the psychologically probing, literary and literate British style, but it remains primarily a news item rather than an aspect of belles lettres . Lapses of days or even weeks between a death and an obituary are routine in the UK, while in the US, timeliness is all-important. American newspapers describe the causes of death, while British newspapers omit the medical details. On the other hand, money, which is usually such a tasteless subject for the well-born Brit to discuss, comes shamelessly into its own after death. I'm still shocked by the listings of wills and estates in papers, especially when the deceased left their fortunes to endow cat sanctuaries or assist distressed dogs.

The big test for British obit writing this summer came in August, with Meyer's death on August 3, followed by Sir Alec Guinness on August 5 and Sir Robin Day on August 6. Obituaries for both Guinness and Day appeared in the newspapers on August 8 (American newspapers printed theirs the day before). The Guardian gave Guinness more space - a full page, although half of it was an artful Jane Bown headshot of Guinness looking sweetly secretive. Other broadsheets opted for photographs of the actor in his dressing room or debonairly posed with a cigarette. Day, represented everywhere in his trademark pinstripes, polka-dot bow tie, and (in Frankie Howerd's phrase) "cruel glasses", shared his Guardian page with an American submarine captain and a Hungarian poet, both of whom had died in July.

The intimate obituaries stressed the differences between the private and the public men. Day, wrote Dick Taverne, could appear "aggressive and insensitive" and might "have seemed the quintessential member of the all-male Garrick Club, one of his favorite haunts". But to his close friends, he was stimulating, amusing, convivial, warm, loyal and modest.

Guinness, wrote Tom Sutcliffe, became an iconic public figure of spirituality and enlightened human understanding, like his Star Wars character Obi-Wan Kenobi, but in private was a reserved man who preferred to keep his friends separate, and, as a husband and father, resented being taken for the boyfriend of John Gielgud, "though," as Sutcliffe noted, "his sexuality was complex".

The lengthy obituaries of Guinness in the American papers were formal, elegiac and official, with the Boston Globe proclaiming that with his passing, the great dynasty of the English actor had ended: "The kings are dead."

In my mind, August will always be the month associated with the death of a princess, in which the art of the British obituary reached its apogee. The dozens of searching, emotional, self-scrutinising columns published by the British press in the week between the car accident and the funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales, constituted a biographical and journalistic archive that made the obituary not merely the raw material of history but an aspect of history itself. In the US, the New York Times pointedly reduced its coverage, suggesting editorially that "responding to the public's natural interest in Diana's story, the media may be fanning it into an unnatural size".

But in the UK, the obituary form that had been established as the main public forum for the expression of information, remembrance, criticism, and grief could not be silenced. Far from instigating hysteria, as some charged, the press used the genre of obituary to turn shock and emotion into a unifying public moment. Even in the midst of Britain's millennial renaissance, such moments too often still depend on death.

fields.headline: Three cheers for us
fields.standfirst: How Nederlands Dans Theater were almost upstaged by their own audience. By  Alice Bain
fields.trailText: How Nederlands Dans Theater were almost upstaged by their own audience. By Alice Bain
fields.body:
You don't often see audience participation in contemporary dance. So when the professionals from Nederlands Dans Theater walk offstage to round up some of the punters, no one knows quite how to react. But before long the amateurs are onstage jiggling and jiving, waltzing and wiggling.

Suddenly the dancers, dressed in uniform black suits, become real people and the real people become dancers. Even the most awkward volunteer seems to fit into place, turning a simple idea into pure magic. No hint of embarrassment or exploitation, just sheer pleasure, elicited by the performers with polite panache. And when a little old lady in a cream cardie is left onstage in solo triumph, the audience cheer as if they were in the presence of a star.

This week the Edinburgh international festival showcased Netherlands Dans Theater in all their configurations. The audience participation came on Tuesday night, when NDT2, a group of 14 classically trained 18- to 22-year-olds, took to the Edinburgh Festival Theatre. Strong and showy, they display an irrepressible enthusiasm. Minus 16, a compilation of the Israeli choreographer Ohad Naharin's work, slots the audience-participation gem into other, unconnected fragments of his oeuvre - an Israeli chant on a circle of chairs, a walk with the dancers that includes a chat and cute solo from each. Naharin's casually dynamic language allows the group to release its youthful energy.

The evening was shared by NDT3, a quartet of fortysomething dancers. Inspired by the strings of Vivaldi's Human Passions, choreo grapher and company member Paul Lightfoot takes a softly, softly approach to his performers. Though gracefully executed, the result looks tired, old-fashioned and coy. To gather up these dancers and present them as under-powered oldies negates their dramatic and interpretative abilities.

On Wednesday NDT1, the main company, took the bigger stage at the Edinburgh Playhouse, accompanied by the Czech Philharmonic Orchestra. They opened romantically, with a piece about belonging, Forgotten Land, choreographed by Jiri Kylian, who has steered NDT to international success over the past two decades. Made in 1981, it is set to Benjamin Britten's Sinfonia da Requiem, a score with a heartbeat, an affirmation of life that the composer wrote in response to the deaths of his parents.

The dancers begin with their backs to the audience, walking in the wind. As the music builds, each couple is framed in close, protective duets, leaning, crouching, winding. They rarely leave each other's side. Britten's score rises in the centre and leads the pair in red to race against the music.

A lyrical choreographer with a tendency to avoid invention, Kylian likes his dancers to fly a lot, and they do it powerfully well. Choreographer Paul Lightfoot prefers to root them to the ground. In Speak for Yourself, first performed last year, he brings on the boys and accentuates male muscle. They are the young Athenians - angled, carved and bendy bodies.

This is a sombre piece, which begins with smoke and ends in the rain. Humour has been given a bodyswerve and the dancers remain cool and measured. Something is missing, however: as novel as it is to see a company splashing about in puddles, Light foot's choreography does not reflect the dramatic change from dry to wet sufficiently to push this piece from good to gripping.

The evening at the Playhouse ends with Sinfonietta, again choreographed by Kylian. Made in 1978, it is a soaring response to Janacek's music of the same name, backed with blue light and dressed in floaty silk. Once more Kylian's dancers put on their wings, but on this occasion it is the score and orchestra that are the stars. Pulled out of the pit, the brass and percussion are up among us in the boxes. Eyes are drawn to them and their rousing fanfare, and the dance, exuberant though it is, becomes the accompaniment.

NDT are never less than immaculate. But perhaps they need to stretch those wings a little.

fields.bodyText: You don't often see audience participation in contemporary dance. So when the professionals from Nederlands Dans Theater walk offstage to round up some of the punters, no one knows quite how to react. But before long the amateurs are onstage jiggling and jiving, waltzing and wiggling. Suddenly the dancers, dressed in uniform black suits, become real people and the real people become dancers. Even the most awkward volunteer seems to fit into place, turning a simple idea into pure magic. No hint of embarrassment or exploitation, just sheer pleasure, elicited by the performers with polite panache. fields.headline: The young Bill
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
At the risk of sounding like an old lady, policemen are getting younger and younger. Time was, every male copper in The Bill (ITV) was a crusty old man with a well-worn suitcase of a face. June Ackland was still a WPC, Burnside hadn't been spun off and Sergeant Bob Cryer was still the beating heart of Sunhill. Now Cryer makes fewer appearances than Howard Hughes, June has got her pips - though her cat was killed by a stalker so it's not all good news for her, and Burnside spends his time tracking serial killers with that Scottish woman and the gay black man.

It just hasn't been the same since WPC Viv Martella was shot by that privet hedge. And the bush got away with a caution and a good going-over with a hedge trimmer. Never was there a sadder moment in British police drama than Martella's demise, apart from when that young PC died atop blazing Christmas trees in Juliet Bravo.

These days The Bill is full of constables who look like they couldn't keep hold of their dinner money in the face of intimidation. Brownlow is still around, bless him, but you always get the feeling that he would prefer to be doing a bit of Shakespeare than saying lines like: "I've got to make a speech tonight and I don't want to be late. Fix my tie, will you?"

Not that The Bill is bad. It's actually all right, if you like that sort of thing. This week there was a touchy-feely story centred around the barely pubescent PC Dale Smith. He befriended Tim, a young Chinese lad whose parents had mysteriously vanished while being chased by Bad Men. The Bad Men, actually money launderers, finally caught up with Smith and Tim, and were ready to snatch Tim, before Smith handcuffed himself to the lad so he had to be kidnapped too. What a stroke of genius. Smith then got himself beaten up and threatened with Reservoir Dogs-style mutilation. A happy ending ensued, with only a murder and a bit of acceptable police brutality to worry about.

More police brutality in Badger (BBC1) but that was OK too since it meant Jerome Flynn got a good smack in the mouth in return. Mysterious goings-on in a remote Northumberland village began with Tom McCabe rescuing a shop dummy from the sea and ended with him returning to his girlfriend, who had earlier confessed to sleeping with another bloke again. There was a faint hope he might meet with a Wicker Man situation but, alas, that was not to be. Instead - and arguably just as awful as being burned alive with goats and chickens - he met Maaaahy Flaaaaherty from EastEnders labouring in a pub, grieved over a dead seal (the only good kind apparently, but that was according to another Bad Man) and used his binoculars correctly. The last not easy for a man as thick as McCabe.

The shop dummy, the old beachcomber and the pub landlord were all mixed up in smuggling cigarettes, you see, and Frank (another Bad Man) wanted them to graduate to importing "stuff from Holland". Not rubbery cheese, as I first thought, but dope actually. Positively Evil Men. Tsk. Hurray for Badger.

Phill Jupitus was on Room 101 (BBC2), confessing to being quite a misanthrope, not to mention an arachnophobe and someone who dislikes extended warranties on electrical goods. While Jupitus was a good guest and Paul Merton is a capable host, there is something so tired and banal about Room 101 that really you feel it should only be on for about 10 minutes, maybe before Newsnight. Or better still, after Newsnight. Actually, around three in the morning would be ideal.

It's nice to see Tony Hart back on telly - Smart Hart (BBC1) - even if he never put any of the countless drawings I sent in into the Gallery.

fields.headline: Bike to the future
fields.standfirst: Antigone set in a Cornish claypit and featuring a chorus of fluffy pink women?  Lyn Gardner  has a few qualms
fields.trailText: Antigone set in a Cornish claypit and featuring a chorus of fluffy pink women? Lyn Gardner has a few qualms
fields.body:
It is the near future. Cornish nationalism is on the rise and the English are determined to put a stop to any uprising. Biking brothers Johnny Throttle and Leanburn Bill take opposing sides, and when both are killed in a motorcycle battle, the recently installed Duke of Cornwall, a puppet of the English regime, insists that Johnny is a traitor and his bones cannot be buried. His sister Gonnieta immediately defies the ban - with tragic consequences for both herself and the Duke's family.

This is the gist of Hell's Mouth, Nick Darke's modern version of the Antigone story, played out at dusk by Kneehigh Theatre amid the puddles and blazing heather of Hendra Pit, an old china claypit in the depths of Nanpea, Cornwall. Such large-scale outdoor theatre has benefits and drawbacks, and both are amply demonstrated here. The sheer magnificence of the landscape that so dwarfs all human activity adds real drama to the piece, whether it is serving as a backdrop to the setpiece motor-cycle battles in which the different sides are signified by streaming pennants, or quieter moments such as a suicide that takes place in the distance with a breathtaking drop from a cliff into a lake below.

But like all theatre on such a grand scale, the evening is often too diffuse, the energy and the words drifting away on the wind, and for all the obvious tragedy of the story and the exceptionally high bodycount, it is never sufficiently intimate to really move you. Only in the closing moments do you get any sense of real pain and grief, as the Duke - bereft of crown, dignity, wife and son - clambers up a distant peak, a tiny, solitary figure silhouetted against the vast, naked sky. Playwright Darke rather dilutes the moral ambiguities of the story by turning the Creon figure - the Duke - into a mere clown, but injects a more satirical humour with the chorus of second-homeowner wives, a gaggle of fluffy pink women with fluffy white dogs. Throughout, the show has a clear political thrust.

Emma Rice's strong performance as Gonnieta, a girl who becomes a rock, holds together an evening that isn't going to win any theatre awards but speaks quietly and confidently to its own community.

The 80 minutes is full of memorable images, too, including a chorus of blind archaeologists with eyes made out of stone who raise skulls out of puddles and peer into both Cornwall's murky past and its murkier future.

 Ends tonight. Box office: 01726 68532.

fields.headline: Russian roulette
fields.standfirst: One more treasured Moscow institution is under threat. The Bolshoi ballet is in mid-purge and structurally unsound.  Ian Traynor reports
fields.trailText: One more treasured Moscow institution is under threat. The Bolshoi ballet is in mid-purge and structurally unsound. Ian Traynor reports
fields.body:
Following a week of backstabbing and brinkmanship fit to grace a Bolshoi production of Boris Godunov, Russia's revered ballet and opera company is to gather amid the fast-fading splendour of its theatre opposite the Kremlin this morning to consider its future.

The Bolshoi is in crisis - physically, financially, and aesthetically. The famous theatre, 147 years old, is in such poor shape that the slightest jolt could literally bring the house down.

From his offices across the road, President Vladimir Putin can watch the rain leaking through the Bolshoi's roof, observe the theatre's slow subsidence into the marshy foundations on which it stands, and see that the reconstruction work started years ago has ground to a halt through lack of funds.

After an August of serial disaster, Putin can ill afford a further blow to Russian prestige So, on Monday he pulled a fast one.

On a day off for the 2,632 Bolshoi employees, Putin purged the Bolshoi bosses, Vladimir Vasilyev, executive director, choreographer, and ex-star dancer and Vladimir Kokonin, the administrative chief. Their posts were abolished, too.

Many of the Bolshoi stars were performing abroad and caught unawares. Vasilyev learned he had been fired from the radio. After sending out invitations to the Muscovite elite for a gala opening for the theatre's 225th season - to have been held yesterday - Vasilyev had to cancel the event.

On Tuesday he boycotted a meeting with the culture minister, Mikhail Shvydkoi, who is the main winner of the unseemly tussle. Shvydkoi will tell a closed meeting of the company this morning that from now on, his ministry will be in overall charge. He will then nominate a little-known crony, Anatoly Iksanov, as the Bolshoi's general director and Gennady Rozhdestvensky, the conductor, previously of the BBC Philharmonic, as the Bolshoi's artistic director.

"There's been conflict at the top of the Bolshoi for years, hindering anything from getting done," says Maya Kabakhidze, the ministry official for the arts. "The minister is not going to interfere in the repertoire. But the top priority for the next five years is the construction problem. That means the general director will be the boss and the artistic director will be his subordinate."

The 1990s were not kind to the Bolshoi, its decline made that much harder to bear by the rise to global acclaim of its great rival, St Petersburg's Mariinsky/Kirov opera and ballet under the mercurial Valery Gergiev.

"The Bolshoi can no longer compete with the Royal Opera House or the New York Metropolitan or Vienna," says Larisa Dolgacheva, opera critic for the Kultura arts journal. "It's such a sad situation - mediocre directors, boring scenography." Vasilyev, a revered former dancer who turned 60 this year, has had more misses than hits in his five years in charge, according to the Moscow critics. "He affects the air of a Chekhovian intellectual, a dreamer who can't cope with the world. He's taken the Bolshoi to a dead end," says Ms Dolgacheva.

The appointment of Rozhdestvensky would restore the Bolshoi tradition of having a musician and conductor as the artistic chief of the 263-strong corps de ballet, 107-strong opera company, 281 orchestra players, and chorus of 196. But the conductor, who made his Bolshoi debut almost 40 years ago, appears to be playing hard to get. Shvydkoi confirmed yesterday he had offered him the post. Rozhdestvensky made it plain he would drive a hard bargain and would not make up his mind until today's crucial meeting.

If Gergiev in St Petersburg is a dynamic 47 and a top name in international conducting, Rozhdestvensky is 69 and some wonder if he is the man to turn the Bolshoi's fortunes around.

"He's a huge talent, an outstanding musician with an extraordinary musical memory," says a Moscow violinist who has known him for 20 years and worked with him frequently. "But he doesn't like staying in one place for long. He gets bored and he can't stand long rehearsals with orchestras. What the Bolshoi really needs is a musical and artistic leader for at least five years to raise the level of the orchestra and of performance."

Art apart, the Kremlin is making it plain that the reconstruction project is the priority. According to the Putin decrees, the company will move into a secondary theatre to be built by January 2002 so that the main theatre can be restored and rebuilt by 2005. The Soviet government ordered the reconstruction in 1987 but work ground to a halt although £80m had already been spent. The reconstruction is expected to cost £270m, though there is scant detail on where the money is coming from.

The job of overseeing the project falls to Iksanov, a respected if little-known arts administrator who managed a theatre in St Petersburg and currently runs the state arts TV channel, Kultura, a post previously held by Shvydkoi.

Under the new broom in the Kremlin, Shvydkoi is building himself an arts empire. Earlier this year he performed the same trick with the Russian film industry, subordinating the state cinema board to his ministry. Some say the sumptuous museums and collections of the Kremlin are next in line.

The new Bolshoi season opens in two weeks in time-honoured fashion with a Glinka opera followed by Swan Lake the next evening. "It's such a remarkable theatre," says Ms Kabakhidze. "But it's in big danger and we don't want to lose it."
