fields.headline: Are you being surfed?
fields.standfirst: Trek to the shops for furniture? Forget it. Now, we can buy it all online. Oliver Bennett clicks through the sites
fields.trailText: Trek to the shops for furniture? Forget it. Now, we can buy it all online. Oliver Bennett clicks through the sites.
fields.body:
Scratch the shiny surface of the internet and you will find a vast electronic mail-order catalogue. It was inevitable that the purveyors of interior decor would converge on the the new medium, and the internet is now teeming with sites that cater to home shoppers, to decorators and to those of us who simply wish to drool over objects of domestic desire without having to traipse down to the high street. Some of the new sites may well be the Heals and Habitats of the future; others may not be with us in a year's time. But it is now possible to furnish your home just by logging on.

One of the smoothest sites comes from a company called Interior Internet, a branded electronic megamart of interior design that is what one might call lifestyle- rather than design-led, with a range of thematic search options - among them are "Nutopia" (futuristic retro), Loft Living, Fantasy, "Chic-and-Bleak" - along with a more functional category search, so that browsers can click on lighting, tables, ashtrays even.

But hang on - isn't this the one retail sector where it is essential to touch and even bounce on your bed or chair to be? "Actually, that hasn't been much of an issue," explains Interior Internet's Alistair Taylor. "The traffic we get isn't really looking for comfortable, bouncy sofas. But we send samples if we can [sofas not included], and if there's a problem when the object arrives, we have a returns policy." And the trade - much of their business comes from interior designers and architects - has already proved itself to be happy to work "with imagery rather than the physical objects".

Taylor set up Interior Internet with fellow fashion graduate Johnston Campbell, and they are typical of the e-generation - twentysomethings who had an idea, got financial backing and went on-line four years ago. They have been online for six months. Theirs is a shell operation: that is, it holds no stock and ships items direct from suppliers and manufacturers, so there is no need for a storeroom or fancy shop, just a bit of soft-modern multimedia design on the site. And there is no shoplifting.

As with the other interiors sites, the goods are represented by thumbnail photographs that can be enlarged at a lick of the mouse. Some items can even be viewed from different angles. You can also read about what's available: the site currently features an article about Italian designer Piero Fornasetti, whose designs itsells. ut the central point is to shift the 30,000 items on sale, which include work by Nicolas Haslam, Andrew Martin, Mark Brazier-Jones and Habitat's Tom Dixon. Some pieces are one-offs, others commissions.

It is a fairly eclectic site, which reflects Taylor and Campbell's tastes. "People seem to think that the internet suggests that we will sell only contemporary things," says Taylor. "But in the loft-living section, there might be an 18th-century bureau. That's what is interesting about decorating - being able to make it gel."

Indeed, Taylor's own north London flat resists the pared-down technological aesthetic, preferring a riot of rococo, rendered in bright colours. He has an ochre living room, a deep-red bedroom, a turquoise spare room and a blue hallway. Walls are dressed with colourful finds, such as a mounted display of Brazilian butterflies, and the look could fit into his site's "fantasy" category.

Some new sites are connoisseur-led, selling provenanced pieces as if artworks, but Taylor is not too bothered with that, professionally or personally: in the middle of his living room is a huge repro chandelier, and the bust overlooking his bed is plaster, not marble.

Amid all this opulence are touches of surrealism. A series of 14 Salvador Dalí prints is arranged in two rows along a wall - "architectural images of the female form", as Taylor puts it. He also has pieces by Fornasetti, the results of auction-picking, and plenty of south-east Asian furnishings, gleaned from various travels.

Eatmyhandbagbitch.com, on the other hand, is a website title of extravagant camp aggression (particularly when growled by way of phone greeting), and its portal is designed in a pink retro-pop style. Georgina Stead, who runs the site and its parent shop with her partner, George Enoch, explains that the name comes from a work of art that Enoch made several years ago "Most modern furniture shops and sites tend to have graphicky pencil images and names that include the words "20th" "century" and "design", explains Stead. "We wanted to be a bit different."

Stead used to work at a bank and Enoch was, and remains, an artist: such collusions between finance and creativity are common in dot.com circles. They did their apprenticeships on market stalls in Camden and Spitalfields, before moving to Brick Lane, which is now such a dot.com centre that some have dubbed it "Click" Lane. They set up the site six months ago, purely as an adjunct to the shop, but it ow turns around 90% of their business. "It's a full-time job to monitor it," says Stead.

On the site are thumbnails of modern antiques by designers from the fifties - Italian Joe Colombo, mid-century Finnish wizard Eero Saarinen and contemporary British designer Ross Lovegrove. It is a mixture, says Stead, of "futuristic and modern" and is divided into regional and stylistic tendencies - a rather more academic and design-savvy approach than the glitzy graphics suggest. "It's not the sort of kitsch that you'd find on some market stalls," she says. "We are concerned with good design."

There are those who use the internet simply as they would a leaflet: modern furniture dealer Graham Manchais among them. He runs his site as a cottage industry, photographing, scanning, selling and delivering on his own. Mancha does not have much time for the futuristic hyperbole that surrounds the internet, but was an "early adopter" of the medium, and has maintained an internet presence for the past six years.

"Back then, hardly anyone in Britain was on the internet," he says. "I only did it because my service provider gave free web space. It was a happy accident."

Mancha testifies to the internet's global reach: when he started the site, he was surprised to receive calls within days of the launch from people in the US who wanted to buy his postwar modern furniture. In fact, Graham Mancha is the classic example of just how the internet can empower small traders. He doesn't monitor the site - which costs him just £10 a month to maintain - and he works from home (in Bedfordshire), which is the perfect way to keep down all those overheads.

webTitle: Comment: The genetic code doesn't hold all the answers

fields.headline: What makes us human?
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The cracking of the genetic code presents many opportunities for human betterment, even if they are somewhat further in the future than most popular commentators, inebriated with their own hype, allow. But it also presents two dangers.
fields.body:
The unravelling of our genetic structure seems, for the time being at least, to have restored media and public confidence in scientific infallibility. What has been hailed as the greatest development in history appears to have painted over the scepticism that came in the wake of nuclear energy, GM foods and other troubling indications that what scientists predicted as new dawns became cloud-laden horizons.

The cracking of the genetic code presents many opportunities for human betterment, even if they are somewhat further in the future than most popular commentators, inebriated with their own hype, allow. But it also presents two dangers.

The first is another dose of scientific reductionism. Ironically, given that he is a southern Baptist, this was somewhat poetically summarised in the words of Bill Clinton, who marked the announcement by proclaiming that we were "learning the language in which God created life". More prosaically, James Watson, the co-discoverer of DNA, said: "Now we know, in large part, that our fate is our genes." New Scientist's opinion was: "Monday 26 June will be remembered as the day when humankind learned, in a sense, what it is to be human."

In fact, humankind learned that only in the sense that a map shows a country but does not describe a national culture or a society. Many scientific and other discoveries have sought to explain our humanity. Many contain a truth but none the whole truth. The human genome project marks a great advance in our understanding of genetics, albeit something of enormous significance. But it does not explain the whole, or perhaps even the most significant part of our human essence. To reduce human beings to the sum of their parts - their minds, their economic motivations, their genes - is to make them less than they are. But also more than they are. We are creatures capable of great scientific, human and artistic achievement but also creatures who are flawed, who often fail, perhaps inevitably, to live up to our better selves and our possibilities.

We are also social beings and so it is ironic that at a time when social science's explanations of human behaviour are often treated with caution, if not downright disbelief, that our genetic selves should now be being seen as an explanation for what we are.

Such reductionism is related to the second potential danger that the new discovery presents. It regards human beings as infinitely perfectable - we are told that cancer, Alzheimer's disease and a host of other ailments that the flesh and mind are heir to may be things of the past. Some of this has a strong element of wishful thinking. Genetic engineering to remove the possibilities of disease is not like changing a fuse, as is being implied. For example, cystic fibrosis has been linked to more than 1,000 different mutations. It is also the case that many people who harbour the potential for genetic disease choose not to be tested. In the case of Huntingdon's chorea it is only a very small minority. This may seem strange but then this is another of those facts of human nature that not even the DNA map can explain.

But behind these predictions of wiping away all our tears, lies an implied belief in human perfectibility, the corralling of at least one of the four horsemen of the apocalypse - disease in its widest sense of not the physical but other kinds of human defect.

Genetic engineering raises the question of the place of suffering in our world. We are being assured, of course, that eugenics is now so discredited by its Nazi past and the horrors perpetrated in Sweden and the US in the 1920s and 1930s that no state will now countenance it. Perhaps not as an instrument of public policy. But cosmetic operations have been performed, at parents' request, on children with Down's syndrome to remove Down's features. Women with learning difficulties have been sterilised without their consent. Given this, is it difficult to envisage "benevolent" court or medical decisions, at the behest of parents and others, to attempt to correct, by genetic means, what nature has made?

Suffering is all around us, much of it not preventable by scientific or other means - loss, misfortune, death, increasing incapacity. To say that it is often unavoidable is not to be complacent or resigned. It is human to feel anger and to seek cure, alleviation or prevention. But we also have to take suffering and make what we can of it. Mary Craig, a mother of two sons with a severe learning difficulty, knew that it defeated some people and was the making of others. As she wrote in Blessings: "The real tragedy of suffering is the wasted opportunity."

Suffering can lay bare the essential self, which is not always the best self. It can strip us of all that is extraneous to our true nature. Pierre d'Harcourt, reflecting on his experience of Buchenwald, said that cleverness, creativity, learning all went down - "only real goodness survived".

The balance to be struck is in recognising the limits of human intervention, an acceptance of suffering and the desire to do all we can to overcome it. Those who hold that existence is finite may find this more difficult than those who take a transcendental view. But why we suffer and how we meet suffering is another thing not written in this newly opened book of life.

 Terry Philpot is editor-in-chief of Community Care and is writing a book on monasticism

fields.headline: Earning his spurs
fields.standfirst:
Henry V
Royal Shakespeare Theatre,
Stratford-upon-Avon
****
fields.trailText:
Henry V
Royal Shakespeare Theatre,
Stratford-upon-Avon
****
fields.body:
Edward Hall's exhilarating battle-dress production of Henry V turns the Royal Shakespeare Theatre into a combat zone and clearly benefits from the RSC's researches with the Army Training Regiment. Traditionally the play has been seen as either a jingoistic celebration or a cynical study in statecraft. In both cases, it is treated as a star vehicle.

The first shock of this production is to find that we are in for a company show as much about the nature of Englishness and the ethos of war as about the qualities of kingship. The lines of the Chorus are divided up democratically and William Houston's Henry emerges as a dogged fighter who has to earn his claims to leadership.

If a key point comes across, it is that the English possess a truculent chauvinism that only turns into heroism in moments of crisis. When the Dauphin's emissary arrives with the tennis balls he is greeted with a jeering rendition of the Marseillaise. The low-life figures are boozy bigots who chant a celebratory song about "Enger-land" specially composed by Billy Bragg. Even when they get to France, we are reminded that cowardice coexists with valour and that there is a tendency to mock the other elements in their multinational force: Adrian Schiller's Fluellen, for instance, seems sublimely unaware he is being sent up as a typically earnest Taff.

The production confronts Shakespeare's ambivalence towards heroism. Houston's Henry, conned by clerics about the legitimacy of his claim to France, turns into a tough fighter and, during the siege of Harfleur, inspires his troops to scale the dress circle. Henry's ruthlessness, however, is not shirked: his notorious order in response to French brutality - "Then every soldier kill his prisoners" - is followed by volleys of gunfire.

It's a tribute to Houston that he manages to win us over in the peacetime scenes. The wooing of Catherine Walker's French princess is excellently done: he has to exercise all his charm to captivate a woman rightly resentful at being treated as a diplomatic trophy.

But this is symptomatic of the way Hall has intelligently rethought the play while giving us a bravura spectacle. Michael Pavelka's design is dominated by a mobile mine-wheel that at one point advances downstage to become a terrifying battle engine. And, while Matt McKenzie's soundscore is overwhelming, there is ironic wit in the music.

I'd also single out Michael Thomas's precise Exeter and Arthur Cox's Bardolph, whose hanged figure reminds us of Henry's refusal to be swayed by old loyalties. That typifies a superb evening that poses endless questions about national identity and the ugly demands of heroism.

Until October 7. Box office: 01789 403403.

fields.headline: Touching bass
fields.standfirst:
Monaco
Scala,
London
**
fields.trailText:
Monaco
Scala,
London
**
fields.body:
With sumptuous melodies wrapped round the almighty bass of Peter Hook, Monaco - the live experience - should be magical. But tonight beauty is a martyr to the sound system.

Hook and cohort David Potts have kept a low profile for the past three years but, with a great new album (also called Monaco) just out, they are ready to take the pop world by storm again.

They kick off with the opening riff to the Who's Anyway, Anyhow, Anywhere. Monaco are more pop than rock, more chart than credible, so it's straight from there into Kashmere and headlong into problems. Potts sounds like he's singing from the runway at Gatwick, his vocals distant and inaudible. The loveliness of the words is completely lost, his voice booming into a blur one moment, falling to a shy whisper the next.

The only voice you do hear is the bass. Hook staggers his way to the edge of the stage, and lets the front row watch as his fingers nimbly work their magic. He may look like your dad, but he plays bass like God. "Alex James, eat your heart out," he grins as I've Got a Feeling begins.

When Hook takes the mike and growls menacingly, the fact that you can't understand a word doesn't matter, as his movements take on a kind of mad sign language of their own. Arms out, hands on his head, a slow wiggling of the hips and a lunging point at the ceiling spell out what he's on about. Seesaw, with its disco beats and anthemic quality at least gets us dancing. As the song draws to a close, Potts smashes his guitar, Pete Townshend style. I know just how he feels.

webTitle: Theatre review: God and Stephen Hawking

fields.headline: Appliance of science
fields.standfirst:
God and Stephen Hawking
Playhouse,Oxford **
fields.trailText:
God and Stephen Hawking
Playhouse,Oxford **
fields.body:
The real affront to Professor Stephen Hawking is not that a play has been written about him against his will, but that it has been done badly. Robin Hawdon's God and Stephen Hawking sits awkwardly between radio play and Open University TV show; its author is so eager to disseminate his learning that he forgets to leaven it with drama. Hawdon compounds the omission by confessing to it. Why else have Robert Hardy's God - a tiresomely smug narrator - herald yet another lecture with an invitation to "snooze, if you like"? This viewer found the offer difficult to resist.

It hardly helps that Hawdon's chosen subject is the clash between scientific progress and religious teaching. Having been exhaustively rehearsed these past 500 years, that debate is low on dramatic currency. Hawdon animates it with painful literalness, conjuring from the heavens a headmasterly deity to costume up as the characters Hawking meets on his journey through life. One such is Einstein, whose quantum physics seminar is all but lost to Hardy's German intonation.

Hawking is more capably played by Stephen Boxer, first as a precocious undergraduate and later as the dogged invalid cramming in achievement before his supposedly fatal condition bests him. But his story is clunkingly told: "Stephen," says a colleague to the future author of A Brief History of Time, "you must write a science book in layman's language."

Hawdon is only modestly interested in Hawking's neglect of his Christian wife Jane. The professor's affair with his nurse is glossed over. We're party to Hawking's private dramas only insofar as they reflect on the God v science face-off. Plays dealing with scientific themes succeed if the science is subject to human drama. Here, unlike in Michael Frayn's Copenhagen, there's neither mystery to impel the narrative nor much concern for the protagonists' emotional lives. The repetitive squabbling over religion is both inadequately written and ultimately fruitless. Hawdon doesn't define his terms, and God, concludes God, can mean anything. Such is the woolly upshot of an uneventful play with little to add to antiquated arguments.

 Ends tonight. Box office: 01865 798600.

webTitle: What to do with that surprise payout

fields.headline: What to do with that surprise payout
fields.standfirst: Jill Papworth thought she would receive a few hundred pounds out of the Scottish Widows takeover. When it turned out to be £5,000, she quickly looked at investments
fields.trailText: Jill Papworth thought she would receive a few hundred pounds out of the Scottish Widows takeover. When it turned out to be £5,000, she quickly looked at investments
fields.body:
In common with thousands of other Scottish Widows policyholders, the arrival this week of my larger-than-expected windfall had me choking on my corn flakes.

Given that I have only a small "Serps opt-out" personal pension plan with Scottish Widows, I'd assumed that I'd get, at best, a few hundred pounds. Despite being a personal finance journalist who should, arguably, know better, I'd therefore taken little notice of reports on how best to invest it.

So, when to my delight a cheque arrived for nearly £5,000, I asked several independent financial advisers (IFAs) how people like me, who have never been in the wealth bracket to seriously invest in equities, could make use of such unexpected windfalls to start building diversified stockmarket-based portfolios.

The aim for most novice investors would be to salt the money away over the medium term - for at least five to 10 years - to achieve capital growth. And opting for pooled funds like unit trust or investment trusts, where your money is put together with that of others and invested across a wide range of stocks, is a safer strategy than investing direct in individual shares. But which funds should one start with and should you be splitting a sum like £5,000 between different funds?

Mark Bolland, technical director of IFA Chamberlain de Broe says: "Over the medium to long term, it makes sense to stash your money away in a tax-efficient environment. So, if you haven't already got one, invest via a tax-free Isa [individual savings account] and find a provider that offers a good range of funds like Gartmore or Henderson.

"Start by building up your UK and European exposure so you could, for example, split your £5,000 and put 75% in Gartmore's UK Growth Fund and 25% in its European Selected Opportunities fund."

An option for investors who haven't the time or inclination to think about the global asset allocation of their portfolio is to invest the whole lump sum in a large, international investment trust and leave diversification up to the fund manager. "I'd go for Alliance Trust, Foreign & Colonial or Henderson Investors' Witan trust which are all very good, broadly spread funds," he says.

Witan is also the top recommendation of Patrick Connolly at IFA Chartwell Investment Management for novice investors. "This low-risk trust will give you a ready-made diversified portfolio in one fund," he says. "It combines the individual expertise of different Henderson fund managers who all contribute to this one umbrella fund which also has very low charges."

Like Mr Bolland, Gavin Haynes, investment director of IFA Whitechurch Securities, favours the UK as the first building block of a diversified portfolio. "The advantages are that there are no currency risks in UK and you are likely to be familiar with the underlying companies that UK funds are investing in," says Mr Haynes.

He recommends a Société Générale unit trust Isa with £5,000 split three ways with £2,000 in its UK Growth, £2,000 in its European Growth and £1,000 in its Technology trust to add, "a bit of aggression".

An alternative would be an Aberdeen Unit Trust Managers Isa with its UK Blue Chip fund as the core holding plus some money in its Technology trust.

International investments should be the next step to building a diversified portfolio says Mr Haynes who favours the EquiSar unit trusts from Sarasin Investment Management which offers, "a good international spread of blue chip companies chosen on a thematic "best of sector" basis".

Dan Kemp of IFA Holden Meehan takes a different approach in recommending that new investors start with international funds, adding other sector and country funds, including the UK, as their portfolio grows.

"First, make use of your Isa allowance, topping up any Isa you've already started to the maximum of £7,000. Remember you can use a new fund , though it must come from the same Isa provider. Then, as a core holding, I'd go for Fidelity's International unit trust or Mercury's Global Titans before building up European exposure using Gartmore European Selected Opportunities."

For investors who want only ethical investments, a sector in which Holden Meehan specialises, Mr Kemp recommends two unit trusts, Murray Johnstone's Ethical World and Jupiter's Ecology.

Will this windfall raise your tax bill?

For thousands of Scottish Widows policyholders, joy over the size of their windfalls has been marred by the potential problem of an unexpected capital gains tax liability.

Patrick Connolly, at IFA Chartwell Investment Management, says the firm has been contacted by clients expecting windfalls under £7,200 - the current annual CGT per person allowance - who have actually received lump sums of £10,000-£12,000.

A higher rate 40% taxpayer receiving £12,200, for example, who has no further capital gains in the tax year faces a CGT liability of almost £2,000. Even basic rate taxpayers could end up paying 40p in the pound if their windfall tips their total earnings into top rate tax territory - although sums paid directly into pension schemes do not attract the tax.

These gains must be declared on tax returns for the year 2000-01, so funds must be available to pay the tax bill in January 2002.

But there are ways of possibly lessening the CGT blow. Investors should first review their existing portfolios to see if they have any capital losses they can offset. "But, if you choose this option, it may be sensible to take independent advice as it may not prove wise to sell a particular investment simply because it is standing at a loss," Mr Connolly says.

The alternative is to invest in vehicles like Venture Capital Trusts (VCTs) and Enterprise Investment Schemes (EISs) which allow CGT liabilities to be deferred and often, with careful planning, avoided entirely.

The downside of VCTs and EISs is that they are generally viewed as high risk investments.

Dan Kemp, of IFA Holden Meehan, suggests those facing a CGT bill might also take advice on whether they could get the full benefit of their windfall by investing part of it in a pension.

A free information pack for Scottish Widows policyholders with a CGT liability is available from Chartwell on 01225 321710.

webTitle: Hot in places but it's getting cooler

fields.headline: Hot in places but it's getting cooler
fields.standfirst: The latest data on house prices may make you wonder, but there are signs that the market is indeed slowing, writes Rupert Jones
fields.trailText: The latest data on house prices may make you wonder, but there are signs that the market is indeed slowing, writes Rupert Jones
fields.body:
Housing market slowdown - what housing market slowdown? That will doubtless be the reaction of many people on reading the latest official house price data from the Land Registry, which seems to contradict recent reports that the housing boom is over and prices are starting to fall.

The Land Registry, a government department, this week issued its figures for the period April 1 to June 30 which show that the price of the average home in England and Wales has crashed through the £100,000 barrier for the first time ever.

The typical property has increased in value by 14.5% over the last year, and is now worth £103,115. The annual rate of growth in Greater London is a lot higher - 23.3% - though there are a number of places that have outperformed the capital, from Somerset in the south to York in the north.

Only a small handful of locations have seen small price falls over the last year, including: Kingston-upon-Hull, Middlesbrough, the north-east Lincolnshire area, Wrexham and Torfaen, south-east Wales.

The figures will cheer homeowners but won't please would-be buyers currently pounding the streets. However, beneath the headline figures can be found signs that the market is indeed slowing. The 14.5% annual rate of growth is down on the record 16.8% annual rate notched up earlier this year, and the figures show prices in some of the most exclusive parts of London appear to be plateauing out.

It is also important to bear in mind that the latest Land Registry figures only relate to house sales completed in the three months to June 30, so they are arguably almost two months out of date. According to Nationwide building society, the cost of an average UK home fell 0.2% in July and now stands at £81,133.

And new figures from the TEAM network of independent estate agents reveal that five out of the 16 locations they surveyed - Devon, Essex, Scotland, Somerset and Avon, and Wessex - saw slight price falls in August.

Nevertheless, the Land Registry figures are the most comprehensive available because they include the vast majority of all house sales over the period, and are broken down by county, borough or unitary authority, and also into property types.

They show that while the average home now costs £103,115, this figure hides a wealth of regional variations. For example, in Stoke-on-Trent an average terraced home costs £25,755, while in the London borough of Kensington and Chelsea a typical terrace will set you back £1.24m - 48 times as much.

Predictably, Greater London tops the regional table, with an average property price of £177,182 (up 23.3% on a year earlier, when it was £143,725). The south-east comes second with an average price of £128,719 (up 18.7%), followed by, in order: the south-west (£101,750 - up 20.3%), East Anglia (£87,293 - up 18.4%), West Midlands (£80,473 - up 11.4%), East Midlands (£72,300 - up 9.4%), the north-west of England (£66,868 - up 7.6%), Yorkshire and Humberside (£65,354 - up 9.3%), Wales (£65,100 - up 9.8%), and the north of England (£61,798 - up 5.l%).

Outside London, the star performer is Reading, one of the towns at the heart of what's been dubbed England's own silicon valley. Reading is home to a growing number of technology companies and internet start-ups, including computer group Oracle, and has seen prices rocket by 34.8% in just 12 months, with the average property now costing £136,753 compared with £101,460 a year earlier.

The new economy effect has also spilled over into nearby Wokingham, where average prices have risen 26.2% in a year (from £144,414 to £182,299), and Windsor and Maidenhead, also in Berkshire, where they have jumped 23.4% over the same period (from £182,332 to £225,106).

Another area that has seen runaway house price growth is Bath and north-east Somerset, where the typical price-tag is now £135,649 - 33.7% up on 12 months earlier, when it was £101,478. However, there is already anecdotal evidence that things may now be levelling out there too. Price growth has been almost as impressive in north Somerset - 31.2% annually - while the figure for Cornwall is a well-above-average 21.2%.

Brighton and Bournemouth have continued to outperform most of the country -average properties in these two towns sell for £115,653 and £107,274 respectively, up in both cases by 30.6%.

In the north of England, areas notching up strong price growth include York (25% in a year - from £67,920 to £84,894) and North Yorkshire (17.4% - from £75,228 to £88,343). Meanwhile, the average property in Greater Manchester now sells for £64,606, up 7.6% on the £60,011 achieved a year earlier.

Dramatic variations in London property prices are leaving the £177,000 average figure for the capital looking increasingly meaningless. The borough of Newham has seen the biggest annual rise in values - a stonking 37%. But the average property there still costs £91,188, the second-lowest in the capital, and just a fraction of the prices being achieved in boroughs such as Kensington and Chelsea (average: £358,899), Richmond upon Thames (£269,542), Hammersmith and Fulham (£268,944) and Islington (£234,066).

Signs of a slowdown in the London market can be detected in the fact that prices in Kensington and Chelsea, and Islington - two boroughs at the forefront of the boom - rose by only 4%-5% between the first and second quarters this year, which is well down on the 8.5% average for London as a whole.

webTitle: Certify yourself for a cheaper loan

fields.headline: Certify yourself for a cheaper loan
fields.standfirst: The one in eight people who are self-employed are often charged punitively high interest rates. But a new type of mortgage is changing that, says Tony Levene
fields.trailText: The one in eight people who are self-employed are often charged punitively high interest rates. But a new type of mortgage is changing that, says Tony Levene
fields.body:
Authors, actors and accountants have always worked for themselves. But with changing job patterns, those in occupations such as nursing, teaching and computing services are now often also self-employed. And that can be a red light when it comes to mortgages.

Around one in eight of the workforce is now wholly or partly their own boss with around 10,000 each week trying to go it alone for the first time. But only a small minority of home loan companies have woken up to this change by offering "self-certification" deals where customers do not have to produce documentary proof of earnings.

The great majority continue to lump the self-employed - and those who set up their own one-person or family companies - as bad risks along with mortgage defaulters and fraudsters.

"Self-employment smacks of dodgy dealings in financial services circles," says Stephen Alambritis of the Federation of Small Businesses. "They're seen as tainted and lumped together with bankrupts. Most lenders are not interested and our members complain that those which even bother to reply to enquires often charge an arm and a leg in interest rates."

And if they grant loans, they insist on two or often three years' worth of audited accounts, disadvantaging those who recently made the move from employment.

But becoming your own boss can be a key time to apply for a mortgage. Many people decide to move home - often searching for extra space so they can run their business from home. And others want to cash in on the growth in property prices so they can finance their new venture at lower interest rates than a business loan from a bank.

One solution is self-certification, where the prospective mortgage customer estimates their own annual earnings instead of relying on an employer or an accountant to come up with the figures. It sounds like a recipe for loan applicants to ask for too much - or to put in fraudulent requests at the other extreme.

But that is not quite as easy as it sounds. "Each application is individually underwritten," says Denzil Morgan at Bristol & West which has lent some £250m since it started self-certification last December.

He adds: "We don't credit-score because it is usually not helpful with self-certification applicants. But we do check on past loans to see if they have shown a good commitment to regular repayments and identify the sources of income. Lifestyle factors are important - we would not lend £250,000 to someone whose previous home was worth £25,000."

Bristol & West's typical loan is around £75,000 - roughly in line with the national average. Morgan believes self-certifiers are conservative in their requests.

Besides helping homebuyers who cannot produce audited accounts, self-certification also enables borrowers to raise cash on their real earnings rather than sums shown by their accountants.

Paul Howard, of Mortgages plc which specialises in loans to those with bad credit records and county court judgments, says there is a dichotomy between accounts which are audited to minimise taxable income and the need of borrowers to raise cash based on what they actually earn.

"Those mainstream lenders which give mortgages to the self-employed and people running their own businesses just look at net profits. They disregard dividends, which are used in tax planning by some small companies, or the way some family concerns pay regular wages to children or others," he adds.

Bill Dudgeon of The Mortgage Business, a Bank of Scotland offshoot focusing on self-certification, believes that accounts are historic - they do not reflect future cash stream from a growing firm.

Lenders also protect themselves by insisting on a sizeable deposit - 15% to 25% is the usual minimum - with the typical borrower putting up 40% of the property's value. A few lenders such as Capital Home Loans, Irish Permanent and Mortgage Express will accept 10% deposits.

Moneyfacts shows there are 15 lenders which currently accept self-certification applications. But the only high street names on the list are Bristol & West and Abbey National - and the latter only accepts forms from brokers rather than directly from branches.

Self-certification rates tend to be on the higher side - especially on loans which have lower deposits, where standard variable rates can go as high as 8.74%. But many are lower. Abbey National uses the same 7.74% standard variable rate as it does for other borrowers.

Brokers who source loans from Mortgage Next can offer mortgages from Britannia subsidiary Verso with discounts of up to 4% for a year, although intermediaries add 0.2% on to the Verso standard 7.78% interest rate. Going direct to Verso gives lower discounts as well as a lower rate and no penalties beyond the cut-rate deal period.

Where you can save nearly £400 a month

Interior designer Dawn Bowring was offered little choice when she bought her Somerset farmhouse a decade ago - pay through the nose or go without.

She took the first route and ended up forking out between 14% and 17% interest. But now she has remortaged through a self-certification loan, with savings of around £350 to £400 a month.

Dawn, 33, has always been self-employed. "I found no bank nor building society at that time who was prepared to lend me anything. They wanted audited accounts which I did not have; and to complicate matters, the house came with an agricultural tie - it could only be sold to a farmer. So I ended up with a loan from a solicitor at a rate that can only be described as extortionate," she says.

She paid each month on time - unaware of newer style loans that could save a small fortune.

"It's odd that banks know I can handle ludicrous interest rates but are sniffy about lending to me at sensible levels," she says.

Dawn only discovered better deals when she took a stand at a local agricultural show where a financial services exhibitor told her about self-certification loans from The Mortgage Business.

fields.bodyText: Authors, actors and accountants have always worked for themselves. But with changing job patterns, those in occupations such as nursing, teaching and computing services are now often also self-employed. And that can be a red light when it comes to mortgages. Around one in eight of the workforce is now wholly or partly their own boss with around 10,000 each week trying to go it alone for the first time. But only a small minority of home loan companies have woken up to this change by offering "self-certification" deals where customers do not have to produce documentary proof of earnings. The great majority continue to lump the self-employed - and those who set up their own one-person or family companies - as bad risks along with mortgage defaulters and fraudsters. "Self-employment smacks of dodgy dealings in financial services circles," says Stephen Alambritis of the Federation of Small Businesses. "They're seen as tainted and lumped together with bankrupts. Most lenders are not interested and our members complain that those which even bother to reply to enquires often charge an arm and a leg in interest rates." And if they grant loans, they insist on two or often three years' worth of audited accounts, disadvantaging those who recently made the move from employment. But becoming your own boss can be a key time to apply for a mortgage. Many people decide to move home - often searching for extra space so they can run their business from home. And others want to cash in on the growth in property prices so they can finance their new venture at lower interest rates than a business loan from a bank. One solution is self-certification, where the prospective mortgage customer estimates their own annual earnings instead of relying on an employer or an accountant to come up with the figures. It sounds like a recipe for loan applicants to ask for too much - or to put in fraudulent requests at the other extreme. But that is not quite as easy as it sounds. "Each application is individually underwritten," says Denzil Morgan at Bristol & West which has lent some £250m since it started self-certification last December. He adds: "We don't credit-score because it is usually not helpful with self-certification applicants. But we do check on past loans to see if they have shown a good commitment to regular repayments and identify the sources of income. Lifestyle factors are important - we would not lend £250,000 to someone whose previous home was worth £25,000." Bristol & West's typical loan is around £75,000 - roughly in line with the national average. Morgan believes self-certifiers are conservative in their requests. Besides helping homebuyers who cannot produce audited accounts, self-certification also enables borrowers to raise cash on their real earnings rather than sums shown by their accountants. Paul Howard, of Mortgages plc which specialises in loans to those with bad credit records and county court judgments, says there is a dichotomy between accounts which are audited to minimise taxable income and the need of borrowers to raise cash based on what they actually earn. "Those mainstream lenders which give mortgages to the self-employed and people running their own businesses just look at net profits. They disregard dividends, which are used in tax planning by some small companies, or the way some family concerns pay regular wages to children or others," he adds. Bill Dudgeon of The Mortgage Business, a Bank of Scotland offshoot focusing on self-certification, believes that accounts are historic - they do not reflect future cash stream from a growing firm. Lenders also protect themselves by insisting on a sizeable deposit - 15% to 25% is the usual minimum - with the typical borrower putting up 40% of the property's value. A few lenders such as Capital Home Loans, Irish Permanent and Mortgage Express will accept 10% deposits. Moneyfacts shows there are 15 lenders which currently accept self-certification applications. But the only high street names on the list are Bristol & West and Abbey National - and the latter only accepts forms from brokers rather than directly from branches. Self-certification rates tend to be on the higher side - especially on loans which have lower deposits, where standard variable rates can go as high as 8.74%. But many are lower. Abbey National uses the same 7.74% standard variable rate as it does for other borrowers. Brokers who source loans from Mortgage Next can offer mortgages from Britannia subsidiary Verso with discounts of up to 4% for a year, although intermediaries add 0.2% on to the Verso standard 7.78% interest rate. Going direct to Verso gives lower discounts as well as a lower rate and no penalties beyond the cut-rate deal period. Where you can save nearly £400 a month Interior designer Dawn Bowring was offered little choice when she bought her Somerset farmhouse a decade ago - pay through the nose or go without. She took the first route and ended up forking out between 14% and 17% interest. But now she has remortaged through a self-certification loan, with savings of around £350 to £400 a month. Dawn, 33, has always been self-employed. "I found no bank nor building society at that time who was prepared to lend me anything. They wanted audited accounts which I did not have; and to complicate matters, the house came with an agricultural tie - it could only be sold to a farmer. So I ended up with a loan from a solicitor at a rate that can only be described as extortionate," she says. She paid each month on time - unaware of newer style loans that could save a small fortune. "It's odd that banks know I can handle ludicrous interest rates but are sniffy about lending to me at sensible levels," she says. Dawn only discovered better deals when she took a stand at a local agricultural show where a financial services exhibitor told her about self-certification loans from The Mortgage Business. The process took six weeks and TMB is protected by its stake in a property that's worth around £750,000 including stables, outhouses, 15 acres and a lake. "I could have produced five years' worth of audited accounts, but they do not reflect my real earnings as I've ploughed lots back into the business," she says. webTitle: What to do when falsely accused of shoplifting

fields.headline: What to do when falsely accused of shoplifting
fields.standfirst: A Sunday morning shopping trip turned into a nightmare for journalist Terence Blacker when he was wrongly arrested for shoplifting
fields.trailText: A Sunday morning shopping trip turned into a nightmare for journalist Terence Blacker when he was wrongly arrested for shoplifting
fields.body:
Like any victim of this humiliating process Mr Blacker would, if he chose to pursue the matter, be entitled to substantial compensation.

He walked into the Somerfield store in Diss carrying newspapers that he had just purchased from a nearby newsagent. After paying for the groceries he was buying from the store he was accosted by two uniformed employees who accused him of stealing the newspapers.

They claimed to have video evidence to support their accusation and made it clear that they would not allow him to leave the store. When they all looked at the video it turned out to feature someone who was clearly not Mr Blacker.

Instead of releasing him after seeing this, the staff continued to detain him. The police were called. A policewoman did then make inquiries at the newsagents and he was released.

Only after he wrote about the incident in a national newspaper did Somerfield even send a letter of apology. The company has not, though, offered any compensation. Indeed, the store has suggested that being involved in incidents like this is a price that people should be willing to pay to help support the fight against shoplifting.

That, though, is not the view the law takes. Any one making a "citizen's arrest", which is what Somerfield did, has to get it absolutely right. Even making a reasonable mistake about someone's guilt does not provide an excuse if a person is wrongly arrested - or falsely imprisoned, as it is legally known.

In 1912 the wife of the manager of WH Smiths at Kings Cross, John Walters, was found to be selling newspapers from her own newsstand in Staines that had been taken from that branch of WH Smiths without payment.

The company's management arrested Walters at work. At trial the jury accepted he was not guilty of theft as he had intended paying for the newspapers.

This meant that no criminal offence had been committed and that the arrest was wrongful. A civil court subsequently awarded him £75 compensation, a sum equivalent to nearly £5,000 in today's values.

While that is perhaps more than Blacker would receive if he sued Somerfield, the level of damages in such cases - usually assessed by a civil jury - tend to be generous compared with those awarded to, say, accident victims.

In a much worse case than Walters' or Blackers', Steven Smith was last year awarded a total of £31,500 against the West Sussex police. They arrested him without believing he had committed any offence, inflicted very minor injuries in the course of doing so, then held him for nine hours.

Despite Mr Smith's case, claims against the police are generally harder to prove, because the Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984 allows for them, unlike store detectives, to make lawful arrests so long as they have reasonable grounds to suspect an offence.

Anyone who finds themselves faced with a false accusation of shoplifting should make it clear that they are not prepared to go anywhere with store staff unless they are formally arrested. There is, of course, no obligation on someone in this situation to prove their innocence.

Somerfield's and retailers organisations' spokesmen have suggested that Mr Blacker could have taken steps to avoid the incident, such as opening the newspapers he had bought before walking into the shop.

However, there is no obligation to do so. Nor is there any obligation to let store staff inspect one's bags or to produce a receipt.

Supermarkets have every right to prevent theft from their stores, but the law requires them to enforce that right only by employing competent, vigilant staff who can distinguish between shoplifters and honest shoppers.

The price of getting it wrong is as high for bullying security staff as it is for their victims, something Somerfield will discover if Mr Blacker decides to take the matter further.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister

fields.headline: Cash share-out puzzles Axa policyholders
fields.standfirst: The £1.7bn distribution tricky to calculate, says Patrick Collinson
fields.trailText: Scottish Widows policyholders may be cock-a-hoop over their bonanza payouts, but policyholders at rival Axa have been left puzzling over highly-complex documents sent out this week detailing windfall payouts from the company's £1.7bn surplus cash.
fields.body:
Scottish Widows policyholders may be cock-a-hoop over their bonanza payouts, but policyholders at rival Axa have been left puzzling over highly-complex documents sent out this week detailing windfall payouts from the company's £1.7bn surplus cash.

More than 660,000 Axa policyholders received the windfall packs this week, detailing how much they will gain from the distribution of Axa's "orphan estate".

Axa is handing out the surplus money that has been built up over many years in the with-profits funds of Equity & Law and Sun Life, both of which are now under the control of Axa, a French-based insurer. The cash distribution is the only way that Axa shareholders can gain access to a share of the £1.7bn.

The details of the payouts are contained in an immensely complex 110-page policyholder circular, accompanied by a voting form, which has to be returned by October 16. The plan has to be approved by policyholders - it needs a 35% yes vote - with payouts expected to be made in February 2001.

The windfalls will come in two parts; firstly a cash payout, which Axa says will be a minimum of £100 and average £400, plus a further 'reorganisation bonus' which will be added to the value of policies. It says one lucky policyholder will collect £90,000.

Policyholders have a choice: they can either vote in favour and gain the cash and reorganisation bonus, or ignore the mailing, in which case they will not receive the cash bonus but will be eligible for a special bonus at an unspecified time in the future.

But policyholders who have contacted Jobs & Money about the windfalls have highlighted how easy it is to be confused about the proposals. Tony and Maureen Webster, who run a guest house in Hemingford Grey, Huntingdon wrote to us this week criticising the proposed payouts as "disgraceful" after she was offered just £221.78 on a pension policy taken out nearly 20 years ago that is currently worth £42,518.

However, after several calls between Axa and Jobs & Money, we were able to identify why the payout appeared to be so small. Somewhat confusingly, the £221.78 payout does not relate to the £42,518 pension policy, but to another, much smaller pension policy that the Websters took out two years later, which has a policy value of around £4,500.

The £4,500 policy is a with-profits policy, which qualifies the Websters for the £221.78 windfall; the £42,518 policy is a unit-linked policy, which will not earn any windfall at all. Unfortunately, this is typical of the gobbledegook common in the life insurance industry. People who have with-profits policies have membership rights in a company - in a sense they "own" the company - while unit-linked policyholders do not.

Given the complexity of the Axa plan, the Websters' confusion is entirely understandable. "You've got to have a degree in rocket science to make head or tail of it," he says.

His opinion is shared by a financial adviser, Chartwell Investment Management. Chief executive Craig Wetton says: "The literature that Axa policyholders are receiving honourably upholds the reputation that financial services companies deliberately attempt to bamboozle customers. Axa are a French company, and if their literature was written in French it would make very little difference to its comprehension by most of the public."

Chartwell has produced a guide to the Axa payouts which can be downloaded from www.chartwell-investment.co.uk, or by writing to Chartwell at 9 Kingsmead Square, Bath BA1 2AB.

Axa says disappointment about the size of payouts stems from confusion about what it is attempting to do. Spokesman Stuart Prosser says: "This is not a demutualisation - it is a completely unique situation. We do seem to be suffering from comparisons with windfalls elsewhere." Anyone wanting to check that they have the correct windfall can consult the formula on pages 23-24 of the policyholder circular - but have a calculator handy.

Axa has also opened a telephone helpline for policyholders on 0345 341341, open from 8.00am to 6.00pm Monday to Friday.

The distribution of Axa's orphan estate is the first of what is expected to be a stream of similar announcements from life companies. Prudential has £8bn in undistributed orphan assets, CGNU £5bn, L&G £2.3bn, Britannic £2bn and Clerical Medical £1.9bn.

webTitle: Why a trip to Europe could prove to be profitable

fields.headline: Why a trip to Europe could prove to be profitable
fields.standfirst: Britain's economy is doing well now - but, warns Robin Stoddart, investors should not rely on the home front alone
fields.trailText: Putting all your eggs in one basket is the most dangerous investment course. That may apply to countries as well as companies, particularly when technological development is a must for any populous, advanced country. How safe is the UK in this regard?
fields.body:
Putting all your eggs in one basket is the most dangerous investment course. That may apply to countries as well as companies, particularly when technological development is a must for any populous, advanced country. How safe is the UK in this regard?

Hundreds of billions of pounds are being spent by European companies on US acquisition, which is a main reason for the euro's weakness. It demonstrates the concentration of leading edge electronics and computer services companies across the Atlantic. Much the same applies in biotechnology. The US is maintaining pre-eminence in aerospace, though Europe has mounted a fair challenge. In oil and most other extraction industries, and agriculture, the US remains a powerhouse. All this backs up Wall Street's strength and financial leadership.

Meanwhile, the UK has been selling out or cutting back in most established industries and many newer ones. Other European countries have held on to their domestic capacity and self-sufficient possibilities with greater tenacity. They have probably been helped by more stable exchange rates.

Now that convergence of growth and financial trends is more apparent than for a very long time, it is easy to assume that prosperity is quite assured among the industrial countries, at least as long as the US leads the way. But some, most notably Japan and Britain, are quite liable to become detached through imbalances in their island economies.

As the advance to all-time peaks in their share markets indicates, France and Switzerland are, next to the US, about the two healthiest-looking economies in the world. Although their economic growth rates are around that of the UK, these are accelerating. They have no problem with the gap between imports and exports or an overvalued currency.

Comparisons between the performance of the top European and British companies is disturbing. It would be even more worrying but for the rise in foreign ownership of prime UK assets and the apparent permanence of their activities, not least in the booming City of London. Exceptions like Rover tend to prove the rule when family control also persists on the Continent, long after it passed into the hands of managers and limited liability companies in nearly all larger segments of the UK economy.

Firms like Nestlé of Switzerland and Interbrew of Belgium accentuate the failures of their British counterparts. Cadbury, about the most successful UK branded goods maker, is relatively puny compared with Nestlé, the world's biggest food group, which bought Rowntree of York for £2bn a decade ago and has many other top brands throughout the world. It also has valuable stakes in cosmetics and pharmaceuticals. Latest results show a big profit acceleration.

The contrast with Allied Domecq and other food and drink producers could hardly be more pronounced. Diageo, the whisky and Guinness group, has been no less amorphous and is also up against faster-growing Continental rivals.

Among smaller companies, the emphasis is on high technology and venture capital investments. A number of UK based firms have performed outstandingly well for investors. They are matched by European companies in most high-tech areas and outnumbered in others, including luxury goods and engineering.

Over the last three years, the best performing unit trust specialising in Europe, M&G European Smaller Companies, has tripled in value. Over one year it has doubled, in common with Henderson European and the new Scottish Equitable fund in the same category. Henderson unit funds are now being converted into open ended investment companies (OEICs), with a less onerous opening commission of 3% , but an increased annual levy of 2% and a new exit charge diminishing over six years.

Investment trusts concentrating on European companies that are growing fastest have done still better in some cases. Fleming European Fledgling, with indirect stakes in unquoted companies, soared by nearly 250% over the last three years, including growth of 140% in the share price over the last year when Invesco Continental and TR European were fairly close behind.

Jewellery firms like Bulgari, sports promoters and other consumer services providers are in their lists. With holdings in larger companies, particularly Swiss and French leaders, Gartmore European and Perpetual European achieved around 60% growth over 12 months and 120% over the past three years.

webTitle: Flying in the face of frankness?

fields.headline: Flying in the face of frankness?
fields.standfirst: Offering eye-catching prices which are less than accurate is a favourite ploy of many businesses. But they are legally liable, says Richard Colbey
fields.trailText: Offering eye-catching prices which are less than accurate is a favourite ploy of many businesses. But they are legally liable, says Richard Colbey
fields.body:
RyanAir's advertising is eye-catching for one thing: the price at which it offers flights. However, obtaining a seat at the advertised prices is near impossible.

Earlier this summer offerings included an improbable £31 return to Venice. That fare, as the company likes to point out, is scarcely enough to cover the tax.

Closer inspection of the small - in fact virtually microscopic - print at the bottom of the advertisement indicated that the real charge for the flight was £34, after a £3 charge for using a credit card, the only means of payment permitted, is added.

Theoretically, that could lead to a prosecution under the misleading price marking regulations, but the triviality of the matter, coupled with the fact RyanAir is based in the Irish Republic, has so far deterred trading standards officers from taking any action.

However, £31, or even £34, fares were very difficult to find on the website to which the advert directs you.

I inserted eight or nine dates at random and found that fares ranged between £82 and £122, still reasonable value, but the company's method of advertising had left a slightly bad taste.

Of course, the words "from" and "subject to availability", the stopgaps of companies which see nothing wrong in advertising what they don't usually offer, can also be found in RyanAir's small print. The words are again far from a watertight guarantee against prosecution but no action appears to have been taken.

RyanAir's luck with the law continued when Jouko Nyakanen, who had booked a RyanAir flight, from Stanstead to Stockholm in February, sought the advice of the Consumers' Association.

His flight had been due to leave at 5.30pm. The screens at the airport told him that it had been delayed. As the screens continued relaying this message, he and several other passengers hung around waiting to be told to board, only to discover, eventually, from the RyanAir desk that the flight had actually taken off without them.

Mr Nyakanen wanted compensation from RyanAir, and there wouldn't really seem to be any doubt that he is entitled to it. Even if the airport, rather than the airline, was to blame for the incorrect information being put on the board, RyanAir's staff should have been aware of this and let the passenger know what was going on. Their failure to do so gives Mr Nyakanen a claim of negligence and breach of contract.

The Consumers' Assocation advised Mr Nyakanen in its Which? publication that the legal position isn't clear-cut.

fields.bodyText: RyanAir's advertising is eye-catching for one thing: the price at which it offers flights. However, obtaining a seat at the advertised prices is near impossible. Earlier this summer offerings included an improbable £31 return to Venice. That fare, as the company likes to point out, is scarcely enough to cover the tax. Closer inspection of the small - in fact virtually microscopic - print at the bottom of the advertisement indicated that the real charge for the flight was £34, after a £3 charge for using a credit card, the only means of payment permitted, is added. Theoretically, that could lead to a prosecution under the misleading price marking regulations, but the triviality of the matter, coupled with the fact RyanAir is based in the Irish Republic, has so far deterred trading standards officers from taking any action. However, £31, or even £34, fares were very difficult to find on the website to which the advert directs you. I inserted eight or nine dates at random and found that fares ranged between £82 and £122, still reasonable value, but the company's method of advertising had left a slightly bad taste. Of course, the words "from" and "subject to availability", the stopgaps of companies which see nothing wrong in advertising what they don't usually offer, can also be found in RyanAir's small print. The words are again far from a watertight guarantee against prosecution but no action appears to have been taken. RyanAir's luck with the law continued when Jouko Nyakanen, who had booked a RyanAir flight, from Stanstead to Stockholm in February, sought the advice of the Consumers' Association. His flight had been due to leave at 5.30pm. The screens at the airport told him that it had been delayed. As the screens continued relaying this message, he and several other passengers hung around waiting to be told to board, only to discover, eventually, from the RyanAir desk that the flight had actually taken off without them. Mr Nyakanen wanted compensation from RyanAir, and there wouldn't really seem to be any doubt that he is entitled to it. Even if the airport, rather than the airline, was to blame for the incorrect information being put on the board, RyanAir's staff should have been aware of this and let the passenger know what was going on. fields.headline: Taking care of Tiddles
fields.trailText: Here's a handy tip. If you're in a conversation at a party with someone and you suspect they're barking mad, but you're not sure - ask them about their pets. It's a subject that flushes out crazy people quicker than anything.
fields.body:
Here's a handy tip. If you're in a conversation at a party with someone and you suspect they're barking mad, but you're not sure - ask them about their pets. It's a subject that flushes out crazy people quicker than anything.

Pets bring out people's characters - and if they're barmy, all the tell-tale signs will be there. You'll have people who have given their pets "funny" names - like Josef Goebbels or Fred West. There'll be people who think their cats are reincarnations of relatives, people who set a place at the table for their cocker spaniel every night and people who have developed psychic relations with their hamsters.

I've never really been much of a pet person myself. I once stayed in Berlin with a woman who had a pet rat with huge testicles, which she called, with an unflinchingly Teutonic eye for accuracy, Mr Bollocks. And perhaps it's that memory - it looked like a fat mouse on a Space Hopper - that has put me off sharing my life with a four-legged friend.

So, I have to say that I've been watching with some surprise the growth of pet insurance, with posters all over the supermarket urging pet-owners to buy the equivalent of private health cover for their animals.

The biggest provider of pet insurance is Pet Plan, which claims over 40% of the country's pet insurance policies, covering 450,000 dogs, cats, horses and assorted creatures.

But there's no shortage of competition. Supermarkets such as Tesco and Sainsbury's have their own pet insurance policies, taking on high street insurers such as Royal & SunAlliance, animal welfare groups such as the RSPCA and specialist services such as Petline, Pet Protect, Petsurance, Pet Healthcare and many more.

So what does pet insurance cover? The most important element is likely to be paying for vets' fees following an accident or illness. These can be more than you might expect - according to the Royal & SunAlliance a cat with a broken pelvis can set you back in excess of £1,100 and a Labrador with a tumour can need £3,000 in treatment.

Pet insurance should also cover the financial value of an animal that dies, strays or is stolen. And common to most policies will be third party liability cover - which pays out compensation if your pet injures someone or damages property.

There are other benefits which can be added, such as refunds for holidays cancelled when a pet is taken ill or kennel fees while an owner is in hospital. And Petline also offers a bereavement counselling helpline.

The pricing of premiums, as well as reflecting the levels of cover, depends on the value of the animal and where you live - with London the highest-charging insurance band, followed by south-east England and the home counties.

For example, Pet Plan charges from £5.25 per month for a non-pedigree cat living in the north of England - and up to £14.25 per month for a pedigree cat in London. Tesco begins its cat cover (outside London) at £3.95.

For dogs, Pet Plan charges from £8.85 per month for a mongrel, Tesco charges from £6.55, Royal & SunAlliance's premiums for dogs begin at £6.99 and Sainsbury's at £8.99, but all of these offer different levels of cover, exclusions and benefits - so there's more to consider than just the headline price.

If you want your rabbit insured, Pet Plan offers £2,000 of cover from between £3.75 per month to £8.50. This policy has the slogan "Insurance for your rabbit, reassurance for you" and at this point I can't help but think there must be one of Beatrix Potter's weirder stories about Nigel Rabbit the Insurance Salesman.

And if you want to burrow deeper into the unfamiliar world of pet insurance, then I'd direct you to a section of Pet Plan's website which promises "The Amusing Side of Pet Insurance".

Among the laugh-a-minute insurance stories is this: "I had finally renewed Boris's puppy cover, having let it lapse. Boris was only insured for one day, when I heard a dreadful squeal in the garden and found Boris impaled on a thick metal fence by his penis!" (It's their exclamation mark - and I bet Boris is still laughing about it).

Or, this "amusing claim": "Jasper was violently sick following his usual walk, so we took him to the vet, who proceeded to remove the 'foreign object' from his throat. They kept pulling and pulling and the object turned out to be an 18-inch stick which ran from his throat to the base of his gut! Jasper is only 21 inches long and unbelievably was completely unharmed! The stick is now on my bookshelf as a momento." Hmm, nice.

Email: coughlan_sean@hotmail.com

fields.headline: Joe Cole fires young England
fields.standfirst:
England Under-21 6 Young 17, A Cole 37, Jeffers 44, Dunn 45, Greening 61, Smith 90
Georgia Under-21 1 Tsitaishvili 29
fields.trailText:
England Under-21 6 Young 17, A Cole 37, Jeffers 44, Dunn 45, Greening 61, Smith 90
Georgia Under-21 1 Tsitaishvili 29
fields.byline: Richard Williams at the Riverside stadium
fields.body:
A display of precocious brilliance by Joe Cole illuminated a landslide victory for England's youngsters against Georgia in this friendly match last night. Perhaps Howard Wilkinson, the FA's technical director and the team's coach, might have been forgiven for feeling that Cole's presence at the European Under-21 championships earlier in the summer, which the 18-year-old missed through injury, might have been enough to alter the complexion of what turned out to be a dismal experience.

Wilkinson's starting line-up included four new caps: the defenders Adam Newton of West Ham, Titus Bramble of Ipswich and Ashley Cole of Arsenal, and the midfielder Michael Carrick of West Ham, playing alongside his club-mate Joe Cole in a midfield completed by David Dunn.

Joe Cole, starting an Under-21 match for the first time after coming on as a substitute against Argentina in February, provided the game's first moment of distinction after 10 minutes by producing a stepover that befuddled his marker, Jaba Mujiri, before flighting a right-wing cross which his namesake headed just over George Lomaia's bar.

Seven minutes later, after Gia Imedadze and David Digmelashvili had both fired high from long range for the visitors, England took the lead when Luke Young rose to Joe Cole's right-wing corner and met it with a robust header. Lomaia, who was already looking vulnerable, could only wave as it went inside his left-hand post.

England's old-fashioned 4-3-3 gave Jonathan Greening, out of favour for the past year at Manchester United, scope to roam across the front line, but it also placed a considerable burden on Carrick, asked to play the holding role in front of the central man-markers. After 29 minutes he was left exposed as the last man when Klimenti Tsitaishvili ran on to a long ball and held off the West Ham man before lobbing over Paul Robinson to level the scores with the aplomb of a young man who made his First Division debut at the age of 14 and is now with Maccabi Tel Aviv.

But the combination of the two Coles restored England's lead eight minutes before half- time when Ashley played the ball up to Joe on the edge of the area, collected the cleverly delayed return pass and fired past Lomaia from 15 yards. A further piece of wizardry from the West Ham prodigy enabled England to extend the advantage after 44 minutes when Francis Jeffers nudged home a loose ball after Darius Vassell had nodded down a cross from the right, and a minute later Dunn made it 4-1 when he ran in from the left to shoot home from the edge of the area.

The goal was Dunn's last act, for Wilkinson chose to use the interval to introduce three more players to international football at this level, and the captain was withdrawn in order to give a first cap to David Prutton, Nottingham Forest's coveted midfielder, arriving with Clarke Carlisle of Queens Park Rangers and Stephen Wright of Liverpool.

The rearranged rearguard showed signs of nerves five minutes into the second half when George Shengalia of Dinamo Tbilisi rose to meet Tsitaishvilli's dipping cross but failed to keep his volley down.

Joe Cole, who had taken the captain's armband on Dunn's departure, demonstrated his ability to accelerate past an opponent when he left Tsereteli trailing in his wake before shimmying past Khizaneishvili on the edge of the area and screwing a low cross-shot wide.

But it was Greening who struck England's next blow, turning inside the area after 61 minutes to guide a low shot past the left hand of the substitute goalkeeper, Mirza Merlani. Greening's reward was an immediate withdrawal as Wilkinson sent on a further gaggle of substitutes, including Andy Campbell, the local hero, and Watford's Tommy Smith, who duly obliged from close range in injury-time.

England Under-21 (4-3-3): Robinson (Leeds United); Newton (West Ham), Bramble (Ipswich, Wright (Liverpool h-t), Young (Tottenham; Carlisle , QPR, h-t), A Cole (Arsenal; Smith , Watford,73; J Cole (West Ham; Parker, Charlton 73), Carrick (West Ham; Hargreaves , Bayern Munich, 62), Dunn (Blackburn; Prutton , Forest, h-t); Greening (Man United; Campbell , Middlesbrough, 62), Jeffers (Everton; Chadwick , Man Utd, 62), Vassell (Aston Villa; Thirlwell , Sunderland,73)

Georgia U-21 (1-4-3-2): Lomaia (Lokomotiv Tbilisi); Khizaneishvili (Spartak Moscow); Sasaia (Wit-Georgia Tblisi), Tsereteli (Alania Vladikavkaz), Abramidze (Lokomotiv Tbilisi), Mujiri (Wit-Georgia Tbilisi); Digmelashvili (Wit-Georgia Tbilisi), Kvaratskhelia (Lokomotiv Tbilisi), Gvazava (Zimbru); Imedadze (Torpedo Kutaisi), Tsitaishvili (Maccabi Tel Aviv).

Referee : T Hauge (Norway).

webTitle: Tudor reigns as Surrey close on title

fields.headline: Tudor reigns as Surrey close on title
fields.standfirst:
Surrey 356 & 53-2
Yorkshire 158
fields.trailText:
Surrey 356 & 53-2
Yorkshire 158
fields.body:
Mike Denness and Alan Fordham, the pitch inspectors from Lord's, spent most of the day and much of the evening considering whether to dock Yorkshire eight points for offering up a damp strip on the first morning. But Adam Hollioake's highly impressive side were busy making such considerations academic, taking several more bold strides towards a crushing win here and a second consecutive title.

Having extended their first innings to 356, for a fourth batting point, Surrey reduced Yorkshire to nought for two, then three for four and finally 158 all out. Hollioake declined to enforce the follow-on - he rarely does - and by the time he accepted the umpires' offer of bad light with 22 overs remaining, Surrey held a lead of 251 with eight second-innings wickets in hand.

Only the weather, it seems, can stop them now. But even a draw would leave them 19 points ahead of second-placed Lancashire with two games to play, the first at home to Durham next week. It is all over bar the crowning.

The sight of Fordham, the cricket operations manager for the England and Wales Cricket Board, inspecting the pitch yesterday morning was quite a surprise after Surrey had scored 330 for eight on the first day. Denness explained that he and Chris Wood, the ECB's pitches consultant, had been called north after the umpires, Barry Dudleston and John Harris, expressed their concern on Wednesday evening.

Coincidentally, Surrey were the visitors and Denness the pitch liaison officer when Derbyshire were docked eight points in June, again for starting a match without the requisite dry pitch. Surrey lost that game, one of only two defeats all season. But any chance of a repeat here was quickly blown away, notably by Alex Tudor.

He did not last long with the bat, falling lbw to Matthew Hoggard in the second over of the day, although by the time Saqlain Mushtaq followed caught behind, Surrey's last three wickets had added 159 with Ian Salisbury left unbeaten on 57.

Hoggard did not bowl badly, ending with three for 100 from 30 overs, but it took Tudor precisely two balls of Yorkshire's reply to raise the question of whether England have selected the best young paceman for their winter tours. Tudor's first delivery nipped back and trapped Simon Widdup plumb in front; the next moved away and found Anthony McGrath's outside edge.

In the next over Ben Hollioake, who capitalised impressively on a rare chance with the new ball in the absence of the injured Martin Bicknell, bowled the left-handed Victor Craven with a beautiful inswinging yorker. And Yorkshire's predicament could have been even worse as Darren Lehmann was caught behind off a no-ball with the total still in single figures.

Lehmann got his head down after that, dominating partnerships of 79 with David Byas and 39 with Gary Fellows. Ben Hollioake switched to the Trafalgar Square end to have Byas caught off bat and pad and, shortly after lunch, Tudor found Fellows's outside edge.

But Lehmann was the wicket Surrey needed and it came presented with ribbons as Gavin Hamilton drove into the covers, called for a single, then changed his mind, with Ian Ward's cool throw leaving the Australian stranded. His 74-ball 66, which included seven boundaries, took his championship tally to 1,181, eight behind the country's leading batsman Justin Langer.

But it was not enough for Yorkshire, as Tudor kept on until he cramped up with figures of four for 75, and Saqlain was then finally called into the attack to take two for nought in eight balls.
