fields.headline: Round up
fields.trailText: Mark Wagh's third championship century tightened Warwickshire's grip on the Second Division promotion clash with their neighbours Worcestershire at Edgbaston.
fields.body:
Mark Wagh's third championship century tightened Warwickshire's grip on the Second Division promotion clash with their neighbours Worcestershire at Edgbaston.

The former Oxford University captain made the most of a flat pitch with an unbeaten 118, exactly two years after scoring 118 against the same county at New Road.

Wagh shared in an opening stand of 166 with Michael Powell (69), who scored his third half-century in four innings. Warwickshire reached 224 for one, only 39 behind, before rain ended the second day before tea.

Glenn McGrath, in his first championship match since returning from international duty in Melbourne, struggled to achieve penetration but maintained his accuracy with one for 35 in 21 overs.

Sussex eased past their follow-on target against Nottinghamshire at Trent Bridge thanks to a chanceless century by Richard Montgomerie. The opener's second century of the season - his first was also against Nottinghamshire - came after Nottinghamshire's first innings had closed on 351.

Darren Bicknell, who resumed on 139 after carrying his bat through day one, added only five before he gave Jason Lewry his third five-wicket haul this summer by slicing a drive to Tony Cottey at backward point. Lewry finished with six for 89.

Montgomerie meanwhile will resume today on 116, with his team still 116 adrift with four wickets remaining. The former Derbyshire seamer Andy Harris has taken three wickets so far.

Simon Katich was left 14 short of 1,000 runs for the season when rain curtailed the first day's play in Durham's First Division relegation battle against Hampshire in Chester-le-Street, with the hosts on 104 for one.

The Australian left-hander was unbeaten on 50, his seventh half-century of the season, and the acting captain Jon Lewis was on 34. They put on 95 after Michael Gough shouldered arms in the third over and was lbw to Alan Mullally for nought.

England lost their first series at Under-19 level for four years when they went down by two wickets to Sri Lanka in a tense finish to the third Test in Worcester.

Sri Lanka began the day on 57 for five, chasing 109 to win, and Malintha Gajanayake and their captain Kaushalya Weeraratne took them to within five runs of victory with a 37-run stand for the seventh wicket.

But with successive balls Justin Bishop, the Essex left-arm seamer who took seven for 42 in the first innings, had Weeraratne caught behind and Ranil Dhammika caught at slip before Gajanayake hit the winning runs in taking his score to 36.

webTitle: Record caps perfect day for Powell

fields.headline: Record caps perfect day for Powell
fields.standfirst:
Essex 292
Glamorgan 360-6
fields.trailText:
Essex 292
Glamorgan 360-6
fields.body:
It was quite a day for Michael Powell. Not only did he collect his first century of the summer but he was awarded his county cap. More importantly his deeds, and those of Matthew Maynard with whom he shared in a slice of history, ensured that Glamorgan reached the third day of their crucial promotion tussle very much in the ascendancy.

Powell burst upon the scene in sensational style as a 20-year-old in 1997 when he scored an unbeaten 200 against Oxford University on his debut. He has never attained such heights since, although he averaged just over 45 last season to top Glamorgan's championship batting.

His talent has never been in doubt but he has often struggled to find a rich vein of form. Yesterday was one of his more rewarding days as he defied a succession of bowling changes for nearly six hours.

He proved particularly strong off his legs and the Essex attack often seemed slow to recognise the fact. He prospered with ease and confidence against bowlers who fed his strength.

Maynard, so experienced and no doubt a calming influence on his young partner, proved an ideal companion during a partnership of 227 which was a Glamorgan record for the fourth wicket against Essex. It beat by 21 runs the one involving Viv Richards and Tony Cottey on the same Southchurch Park ground 10 years ago.

With the score on 99 and Maynard only just into double figures he survived a difficult chance to the Essex wicketkeeper James Foster, diving to his right after Danny Law had found the outside edge.

Maynard took full advantage of his reprieve to record his second century of the summer, pulling Peter Such for successive fours to complete it. He had earlier employed a pull-cum-sweep to dispatch the off-spinner for six.

Having seen Glamorgan beyond 300 to claim a third batting point, the pair departed within two overs of each other, both victims of Such. Powell had made 128 when he pushed forward and presented Paul Prichard with a regulation slip catch, and Maynard, on 102, edged a delivery into his stumps.

Essex took the new ball soon afterwards but their only success came when Keith Newell was lbw to Danny Law. Glamorgan registered their fourth batting point just before the close, which arrived with them on 360 for six and holding an advantage of 68. With Adrian Dale still in attendance there is every likelihood of them stretching it into three figures.

It was a praiseworthy effort by Glamorgan, particularly as they were without their leading run-gatherer Matthew Elliott, whose season has come to a premature end because of a knee injury.

fields.headline: Northants grindrivals underfoot
fields.standfirst:
Northamptonshire 469
Gloucestershire 65-3
fields.trailText:
Northamptonshire 469

Gloucestershire 65-3
fields.body:
Some would contend that Dr Marten's, cobbler to the better class of thug, is at least partly to blame for the excesses of skinheads and the National Front.

Northamptonshire's trusty sponsor, though, is exerting a more productive influence on the county's fortunes in the middle. The ruthless way the Second Division leaders are going about their business here evokes a boot being mercilessly applied to the ribs of a defenceless rival.

As they ground their way to impregnability at barely 2 runs an over, the day belonged, cockle-warmingly, to Tony Penberthy - "Pembers" to all and sundry and elder statesman among the circuit's growing band of Cornishmen. He turns 31 today and is one of those lovably utilitarian coves whose deeds are better appreciated by folklore than selectors.

Hooking with a happy relish, at which Xavier Hollander herself might have blanched, he scored the first century of a fine, if unsung, season, the fifth of a career spanning a dozen summers, and accepted the acclaim while lowering his head in sheepish modesty. The ensuing straight-driven six off Tom Cotterell was that of a man finally secure enough to give vent to self-expression.

So benign was the pitch, the most authentic shot came courtesy of an off-drive from the No10, Darren Cousins. And Jason Brown, having mustered but a single in his previous seven visits to the crease, rattled his way to two before Martyn Ball ended the torment.

The reply opened to the sound of Cousins rumbling in off a run that might have stretched back to Market Harborough had the indoor centre not intervened. After conceding five from his first three deliveries, he served up 33 successive dot balls. And the subservient mood persisted.

Brown broke through in his fourth over, hurrying one through to trap Tim Hancock on the back foot. He struck again before bad light intervened, inflicting the same fate on Matt Windows, and Cousins reaped his due when he darted one back to pin Kim Barnett

Nick Cook, the Second XI coach who has overseen Brown's progress, greeted the off-spinner's omission from England's winter party with dismay, highlighting Brown's 46 wickets in seven outings and decrying the fashionable insistence on "two-dimensional" players.

fields.headline: England dreaming of a 60s revival
fields.standfirst: Nasser Hussain may be on the verge of ending a 31-year losing streak
fields.trailText: No one talks about the Wisden Trophy. It is not taboo, as such. It just sounds as if it is a relic from history, like the Jules Rimet. But in the next few days it will be dusted down and given a dash of Silvo, ready to make a reappearance, glinting in the sunshine of our consciousness. It will be awarded to the England captain Nasser Hussain at the end of the Test, provided England manage to avoid defeat here.
fields.body:
No one talks about the Wisden Trophy. It is not taboo, as such. It just sounds as if it is a relic from history, like the Jules Rimet. But in the next few days it will be dusted down and given a dash of Silvo, ready to make a reappearance, glinting in the sunshine of our consciousness. It will be awarded to the England captain Nasser Hussain at the end of the Test, provided England manage to avoid defeat here.

An England captain has not got his hands on the pot for 11,371 days, since Ray Illingworth held it aloft after beating West Indies 2-0 in 1969. That is why no one talks about a trophy that was first competed for in 1963, and which is the Anglo-Caribbean equivalent of the Ashes.

West Indies have dominated England so completely over the past three decades, winning 13 consecutive series, that most people assumed the trophy was being used as a rum-punch bowl at some distant steel-band bash.

England's dismal run represents the longest period of failure where two international teams compete for a prize. In any sport. Their glum sequence equals America's period of dominance of the Ryder Cup. America, beaten by England in 1957, then went 13 contests without defeat.

The United States' women tennis players beat Britain in the annual Wightman Cup for 11 years running between 1979 and 1989 before walking away from the competition with a huge yawn.

The US sailors won the America's Cup, which was nailed to the floor of the New York Yacht Club, 24 times between 1870 and 1983. But they competed against more than one country.

Like the Ashes, the Wisden Trophy is normally kept in the museum at Lord's. But unlike the Ashes it is considered robust enough to move and in 1998 it was taken to Antigua to be presented to Brian Lara after he had led West Indies to their latest victory. It should be on display in the Oval long room over the next few days.

You can almost hear John Arlott's rich tones coming down the time tunnel from that 1969 series. "... And it's Holder to Knight. Sounds rather like a dance tune, doesn't it?"

Without undervaluing England's achievements, West Indies were in as big a mess 31 years ago as they are today. They limped into the country after a difficult tour of Australia and in a damp summer went into the first Test at Old Trafford short of match practice.

Like today, they were going through a period of decline after a long period of domination. There was no Wes Hall or Charlie Griffith, no Rohan Kanhai, Seymour Nurse or Conrad Hunte. Eleven of their 16 players were Test newcomers in English conditions.

For Brian Lara today read Garry Sobers then. At 33, Sobers still had much wonderful cricket left in him. But he was stale and not fully fit that year, with a piece of chipped bone rattling around in his shoulder like a marble in a biscuit barrel.

He scored only 150 runs in the three Tests at an average of 30, compared with the 722 (103.14) he made on his previous tour in 1966. He tended to bowl his faster stuff in brief spells and could not manage his wrist-spin at all.

Lance Gibbs was merely a gangling shadow of his old self and the Test bowling averages were led by John Shepherd and Grayson Shillingford.

It was such a long time ago that the leading batsmen in England that summer were John Edrich, Ted Hemsley, Mushtaq Mohammad and Barry Richards; Alan Ward, Mike Procter, Derek Underwood and Tom Cartwright led the bowling averages.

It was the year Neil Armstrong walked on the moon, making a giant leap for mankind. And a pint of bitter cost 11p. It was so long ago that England's footballers were in possession of something called the Jules Rimet Trophy.

webTitle: England are missing a chance to blood stars of tomorrow

fields.headline: England are missing a chance to blood stars of tomorrow
fields.trailText: I can't help thinking our priorities are wrong as England prepare to play in France tomorrow. The failure at Euro 2000 provided an opportunity to make a clean break and plan for the future. Yet short-term thinking has taken hold again.
fields.body:
I can't help thinking our priorities are wrong as England prepare to play in France tomorrow. The failure at Euro 2000 provided an opportunity to make a clean break and plan for the future. Yet short-term thinking has taken hold again.

To my mind the squad Kevin Keegan chose for Paris should have sent a clear signal: that we are planning not so much for the next World Cup but more for 2004 and 2006. It was a chance to begin regenerating so we soon have a team capable of competing with the best and playing with a style so lacking over the summer.

Instead we appear to be scrambling short-sightedly from game to game, hellbent on reaching the 2002 finals without pausing to look further ahead. Only three of the Euro 2000 squad were not selected. With Alan Shearer having retired and Robbie Fowler injured, that means only Richard Wright, a promising young keeper, was dropped.

True, Rio Ferdinand and Kieron Dyer have been brought back. But it has taken injuries to elevate Alan Smith, and there are no places for Frank Lampard, Joe Cole, Jon Harley or Francis Jeffers among others. To my mind they should have been included, whereas ageing players such as David Seaman, Paul Ince and Tony Adams should have been left out.

I must add that I don't blame Keegan for his fixation with the Germany qualifier next month and with reaching the 2002 finals. Succeed and he will be a saviour again, fail and he will face all kinds of flak. The shame is that the hierarchy at the Football Association has not come out and told him to work for the future, making it clear that if we reach Japan and South Korea all well and good but above all let's build an exciting, fluid side.

That would be a very brave move but I'm sure the public would accept defeat by Germany if they felt progress was being made. Scratching a 1-0 win achieves nothing if we just scramble into another competition, go out after three or four matches and hear complaints yet again that we're not good enough.

I believe the talent is there to learn the lessons. You only have to watch five-a-sides at Premiership training grounds to see that. A lot of our players are not put to shame by the foreign stars, and we just need to take that on to the field. After Euro 2004 in Portugal comes a World Cup in Germany, so the conditions are in our favour if we get things right.

Injuries to Steven Gerrard, Emile Heskey and Rio Ferdinand have not helped Keegan in the lead-up to tomorrow but his plans for the first two qualifiers still seem some way from mine. My ideal starting line-up against Germany, playing 3-5-1-1, would be: Wright (aged 22); Ferdinand (21), Campbell (25), Barry (19); Dyer (21), Anderton (28) or McManaman (28), Beckham (25), Gerrard (20), Harley (20) or P Neville (23); Scholes (25); Owen (20).

That by no means leaves England without experience. David Beckham and Sol Campbell each have more than 30 caps and others have played in two major tournaments. The Neville brothers and Fowler would remain important squad members.

But together with youth the line-up contains players who can look after the ball, and hopefully several more youngsters will burst through. Joe Cole and Michael Carrick we already know about. Others should be on their way.

You need only look at tomorrow's opponents to see how well a forward-thinking policy can work. After failing to qualify for the 1994 World Cup France dispensed with Eric Cantona and David Ginola and built their side with others.

Alongside established internationals such as Didier Deschamps and Laurent Blanc came people such as Lilian Thuram and Zinedine Zidane, who might not have been such a big player if Cantona had stayed around. Then they planned the system so others would come through, and we are trying to do the same.

Patrick Vieira was given his chance at 20 and Thierry Henry, Nicolas Anelka and David Trezeguet have emerged in the past few years. There is not an abundance of brilliant young English talent but those around need to be given a chance to establish themselves.

Keegan would have to be prepared to fail with some but we could still qualify for 2002 with a young, experimental squad. The most important thing, though, is that we should play neat, attractive football and perform as a team. It's time to move on.

webTitle: Second failed test dashes Hartson hopes

fields.headline: Second failed test dashes Hartson hopes
fields.trailText: John Hartson was at home last night, far from his Wales international colleagues and seemingly even further from the big-club move he craves after the second devastating medical verdict on the 25-year-old striker in five months.
fields.body:
John Hartson was at home last night, far from his Wales international colleagues and seemingly even further from the big-club move he craves after the second devastating medical verdict on the 25-year-old striker in five months.

One of the most surprising transfer deals in recent years fell through after Hartson yesterday failed the "toughest-ever" medical set by Rangers, thus scuppering his projected £7m move to Ibrox and his unexpected chance of playing in the Champions League.

As a result the Wimbledon striker did not rejoin his Welsh team mates for yesterday's flight to Belarus with the FA of Wales spokesman Mark Evans saying: "John has decided not to travel as he is not in the right frame of mind. It was something Mark Hughes [the Wales manager] was prepared for if the move broke down."

Despite brave noises from the player's agent Jonathan Barnett that the move could be resurrected, the chances of Hartson leaving Wimbledon in the near future appear slim.

In March a £6m move to Tottenham collapsed after a medical because of doubts about a long-standing knee problem. Since then Hartson, who missed more than four months of last season, has had a hernia operation and has played only a handful of games since mid-December.

A Rangers statement said: "Due to the fact John Hartson has not played a sufficient number of top-class matches recently, Rangers... are of the opinion he would not be at the level of match fitness required at this particular stage of the season in view of our involvement in the Uefa Champions League. Rangers FC and the player are very disappointed."

Nevertheless, Barnett said: "The move isn't over as far as I and John are concerned and I am hopeful that something can still be sorted out. He has played only two games this season and failed to meet their requirements at this stage, but it's by no means dead."

Rangers suffered a further blow hours after the Hartson verdict when they missed out on another striker before tonight's Champions League deadline as the Italian Cristiano Lucarelli rejected a £9m move from Lecce.

 A former Atletico Madrid striker who was shot by a fascist firing squad in 1939could become football's first saint. Manolo Garnica is one of 10,000 victims of the Spanish civil war proposed as candidates for beatification, a step toward sainthood. Atletico were relegated last season and the chairman Jesus Gil said: "Knowing that we have such an important fan in heaven will show the devil himself that Atletico Madrid can't stay in his kingdom any longer."

A Rangers statement said: "Due to the fact John Hartson has not played a sufficient number of top-class matches recently, Rangers... are of the opinion he would not be at the level of match fitness required at this particular stage of the season in view of our involvement in the Uefa Champions League. Rangers FC and the player are very disappointed." Nevertheless, Barnett said: "The move isn't over as far as I and John are concerned and I am hopeful that something can still be sorted out. He has played only two games this season and failed to meet their requirements at this stage, but it's by no means dead." Rangers suffered a further blow hours after the Hartson verdict when they missed out on another striker before tonight's Champions League deadline as the Italian Cristiano Lucarelli rejected a £9m move from Lecce.  A former Atletico Madrid striker who was shot by a fascist firing squad in 1939could become football's first saint. Manolo Garnica is one of 10,000 victims of the Spanish civil war proposed as candidates for beatification, a step toward sainthood. Atletico were relegated last season and the chairman Jesus Gil said: "Knowing that we have such an important fan in heaven will show the devil himself that Atletico Madrid can't stay in his kingdom any longer."

fields.headline: Blatter proposal mortifies Oldham
fields.standfirst: Second Division Lancashire club ponder a future without transfer lifeline
fields.trailText: As officials emerged from yesterday's meeting in Geneva to announce the end of the transfer system, the implications were already being felt hundreds of miles away at Boundary Park and, for that matter, all the other small clubs in Europe.
fields.body:
As officials emerged from yesterday's meeting in Geneva to announce the end of the transfer system, the implications were already being felt hundreds of miles away at Boundary Park and, for that matter, all the other small clubs in Europe.

Oldham Athletic's public relations officer Gordon Lawton had just heard Sepp Blatter on the radio announcing that the transfer system was dead; no longer will clubs have to pay fees for players aged 24 or more.

For Lawton and his fellow officials at the Lancashire Second Division club, the Fifa president's words could sound the death knell for an institution they serve and support so loyally. "We rely on transfer money, it helps keep the club afloat," he said. "It's vital for clubs like ours. It's the only thing that keeps us going.

"We have enough trouble as it is. It can be a real struggle trying to make ends meet on a weekly basis. This is going to make it even harder."

Lawton estimates that by selling one player a season for a minimum of £500,000 Oldham, a Premiership club from 1991-94, can stay afloat. "That sort of money helps pay the wages of all non-playing staff for the whole year and a number of other expenses."

Oldham sold the full-back Carl Serrant to Newcastle United for £600,000 in September 1998 and last season Stuart Barlow joined Wigan for £70,000.

Under Fifa's new proposals they would have got nothing for Barlow while the loss of Serrant, who was coming up to his 23rd birthday, would only have yielded compensation. Though it is not clear how much, Lawton believes that it would have been nowhere near the amount they actually banked for the defender.

"Things are just going to get harder for us with these new rules," Lawton added. "It's going to be fine for the big boys and the big-name players. They will be able to go out there, pay big salaries and the players will get fat salaries. It's a payday for them but not for us and our players."

The European Commission decided to challenge the current transfer system following a complaint from the Italian club Perugia, who refused to pay a transfer fee to a Belgian club. The commission believes that as in any other industry, players should have the right to change employers provided they give a period of notice.

Lawton, however, believes that politicians need to take into account the unique nature of sport in general and football in particular.

Oldham claim that it was difficult enough adjusting to the demands of the Bosman ruling but that these plans will be much harder to come to terms with.

While Fifa has said that compensation should be paid for players aged 18 to 24 and that this might benefit some clubs who lose out on players they have helped develop, Lawton believes that the amounts may not be enough to guarantee the financial future of small clubs.

He said: "Who knows, we might go under with an end to transfers. Life is going to be very difficult. This whole thing could be a real disaster.

"We need solid transfer money, not vague guarantees of compensation."

Others within the game believe that the issue of compensation has not been properly thought out and could cause even more problems for clubs and players.

John Barnwell, head of the League Managers' Association and who was following yesterday's events in Zurich, said: "How will levels of compensation be sorted out?

"For players under 24 do you evaluate it on training and time spent with a young footballer? If so, do you pay the same amount of compensation for someone who has been at Liverpool's academy as you do for someone who has been at Exeter?"

Fifa has not announced how it will evaluate compensation levels. Many feel that it might be based on the length of contract, appearances or even goals scored.

The new proposals are also something of a double-edged sword. While players will be able to walk away from clubs and terminate their contracts, given a period of notice, clubs will also be able to sack players, with notice. "It works both ways," said Barnwell. A player could have a bad game or fall out with the boss and he could be out of the club."

The game's wealthier, high-profile players, however, are unlikely to be concerned at being sacked by their clubs, given that most have earned enough never to work again.

"It's the vast majority that I feel sorry for," said Barnwell. "Small players and small clubs are going to be hardest hit by the new proposals."

fields.headline: Beckham takes the central line
fields.standfirst: Onus on United midfielder to outclass Zidane and run game for England
fields.trailText: David Beckham will be asked to compare notes on creative midfield play with Zinedine Zidane in the Stade de France here tomorrow night as Kevin Keegan strives to restore to the England team the inventiveness and imagination so badly lacking in Euro 2000.
fields.body:
David Beckham will be asked to compare notes on creative midfield play with Zinedine Zidane in the Stade de France here tomorrow night as Kevin Keegan strives to restore to the England team the inventiveness and imagination so badly lacking in Euro 2000.

For a long time now a strong body of opinion has argued that a player with Beckham's passing ability is wasted when his role is limited to supplying crosses from the right. With Darren Anderton now fully fit Keegan will waste no time testing this theory.

So Beckham will switch to a central role tomorrow, with Anderton looking certain to return to the right flank. With Keegan expected to employ a five-man midfield in an effort to avoid his team being outpassed by the French, the Pauls Ince and Scholes look like joining Beckham in the centre.

Definitely playing, as well as Beckham and Tony Adams, the new England captain following Alan Shearer's retirement from internationals, are Andy Cole and Gareth Barry. Cole will lead the attack either in partnership with Michael Owen or as a lone striker closely supported by Scholes.

Barry, whose previous two caps have been as a substitute, will be a left wing-back if Keegan goes for a 3-5-2 system or left-back in a 4-4-2 formation, with Phil Neville on the right. Barry's normal position for Aston Villa is on the left side of a back three but he could not play there for England without disturbing Sol Campbell.

If Beckham shows real signs of becoming a serious creative force for England then tomorrow's game against the world and European champions will bring important benefits to Keegan and his squad for the opening 2002 World Cup qualifiers against Germany and Finland early next month.

Certainly the 25-year-old Manchester United player, wearing a diamond stud in each ear and sporting the wristwatch equivalent of Big Ben, appears to relish a further opportunity to vindicate those who would like to see him given a run in this position.

"I hope I can show that I'm a better player in this role than I am on the right," he said last night. "Maybe one game is not enough. Certainly I would like to have a few more matches to get used to playing in this position."

Beckham also endorsed Keegan's stewardship. "He's the best England manager I've played under... but then I've only played under two," he added. "He's a great motivator. He makes us want to go out and do well both for him and the country. He is a great man manager."

In spite of Beckham's confidence it has to be said that previously his reluctance to go past opponents from central midfield, preferring to play long passes to the flanks or the front-runners, has raised doubts about his ability truly to run a game in the manner of a Zidane, a Roberto Baggio or even a Paul Gascoigne.

Cole, who missed Euro 2000 in order to have an operation on a trapped nerve in a foot, felt that Shearer's retirement would help Keegan try something different up front but was not assuming that he would keep the central striker's position long-term. "I'm 29 and I don't know how long I've got to go," he said, "and there are so many good young strikers coming through who will need to be given a chance."

Barry confessed that he would probably have never been in Keegan's European Championship squad had he not been naturally left-footed. Yet the Villa 19-year-old has an ability to control and distribute the ball in a calm and collected manner beyond his years. And nothing will help England tomorrow night if they do not pass the ball properly and move off it with more enthusiasm than they did earlier this summer.

England (possible, 3-5-2): Seaman ; Keown , Adams (all Arsenal), Campbell ; Anderton (both Tottenham), Beckham (Man Utd), Ince (Middlesbrough), Scholes (Man Utd), Barry (Aston Villa); Cole (Man Utd), Owen (Liverpool).

fields.headline: Atherton contemplates the end
fields.trailText: As Michael Atherton, as staunch and disciplined as ever, battled with limited support yesterday to try to turn England's long-awaited series victory against the West Indies into a reality, it was not the happiest time to imagine how life might be without him.
fields.body:
As Michael Atherton, as staunch and disciplined as ever, battled with limited support yesterday to try to turn England's long-awaited series victory against the West Indies into a reality, it was not the happiest time to imagine how life might be without him.

Fretful, on this evidence. Brace yourself for the unpalatable fact that this time next year Atherton is like to end an Ashes series on this very ground by announcing his retirement.

Atherton does not believe in excess. His judgments are as sparing and discerning as the 83, fashioned in more than four-and-a-half hours, which proved invaluable to England's cause. To close at 221 for five, after Atherton and Marcus Trescothick had blissfully assembled 159 for the first wicket, was to fear that an impressive summer's work was unravelling at the last.

When England talk of winning a Test series, such has been their inconsistency that it is best to take nothing for granted. When Atherton talks in the New Statesman of one more year before his retirement, it is advisable to take it at face value.

"I can't really envisage going beyond next year," he said. "Not much longer than a year, that's for sure. Whether it would be for Lancashire or England, the next year would be the maximum period." And then he remarked that he had been surprised by his own certainty.

Buoyed by his success yesterday he withdrew again into vagueness. "With my history of back trouble, I don't look beyond the next year," he admitted, but made it sound like a batsman routinely refusing to look beyond the next ball. As long as that is safely negotiated, there is always another one to come along.

At 32, talk of retirement might be considered premature, a temporary consequence perhaps of reaching 100 Tests and seeing no immediate challenge. Alec Stewart is five years his senior, and still retains the air of someone programmed for non-stop sit-ups. But Stewart, spared serious injury, is a young 37; for all Atherton's schoolboyish countenance, his genetic back condition ages him. It has troubled him for the best part of 10 years and, when it does not, he is troubled by people asking about it.

His regime is a demanding one: Pilates, the exacting stomach-exercising regime carried out by ballet dancers; pain killers; a steriod injection twice a year. And, before yesterday, there had been suggestions of creeping vulnerability, with only 120 runs this summer in seven innings. He has been such a quality performer that his Test average should remain at 40 as if by rights. No one wants to see it dipping towards the mid-30s.

He makes light of any self-doubt. "I don't believe there's anybody who doesn't have a period of self-doubt," he said. "Professional sport doesn't work like that because confidence is so fragile." But he is adamant that, in establishing a record 52 Tests as England captain, he did one tour too many. He will not make the same mistake again.

"There was something in the pitch all day. It was the type of pitch where a cluster of wickets could easily come. Clearly the first hour will be a critical period in the match.

"Oval pitches used to be quick and bouncy. You knew you could be hit on the head, but you could also hit through the line of the ball. Now its character has changed and it grips a bit for the spinners, but it's still a decent surface for everybody."

webTitle: Vialli ups the stakes with Bogarde

fields.headline: Vialli ups the stakes with Bogarde
fields.trailText: Gianluca Vialli increased the pressure on places in his multinational defence when Chelsea moved quickly back into the market yesterday to take the Dutch international Winston Bogarde from Barcelona on a free transfer.
fields.body:
Gianluca Vialli increased the pressure on places in his multinational defence when Chelsea moved quickly back into the market yesterday to take the Dutch international Winston Bogarde from Barcelona on a free transfer.

Although the Bogarde deal was preceded by the £4.5m sale of Emerson Thome to Sunderland - business worth a quick £2m profit for Chelsea - the versatile incoming Dutch international is expected to play a larger role in Vialli's plans than the outgoing Brazilian defender.

After agreeing the move for Thome, who arrived at Stamford Bridge for £2.5m only eight months ago, Vialli swiftly added a fourth Dutchman to his squad once he confirmed that Bogarde, 30 next month, was available for nothing with Barcelona waiving the remaining year of his contract.

The arrival of the 6ft 2in Bogarde may be seen as a further threat to Frank Leboeuf, despite the Frenchman's recent return to Chelsea's central defence, but the Dutchman will also give Vialli greater options at left-back.

English confidence in Chelsea's title credentials may have dipped already but Bogarde, winner of domestic titles and cups in both Holland and Spain, believes Vialli and his squad have got what it takes to win the championship.

"A move to England with Chelsea," said Bogarde, "was my ultimate dream. There were a number of other clubs interested in me but I believe Chelsea have got a team that can win the Premiership - and that made them the most attractive option. They have enormous quality throughout their team and hopefully I can become a valuable part of that." He has signed a four-year contract at Stamford Bridge.

Bogarde, who also interested Newcastle, has won 19 caps for Holland was in the Ajax squad that won the Champions Leauge in 1995 and linked up again with Louis van Gaal at Barcelona after an unsuccessful spell with Milan.

Meanwhile Thome, upset at quickly losing his place to Leboeuf after just one game this season - in the dismal defeat at Bradford City last week - jumped at the chance to become Sunderland's record purchase.

The 28-year-old centre-back took only two hours to sign a £1 million-a-year contract which will keep him at the Stadium of Light until 2004.

Peter Reid moved for Thome after finally abandoning hope of securing Ugo Ehiogu from Aston Villa and will give the Brazilian his debut at home against West Ham on Wednesday.

Thome, signed by Vialli had Sheffield Wednesday, made 20 league appearances for Chelsea.

fields.headline: Big Brother: a chronology
fields.standfirst: The 10 Big Brother contestants entered the house on Friday July 14. Here's what happened - at a glance.
fields.trailText: The 10 Big Brother contestants entered the house on Friday July 14. Here's what happened - at a glance.
fields.body:
Friday July 14: The 10 contestants enter the Big Brother house.

Tuesday July 18: The first programme is broadcast on Channel 4.

Tuesday July 25: Sada and Caroline become the first nominees for the Friday night eviction vote.

Friday July 28: The public votes out Sada.

Tuesday August 1: Andy and Caroline are nominated for eviction.

Friday August 4: Andy is evicted.

Sunday August 6: The Sun sends a remote-controlled helicopter over the Big Brother house to drop leaflets urging the housemates to vote out "Nasty" Nick, as part of the newspaper's "Kick out Nick" campaign (Nick Bateman support register: www.mercury.beseen.com/guestbook/c/185266/guestbook.html). But the contestants are ordered into the girls' bedroom for the duration of the air raid and are none the wiser.

Tuesday August 8: Tom and Caroline are nominated.

Friday August 11: Caroline is voted out.

Tuesday August 15: Craig and Nichola are nominated.

Thursday August 17: Following discussions in the early hours of the morning, the housemates figure out that Nick has been trying to influence the weekly eviction nominations. They confront him at lunchtime during the weekly house meeting and after a tense afternoon Channel 4 and Big Brother producer Endemol announce at 5pm that Nick has been thrown off the show for "persistent infringement of the Big Brother rules".

Friday August 18: Nick faces the media at an afternoon press conference and says he is "just an ordinary guy who took part in a very unusual experiment". That evening, Nichola is chosen for eviction in the weekly phone poll.

Saturday August 19: Nick's replacement, Claire, arrives in the evening. She cannot nominate people for eviction, or be nominated herself, for a week.

Tuesday August 22: Tom, Craig, Darren and Anna are all nominated - the first time more than two housemates have been up for eviction. Darren got three votes, while the others all had two.

Friday August 25: Tom is voted out of Big Brother, by the narrowest of margins. He gets 30% of the phone votes, while Darren gets 29%.

Monday August 28: When Darren goes to the diary room to tell Big Brother his nominations - Mel and Craig - due to a technical error the other contestants hear what he says. The producers decide to let the housemates make their nominations again.

Friday September 1: Claire voted out of Big Brother house.

Sunday August 6: The Sun sends a remote-controlled helicopter over the Big Brother house to drop leaflets urging the housemates to vote out "Nasty" Nick, as part of the newspaper's "Kick out Nick" campaign (Nick Bateman support register: www.mercury.beseen.com/guestbook/c/185266/guestbook.html). But the contestants are ordered into the girls' bedroom for the duration of the air raid and are none the wiser. Tuesday August 8: Tom and Caroline are nominated. Friday August 11: Caroline is voted out. Tuesday August 15: Craig and Nichola are nominated. Thursday August 17: Following discussions in the early hours of the morning, the housemates figure out that Nick has been trying to influence the weekly eviction nominations. They confront him at lunchtime during the weekly house meeting and after a tense afternoon Channel 4 and Big Brother producer Endemol announce at 5pm that Nick has been thrown off the show for "persistent infringement of the Big Brother rules". Friday August 18: Nick faces the media at an afternoon press conference and says he is "just an ordinary guy who took part in a very unusual experiment". That evening, Nichola is chosen for eviction in the weekly phone poll. Saturday August 19: Nick's replacement, Claire, arrives in the evening. She cannot nominate people for eviction, or be nominated herself, for a week. Tuesday August 22: Tom, Craig, Darren and Anna are all nominated - the first time more than two housemates have been up for eviction. Darren got three votes, while the others all had two. Friday August 25: Tom is voted out of Big Brother, by the narrowest of margins. He gets 30% of the phone votes, while Darren gets 29%. Monday August 28: When Darren goes to the diary room to tell Big Brother his nominations - Mel and Craig - due to a technical error the other contestants hear what he says. The producers decide to let the housemates make their nominations again. Friday September 1: Claire voted out of Big Brother house.

fields.headline: England slip in the showers
fields.trailText: Only 38 overs were possible today amid the Oval showers, but England still got themselves into a real tangle, losing their last five wickets for 60 to complete a collapse of ten for 122 on the truest strip of the summer.
fields.body:
Only 38 overs were possible today amid the Oval showers, but England still got themselves into a real tangle, losing their last five wickets for 60 to complete a collapse of ten for 122 on the truest strip of the summer.

This represented one step back after the two they had taken forward at Headingley, where England also began the second day five down. On that occasion they took control with some of the most positive batting of the series, turning ones into twos, twos into threes and the West Indian fielders into schoolboys. Here they seemed burdened by the weight of history ("31 years of hurt" has become a cliche almost overnight) and Graeme Hick and Graham Thorpe were as strokeless as they can ever have been.

Everyone agreed that England had to get through the first hour against the second new ball unscathed. It's just that they forgot how to score runs in the process - so much so that by the time Hick was trapped in front by Ambrose, just 33 runs had come in 20 boundaryless overs. In fact, it took until 3.40pm - when Andy Caddick square-cut Courtney Walsh - for anyone to reach the boundary at all. England weren't just letting the Windies bowl at them; they were letting them back in the series.

If Hick was brilliantly worked over by Ambrose, who still loves bowling to him as much as he did in Hick's disastrous debut series nine years ago, then Thorpe was brilliantly thought out by Walsh - again (expect several Oscar Wilde allusions in the press tomorrow). He was so embarrassed by his second failure to deal with the slower ball that he was on his way to the pavilion before Aussie umpire Daryl Harper had raised his finger ("Strewth, mate! Walking for an lbw?"). Meanwhile Wasim and Waqar will surely be honing their slower one before England arrive in Pakistan in October.

The rest of the batting was a throwback to the days - admittedly not all that long ago - when the tail folded almost as easily as a 50-rand note in Hansie Cronje's back pocket. Dominic Cork, a double-centurion last week, was frenetic even when making 0, Caddick tried to pull Walsh, and it took a chirpy 17-run last-wicket stand between Darren Gough and Craig White to lift England to 281.

West Indies bowled well. Nixon McLean, with a mixture of accuracy and hostility that has proved beyond Franklyn Rose and Reon King, confirmed that he may be the best-placed of the second-string seamers to assume the mantle of Curtly and Courtney. Curtly and Courtney again confirmed that, if and when they retire, they'll go out at the top.

But with rain forecast for tomorrow, 281 could yet prove a useful total on a wicket that has enough in it to keep the seamers happy. And there was some help for Caddick and Gough when they ran in this evening. They will have to bowl well to keep Brian Lara quiet, though. A quick hundred from him and there could be some nerve-wracking sessions ahead.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

fields.headline: Wap - a glossary
fields.standfirst: Learn how to talk the talk. If you don't know your HDML from your HTML, read on...
fields.trailText: Learn how to talk the talk. If you can't tell your URL from your elbow, read on...
fields.body:
3G (3rd Generation) - the overall term used for the next generation of mobile communications. 3G networks will offer higher capacity, quality and data rates than available today, and allow us to move towards mobile video on demand, streaming audio, high-speed multimedia, and mobile web access.

Bluetooth - Bluetooth is a wireless technology specifically designed to enable infrared communication between small, mobile devices. The inspiration behind this technology was the elimination of when files, data and information is transferred between devices. Devices, such as laptops, phones, digital cameras, PDAs, even fridges, have to use Bluetooth technology in order to 'talk' to each other, but most manufacturers are currently working on installing Bluetooth so the concept of devices talking to themselves is not just an abstract vision of the future.

GSM - Global System for Mobile Communications -the existing international digital cellular standard and the current phone standard used by all phones. GSM was designed for voice calls rather than internet calls, which is why WAP doesn't work at all well on them and connection speeds never surpass 38.4 kbps.

GPRS - General Packet Radio System. Essentially the stepping stone between GSM and UMTS, and the upgrade of GSM, designed especially for internet usage. Is available now to corporate users, although consumers have to wait until next year. GPRS means that users are always connected, and instead of being charged per call, are charged for the amount of data that is transferred. The benefit over GSM/WAP is that voice calls can be made at the same time as internet browsing.

HDML - Handheld Device Markup Language

HTML - Hypertext Markup Language

LCD - liquid crystal display, such as the screen found on an i-Mode cellular phone used for reading emails and accessing the Internet

Navi-roller - the name given to the scrolling (ie navigating) device on mobile phones.

PDA - personal digital assistant. Usually a hand-held device, such as the Palm Pilot. WAP isn't just for cellular phones.

URL - Uniform Resource Locator

Walled garden - the strategy adopted by many of the mobile operators. The term refers to the practice of operating closed networks, meaning that only sites which have a deal with the telephone company can be displayed on the device.

WAP - Wireless Application Protocol. The browser standard developed by Phone.com and supported by the majority of the mobile industry.

WML - Wireless Markup Language (the format HTML pages have to be converted to in order for WAP phones to access them)

UMTS - Universal Mobile Telecommunications System. Expected to be launched commercially in 2002, although pundits believe it will be plagued by problems and not get off the ground properly until 2004. UMTS is the third generation of mobile network, following analogue and digital (GSM/GPRS), and is expected to allow connection speeds of up to 2mbs (that's two million bits of information per second, compared with the fastest normal phone-line internet connection today of 56kbs).

fields.headline: West Indies survive shortened session
fields.standfirst: England were bowled out for 281; West Indies were 13-0 when bad light stopped play
fields.trailText: England's bowlers were unable to force a breakthrough in a 14-over spell at the end of the second day as Adrian Griffith (4*) and Sherwin Campbell (6*) held firm at the Oval. With survival on their minds, the West Indies openers scored at less than one run per over.
fields.body:
England's bowlers were unable to force a breakthrough in a 14-over spell at the end of the second day as Adrian Griffith (4*) and Sherwin Campbell (6*) held firm at the Oval. With survival on their minds, the West Indies openers scored at less than one run per over.

After a lengthy afternoon stoppage for rain, a diminished crowd roared Darren Gough and Andy Caddick in at the start of the mini-session, though they made little headway as they bowled unchanged until bad light ended the day's play prematurely. Adrian Griffith can count himself lucky to have survived a good lbw shout to Caddick after the ball looked to have pitched on the stumps and stayed straight.

West Indies' bowlers had earlier taken England's remaining five wickets for the addition of 60 more runs as England were all out for 281. England's last two wickets fell in a rain-shortened afternoon session to add to the three England lost in a crazy half-hour before lunch.

In truth, batting looked a different prospect on this pitch in the morning session - no one could manage a boundary until Caddick cut Walsh for four at 3.40pm - and yesterday's opening stand of 159 from Michael Atherton and Marcus Trescothick could yet prove vital in the context of this Test match: England's remaining nine wickets put on a combined total of 122.

Walsh huffed and puffed at the tail after the rain break: he gave Caddick a withering glare as he departed after mishooking to Hinds at leg gully for just that one scoring shot and Gough, who earlier pulled MacLean for four, received a nasty short ball from Courtney which he just managed to duck under.

When White cut the last ball of a Walsh over for four, run-gathering looked a touch easier. The last pair added 17 before Walsh bowled Gough with an offcutter and England were 281 all out.

Earlier, Thorpe and Hick had been the model of studiousness while they were denying West Indies for 90 minutes, after the visitors took the new ball at the start of the first full over of the day. Curbing their naturally attacking instincts, they held firm as the ball swished past edges, gloves and stumps and rapped dangerously onto pads. But with the last ball of a maiden, Ambrose found Hick's pads with a thud; rarely can he have spent 73 balls garnering just 17 runs.

Next over, Walsh sent Thorpe back with another super slower ball in a manner similar to that which ended Thorpe's return to the Test side at Old Trafford. This time the ball struck low on the pads, rather than Thorpe's foot, and with their last batsman gone for 40, England were under the kosh again at 254-7. Then Ambrose, pitched up a straight ball, it hit Cork's pads and umpire David Shepherd duly confirmed the fifth lbw of the innings.

fields.headline: The future for Wap
fields.standfirst: Wap is only the beginning. And with GPRS and UMTS just around the corner, the pressure is on to meet users' high expectations
fields.trailText: Wap is only the beginning. With GPRS and UMTS just around the corner, the pressure is on to meet users' high expectations, writes Amy Vickers
fields.body:
Wap is just phase one in the development of mobile internet access. In less than a year, GPRS (a broadband network) will have replaced GSM (a voice network that only allows for connection speeds of up to 9.6kbs per second), and Wap technology will have evolved to cater for this type of connection. The "always on" nature of GPRS means that "push" services (when information and services are sent rather than being pulled from Wapsites) will become much more common.

By 2003, the third generation (3G) mobile communication standard (UMTS) should be in force (give or take development problems), boosting bandwidth to 128kbs per second and allowing for a more visual browsing experience with full motion video capabilities.

Winners of the UMTS licences are expected to start rolling out their new networks in 2002. However, it is widely expected that a number of giant-sized obstacles will plague the smooth introduction of the new networks. After the frantic bidding process that poured a staggering £22bn into government coffers, licence winners (Vodafone, BT Cellnet, Orange, One2One and Canadian operator TIW) are now having to spend billions more on compressing technology to fit in a mobile handset and putting the building blocks in place to support the network.

Current UMTS prototypes leave a lot to be desired. When Ericsson showed off one of the world's few working phones compatible with UMTS a few months back, it's safe to say that everyone was astounded to see that the only way of getting the phone mobile was by packing all the hardware and software into a van. Additionally, battery technology is something the operators are going to have to work on, given that a UMTS phone will only be able to run for a few seconds before burning out on current battery technology.

GPRS and UMTS (if the boffins get their heads together) will pave the way for location relevant services that can track where a user is, and dependent on the services signed up for, can target them with information, directions and news about the local area. These type of services are ripe with potential, and may just provide the killer apps that can repair Wap's bad reputation. They could also create a public outcry about privacy unless the companies developing these types of services tread carefully.

With recent surveys showing that around half of the most popular European websites already have a Wapsite, perhaps the biggest challenge now is to ensure the gap is bridged between the reality and the rhetoric surrounding Wap, and that meeting user expectations are seen as top priorities. In the meantime, learning to live with slow connection times and frequent drops in service is part and parcel of the evolution of mobile technology.

fields.headline: What works with Wap
fields.trailText: At present, Wap is like a step back in time - to the early days of the web when there were only a handful of sites to choose from. While Wap can deliver basic graphics, these are somewhat limited by exactly what the phone's screen can display and the slow connection speed. Most Wapsites, therefore, comprise just simple text with basic links to other pages.
fields.body:
At present, Wap is like a step back in time - to the early days of the web when there were only a handful of sites to choose from. While Wap can deliver basic graphics, these are somewhat limited by exactly what the phone's screen can display and the slow connection speed. Most Wapsites, therefore, comprise just simple text with basic links to other pages.

At this juncture, the biggest market opportunity for Wap services is heralded as being location-based services such as local restaurant booking, finding locations and travelling from A to B. While companies struggle to develop services of this type for GSM Wap services, other information-based services such as news, sport, and financial and weather reports, are making inroads into the Wap market.

Entertainment is another area perfect for Wap mobile usage, with many companies working on infrared online games in anticipation of GPRS.

Other types of content such as e-commerce and banking haven't really got off the ground, mainly because of the security issues associated with mobile phones. Currently security is dealt with using wireless transport layer security (WTLS) which is reasonably secure but needs to incorporate mechanisms for digital signatures.

fields.headline: Wapulising content
fields.standfirst: The problem with Wap...
fields.trailText: The problem with Wap... by Amy Vickers
fields.body:
Part of the problem with Wap at the moment is that many of the people repurposing content for Wapsites often fail to take into account current limitations of the devices. Most are uploaded straight from websites and therefore text is sometimes too long, or links are broken or un-navigable on a Wap browser.

Given that many designers of Wap services have to design for multiple devices, each requiring different coding, Wap development is often far more expensive than simply designing for conventional web browsers.

Wap may be big on hype, but a quarter of websites that have been repurposed for Wap don't work. This was the key finding of a new report from Wap development portal AnyWhereYouGo.com.

One in four Wapsites are riddled with faults making them inaccessible to users, says the report, and it's all because of a few simple errors in the coding of WML (wireless mark-up language) pages that are causing the problem. Around 28% of the 50 sites tested by AnyWhereYouGo.com are said to have contained damaging errors.

webTitle: Runway was not checked for doomed Concorde

fields.headline: Runway was not checked for doomed Concorde
fields.standfirst: The preliminary report on the Concorde crash (in French)
fields.trailText: A runway inspection delay at the Charles de Gaulle airport used by the doomed Air France  Concorde meant it had not been checked for more than 12 hours, it emerged today.
fields.body:
A runway inspection delay at the Charles de Gaulle airport used by the doomed Air France Concorde meant it had not been checked for more than 12 hours, it emerged today.

The preliminary report into the crash on July 25 that killed all 109 on board the supersonic plane and four on the ground, showed that the inspection had been delayed for a fire practice.

Three inspections are usually carried out at the Paris airport at flexible times, compared to at least five a day at London's Heathrow, it emerged.

On the fatal day, the first inspection was carried out at 4:30am (3.30am BST), according to the report. A partial inspection was made at 2:30pm because a plane was believed to have collided with a bird.

But a second full inspection at 3pm was postponed because of the fire practice between 2:35 and 3:10pm).

This showed the runway was not fully inspected for more than 12 hours before the Concorde took off, at 4:42pm.

A British Airports Authority (BAA) spokeswoman said: "We carry out about five inspections under normal circumstances, but if there are adverse weather conditions we would do more. "All the inspections are the same and take around 45 minutes to complete and are done throughout the day, but not at any set time.

"A 12-hour delay between inspections would not happen at Heathrow."

No conclusions were drawn from the preliminary crash report, published on the internet, but the inspection delay did not necessarily have a bearing on the presence of a metal strip that gashed the plane's tyres.

An airport official said nothing untoward had been reported on the runway, either by pilots using it or by cleaners and the firemen in the hours leading up to the crash.

"If anything wrong would have existed, it would have been noticed immediately," airport authority spokesman Didier Hamon said at a Paris news conference.

"We do believe that everything was done that day as it is normal to do," he added. "On that day, nothing abnormal, nothing exceptional was reported to the airport authority."

It could be at least a year before the final report is published by the BEA - France's Accident and Inquiry Office.

A judicial investigation is also in progres. This comes a day after the BEA released its preliminary report on the accident which gave a blow-by-blow account of the final moments of Air France Flight 4590 that, in less than two minutes, took off then plunged in flames into a small hotel north of Paris.

The highly technical 75 page report detailed debris including a more than 8.8 lb tyre part with a near 13 inch gash, the bent metal strip that destroyed the tyre and the crash site.

The report stresses that it was the destruction of a forward tyre on the left landing gear - gashed by the stray piece of metal - that likely triggered a chain of events dooming the flight. Investigators have said the part did not appear to belong to the doomed plane but no airline whose planes used Charles de Gaulle airport's runway 26 that day has reported any missing parts on its aircraft, it was announced.

There was no hint in the report or by officials that the part might have come from something other than an aircraft.

A transcript of the crew's gallant attempts to save the burning Air France Concorde was also published in the report.

Less than two minutes elapsed from the control tower warning the crew that flames were showing and the last words from the plane. webTitle: Reiziger urges team-mates to get Keane sent off

fields.headline: Reiziger urges team-mates to get Keane sent off
fields.trailText: Barcelona defender Michael Reiziger has urged his team-mates to try and get Roy Keane sent-off during Holland's World Cup qualifier against the Republic of Ireland tomorrow.
fields.body:
Barcelona defender Michael Reiziger has urged his team-mates to try and get Roy Keane sent-off during Holland's World Cup qualifier against the Republic of Ireland tomorrow.

Reiziger's astonishing outburst was relayed on his own website. However he was later forced into a U-turn, presumably under pressure from Dutch authorities.

Reiziger said: "Ireland has a couple of quality players including Manchester United's Roy Keane, although I hear he has an injury problem and may not play.

"Assuming he does, if we're smart we could get him a red card because he has a dodgy temperament. If referees know that about a player they are always far more likely to card them.

"We will have to provoke Keane in some way, perhaps holding his shirt or walking into him after he passes the ball. Players are also known to whisper comments about another player's mother or the size of parts of his body.

"I don't like that side of the game very much but if it helps us to win then it's worthwhile."

Reiziger, however, then said, it would be wrong to suggest that he should try and get a fellow professional sent off. "Perhaps I went over the top a bit in my last diary entry," he said. "Of course I want to win this important match against Ireland and do the best for my country. "But I was wrong to suggest that one way of doing this was by getting a fellow professional sent off. I really don't like that part of the game.

"Lots of niggling does go on during matches with name-calling and shirt-pulling quite common - it seems to be part of the game these days. Roy Keane is a fantastic player and I have nothing but absolute respect for him and everything that he has achieved with both Manchester United and Ireland."

fields.headline: A breath of fresh air
fields.standfirst: Fashion editor  Jess Cartner-Morley seeks inspiration from the 60s movie classic A Bout de Souffle
fields.trailText: Fashion editor Jess Cartner-Morley seeks inspiration from the 60s movie classic A Bout de Souffle.
fields.body:
Movies and glamour go together like tea and toast - or, rather, like champagne and canapes. Hollywood stars, from Greta Garbo to Gwyneth Paltrow, have been lauded as icons not just of beauty, but of style. But now, film as a directional influence on fashion is at a low ebb.

In the 30s, the American department store Macy's did a roaring trade in dresses that were copies of gowns worn by Joan Crawford in her films; this year, the high street cleaned up with copies of Jennifer Lopez's Versace dress, worn not on screen, but to the Golden Globes. Think of Audrey Hepburn - the image that most likely comes to mind has her with piled-up hair, sunglasses and pearls in Breakfast at Tiffany's; now, it is the real-life Lopez and Paltrow that girls emulate, not their fictional characters.

Most mainstream Hollywood films are styled in such an impeccably slick, unarguably up-to-date way that they end up directly mirroring designer fashion, rather than operating at a tangent to it.

It was not always so. The films that have made most impact on our style sensibili ties feature clothes which are an extension of the characters, rather than a catwalk rerun. Think of Diane Keaton in mannish shirt, tie and trousers in Annie Hall; Madonna loaded with eyeliner and trashy black lace in Desperately Seeking Susan.

The recently re-released A Bout de Souffle (Breathless) is still remembered not just as the film that launched the career of Jean-Luc Godard, but as the film that launched the gamine crop and simple chic aesthetic of Jean Seberg's character, Patricia. The film may be 40 years old, but it has more to offer those in search of wardrobe inspiration than the rest of the summer's releases put together.

No one has ever looked as classy in what is essentially a promotional T-shirt as Patricia does sauntering along the Champs-Elysées in Herald Tribune cap-sleeved top, capri pants and ballet flats. There is a quirkiness to Patricia's wardrobe that perfectly echoes the mercurial nature of her character: one minute she is boyish in a man's shirt, the next the essence of understated European chic in a simple sweater, later as coquettish as a pre-teen birthday girl in a full-skirted, black-and-white striped dress.

Seberg's daisy-fresh, innocent-abroad looks are perfectly offset by Jean-Paul Belmondo, who, as Michel, a thief on the run, oozes the laconic sex appeal of a young Humphrey Bogart (on whom Michel models himself). Hounded by the police and the media, Michel is, quite literally, the poster-boy of the romantic criminal: rumpled and dark-shadowed but still well-turned-out, sporting a dapper houndstooth check tie, a rakish fedora hat. This is a film where image matters. Michel's final, desperate attempt to flee the law is interrupted when a fellow criminal stops him to say that his choice of silk socks with woollen trousers is an absolute no-no. And that's the moment when we know it's all over.

webTitle: Botched exam results not given computer check

fields.headline: Botched results not given computer check
fields.standfirst:
Scots authority failed to gather schools' exam predictions

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The saga of Scotland's discredited examination authority descended into farce yesterday when it emerged that customary computer checks on exam results had not been carried out.
fields.body:
The saga of Scotland's discredited examination authority descended into farce yesterday when it emerged that customary computer checks on exam results had not been carried out.

An undisclosed number of pupils have been told they have failed new-style higher grade exams when they should have passed, while others have received lower grades than they should have.

Although the Scottish Qualifications Authority has consistently claimed there was no lowering of quality control in this year's procedures, it yesterday belatedly conceded that computer checks had not been done on the results in the new highers, as they would have been done in past years.

The Headteachers' Association Scotland has said that the discrepancies in grades predicted by schools and what pupils obtained was two to three times what would otherwise be expected. In some schools it was up to 10 times greater.

The Scottish executive said yesterday that a lack of computer checks might account for some of these anomalies.

Nicola Sturgeon, education spokeswoman for the Scottish National party, commented that the authority had now lost all credibility.

"We are not talking about a few thousand results being wrong. We are now talking about potentially every new higher result having doubt cast upon it," she said.

In past years, the authority used a computer programme to check quality control - the "derived grades procedure", which took into account a school's prediction as to its student's exam grade to raise a mark if he or she came close to a cut-off point between grades; it could therefore result in a pupil jumping up a grade, and sometimes applying the procedure could mean the difference between someone having a pass or a fail.

The authority yesterday admitted that the programme had not been used this year because school predictions were not available.

It promised, however, that any anomalies would be sorted out by its appeals procedure, and said that the programme would be reinstated for next year's exams.

A deadline for submitting appeals has been set for this weekend.

However, the corrected results following an appeal are not expected to be announced for a number of weeks - thus leaving students who have been mistakenly told they have failed to meet the standard required for their chosen university to possibly find out that they have in fact done sufficiently well to merit entry, just as they are about to start an alternative, fall-back course.

David Caldwell, director of Coshep, the Scottish university principals' organisation, said yesterday that the universities would endeavour to make sure that all students whose successful appeals meant that their results met the requirements of their offer through Ucas, the universities' clearing house, would get on to their chosen university course.

"The timing is awkward, as the results of the appeals will be coming through at the same time as the academic year begins, but we will do our best to make sure no one is disadvantaged."

Brian Monteith, the Conservative education spokesman, said that the authority could no longer be taken at its word, as it had previously repeatedly asserted that its quality control was the same as in previous years.

The continuing crisis is putting increasing pressure on the Scottish education minister, Sam Galbraith, for him to resign. He does not accept he has the ultimate responsibility for the authority's failings, but he may not be able to ride out the storm much longer.

When the Scottish parliament reconvenes next week, he will be called before its education committee, where he will face fierce questioning as both the Conservatives and the SNP attempt to secure his ministerial scalp.

If Mr Galbraith does not perform sufficiently well in front of the committee, he may be forced to go then.

From bad to worse

March Ministers learn there are problems, but are assured they will be sorted out by the qualifications authority.

August 10 Results sent out. Thousands of pupils receive incomplete or inaccurate certificates; thousands more receive none at all; and many certificates make no sense.

August 11 Principals of Scottish universities say they have no confidence in the authority.

August 12 Authority chief executive Ron Tuck resigns.

August 17 A level results published outside Scotland, while 5,000 Scottish students continue to await accurate results.

August 21 Scottish executive confirms 700 students will be late in entering clearing.

August 23 Ucas says number of Scottish pupils taking up university places has fallen 6.6%.

August 29 Authority admits 4,000 standard grade pupils given incorrect results.

August 30 Authority admits faxing wrong standard grade results to schools. Two senior figures resign.

August 31 Authority admits quality control measures are lower than in previous years.

webTitle: Analysis: public sector workers needed from abroad

fields.headline: Foreign legion
fields.standfirst:
Thousands of teachers, doctors, nurses and social workers must be recruited from abroad to fill shortages created by a decade of poor pay

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Thousands of teachers, doctors, nurses and social workers must be recruited from abroad to fill shortages created by a decade of poor pay
fields.body:
The demand by Tory health spokesman Liam Fox for stricter English language tests for overseas-born doctors was bound to warm the hearts of racists. But it highlighted the extent to which frontline public services have become dependent on imported labour to keep the show on the road.

Reliance on foreign professionals goes beyond doctors, more than a quarter of whom qualified overseas. Without a continuing transfusion of nurses, teachers and social workers, health, education and social services in some parts of the country would be unable to function. Five years ago, the proportion of nurses from overseas registering in Britain was 12%. By last year it had risen to 28% and the numbers have increased sharply in recent months. The number of nurses recruited from the Philippines - already one of the largest overseas groups - is estimated to have risen by 400% in the past year.

With schools this week facing an unprecedented shortage of teachers, local authorities in London are scouring such English-speaking countries as Australia and Canada to fill the vacancies. TimePlan, the biggest supply agency, has a target to hire almost 2,000 extra teachers; it estimates that at least 3,000 overseas teachers are required to staff London schools all year round. Supply teaching agencies in some parts of the capital say that up to 70% of teachers on their books are from abroad.

There is also a severe shortage of social workers and an increasing number of South Africans, Scandinavians and Belgians are being brought over to make up the numbers. A confidential survey for the Association of London Government earlier this year found staff vacancies have reached 50% in some London social services departments. And with police numbers down almost 3,000 since Labour was returned to office, Home Office officials are considering changing the rules to allow the police to recruit from abroad.

A crisis in public sector recruitment has been building for almost 20 years and pay is at the heart of it. After an initial partial catch-up at the start of Margaret Thatcher's first term in office, public service workers have seen their pay fall relentlessly behind ever since. Between 1982 and 1997, the gap between the average earnings of public employees and those of the private sector grew by 16%. After 1993, when the government froze the public sector pay bill, increases were achieved only by shedding hundreds of thousands of jobs. With Gordon Brown committed to maintaining Tory spending plans during Labour's first two years in office, the squeeze continued, while seven years of growth continued to drive private sector earnings ahead.

Between 1992 and 1999, official figures show that the hourly real-terms pay of private sector employees increased by 4.2% more than that of their public sector counterparts. While private sector employees' pay increased as the chart shows, the real hourly rate for teachers actually fell - partly because older teachers were leaving the profession and being replaced by less-experienced and lower-paid staff.

Meanwhile, as the labour market has tightened in the wider economy, particularly in the south-east, and skill shortages have started to force up pay, private sector employers have also been looking abroad to offset the lack of trained staff in Britain and take the pressure off their payrolls.

The CBI describes skills shortages as serious and growing - though less pronounced than in previous periods of sustained growth - and highlights the short supply of IT and computer professionals in particular. Others point to pressure in sales, customer and financial services and construction.

A survey by the Cranfield School of Management cited the recruitment of overseas staff - from South Africa, Australia and the EU in particular - as a significant factor in offsetting upward pressure on pay.

If better paid jobs in the private sector and lack of affordable housing in London are aspects of the public sector crisis they are not the only factors. Unison, the public services union, points to the the treatment of employees in the public sector and the way their jobs have been undervalued over the past two decades. "The culture of private good, public bad and the way some people have come to sneer at the public ethos inevitably leads to demoralisation". Teachers' leaders make similar complaints. They do not expect that new incentive packages or overall government spending increases will close the public-private pay gap in the foreseeable future so dependence on foreign workers is bound to continue.

In fact, numbers will have to increase - particularly in health - to meet the government's targets. The NHS is already short of about 17,000 nurses and needs several thousand extra doctors, dentists and consultants - while moves to boost training numbers will take years to feed through. The government is relying on surpluses of doctors in countries such as Spain and an "over-supply" of nurses in some parts of Scandinavia to meet their targets. It has also sanctioned an NHS agreement with the Chinese government to use Chinese nurses on short-term contracts.

Since the end of last year, recruitment of health professionals from developing countries has been officially discouraged, unless home governments give consent. NHS recruitment of South African nurses has been cut back since Nelson Mandela appealed to Tony Blair to stop leeching his country's desperately-needed health workers. But the Philippines is considered an exception because it trains more nurses than it employs and depends on their foreign currency remittances.

But these are short-term stopgap measures. "People from overseas have made an outstanding contribution to our public services and we're glad they came here," says Unison. "But we shouldn't be poaching from countries that need them - we should be making these jobs attractive enough for people here."

Seumas Milne is our labour editor
