webTitle: What the Marjorie Evans ruling means

fields.headline: What the Marjorie Evans ruling means
fields.standfirst: Headteacher 's conviction overturned
fields.trailText: The days when teachers were able to 'administer discipline' with the aid of a cane or blackboard duster are long gone. Anyone working with children today has to take great care before they come into physical contact with their charges.
fields.body:
The days when teachers were able to 'administer discipline' with the aid of a cane or blackboard duster are long gone. Anyone working with children today has to take great care before they come into physical contact with their charges.

The abolition of corporal punishment, a greater willingness on the part of parents to take (or threaten) legal action and a number of high-profile cases of paedophilia have all played a part. The case of Marjorie Evans, who has just been cleared of the charge of slapping a pupil, has brought the difficulty of dealing with violent pupils into sharp focus.

"The teacher is in a no-win situation," Doug McAvoy, the general secretary of Mrs Evans' union, the NUT, told Guardian Unlimited this afternoon. "If they have to deal with pupils who are misbehaving to the extent of having to restrain them, they are vulnerable to these kinds of malicious allegations. Youngsters do, from time to time, try to get a teacher sacked viciously and malevolently.

"But if a teacher does nothing, they could be sued for negligence if they failed to restrain a pupil." The NUT will be producing new guidelines for teachers who find themselves in a similar situation to that of Mrs Evans. It will advise them to refuse to teach pupils who have a history of violence.

Furthermore, unless the government makes it easier for schools to exclude such pupils, says Mr McAvoy, the NUT will advise members to follow their own guidelines rather than the official rulings.

Last July the rules concerning exclusions were tightened - chiefly because parents so often appealed their child's exclusion, and frequently managed to overrule the head's decision. But for Mr McAvoy, these concessions did not go far enough. They still force teachers into situations which put them at risk of prosecution.

Teachers are entitled to use 'reasonable force' to restrain a violent pupil. Mrs Evans used a 'restraint hold' because the pupil involved was punching, pushing and head-butting her as they walked between classrooms.

But no legal definition exists of 'reasonable force'. The department of education says that force "must be in proportion to the circumstances of the incident and the seriousness of the behaviour or the consequences it is intended to prevent". In other words, every case must be judged individually. If the department of education went further and defined what constituted 'unacceptable' physical contact, it would be even easier for pupils to make the kind of malicious allegations that almost ended Mrs Evans' career.

fields.headline: Adland's creative young guns
fields.standfirst: Talented creative duos are the life-blood of the advertising industry. Emma Hall casts an eye over some of the most vibrant, young pairings to have recently taken adland by storm.
fields.trailText: Talented creative duos are the life-blood of the advertising industry. Emma Hall casts an eye over some of the most vibrant, young pairings to have recently taken adland by storm.
fields.body:
Creative directors are always looking for something they have not got. And that usually means youth, freshness and an original approach.

Advertising agencies need constant injections of energy from young creatives who are still excited by the possibilities the profession offers. They need people who are in touch with life outside the confines of the client/agency relationship.

"I'd rather have to reign them in than kick them into action," says Soul creative director Bruce Crouch. Crouch, who was Bartle Bogle Hegarty's creative director for three years, wants raw thinking from his young teams, even if their ideas are too edgy to be translated directly into commercials.

"Be rebellious, challenge me," Crouch demands. "We'll mould you."

Tim Hearn, the creative director of St Luke's, agrees: "Why should I hire someone if I already have a whole department full of people who can do the same thing? I want people with ideas so odd that no one here would have thought of them. And we have some pretty odd people here."

Ironically, one enemy of raw creative talent is the advertising colleges. Many creative directors criticise them for churning out teams that have been taught to think only in formulaic terms. "I don't believe in studying old ads. It's creative BSE. Where's the new air?" asks Trevor Beattie, creative director of TBWA.

"You should be studying life, relationships and television programmes," he says.

Creative types can study the past masters all they like, but the lessons they learn are limited by the fact that the advertising and marketing worlds are a lot more complex than they were just two years ago. Simple ideas are common currency and new media requires new thinking. This situation can make life more complicated for creative directors seeking new talent.

Robert Campbell, joint creative director of Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R, says: "As the criteria by which we judge ads broadens, it's harder to guess who's going to be good at them. You have to look for freer thinking individuals with strong ideas."

Some creative directors inevitably complain that, because of the new profusion of creative industries, the most talented youngsters are no longer seeking a career in advertising. "It is rare to see someone who is 100 per cent-committed to advertising," Hearn says. "You usually get the feeling that they'd rather be doing something else but think they can get into it through ads."

So the smart agencies put a lot of energy into finding new blood and send out scouts to snap up student talent before it is siphoned off by new media moguls.

Real talent has always been rare, but all top creative directors can come up with a select list of hot young things whose work they admire.

Beattie believes the current crop of new talent is better than it has been for many years. "There's a new energy about advertising," he insists. "The new media revolution has made everyone think more creatively."

webTitle: Real players plot dressing room revolt over Macca

fields.headline: Real players plot dressing room revolt over Macca
fields.trailText: Senior players at Real Madrid are plotting an astonishing dressing room revolt against manager Vincente Del Bosque - whom they accuse of "humiliating" Steve McManaman.
fields.body:
Senior players at Real Madrid are plotting an astonishing dressing room revolt against manager Vincente Del Bosque - whom they accuse of "humiliating" Steve McManaman.

According to a report in the Spanish newspaper Marca, a "senior player who carries a lot of weight" at the club faced up to Del Bosque and attacked him for selling Fernando Redondo four weeks ago. Since then the atmosphere at the club has been a "powder keg waiting to blow" and looks certain to explode because of the treatment dished out to McManaman.

The player (probably Fernando Hierro) told Marca: "We cannot stand by while this is happening. What happened to Redondo happened - well in the end Fernando had a good offer - but McManaman, what has Macca done to deserve the treatment he is getting from the manager?"

He then went on to claim that the dressing room agrees that McManaman has been "treated with disrespect and is being humiliated - for no reason at all."

Marca claims that the players "agreed from early on" that Real weren't being honest with McManaman, but it was only after the club's Super Cup defeat against Galatasaray last week - a game for which McManaman did not even make the squad - that they spoke about the case and decided to act. According to the senior player they are "going to write a letter, denouncing what is going on."

"May all the world know," he added.

Marca claim that Real dressing room could publicly pronounce against Del Bosque soon after squad members return from international duty early next week.

webTitle: The GPRS network, i-mode and HTML browsers

fields.headline: Internet networks, browsers and Japan's alternative to Wap
fields.standfirst: What the availability of GPRS will mean for the Wap industry; how i-mode, the Japanese equivalent of Wap, measures up against it; plus getting round the problems of HTML browsing on mobile phones
fields.trailText: What the availability of GPRS will mean for the Wap industry; how i-mode, the Japanese equivalent of Wap measures up against it, plus getting round the problems of HTML browsing on mobile phones. Amy Vickers reports
fields.body:
Why is everyone now talking about GPRS?

Current device limitations aside, the other key problem at the moment is that GSM is an unreliable internet network. With GPRS, an "always on" network designed for data (ie internet) calls, said to be just around the corner, this problem will be resolved in the next six months. Most pundits believe Wap won't really take off until GPRS becomes widely available.

BT Cellnet was the first UK network to launch GPRS services in the summer this year, although the other networks claim to be close behind. The BT Cellnet service, PocketNet Office, is only available to corporate users at present and costs £45 per month for 50mb of data traffic (different pricing plans apply with GPRS), plus around £199 for the handset (Motorola Timeport) and standard charges for voice calls. It is expected that the GPRS service and handsets will be rolled out to consumers at the beginning of 2001. Clearly, like Wap handsets, these handsets will no doubt be subsidised to drive mass market uptake.

PDA manufacturers are currently working with the mobile operators on ways in which they can develop add-ons to handheld devices that convert the PDA into a GPRS phone. The latest devices from Microsoft's PocketPC division have been developed so that GPRS attachments can easily be slotted onto the devices once they become available.

What is i-mode?

While Europe and the US is stuck with Wap, i-mode is taking Japan by storm. I-mode is the mobile internet technology developed by NTT DoCoMo and unlike Wap, is always switched on so that users are pushed internet services rather than having to pull them from (dial up to) Wapsites. DoCoMo is currently causing friction among Wap developers in Europe and the US by talking about international expansion, in particular expanding its i-mode software beyond Japan. Given the lack-lustre reaction to Wap since it launched over here and the operators crying out for more flexible technology, it is perhaps the perfect time for i-mode to make its move on Europe and the US.

It may be a few years, though, until DoCoMo is able to make its move on the UK. Its partnership with TIW, the owner of the UK's fifth UMTS third-generation mobile phone network, could lead to TIW opting for I-mode technology above Wap, but it is still early days and nothing has yet been confirmed. Whether I-mode takes off over here is yet to be determined, particularly since all European operators have now accepted Wap as a standard.

HTML browsing

While acceptance of Wap technology has been rapid among operators that now install Wap browsers on new phones as a matter of course, the fact that HTML browser software exists for mobile phones has been largely overlooked. At present, Wap is seen as something of a hassle given that Wap browsers can't read HTML pages (ie web pages), and Wapsites have to be written in wireless mark-up language (WML) and organised in decks, which are different for every device.

This could soon change, however. A growing number of mobile phone operators have already started offering Wap users the option of a second mobile internet browser. The Sony Z5 not only comes with a pre-installed Wap browser but also has Microsoft Mobile Explorer built in, which supports HTML (i.e the language in which websites are written). Mobile phone manufacturer Benefon is also about to launch a phone with MME preinstalled. Sadly, unlike PCs, users can't just download a HTML micro-browser onto their phone, or for that matter any upgrades to current applications.

MME software means that users aren't restricted to browsing the small number of Wapsites currently available, and instead, can browse websites through their phones. Generally, MME allows websites to be displayed as text, although the browser doesn't currently support graphics such as Flash or ActiveX.

fields.headline: Headteacher cleared of slapping pupil
fields.standfirst: What the ruling means
fields.trailText: Headteacher Marjorie Evans today won her appeal against her conviction for slapping an unruly pupil at Cardiff crown court.
fields.body:
Headteacher Marjorie Evans today won her appeal against her conviction for slapping an unruly pupil at Cardiff crown court.

High court judge Mr Justice McKinnon told a packed court he was allowing the challenge. He told Mrs Evans he believed her account of the incident, and that she would leave the court completely vindicated with her reputation unblemished.

There were restrained cheers from her supporters in the public gallery when the judge announced his decision this morning.

Mrs Evans, of Usk, south Wales, was given a three-month suspended sentence at Abergavenny magistrates court in south Wales in July, after stipendiary justice Vivian Manning-Davies found her guilty of common assault.

The sentence has now been quashed and Mrs Evans is no longer liable for previous court costs.

Summing up at the end of the two-day appeal hearing, defence barrister Greg Taylor said that there was "no substance" in the allegation that she had slapped a 10-year-old boy across the face after losing her temper with him.

"It doesn't make sense and the reason it does not make sense is because it is not true," Mr Taylor said.

The 56-year-old headteacher with 35 years of experience admitted at the high court hearing that she used a textbook method to restrain the boy, who is now 11, but denied slapping him.

She told the court the restraint was because he was trying to punch, push and headbutt her as they walked from the special needs unit to the main part of the south Wales junior school in September 1999.

At the appeal hearing, she said she had warned other teachers about the boy, who suffers from attention deficient hyperactive disorder, because he "had threatened to sue people".

Mrs Evans added that, after having to restrain the boy by taking his arms and folding them over his chest, he said: "I'm going to sue you. You hit me."

At the hearing yesterday, special needs teacher Sandra Cutler said she had heard Mrs Evans confess to slapping the youngster in the staff room at lunch time on the day of the incident.

Mrs Cutler told the court she heard Mrs Evans say, "Yes I hit him. And he won't be doing that again." She did not mention the incident to anyone and went to the police two days after the magistrates court hearing started on May 15 2000.

Another teacher at the school, Janet Bowen, told the court Mrs Evans had told teachers in the staff room that day that she had not hit the boy, but had had to restrain him.

On Wednesday, the first day of the trial, the boy told police in a videotaped interview that there had been a plan to get the head out of the school.

Friends, family and leading members of the National Union of Teachers have been in court throughout the two-day hearing to show their support for Evans.

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "I am very pleased to hear she has been found not guilty.

"I think this will raise public awareness of the difficulties teachers are faced with when dealing with disruptive pupils."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Union of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said: "I think it is very welcome news and I just hope that in future youngsters who assault teachers are treated with equal severity by magistrates."

fields.headline: Close encounters of the Wap kind
fields.standfirst: After the initial rush to provide access to the internet via mobile phones, Wap technology is still viewed as a work in progress, yet to realise its true potential
fields.trailText: After the initial rush to provide access to the internet via mobile phones, Wap technology is still viewed as a work in progress, yet to realise its true potential. Amy Vickers cuts through the jargon and hype to reveal the facts
fields.body:
You'd have had to have been on Tansarrey during the past nine months not to have noticed the amount of media attention given to Wap or the increasing number of people decked out in the latest Star Trek PDA gadgets that not so long ago we used to call electronic personal organisers. The market has moved on so quickly that it's sometimes difficult to remember the day when Wap was nothing more than a technology talked about by those geeky mobile phone boffins.

After the initial hype at the start of the year and the panic because no one could find a single Wap phone in the shops, the Wap craze finally settled down around April time - once people tried out the phones and realised Wap was not all what it was cracked up to be. Criticism levelled at Wap since has been a trifle strident to say the least, in particular the hackneyed old rhyme "Wap is crap" and the universal dismissing of the technology.

But whatever its current shortcomings, even the most brusque of critics accept that Wap is a technology in its very first incarnation and, as sure as evolution, that the technology will have changed beyond all recognition a year from now. Indeed, a year from now, users will no longer be able to buy normal (non Wap) phones, says a report from Forrester Research which predicts that all phones sold in 2001 will be Wap-enabled, and that the more successful Wap sites will be those that use "trigger services" (e.g. prompts via SMS) to attract Wap users to their channels. In five years' time, the report continues, more than 41m UK people in the UK will be mobile users, the bulk of which will be using a Wap-enabled phone.

Clearly, the potential for the internet on a mobile phone is gargantuan, albeit bound by the present limits of a 3 cm square screen, an LCD low-pixel display and a clumsy way of inputting text. While navi-rollers have gone some way in helping navigation around Wap services, the most popular way of inputting text into a handheld devices is by simply writing with a stylus onto a text pad. For those who can't get their heads around anything other than a qwerty keyboard, Palm also sells a fold-up keyboard which slots into the bottom of the PDA. While the jury is out on which current device - the PDA or the Wap phone - will become the preferred device (in terms of look and feel), what is certain is that the two will converge in the next few years and there will be no need to carry around two different devices. Device mystics think that perhaps the PDA which has a GPRS attachment allowing for phone calls and internet connections (such as the Compaq iPAQ Pocket PC), will be the one that wins the day - merely because of the size of the screen, the functionality and the colour display. Hybrid models, such as the Nokia Communicator 9110i, also stand a good chance of becoming widespread devices, although increased penetration is heavily dependent on the price of the devices gradually coming down.

Wap's it all about?

Wap is the current standard connecting to the internet on mobile phones, having been developed by Phone.com in 1997. It was designed for small screens, low power consumption, a wide variety of networks and user devices, one-handed operation and imperfect network coverage. While this will stay the same in the coming years, changes in bandwidth will require that Wap evolves and becomes a far more useful tool than it currently is.

The evolution of Wap gained some momentum in August this year when Nokia released its own Wap browser (version 2.0) and invited third-party firms to fine-tune it by giving out the source code. While this move notably upset the likes of Phone.com, it means that Wap will be opened up as a technology, allowing companies developing Wap content to play around with it and fine-tune it to better fit their own services.

One of the main contributors towards the pervading sense of disenchantment with Wap has been the confusion surrounding the concept of the mobile internet among consumers. BT Cellnet has been largely to blame for this, mainly by running advertising that glorifies the concept of surfing the internet on mobile phones. It comes as no surprise to hear that consumers have come to expect the same kind of browsing experience on phones as they do with computers and internet browsers. The reality, that websites don't work on mobile phones and that Wapsites are little more than just text-based services, by and large, adds to Wap disappointment.

Another drawback to Wap is the "walled garden" strategy adopted by many of the mobile operators. The concept of a walled garden - i.e fencing something in - has been one of the most criticised features of many of the mobile operators' Wap strategies, mainly because the gardens are not attention-grabbing.

Another problem has been the lack of uniformity in the URLs given to the Wapsites. For instance the now defunct BBC Wap service was located at: http://www.bbc.co.uk/mobile/mainmenu.wml - not exactly the most intuitive nor easiest to remember address, or for that matter the easiest to input via a mobile phone keypad. Other sites are just as bad, http://www.unmissabletv.com/txw/Wap.wml and http://www.ents24.com/index.wml are just two of the many sites inadvertently contributing towards the general feeling of confusion and disenchantment directed at Wap. Things need to change, and Wap need to get some good PR. fields.bodyText: You'd have had to have been on Tansarrey during the past nine months not to have noticed the amount of media attention given to Wap or the increasing number of people decked out in the latest Star Trek PDA gadgets that not so long ago we used to call electronic personal organisers. The market has moved on so quickly that it's sometimes difficult to remember the day when Wap was nothing more than a technology talked about by those geeky mobile phone boffins. After the initial hype at the start of the year and the panic because no one could find a single Wap phone in the shops, the Wap craze finally settled down around April time - once people tried out the phones and realised Wap was not all what it was cracked up to be. Criticism levelled at Wap since has been a trifle strident to say the least, in particular the hackneyed old rhyme "Wap is crap" and the universal dismissing of the technology. But whatever its current shortcomings, even the most brusque of critics accept that Wap is a technology in its very first incarnation and, as sure as evolution, that the technology will have changed beyond all recognition a year from now. Indeed, a year from now, users will no longer be able to buy normal (non Wap) phones, says a report from Forrester Research which predicts that all phones sold in 2001 will be Wap-enabled, and that the more successful Wap sites will be those that use "trigger services" (e.g. prompts via SMS) to attract Wap users to their channels. In five years' time, the report continues, more than 41m UK people in the UK will be mobile users, the bulk of which will be using a Wap-enabled phone. Clearly, the potential for the internet on a mobile phone is gargantuan, albeit bound by the present limits of a 3 cm square screen, an LCD low-pixel display and a clumsy way of inputting text. While navi-rollers have gone some way in helping navigation around Wap services, the most popular way of inputting text into a handheld devices is by simply writing with a stylus onto a text pad. For those who can't get their heads around anything other than a qwerty keyboard, Palm also sells a fold-up keyboard which slots into the bottom of the PDA. While the jury is out on which current device - the PDA or the Wap phone - will become the preferred device (in terms of look and feel), what is certain is that the two will converge in the next few years and there will be no need to carry around two different devices. Device mystics think that perhaps the PDA which has a GPRS attachment allowing for phone calls and internet connections (such as the Compaq iPAQ Pocket PC), will be the one that wins the day - merely because of the size of the screen, the functionality and the colour display. Hybrid models, such as the Nokia Communicator 9110i, also stand a good chance of becoming widespread devices, although increased penetration is heavily dependent on the price of the devices gradually coming down. Wap's it all about? Wap is the current standard connecting to the internet on mobile phones, having been developed by Phone.com in 1997. It was designed for small screens, low power consumption, a wide variety of networks and user devices, one-handed operation and imperfect network coverage. While this will stay the same in the coming years, changes in bandwidth will require that Wap evolves and becomes a far more useful tool than it currently is. The evolution of Wap gained some momentum in August this year when Nokia released its own Wap browser (version 2.0) and invited third-party firms to fine-tune it by giving out the source code. While this move notably upset the likes of Phone.com, it means that Wap will be opened up as a technology, allowing companies developing Wap content to play around with it and fine-tune it to better fit their own services. One of the main contributors towards the pervading sense of disenchantment with Wap has been the confusion surrounding the concept of the mobile internet among consumers. BT Cellnet has been largely to blame for this, mainly by running advertising that glorifies the concept of surfing the internet on mobile phones. It comes as no surprise to hear that consumers have come to expect the same kind of browsing experience on phones as they do with computers and internet browsers. The reality, that websites don't work on mobile phones and that Wapsites are little more than just text-based services, by and large, adds to Wap disappointment. Another drawback to Wap is the "walled garden" strategy adopted by many of the mobile operators. The concept of a walled garden - i.e fencing something in - has been one of the most criticised features of many of the mobile operators' Wap strategies, mainly because the gardens are not attention-grabbing. Another problem has been the lack of uniformity in the URLs given to the Wapsites. For instance the now defunct BBC Wap service was located at: http://www.bbc.co.uk/mobile/mainmenu.wml - not exactly the most intuitive nor easiest to remember address, or for that matter the easiest to input via a mobile phone keypad. Other sites are just as bad, http://www.unmissabletv.com/txw/Wap.wml and http://www.ents24.com/index.wml are just two of the many sites inadvertently contributing towards the general feeling of confusion and disenchantment directed at Wap. Things need to change, and Wap need to get some good PR. One of the first things that needs to happen is an overall move towards a specific URL such as Wap.thesitename.com which would go some way to alleviating some of the frustrations associated with finding decent Wapsites.

fields.headline: Cult curator
fields.standfirst: With more than 25,000 LPs straining the floorboards of his home, John Peel is more curator than collector, tending to a precious archive of leftfield music
fields.trailText: With more than 25,000 LPs straining the floorboards of his home, John Peel is more curator than collector, tending to a precious archive of leftfield music.
fields.body:
When a man's house has to be fitted with reinforcements in order to take the weight of his records, you know that his vinyl addiction has reached rarely seen heights of severity. John Peel's record collection is beyond a joke. There's a large wooden shed used only to accommodate his 12-inch singles, and another one, just past the chicken coop, which houses the 45s. Being Britain's leading vanguard of any kind of music that falls out of the mainstream justifies the addiction somewhat, but these records aren't just the tools of his trade - they're too cherished for that.

"As my wife would confirm if she wasn't out shopping, I still spend an insane amount of time - six to eight hours a day - listening to records and putting together lists for the show," says Peel from the hub of his record world, which is his East Anglian farmhouse's old garage. All the new releases come here, a large cardboard box making up a week's worth of the records sent. The room has a boyish, den-like feel; between the racks of records and CDs are football memorabilia, photographs of his wife, Sheila, and hot rod magazines from the 50s and 60s.

Although the room feels chaotic and cramped, the records are very well ordered. The ones chosen to be played on future shows are recorded on a list, before being elevated from the boxes on the floor to the heights of the collection itself. Each is recorded on a card index. "People say, 'Why don't you put the collection on computer?' But to put 25,776 LPs on to a computer would almost certainly take the rest of my life."

Passing into another room that houses Peel's first 1,500 records, it dawns on me that a curator's mindset must be essential just to keep the collection at least reasonably accessible. This is where his four children, and their boyfriends and girlfriends, come in handy. "Last summer I paid my daughter Flossie's then boyfriend to file my seven-inch singles, and he turned out to be the best filer I ever had. Unfortunately he and Flossie broke up shortly afterwards. Young people have so little consideration. My son William did that lot of CDs," says Peel, pointing to a rack, "and got paid prodigious sums of money to do so, but he took all summer - he's naturally an extremely indolent boy. He seems to have no grasp of the alphabet, either."

Some men have garden sheds to potter about in and get away from the wife; Peel has his two outhouses of records. "I'll come in here to find something, and almost always find something else that I've completely forgotten about. It's a great stress-reliever." Peel mulls over a 45 by Wild Willy Barrett, an eccentric hippie chiefly famed for his collaboration with 70s pub rocker John Otway. The record collector's mind is at work here - revelling in the obscure, celebrating the authentic, and finding release in a three-minute song.

Peel has been a DJ since 1963, working in the US for a number of radio stations before joining Radio 1 from its birth in 1968. He has the freedom to play what he likes, and what tends to make it through is anything that fulfils a degree of honesty, be that a scratchy old reggae 45 or the latest student union indie favourite. A few records have moved beyond work into the realm of the intensely personal. "I've got a clutch of about 20 records which I'll grab in an emergency, and which will go into the grave with me," Peel explains. They're all 45s, they're all impossibly obscure, and each one, says Peel, "can almost always reduce me to tears".

Within this sacred box, there's a Jagger-Richards composition, I'd Rather Be Out with the Boys, by mid-1960s Manchester no-hit wonders the Toggery Five; and a great reggae take on Paul Simon's Richard Cory by Jamaican singer Yami Boro, who, not quite understanding the words of the song, called it Richer Cory. "There's a reggae version of Whiter Shade of Pale which does the same thing," says Peel, "but the lyrics of that song were complete bollocks anyway, so misinterpreting them just adds another dimension."

There are also a number of heartbreaking early-70s soul ballads. In one, Stanley Winston's No More Ghettos in America, the singer's voice quivers before collapsing into feverish falsetto. "This is the only record this guy made," Peel explains, just as Winston breaks down entirely. "You hear somebody like Mick Hucknall described as a soul singer after his 25th LP. This guy made this one 45 and the first 30 seconds eclipses Hucknall's entire output." And each of these records tells a story in Peel's life - such as the R'n'B classic You'd Better Move On by Arthur Alexander. "It was given to me by a girlfriend in Texas, and I think it was a hint. Her way of saying, 'Suit action to the title, fatboy.' "

A British institution, John Peel, like so many music lovers, is a sentimentalist at heart, a man who can live through his most valued vinyl finds. "I'll play them all together one day," he says of his 20 moments of greatness, "and then go mad."

fields.headline: Formations, Fabrication, and Frustration
fields.trailText: KOOG GETS SERIOUS
fields.body:
KOOG GETS SERIOUS

First the good news: England's side to face France tomorrow does not include Phil Neville. Or his brother. Or any member of the Neville family. And if that wasn't strange enough, Kelvin Koogan's big Parisian adventure hasn't - so far - seen him wildly beating his red and white drum and loudly proclaiming: "people might think I'm crazy but we've got a great chance of winning 3-0!" Instead he's testing out a new 4-4-1-1 formation, playing Gareth Barry and giving David Beckham another chance to prove he deserves to play in the centre. Which all sounds strangely sensible.

Of course, Koog being Koog there was the usual boyish enthusiasm, despite half the press pack wearing black (and it wasn't because black is the new black on the Paris catwalks either). He praised Villa defender Barry calling his performance in training "fantastic", and telling reporters he would take tomorrow's game "in his stride". "He's a great user of the ball and doesn't get flustered and I think that is a major, major plus at international level," Koog continued, looking at neither Neville brother in particular.

And there was also a coherent enough explanation for his contentious decision drop the red-hot Michael Owen in favour of a Scholes-Cole axis as well. "His form has been very good but I wanted to try playing one-up and one-off," said Koog. "Andy Cole has become very adaptable, we did play like that at Newcastle and the Beardsley-Cole partnership was tremendously difficult to play against." And seeing as Koog didn't mention that he broke up that "tremendously difficult to play against" partnership by selling Cole, then neither will we.

England team: Seaman; Barry, Adams (captain), Keown, Campbell; Barmby, Wise, Beckham, Anderton; Scholes; Cole.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

DIDI DO WELL?

Who says that Rangers are streets ahead in Scotland? Not the Fiver for sure (and that's in a Dutch accent). While others thought the arrival of Ronald de Boer had confirmed that Rangers were the only big club in Scotland, the Fiver knew that Celtic manager Martin O'Neill would have a deal or two up his sleeve. And so it has proven today, when the jumpy Irishman announced the signing of some French bloke and Alan Thompson, occasional Aston Villa substitute.

"I have not bought these players now because of any European deadlines", said O'Neill, which was a relief. "That is no way to run a club - and in any case our over-riding priority this season is the league championship. That is why Alan and Didier are here." A glance at our "Frenchmen in Scottish football" flick book informed us that "Didier" is in fact Didier Agathe, a 25 year-old striker who has scored four goals in five league games since joining Hibernian in the summer. Why that deserves a £50,000 transfer to Celtic is anyone's guess (although it's more reason than any player will need come next season).

Even more mysterious is the £2.5m signing of the so-unpredictable-you'd-think- he-was-an-episode-of-Brookside Alan Thompson. "Alan is well known to me and I've seen him play a lot of times," said O'Neill. "It hasn't been the best of years for him but he is a talented player - a very talented player - and this move will really get his confidence going again." Presumably Mad Mart knows more than we do, and we look forward to seeing Thompson knocking on the door of the England team. After all, Regi Blinker is back in the Dutch squad. Isn't he?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Phil's a genuine boy, he does as he's told and that's why he's still in the squad. I still believe very much in him, he's still one of my squad."

Kelvin Koogan with yet another ringing endorsement of Phil Neville.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE MACCA APPRECIATION SQUAD

Would you believe it. Steve McManaman, the prisoner of the Iberian peninsula, the plank of the Plaza Major, the man on the bench, is at the forefront of a movement that is shaking Real Madrid to its very core. Or, at the very least, wobbling it slightly.

Macca was told by Real earlier in the summer that he was no lon[boooring -teenage Fiver ed]. He has since been variously tipped for a move to Lazio, Arsenal or even, please control yourselves, Middlesbrough, but according to reports in today's Marca, Macca's teammates want him to stay at the Bernabeu and are prepared to fight Vicente del Bosque to keep him.

Marca quote a "senior player" who says the Real squad are angry with the management at the sale of Fernando Redondo and the "humiliation" of Macca. There have been rows in the dressing room, and the players are on the verge of speaking out. "We're going to sign a letter denouncing what is going on," the player told Marca. "Everyone will sign it, so the whole world will know." Next thing you know they'll be chaining themselves to the railings. Can't wait till Robbie Fowler wears the t-shirt.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Bobby Robson is looking to bring Portuguese international Vitor Baia to Tyneside, reports Planet Football. They say the Newcastle manager will offer the former Barcelona keeper - who is available on a free transfer after being released by Barcelona - a £1.4m a year contract. Newcastle have also been linked once more to Wimbledon's unsettled Jason Euell.

Everton are "in the frame" to sign Inter Milan defender Cyril Domoraud, according to Planet Football's "sources in Italy". Walter Smith is believed to have made contact with the 29-year-old Ivory Coast international, but faces stiff competition from Spanish side Celta Vigo.

Arsenal boss Arsene Wenger is expected to travel to Latvia this weekend to watch Andrejs Rubins and Igor Stepanov play against Scotland.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Manchester City manager Joe Royle has stripped Richard Edghill of the captaincy and dropped him for the match against Leeds on Tuesday. "I have relieved Richard of the captaincy. It is for his own good primarily and to take the pressure away from him," Royle told the club's official website. "I have told him also that he won't be playing on Tuesday, again just to take him out of it and relieve the pressure. I have asked Alfie Haaland to be the new captain and he has accepted."

Fabien Barthez could miss tomorrow night's friendly with England after hurting his ankle. The 29-year-old suffered the injury while tackling Nicolas Anelka and limped off the field. "It's a small injury," said team doctor Jean-Marcel Ferret. "It's not very serious because he can walk but we won't take any risks."

Barcelona have agreed a deal to bring teenage Argentine sensation Javier Saviola to the Nou Camp. For a fee of £8m, Barca will hold half of Saviola's contract, River keeping the other half. The 18-year-old who broke scoring records in Argentina last season, will move to Spain at the end of the season.

Leicester City are poised to sign Sheffield Wednesday striker Richard Cresswell for £750,000.

Livingston manager Jim Leishman has been named Bell's Manager of the Month for August. Leishman, who took over from Ray Stewart earlier this year, has guided Livvy to the top of the First Division and into a CIS League Cup third round tie with Hearts next week.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 3: Tranmere v Stockport (7.00pm) Alternatively tune into the double bill of Channel 4 News and Xena: Warrior Princess. Tasty!

Eurosport: Football: the best of the 1998 World Cup (8.00pm) Or you can watch The Bill instead. Highbrow!

Which is why we are pleased to announce the launch of Woolnough Wax - a smooth, yet sensuous hair lacquer which controls even the most bothersome bouffant. Place your orders today!

fields.headline: House rules
fields.standfirst: "Nasty" Nick Bateman broke the rules. Here's what he was up against (besides the other contestants).
fields.trailText: "Nasty" Nick Bateman broke the rules. Here's what he was up against (besides the other contestants).
fields.body:
The basic Big Brother premise: 10 participants live together in a house that is under constant, 24-hours a day surveillance from TV cameras and webcams and in complete isolation from the outside world, for nine weeks. Each week the public votes out one contestant, with the last one left standing picking up the £70,000 prize.

The 10 contestants were selected from more than 40,000 applicants. The selection process involved an in-depth questionnaire, followed by a round of interviews, psychological tests and auditions.

They entered the Big Brother house on Friday July 14. Over the next nine weeks, two contestants are nominated for eviction by their fellow housemates each week, with the public having the final say on who gets booted out in a phone poll that closes on Friday nights. In the final week, viewers will vote for one of the three remaining contestants, who will win the £70,000 prize.

Each participant was allowed to take in one suitcase of clothing and a small case of personal belongings, including books, cigarettes and photographs. Radios, TVs, clocks and watches are banned.

The contestants must each week perform a task, which have so far included riding 1,200km on an exercise bike, sending a semaphore message and an assault course. They can win extra spending money if they complete them successfully. Otherwise, they must survive on a housekeeping budget of a about £1.50 per person per day, along with basic provisions, which are replenished every two weeks. The inhabitants are only allowed into the storeroom where the provisions are kept for one hour each morning.

fields.headline: Come on then, if you think you're hard enough
fields.standfirst: As Snatch hits cinema screens, Brit gangster chic is the new look to die for.  Peter Lyle  is not impressed
fields.trailText: As Snatch hits cinema screens, Brit gangster chic is the new look to die for. Peter Lyle is not impressed.
fields.body:
Film and fashion have been flirting since before Charlie Chaplin first put a hat on, but this week the love affair reached a new high - one with a distinctly dodgy twist. First, Martin Scorsese revealed that, having tackled boxing, gambling and organised crime, his next project would deal with the most crooked business of them all - fashion - in a film about the Gucci family feud. And Guy Ritchie's latest film, Snatch, which hits cinema screens today, is sure to extend the mockney-mobster aesthetic pioneered by its predecessor, Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels. This fashionable new look is seeping, with ever greater concentration, into the style sensibility of the average twentysomething British male. Not since James Dean slouched in Rebel Without a Cause has on-screen style made such an impact on our wardrobes.

Gangster chic is arguably cinema's greatest contribution to men's fashion, and after decades of New York tough guys, Ritchie - himself seldom seen without his Alfred Dunhill cashmere coat - has shown that British men can wear it, too. And they love him for it. The current issue of the totemic lad mag Loaded, for example, describes Snatch as "the crowning and probably final moment of gangster fashion". Meanwhile, FHM devotes a dozen pages to the film's key characters in its fashion section. Inside you can read how the Savile Row tailor and unflagging self-publicist Ozwald Boateng provided bespoke costumes for Lock Stock's original cast of "authentic" tough guys.

If that's not enough evidence of the film's fashionable influence, go out tonight and observe twentysomething males queuing up to be first to take in Ritchie's latest and note how the British gangster movie's essential accessories - shiny loafers, pressed shirts, glinting boxes of 20 B&H - are influencing our nation's smart-casual sensibility.

Never mind the fact that real east-end petty criminals prefer to go to work in grubby Air Maxes and lurid Puffa jackets; faux cockney-criminal chic lets you look: a) sharp, b) a little bit tasty, and c) like a proper geezer - and who can complain about that?

In retrospect, this state of affairs is the logical conclusion of a succession of gangster looks that film-makers have brought us over the past decade. It began with the hugely influential Reservoir Dogs and the slimline white-shirt, black-tie outfits worn by its protagonists. The get-up offered a knowing nod to the seedy glamour of Sinatra's Rat Pack and showed a generation of formalwear-phobic young men that suits wouldn't necessarily make them look like accountants - or, worse, schoolboys.

A raft of cheapo sub-Tarantino crime flicks experimented with variations on the same sartorial theme, while several British-made gangster films, before and after Lock, Stock, tried to give the suit a comparably iconic presence. For the average movie-going geezer, though, Brit gangster fashion was always a little bit outre and risque, and had too many echoes of mod and 60s flamboyance to make the leap from screen to high-street store; you could happily admire it and buy the poster, but you wouldn't want to emulate it through your wardrobe. What Ritchie has done is domesticate the gangster look, make it safe for the fashion-fearing modern man who thinks being seen in pinstripes is as emasculating as arriving at the pub with a pink poodle.

Effecting this shift has been something of a triumph - which is precisely why it is so depressing. "I reckon if you get too interested in clothes, it all starts getting a bit fruity." That's the enlightened line Ritchie takes in September's FHM. You might have thought that his settling down with the most audacious, fashion-friendly pop star of the last 20 years would have broadened his style horizons, but you'd be wrong. "Frankly," he continues, Madonna "would have me dressed up like a poof if she could". The godfather of Brit gangster chic sounds like an uptight estate agent after a few too many at the cricket club - a million miles from the iconic movie gangsters of the past.

In Scorsese's Casino, Robert De Niro may have been hard as nails, but that didn't stop him wearing Dame Edna sunglasses and primary-coloured pimp suits. Even the macho supermen of 70s blaxploitation flicks such as Black Caesar found the time to invest in some decidedly "fruity" ruffled shirts and velvet jackets. Movie gangsters of old strutted like peacocks and preened themselves like poodles; they pushed the fashion envelope just as they tested the farthest limits of the law. They had a fatalistic, forbidden glamour. These days, we have to make do with geezerdom instead.

Thankfully, there is a glimmer of hope for those of us bored silly by the nightclub bouncer-meets-monied-football hooligan look of gangster chic and, more importantly, its trickle-down effect on British menswear in general. The cultural swing back to modern tailoring - something often touted in recent times - is finally gathering some real momentum. Richard James and Gieves & Hawkes, both purveyors of finely crafted, grown-up menswear, have just opened flagship, central-London stores and won acres of approving magazine coverage by doing so. Burberry, too, is enjoying a new wave of interest in its classic cuts. And a cover story in the latest issue of money magazine Forbes Global heralds the renaissance of "dressing down in style", arguing that the demise of the suit as a workplace uniform, combined with a growing awareness among men of the potential for elegance and individuality offered by a properly made two-piece signals a shift in style choices in the west. If that trend expands, it means a new dawn in fashion for men who go to a tailor with confidence, rather than those who need to buy their self-assurance and masculine credentials off the shelf. It's about time.

In 1986, Madonna recorded a song called White Heat, a tribute to James Cagney in the 1949 gangster classic of the same name. The chances of her recording a comparable tribute to the verve and panache of her husband's leading men - say, Vinnie "You're the Bollocks, Innit" Jones - look decidedly slim. And on that note, what's the likelihood of Brit gangster chic going down in the histories of timeless screen style? As Al Pacino said in Donnie Brasco - slumped on the flock sofa in a hideous tracksuit, but still knocking the style spots off the Snatch mob - fugedaboutit.

fields.headline: England are all out for 281
fields.standfirst: England were bowled out for 281 in their first innings
fields.trailText: West Indies grabbed the upper hand at the Oval after they bowled England out for 281. The remaining two wickets fell in a rain-shortened afternoon session to add to the three they lost in a crazy half-hour before lunch.
fields.body:
West Indies grabbed the upper hand at the Oval after they bowled England out for 281. The remaining two wickets fell in a rain-shortened afternoon session to add to the three they lost in a crazy half-hour before lunch.

In truth, batting looked a different prospect on this pitch in the morning session - no one could manage a boundary until Caddick cut Walsh for four at 3.40pm - and yesterday's opening stand of 159 from Michael Atherton and Marcus Trescothick could yet prove vital in the context of this Test match: England's remaining nine wickets put on a combined total of 122.

Walsh huffed and puffed at the tail after the rain break: he gave Caddick a withering glare as he departed after mishooking to Hinds at leg gully for just that one scoring shot and Gough, who earlier pulled MacLean for four, received a nasty short ball from Courtney which he just managed to duck under.

When White cut the last ball of a Walsh over for four, run-gathering again seemed an easier pastime. The last pair added 17 before Walsh bowled Gough with an offcutter and England were 281 all out.

Earlier, Thorpe and Hick had been the model of studiousness while they were denying West Indies for 90 minutes, after the visitors took the new ball at the start of the first full over of the day. Curbing their naturally attacking instincts, they held firm as the ball swished past edges, gloves and stumps and rapped dangerously onto pads. But with the last ball of a maiden, Ambrose found Hick's pads with a thud; rarely can he have spent 73 balls garnering just 17 runs.

Next over, Walsh sent Thorpe back with another super slower ball in a manner similar to that which ended Thorpe's return to the Test side at Old Trafford. This time the ball struck low on the pads, rather than Thorpe's foot, and with their last batsman gone for 40, England were under the kosh again at 254-7. Then Ambrose, pitched up a straight ball, it hit Cork's pads and umpire David Shepherd duly confirmed the fifth lbw of the innings.

webTitle: Keegan names defensive line-up for France

fields.headline: Keegan names defensive line-up for France
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan has announced a defensive-looking side for tomorrow's match with France.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan has announced a defensive-looking side for tomorrow's match with France.

England will play a 4-4-1-1 line-up with Martin Keown and Tony Adams in central defence and Sol Campbell at right back. Keegan also starts with Gareth Barry at left-back, believing the time has come for the 19-year-old to take a step up.

"His training has been fantastic but in many ways the big test is what you do on the pitch," Keegan said. "I think he will take it in his stride. He's a great user of the ball and doesn't get flustered and I think that is a major, major plus at international level."

Up front Keegan will play Manchester United's Andy Cole as a lone striker ahead of Paul Scholes. There is no place for Michael Owen, much to the Liverpool striker's disappointment.

"I've talked with Michael and he's fine about it - he's a very mature lad - but obviously he's disappointed," said Keegan. "His form has been very good but I wanted to try playing one-up and one-off. Andy Cole has become very adaptable, we did play like that at Newcastle and the Beardsley-Cole partnership was tremendously difficult to play against."

In midfield Dennis Wise will play in a holding role, David Beckham will join him in the centre with Darren Anderton playing on the right and Nick Barmby filling the problem position on the left.

Keegan added: "Looking at the French, the way they play, I thought this was best. We're playing the very best here and trying to get the balance right."

Keegan insisted his selection for the friendly at Stade de France did not rule out anyone for the first World Cup qualifier against Germany next month. He said: "I know what Paul Ince can do I know what Michael Owen can do and they will come back into contention for the Germany game - there's no doubt about that."

Keegan also had comforting words for Phil Neville, who conceded the penalty which ended England's Euro 2000 hopes against Romania.

"Phil's a genuine boy," he said. "He does as he's told and that's why he's still in the squad. I still believe very much in him, he's still one of my squad."

Keegan then went on to insist England that must produce a "step forward" in tomorrow's game.

"I want a good performance, a step up that makes the players feel they've taken a step forward," he said. "We are not going to play this quality in our World Cup qualifying group, with no disrespect to the teams we'll play then."

"Results help you. They help me and the players. I want to get the players back into believing, as we did before Euro 2000. They need to get that belief back into themselves again.

"But the down side is that this is a game where you can lose some self belief. But as long as we do better than we did in Euro 2000 it will set us up nicely."

England team to face France in Paris tomorrow: Seaman; Barry, Adams (captain), Keown, Campbell; Barmby, Wise, Beckham, Anderton; Scholes; Cole.

fields.headline: The fame game
fields.standfirst: Where are they now (the losers that is)? Was it worth it (financially speaking, of course)?
fields.trailText: Where are they now (the losers that is)? Was it worth it (financially speaking, of course)?
fields.body:
PR svengali Max Clifford has predicted that Big Brother bad boy Nick Bateman could earn £1m in the next year, after being thrust into the limelight by the Channel 4 gameshow. Bateman has already sold his story to the Sun for £70,000.

Bateman and six other of the original contestants said before entering the house that their dream job would be working in the media or entertainment industries. Bateman, Mel Hill, Darren Ramsey and Sada Walkington all fancy themselves as TV presenters.

Walkington, the hippy chick and first evictee on Friday July 28, is reaping the benefits of her brief flirtation with fame. In her first week after leaving the house, Walkington reckoned to have made "a couple of grand" from appearance and interview fees, was interviewed on the Big Breakfast and given a holiday in Bhutan by Ebookers.com. Magazines ranging from Company to GQ are lining up to do features on her, and she has landed a part in a radio commercial for Yahoo!. What Walkington has ambitions to become a TV presenter. She told the Big Brother website: "I'm looking for a cultural angle, very much to do with travelling and alternative lifestyle."

Caroline O'Shea, after becoming the third person to be voted out of the house, had her single, Prince Charming, premiered on radio DJ Jonathan Coleman's Heart FM show. Another evicted housemate, Nichola Holt, has been offered a six-week contract with a circus. Big Brother producer Bazal is fielding all media offers and requests on behalf of evictees, and offering advice on what to accept.

Two young female contestants from the Dutch version of the show have posed for Playboy covers. Dutch and German Big Brother cast members recorded albums - the German one shifting 200,000 copies on its first day in the shops.

Bart Spring in't Veld - the 23-year old ex-soldier who triumphed in Big Brother's first series in the Netherlands - went on to guest present one of the country's most popular radio shows, took up modelling and started a clothing company. But Veld told the Guardian recently that he didn't like all the exposure and was scaling back his media work.

Big Brother producer Bazal is fielding all media offers and requests on behalf of evictees, and offering advice on what to accept. Two young female contestants from the Dutch version of the show have posed for Playboy covers. Dutch and German Big Brother cast members recorded albums - the German one shifting 200,000 copies on its first day in the shops. Bart Spring in't Veld - the 23-year old ex-soldier who triumphed in Big Brother's first series in the Netherlands - went on to guest present one of the country's most popular radio shows, took up modelling and started a clothing company. But Veld told the Guardian recently that he didn't like all the exposure and was scaling back his media work.

webTitle: Ahead of its time or inevitable decline?

fields.headline: Ahead of its time or inevitable decline?
fields.standfirst: With so many big-name backers, why did Boo.com become a dot.com nightmare come true? Dan Milmo highlights the lessons many dot.coms need to learn if they are not to go the same way.
fields.trailText: With so many big-name backers, why did Boo.com become a dot.com nightmare come true? Dan Milmo highlights the lessons many dot.coms need to learn if they are not to go the same way.
fields.body:
The story of failed internet retailer Boo.com is a new media nightmare. It is not so much a roller-coaster ride to noble failure as a free-fall into dot.com oblivion.

Boo was set up by the Swedish pair Ernst Malmsten and Kajsa Leander, who became overnight stars with their book-selling venture Bokus.com. When it came to writing Boo's obituary, the British press ignored this, preferring to highlight Ernst's past life as a poetry critic and Kajsa's spell as a catwalk model.

The company had an impressive list of backers, including banking giant Goldman Sachs and Bernard Arnault, chairman of Christian Dior and French luxury goods company LVMH.

One former Boo employee says: "The investors were blinded by the success of Bokus and gave Ernst and Kajsa too much rope. The owners had their fingers on the pulse in terms of the concept, but they chucked money at the company when they did not need to."

Boo was 18 months old when it imploded in May, having spent £115m and leaving debts of £25m. At one point, the company was wasting £600,000 a week. Former staff told of Ernst and Kajsa's "champagne, caviar and Concorde" lifestyle - what with complimentary mobile phones, alleged all-night drinking sprees and daily breakfasts at top Soho hotels near the company's offices in Carnaby Street.

The advertising campaign was suicidal for a company that saw trendy twentysomethings as its target market. The cinema and TV ads, shot using hand-held video cameras, followed a horde of badly dressed geeks as they set about irritating rough US neighbourhoods. It looked like a dodgy rip-off of a Beastie Boys video, which it was.

The much-hyped website, which is said to have cost £25m to put together, allowed visitors to try on clothes in a virtual dressing room. The three-dimensional stock images cost £320,000 alone. The site could take orders in seven languages and 18 currencies, but was too complex and jammed customers' computers.

One analyst says: "Boo was ahead of its time with the website, as you needed access to a powerful modem and broadband capabilities to run it. This was simply a case of chronic mismanagement. There is definitely a problem in the new economy in that the companies are grossly over-valued and do not have the expertise to get out of a self-made hole."

Boo's software was sold to internet incubator Bright Station in June for £250,000. The Daily Mirror's disgraced City Slickers team dubbed Bright Station chief executive Dan Wagner "the new Bill Gates", and he is renowned as one of the more colourful characters in the City. The company's shares plummeted under its former name, the Dialog Corporation, following a disastrous £175m acquisition. But Bright Station is bullish about the future and hopes Boo's core assets will fare better under new ownership.

Bright Station chief financial officer David Matty says: "The software has tremendous potential, as it is robust and scaleable. It is also multi-lingual and can deal with several different currencies. This is a good system we are sitting on, and it can only get better. Developing it is not a problem, as we have 40 of Boo's technology staff working for us now."

Boo's business sins are not unique, but its meteoric rise and fall is a remarkable internet horror story. If it is to serve a higher purpose than being the butt of analysts' jokes for the next 10 years, it must act as a lesson to internet start-ups. It seems, however, that the same mistakes are being repeated.

Gerry Mulvin of e-commerce strategy company Bain & Co believes Boo's idea of selling street fashion to young internet users was viable, but that everything else was a disaster. He says: "The amount of money it spent was appalling. Once the money goes out of the door, it will not come back unless it is used to generate revenue. Boo needed more aggressive, accountable cash management."

But his main criticism is reserved for venture capitalists who made billions of dollars in the mid-1990s from the likes of AOL and Netscape in the US and then tried to repeat the success in Britain. "People started to chuck money at everything. The venture capitalists are to blame [for Boo's demise] because they should have said it was time to stop. But these companies take the portfolio approach of investing in 20 companies and making all their profit from a single success.

"It's not about having a strategy, but getting the company to flotation. Old world rules still apply, in that every customer has to make you money. So many dot.coms are doing the same thing as Boo, except with less largesse."

Despite the wayward behaviour of many start-ups, there are notable successes. AOL, for example, was the senior partner in a £220bn merger with Time Warner at the beginning of this year, and it is building a strong presence in Europe through a series of alliances and acquisitions. Online auctioneer eBay is valued at £12bn, thanks to its dominance of a high margin, high growth business. It has fought off competitors to claim 88% of the market, and has the rare status of being a profitable consumer e-commerce company.

Nonetheless, Mulvin believes more Boos will ring out from the stock market, because only 25% of US companies to have floated since 1995 have made a profit. Boo has already been joined in "the great start-up in the sky" by Dressmart and health products e-tailer Clickmango.com. And with analysts predicting other ventures will soon run out of cash, there is plenty of room for more.

webTitle: How the show was put together

fields.headline: How the show was put together
fields.standfirst: Big Brother is set on an island in Bow, London, where big brother watches over the householders - even when their in the toilet - using 26 cameras.
fields.trailText: Big Brother is set on an island in Bow, London, where big brother watches over the householders - even when their in the toilet - using 26 cameras.
fields.body:
The Big Brother house has been purpose-built on an island at Three Mills Studios in Bromley-by-Bow, London. There are 26 cameras around the house and garden - even the toilet and shower are filmed. Each contestant has a personal microphone that is switched at all times, and there are a further 30 mikes around the house.

The video feed splits into two for the TV and Web production teams. Big Brother airs on Channel 4 nightly, Monday to Friday, with a weekly round-up late on Saturday night. The website has six live video feeds, which are watched around the clock by an 18-strong editorial team that monitors, logs and reports on the participants' activities. Trained monitors watch out for instances of obscenity, nudity and libel.

Big Brother is made by independent producer Bazal, which is responsible for Ready Steady Cook, Ground Force and Changing Rooms. The website has been designed by digital media company Victoria Real. Spanish internet service provider Terra Networks is acting as the web host, in partnership with Real Networks - which supplies the Real Player software needed to stream video footage from the house - and Intel.

Bazal is a subsidiary of the Dutch company Endemol Entertainment - Europe's largest TV production company and owner of the Big Brother format. Endemol also owns a 50% stake in Victoria Real. The Dutch company is in turn owned by Spanish telecoms and media giant Telefonica-owner Terra Networks.

fields.headline: Chattering classes express disapproval
fields.standfirst: Big Brother has been almost universally condemned by media commentators and critics as a new low tide mark in the quality of UK TV output - or, even worse, just plain dull.
fields.trailText: Big Brother has been almost universally condemned by media commentators and critics as a new low tide mark in the quality of UK TV output - or, even worse, just plain dull.
fields.body:
David Aaronovitch in the Independent on August 9, said: "There is nothing Nick [Bateman], Channel 4 or the psychologists can do to obviate the fact that all the Brotherites are staggeringly, skull-crushingly, die-on-a-sofa dumb... There is, however, an upside to all this. What the Channel 4 kids also demonstrate is far less inhibition than earlier generations, much greater openness and - yes - more tolerance. And perhaps blandness is a price worth paying for that. Just."

Barbara Ellen in the Observer on August 13: "Like Jerry Springer before it, Big Brother is TV heroin: addictive, full of garbage and distinguished by the fact that those who consume are as degraded by the experience as those who peddle it. We've all heard about the banality of evil - Big Brother brings you the banality of banality."

An Independent leader on August 12 read: "Where will it all end? We must fervently hope that some bright spark in the commissioning department at Channel 4 is not pondering the apparently thriving trade in illegal videos of executions carried out by the authorities in Afghanistan and Saudi Arabia. We fear, however, that the pilot may already be in the pipeline and will be sneaked out later in the summer as You've Been Chopped."

Daniel Johnson in the Daily Telegraph on August 12: "Big Brother apparently pretends to be an experiment, a study of relationships and the effects of loss of privacy... This series is as cynical an exercise in voluntary and mutual exploitation as has ever been screened in this country... Good taste is banned. When they [the contestants] spend a week learning to signal in semaphore, the content of the message has to be horoscopes from the Sun."

fields.headline: Jungle.com sold for £37m
fields.trailText: Jungle.com, one of the UK's best known e-commerce firms, has been sold to Great Universal Stores for £37m - a fraction of its earlier valuation.
fields.body:
Jungle.com, one of the UK's best known e-commerce firms, has been sold to Great Universal Stores for £37m - a fraction of its earlier valuation.

Steve Bennett, the founder and chief executive of Jungle, which sells items including electronic equipment, compact discs and videos, is expected to make around £7m from the sale of the company he launched on the internet last August.

Earlier this year, he had hoped to float the group with a valuation of up to £750m, with his personal stake valued at up to £250m.

However, the plunge in the value of technology shares in March dashed hopes of a stock market listing and forced the group to scale down its offer price to prospective buyers. It is understood the company attracted potential interest only after the price had fallen below £40m.

GUS, which owns the Argos chain, is believed to have faced strong competition for jungle.com from rival groups Dixons and Kingfisher.

The £37m deal, which includes the repayment of around £12m of debt, will tie Mr Bennett to the company for the next four years.

He said: "GUS give jungle.com the muscle to take us to the next stage in our growth. Of the many offers we had for the business, GUS was by far the best fit."

John Peace, chief executive of GUS, said: "There is a strong strategic fit between these two businesses. GUS will be able to offer its customers a wide range of computer and office products via the most convenient channel, be it ordering via store, catalogue or internet."

Despite being the UK's second most recognised e-tailer, behind Amazon, jungle.com lost £11.4m in the 12 months to July 31, on the back of heavy marketing and development costs.

A high-profile advertising campaign turned Jungle into one of the most visible e-commerce brands in Britain, making the valuation slump all the more surprising.

fields.headline: The rat race
fields.standfirst:
What's happening in Big Brother

Special report: Big Brother
fields.trailText: What's happening in Big Brother
fields.body:
Anyone currently entertaining the notion that the past week's Big Brother was rather dull, and that maybe Channel 4 moved it forward a scheduling slot at precisely the wrong moment - think again, dissenters. Yes, there was rather more snoozing and task-fulfilling going on than one might have hoped.

No, watching Anna count her lunges to and from the loo doesn't quite qualify as scintillating, titillating, Who-Wants-To-Be-A-Millionaire?-rivalling TV.

And yes, there are only so many times we can wonder over the curious microclimate, which allows this nubile young household to sunbathe whilst the rest of us shiver in light sports jackets and jeans. But the subtext! Most significantly, this was the week when it finally became clear that no one would be sleeping with anyone, at any time. All hopes for a sweaty, grasping union between pneumatic Claire and the ridiculously squat Craig faded with the proposed expulsee short list, and the high-voltage coquetry of Mel seems like a distant memory already.

But better yet, Big Brother himself has undergone a total personality transformation. Having spent the past six weeks posing as inscrutable, stern, authoritarian, a sinister voice of reason and all-round grown-up, he's finally morphed into a puerile, lascivious and downright irresponsible type. These days, it's hard not to picture him as the kind of middle-aged man who writes serious reviews of massage parlours, and subscribes to erotica.

"Take all your clothes off, and photocopy your bits," he sniggered.

"Splash about in the hot tub with Claire. She's had a boob job, you know," he slimed.

"Oops, did I not soundproof the diary room? Have I caused chaos? Oh well. I probably meant to do it. Creates an interesting new dynamic, don't you think?"

Maybe the power's gone to his head. But speculating over the nature of his next leering decree or outrageous gaffe is going some way towards filling the aching void that Nick Bateman left in his wake.

fields.headline: On the menu: champ
fields.standfirst: Food on the net
fields.trailText: Food on the net
fields.body:
As in champing at the bit?

No, as in champion veg.

Alright, go ahead. What's in it?

Nothing more than mashed potato, milk and chopped spring onions or nettle tops.

Nettle tops?

The top of the young nettle is nutritious and packed with flavour. There are schools of thought which favour chives or parsley, but that's getting into very murky waters. And should you be so thoughtless as to stir in butter or cream, then it won't be champ at all, but pandy, or that's what they say.

Who is responsible for this scrumptious stomach filler?

It is one of Ireland's great contributions to world gastronomy, and is served on Halloween in particular.

www.clubchefdirect.co.uk

Heritage Foods - suppliers to many of the UK's top restaurants - have taken the chefs-on-the-net idea one stage further, by offering home cooks the chance to buy the same produce that chefs use in restaurants.

Pros: No more hunting around for ingredients that you don't even know how to pronounce and a surprise freebie with most orders.

Cons: A two-tier system guarantees delivery to club members (who stump up the £100 annual fee) only.

Delivery: Orders placed by midday are delivered by overnight courier.

Charges: Free for members, £10 per order for non-members.

Coming Up: Dr Chef ... a service that allows members to email a chef with their culinary queries.

fields.headline: Brotherly love
fields.standfirst: Channel 4's Big Brother is a multimedia phenomenon the likes of which have never been experienced before (well, not in the UK anyway). Jason Deans reports.
fields.trailText: Channel 4's Big Brother is a multimedia phenomenon the likes of which have never been experienced before (well, not in the UK anyway). Jason Deans reports.
fields.body:
Big Brother (official site: www.bigbrother.terra.com ) is probably the biggest example of "watercooler television" - the channel controller's wet dream and a show that people talk about obsessively in the office the next day - since BBC2 twentysomething drama This Life, which was screened three summers ago.

More significantly, Big Brother is the first UK TV programme to make the crossover and become a major online media phenomenon. The unfolding saga of contestant "Nasty" Nick Bateman's eviction from the house on Thursday August 18 was followed live by hundreds of thousands - possibly millions - of people via audio and video feeds on the programme's website.

As media commentator Mark Lawson pointed out in the following day's Guardian, this was the first example of a mass audience gathering around computer screens - rather than TVs - for a shared media experience.

When Big Brother started in mid-July, the website was receiving about 1.5m page impressions per day, according to internet host Intel. In the week before Bateman's eviction, this increased to about 2.5m per day - more than BBC News Online and making Big Brother the most popular website in the UK.

On August 18, site traffic tripled to 7.8m page impressions, according to unofficial figures. Meanwhile, live video streams peaked at more than 8m (compared with 2.5m normally). Real Networks reports that 500,000 users have downloaded the software needed to watch Big Brother on the web.

But this internet activity has not had an adverse affect on Big Brother's TV ratings. The specially extended Big Brother update on Thursday 18 August drew an average audience of 5.5m between 11pm and midnight. This is a huge number for this late in the evening; the show's 63% audience share was Channel 4's biggest since the TV premier of Four Weddings and a Funeral in November 1995.

The following evening, Bateman's interview with Davina McCall also attracted a 5.5m audience. Because the show went out earlier in the evening, the audience share was lower, at 46%, but still a big success for Channel 4, which usually averages only about 10%. After these ratings successes, Channel 4 brought forward its Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday night updates from 11pm to 10pm.

Earlier in its run - in the seven days ending July 30 - Big Brother helped Channel 4 to record its best weekly audience share since October 1997, at 11.6%, according to unofficial overnights ???. The seven 30-minute episodes broadcast at 11pm on weekdays up to August 2 averaged nearly 2.6m and a 22% audience share - almost double the Channel 4 norm in this timeslot.

The show has taken a firm hold of the UK media. At first, newspaper reviewers and columnists were distinctly sniffy and dismissed it as a new low in exploitative TV, or, worse still, just plain boring. But as the weeks have gone by, Big Brother has increasingly become the focus of media attention, particularly as Bateman's scheming antics began to capture journalists' imagination. The Sun took the lead by launching a "Kick out Nick" campaign and sending a remote-controlled helicopter over the Big Brother house to drop leaflets warning the other contestants - unsuccessfully - about his dodgy behaviour.

In the first week after the 10 contestants entered the house of two-way mirrors on Friday July 14, the show was mentioned in 43 stories in the national press. webTitle: Lifting navy's gay ban has made fewer waves than women at sea

fields.headline: Lifting navy's gay ban has made fewer waves than women at sea
fields.trailText: Allowing gay people to serve in the Royal Navy has caused fewer problems than sending women to sea for the first time 10 years ago, a senior officer said yesterday.
fields.body:
Allowing gay people to serve in the Royal Navy has caused fewer problems than sending women to sea for the first time 10 years ago, a senior officer said yesterday.

Rear-Admiral James Burnell-Nugent, assistant chief of navy staff and a former captain of HMS Invincible, said the ruling raised issues over accommodation aboard ships but otherwise had not raised serious problems.

The armed forces were forced to drop their ban on gay people after a ruling by the European court of human rights last year.

Admiral Burnell-Nugent said that allowing Wrens to serve alongside men at sea had proved a success and had improved the atmosphere aboard Britain's warships.

"Although some did not welcome the change of policy [on gay people] it has not caused any great degree of difficulty," he said in an interview with the Plymouth-based Western Morning News. "I think it has caused less of a ruffle than the issue of women at sea."

He added: "If we want to be in an armed force that preserves democracy at home and promotes it around the world then part of that is to be signed up to democratic principles ourselves."

Sebastian Sands, of the gay rights group Stonewall, welcomed the comments. "We are delighted that the admiral has realised that what we have argued right from the start has worked out in practice.

"We never envisaged there would be any problems and we believe one of the causes of homophobia is imagined fear which never comes to fruition in reality."
