fields.headline: DNA testing
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair has announced plans to take DNA samples from every criminal in Britain. Julian Glover explains the issues surrounding the proposals
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has announced plans to take DNA samples from every criminal in Britain. We explain the issues surrounding the proposals.
fields.body:
What's the prime minister said?
In a speech to police officers in Kent, Tony Blair promised to provide an extra £109m in order to take DNA samples from everyone arrested in Britain. He claimed that the move would help the fight against crime by ensuring that samples "from virtually the entire criminally active population" are stored on a national database.

Why do the police want the samples?
Because DNA provides a genetic code which is almost unique to each human being. As with a fingerprint, this code can link an individual to the scene of a crime - and while criminals find it easy to avoid leaving fingerprints it is far harder to ensure nothing is left which might be tested for DNA. In particular, material which can be tested for DNA is often available in the cases of violent crimes such as rape and murder. Now police officers will be able to match the samples against a massive database.

Why has the PM announced the new funds now?
Because he is attempting to combat a widespread public perception that Labour is failing on the issue of law and order. Polls show that the Conservative party has pulled ahead on the issue. In response, ministers have been this week making a series of announcements on crime - including a bid by Jack Straw, the home secretary, to recruit more officers. Mr Blair's speech is part of this campaign.

And does his announcement mean anything in practice?
Yes - though it's not quite as significant as the PM claims. The police already have the power to take DNA samples from people they arrest and the national database is also in place. The prime minister's speech does not mean that the law will be changed. But until now, the high cost of DNA testing - £40 per test - has prevented its widespread use. It's only been used for serious crimes such as murder and as a result the national database contains only 940,000 samples. Now everyone who is arrested will be tested and the result will be a database of almost 4m samples by 2004.

Sounds like Big Brother. Is anyone worried by this?
Civil liberties campaigners are very concerned about misuse of the samples. They claim that the forensic science laboratory already contains 50,000 DNA samples which are held unlawfully. The police are required to destroy samples from everyone who is arrested but not convicted. Activists will be watching carefully to make sure this happens. But the prime minister insists that "the civil liberties argument is completely misplaced".

What happens abroad?
In the United States, campaigners against capital punishment are using DNA testing to prove that some people on death row are innocent. Because DNA evidence is so conclusive, this has had an impact on the way Americans see the death penalty. Several US states are also setting up DNA databases similar to those in Britain.

fields.headline: GUS to pay £36m for Jungle.com
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Jungle.com, one of the UK's best known e-commerce firms, is expected to be sold to Great Universal Stores, which owns the Argos catalogue stores, for around £36m. An announcement is expected today.
fields.body:
Jungle.com, one of the UK's best known e-commerce firms, is expected to be sold to Great Universal Stores, which owns the Argos catalogue stores, for around £36m. An announcement is expected today.

GUS is understood to have seen off rival approaches from retailers Kingfisher and Dixons Group to take control of Jungle.com, which had been planning a stock market flotation of its own as recently as three months ago.

Steve Bennett, Jungle's chief executive and leading shareholder, last night refused to comment on whether he was in talks with GUS but confirmed that both Kingfisher and Dixons had approached him.

"I will be making a major announcement about the future of the company from the safari park at Woburn Abbey at midday [today]," 34-year-old Mr Bennett said. He is presently hosting a suppliers' conference at the venue.

GUS declined to comment.

A high-profile advertising campaign has turned the computer and home entertainment retailer into one of the most visible e-commerce brands in Britain.

However, many observers will be surprised by how much the company's valuation has fallen since the start of the year.

In February, analysts were tentatively valuing the company as highly as £700m after investment bank UBS Warburg was appointed to examine a possible flotation.

However, the sell-off in high technology stocks forced Warburgs to dramatically scale back the figure and by June, Mr Bennett said, the bank was targeting a flotation value of around £180m.

A further depression in the value of e-commerce companies has forced Jungle's adviser to reduce the valuation to just £36m, including £10m in debt.

Mr Bennett says the company is expected to turnover around £100m this year.

It is understood that GUS plans to integrate Jungle into its Argos retail group, which it bought two years ago, and use it principally to sell computers and software. The division is run by Terry Duddy, a former chief executive of Dixons' PC World.

The Argos catalogue goes into 17m homes in Britain and Mr Duddy is thought to believe that he can build a serious rival to Dixons - which dominates PC sales in Britain - by leveraging the strength of that database online.

GUS has around 15 websites based on brands including Experian, Argos, Kays and Innovations. Tellingly, the company does not have a presence in the PC market.

Mr Bennett has previously said that if a flotation was not a possibility he would consider a link-up with a traditional bricks and mortar retailer.

Jungle was set up in the middle of last year with the £10m backing of venture capital group 3i. It holds a 25% stake. Mr Bennett had previously built up the Software Warehouse retail group with fund ing from 3i. The stores were sold to a management buyout team in May but Jungle took over its PC mail order business.

Jungle.com has spent in excess of £5m on television, radio and press advertising.

The company's corporate theme is The Lion Sleeps Tonight, a hit in the 1980s for Tight Fit.

Mr Bennett recently persuaded the band's lead singer to give up his job as an entertainer at a Butlin's holiday camp in Devon to help promote Jungle. In his spare time Mr Bennett is building an internet portal called GlobalShed.com, which will specialise in do-it-yourself activities, with the assistance of television's Big Breakfast presenter Johnny Vaughan.

fields.headline: Student held over internet hoax
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: The FBI yesterday arrested a man in connection with a bogus online news release which last week wiped $2bn (£1.3bn) from the stock market value of Emulex, a Californian networking company.
fields.body:
The FBI yesterday arrested a man in connection with a bogus online news release which last week wiped $2bn (£1.3bn) from the stock market value of Emulex, a Californian networking company.

Last night, the US attorney's office was due to file criminal charges alleging that the man made $250,000 from the hoax.

The suspect, understood to be a student in his 20s, was arrested at a house in Los Angeles.

No further details were released, although the man was expected to be charged with fraudulent use of the internet.

Shares in Emulex fell more than 50% last Friday after a bogus press release announced that it was in financial trouble. The release, disseminated by Internet Wire, an online public relations service, announced falsely that the company's chief executive had resigned, that it expected to lose money in the next quarter and that it had been forced by regulators to restate 1998 and 1999 earnings.

The report was picked up by Dow Jones and Bloomberg news wires and the share price of the company sank.

Stock market watchdogs such as the securities and exchange commission immediately launched an investigation, as did the FBI and US attorney's office. Civil action is also being considered.

The rapid spread of the news and devastating effect on Emulex's stock price has prompted a review of operations by several news services and public relations firms. Many fear that the growth on online news has encouraged the race to deliver news at the expense of fact checking.

The unnamed man is not the first to be held in custody for alleged internet fraud involving the financial markets in the US. A securities day trader was arrested in March for allegedly posting a bogus press release about Lucent Technologies.

fields.headline: Battersea power station
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about London's biggest industrial white elephant
fields.trailText: All you need to know about London's biggest industrial white elephant
fields.body:
1. Plans to turn the derelict Battersea power station in south London into a leisure complex have been given the go-ahead by Wandsworth council.

2. Work on the £500m project is expected to start next year after the council's planning committee unanimously backed a scheme to redevelop the 35-acre site.

3. The building has taken on an iconic presence on the banks of the Thames. Sir Ian McKellen starred in a 1995 film version of Shakespeare's Richard III, set in 1930s London, which used the industrial monolith as a backdrop.

4. And for reasons which remain mysterious, the progressive rock band Pink Floyd used an image of a pig flying between the towers of Battersea power station on the cover of their navel-gazing 1977 album Animals.

5. A 1927 proposal to site a large power station on the south bank of the Thames sparked controversy, with questions raised in parliament about the harm caused by possible pollution from Battersea to paintings in the nearby Tate gallery on Millbank.

6. Ironically, Battersea power station was the first choice of venue for the new Tate Modern. But financial considerations meant that the honour went to the smaller Bankside power station, east up the Thames at Southwark.

7. Both Bankside and Battersea power stations were designed by architect Sir Giles Gilbert Scott. He also created Liverpool's Anglican Cathedral, university libraries in Oxford and Cambridge, Waterloo Bridge in central London and the famous British red telephone box.

8. Battersea power station, with its four distinctive towers (added in 1953), Art Deco control room, Italian marble turbine hall, polished parquet floors and wrought iron staircases, is the largest brick building in Europe. It quickly won many admirers and was granted grade II listed status in 1980.

9. The station was the third largest in Britain, providing London with up to 509 megawatts of electricity for 50 years until its closure in 1983. It was bought from the Central Electricity Generating Board for £1.5m by developer John Broome, who planned to build an Alton Towers-style complex on the site. The roof was removed in 1988 for development, but costs spiralled after structural problems were discovered. Five years later the site was sold to Parkview.

10. Parkview plans to rebuild the roof and west wall in glass and convert the interior to nine separate levels. Four towers below the landmark chimneys will contain lifts and escape stairs, while one of the 370ft chimneys will house a "thrill ride". There will also be two hotels, a theatre, cinema, flats, rooftop restaurants and a dedicated rail link from Victoria station. English Heritage has described the plan as "the first scheme of real quality proposed for the power station".

fields.trailText: If you: (a) shift nervously in Terminal Three, distracting yourself with duty-free "shopping"; (b) always listen to safety announcements (wondering if the emergency exits open in or out) ; (c) applaud the pilot on take-off and landing; or (d) ask yourself over and over "am I going down?" (with specific reference to air travel), you can now indulge your flight paranoia with www.amigoingdown.com. This thoughtful website helps gauge the likelihood of a fatal fall from the sky by simply keying in your flight details. Flying from Moscow to Georgia with Air India? Chances of perishing are one in 163,654. "That's really not that good for this route," the site advises.

(with specific reference to air travel), you can now indulge your flight paranoia with www.amigoingdown.com. This thoughtful website helps gauge the likelihood of a fatal fall from the sky by simply keying in your flight details. Flying from Moscow to Georgia with Air India? Chances of perishing are one in 163,654. "That's really not that good for this route," the site advises.

Flying from London to Sierra Leone is a little less risky (one in 453,500). But if you are thinking about travelling to the troubled African country, then you should, perhaps, consider hiring a private army for your protection. Visit www.sandline.co.uk for the details - but make sure you are an internationally recognised government (preferably democratically elected) and not a rogue state, terrorist group or drug cartel, or they won't deal with you.

If you can't afford protection, equip yourself with a surrealist smokescreen culled from the surrealist compliment generator. "You are the Ayatollah of confusion on the night of Divali", should bamboozle any assailant long enough for you to make a run for the first flight home - if you're prepared to risk it.

Or you could just sit safely at your computer and wreak havoc on a nearby planet. The site www.janus.astro.umd .edu/astro/impact.html lets you simulate a solar collision. Choose your target (Earth), projectile size (5km diameter) and velocity (20km per second) and kaboom! You've made a crater 60km wide and 1km deep causing the largest-ever earthquake. Oh, and increased the risks of any flight leaving Moscow airport, too.

But if you are thinking about travelling to the troubled African country, then you should, perhaps, consider hiring a private army for your protection. Visit www.sandline.co.uk for the details - but make sure you are an internationally recognised government (preferably democratically elected) and not a rogue state, terrorist group or drug cartel, or they won't deal with you. "You are the Ayatollah of confusion on the night of Divali", should bamboozle any assailant long enough for you to make a run for the first flight home - if you're prepared to risk it. Choose your target (Earth), projectile size (5km diameter) and velocity (20km per second) and kaboom! You've made a crater 60km wide and 1km deep causing the largest-ever earthquake. fields.standfirst: Each week throughout the season, Football Unlimited's finest take on the bookies, and you the reader, in an attempt to find the betting champion. It's a marathon not a sprint, brought to you in association with Blue Square

fields.body:
Current totals:
Paul MacInnes = £104.97
Football Unlimited readers = £90
Sean Ingle = £87.19
Scott Murray = £84.62

Paul MacInnes

Holland v Republic of Ireland - Half-time draw/full-time Holland at 4-1: £6

Straying away from this weekend's main game, and looking for bets that end in a 1, I have backed the Dutch to come through a tough test in the Stadium on Saturday night. The Dutch are without several key players, including Jaap Stam, Marc Overmars, and Edgar Davids. The Irish meanwhile have acquitted themselves well in recent internationals abroad, although never quite achieving the result they were after (1-0 defeats by Croatia and the draw with Macedonia stand out from Euro 2000). I back this trend to continue.

This week's guest bet comes from Craig Thomas, a web developer from London

France v England - Thierry Henry first scorer, correct score 3-1 (to France) at 28-1: £7.50

I always like the combination of first scorer and final score, as you can quite often find good value. France are going to win, no doubt about that, and I don't think 3-1 is an unlikely score. Henry meanwhile scored two good goals against Charlton last week and if he isn't in form already he's certainly coming into it.

Sean Ingle

£20 accumulator on Israel to beat Liechenstein (1/20), Yugoslavia to beat Luxembourg (1/14), Brazil to beat Bolivia (1/8) and Sweden to beat Azerbaijan (1/5)

So Blue Square's betting expert doesn't like multiples? Well he won't after this beauty of a bet (he says setting himself up for another painful fall). Because if these likely-looking certs come off, I'll win about a tenner.

Let's start with the two most obvious bets. The erratic and temperamental Yugoslavs are surely good enough to put a goal or ten past Luxembourg. The same applies to Israel - who recently beat Russia in a friendly - who play Liechenstein. Slightly more risky (but only just) are my bets on Brazil to beat Bolivia and Sweden to beat Azerbaijan. Brazil have struggled lately, but Bolivia are ninth out of ten in the South American qualifiers and have lost all four of their away games so far. Finally, Azerbaijan - who cost me a small fortune when they drew against Portugal last year - surely won't be able to repeat the trick against Sweden, who have a great record away from home (during Euro 2000 they won at Bulgaria and Poland and drew against England at Wembley).

It all looks simple enough, and the combined bet pays about one-and-a-half to one. It's not a lot, but it's a start. So hopefully by Monday I'll be celebrating a small - and relatively safe - profit.

Scott Murray

£10 Treble: France to beat England (4/7); Germany to beat Greece (1/4); Holland to beat Republic of Ireland (2/5)

Three of the strongest countries in Europe - and, before you point an accusing finger at Germany, remember they've just tonked Spain 4-1 - should have no problems seeing off lesser opposition at home. I should win over two-and-a-half times my stake with this, and seeing I'd expect these teams to win these sort of games every time, I reckon that's good enough value.

Would you like to bet your life away? Send a mail to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk with a subject heading that goes something like "I have no moral qualms about betting with somebody else's money", and next week it could be you!

And don't forget to find out just how badly our betters have fared on Monday when Blue Sq's analyst Patrick Murray will help to steer them back onto the right path.

webTitle: The Empty Chair by Jeffery Deaver

fields.headline: The Empty Chair by Jeffery Deaver
fields.trailText: Disabled cop takes his New York sophistication to North Carolina and wups them Southern boys' asses
fields.body:
Lincoln Rhyme's specially adapted van pulled into the Avery medical centre in North Carolina. "Don't have the operation," Amelia Sachs, the devoted sidekick, said to New York's finest quadriplegic criminal scientist. Just after they arrived, Jim Bell of the Paquenoke County Sheriff's department knocked on the door.

"We sure could use some help," he said. "We've got two girls, Mary Beth and Lydia, kidnapped and a man killed. The perp, Garrett Hanlon, a 16-year-old screwball, is on the run in the swampland."

"We'll be right with you," said Rhyme.

"It won't be a pushover."

"Leave the crip gags to me."

"You could get lost for days north of the Paquo river," said Sachs over the radio, as she trawled through the undergrowth with three of Tanner Corner's finest.

"Not if you follow the evidence," growled Rhyme.

"I reckon he must have gone up to the quarry," said Sachs.

"I don't think so," replied Rhyme, studying his list of the physical evidence. "He's trying to fool us. He's at the mill."

"Got Garrett and Lydia. There's no sign of Mary Beth."

Reunited at Tanner's Corner, Sachs and Rhyme discussed the case. "I'm not so sure Garrett killed the man or meant any harm to the girls," said Sachs.

"That's not what the evidence says. And we still haven't found Mary Beth."

"We have ourselves a problem," said Jim Bell to Rhyme. "Your woman Sachs has busted Garrett out of jail and gone on the run. She's also shot and killed my lawman, Jesse Corn."

Rhyme had to help her. He studied the evidence. "She's trying to get Garrett to take her to Mary Beth. He wants us to think they've gone towards the ocean."

Mary Beth was safe. How did Rhyme track them down so quickly, wondered Sachs, as the cuffs were placed on her wrists.

Sachs stood in the dock, facing five to 10. "Any pleas?" asked the judge.

"Yes," said Rhyme. "Neither Sachs nor Garrett is guilty. The whole town, including half the police force, has been part of a conspiracy to manufacture and transport illegal pesticides and has been killing anyone who gets in their way. Jesse Corn was in on it, too."

"Case dismissed."

And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested

fields.headline: The birth - and future - of Big Brother
fields.standfirst: Big Brother has its origins in the Netherlands - where two contestants were filmed having steamy sex - and is poised to air in 13 countries this year.
fields.trailText: Big Brother has its origins in the Netherlands - where two contestants were filmed having steamy sex - and is poised to air in 13 countries this year.
fields.body:
The origins of Big Brother Endemol's original proposal for what became Big Brother drew its inspiration from the US Biosphere 2 project, was called Golden Cage and involved putting contestants in a mansion for a year. But it would have cost £15m to make the show, so the plan was scaled back to more manageable proportions.

Big Brother around the globe Different versions of Big Brother will air in 13 countries in the next few months. The show started out in the Netherlands last autumn, before popping up in Germany, Spain, the US and UK. Big Brother is poised to debut in Portugal, Switzerland, Sweden, Belgium, Denmark, Norway, South Africa and Poland, while Dutch and German audiences will this autumn get the chance to cast their eyes over a second group of 10 TV laboratory rats. The Dutch and US versions run for 100 days, compared with 64 days for the UK series.

The Netherlands A second series of Big Brother is due to air in the Netherlands - where it all began - on September 14. This time around, commercial broadcaster Veronica plans to break into regular evening programmes with news flashes from the Big Brother house. Veronica is also in talks with Dutch cable channels about a pay-TV or pay-per-view deal to put Big Brother on air around the clock. The prize money remains at 250,000 guilders (£68,681), but contestants will have to work harder to win it. They will be more isolated and have to bake their bread, tend a garden and be generally more self-sufficient, according to a Veronica spokeswoman. The biggest talking point of the first Dutch series was undoubtedly when two contestants, Bart Spring in't Veld - the eventual winner - and Sabine Wendel, were caught by an infrared camera having sex in Veld's bed. The first Dutch series drew an average 27.5% audience share across 100 editions, with 53% of the total TV audience tuning in for the finale. The accompanying website generated 52m page views during the show's run.

Germany The German version of Big Brother almost did not get made. Before going on air, the show came under fire from political and religious leaders, who claimed it would violate a clause in the German constitution that protects human dignity. The producers defused the protest by agreeing to turn off the cameras for an hour each day.

US (official US site: www.webcenter.bigbrother2000.aol.com/entertainment/NON/) At the end of the 10 US contestants' 100-day trial by media on July 5, one of them will walk away with in $500,000 (£344,000) in prize money. But the US version has suffered as a result of competition from Survivor, another "constructed reality" show that is also airing on CBS. Survivor, in which 16 contestants are stranded on a tropical island near Borneo and have to vote each other out of the show, with the winner scooping $1m (£685,000), began over a month before the US Big Brother. The show - which is based on a format owned by Charlie Parsons, co-founder of UK independent TV producer Planet 24 - has attracted huge viewing figures and similar, frenzied media attention. The Survivor finale, broadcast on Wednesday August 24, was watched by more than 51m Americans - making it the second highest rating CBS show ever.

webTitle: The final seconds of crashed Concorde

fields.headline: The final seconds of crashed Concorde
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: The final terrifying moments of Air France flight 4590 were revealed yesterday as French accident investigators released their preliminary report on July's Concorde crash outside Paris that killed 113 people.
fields.body:
The final terrifying moments of Air France flight 4590 were revealed yesterday as French accident investigators released their preliminary report on July's Concorde crash outside Paris that killed 113 people.

In a chilling transcript, the cockpit voice recorder graphically describes the final 77 seconds as the pilot, Christian Marty, struggles for control of the airliner, by now shooting flames from its left wing.

At 2.43pm, shortly after take-off, the control tower warned: "Concorde zero... 4590, you have flames. You have flames behind you."

The crew, unable to retract the undercarriage and losing power fast, tried desperately to reach nearby Le Bourget airport. Seven seconds after the first message from air traffic control, the chief navigator confirmed: "Breakdown engine two." Then, four seconds later: "Cut engine two."

As the aircraft tried to gain speed for an emergency landing, Mr Marty, in his last words, was heard to say: "Too late... No time." Just after 2.44pm, the co-pilot exclaimed: "Le Bourget, Le Bourget. Negative; we are trying Le Bourget." Sixteen seconds later, the recording ends. The plane ploughed into a hotel in the small town of Gonesse.

The crash prompted Air France to ground its remaining Concordes immediately; British Airways followed suit three weeks later.

The investigators from the French accident inquiry board, BEA, confirmed their earlier hypothesis that a burst tyre had set off the fatal chain of events that downed the New York-bound plane, killing all those on board - mainly German passengers and nine crew - and four people on the ground.

"The July 25 accident shows that the destruction of a tyre, an event that we cannot say will not recur, had catastrophic consequences... preventing the crew from rectifying the situation," the report said. "The crew had no way of knowing about the nature of the fire, nor any means of fighting it."

It confirmed that a metal strip, probably from another plane, had been found on the runway. "It has holes in it and in some of these holes appear to be Cherry aeronautical rivets. This strip has not been identified as coming from Concorde," the report said.

The BEA said last month that the 16-inch piece of metal had "almost certainly" gashed the Concorde's tyre, sending large chunks of rubber hurtling at tremendous speed into the plane's fuel tanks, contained in its delta-shaped wings, and sparking the blaze.

"At least one fuel tank was ruptured in one or more places, resulting in a substantial fuel leak. The leaking fuel caught light and a very violent fire ensued throughout the duration of the flight. Engine problems occurred in engine number two and, briefly, in engine number one," yesterday's interim report, released on the internet, said.

Over the 25 years Concorde has been in commercial operation, there have been at least seven incidents in which one or more of the plane's tyres have burst, leading to punctures in the wings or fuel tanks.

But in all of those incidents it was a piece of flying metal - from the undercarriage or water deflectors - that caused the damage, not tyre rubber itself. Safety efforts were therefore concentrated on strengthening all metal parts that could be broken off in a tyre burst, but not on protecting the wings.

"The crew had no way of knowing about the nature of the fire, nor any means of fighting it." It confirmed that a metal strip, probably from another plane, had been found on the runway. "It has holes in it and in some of these holes appear to be Cherry aeronautical rivets. This strip has not been identified as coming from Concorde," the report said. The BEA said last month that the 16-inch piece of metal had "almost certainly" gashed the Concorde's tyre, sending large chunks of rubber hurtling at tremendous speed into the plane's fuel tanks, contained in its delta-shaped wings, and sparking the blaze. "At least one fuel tank was ruptured in one or more places, resulting in a substantial fuel leak. The leaking fuel caught light and a very violent fire ensued throughout the duration of the flight. Engine problems occurred in engine number two and, briefly, in engine number one," yesterday's interim report, released on the internet, said. Over the 25 years Concorde has been in commercial operation, there have been at least seven incidents in which one or more of the plane's tyres have burst, leading to punctures in the wings or fuel tanks. But in all of those incidents it was a piece of flying metal - from the undercarriage or water deflectors - that caused the damage, not tyre rubber itself. Safety efforts were therefore concentrated on strengthening all metal parts that could be broken off in a tyre burst, but not on protecting the wings.

fields.headline: The proof of the pudding
fields.standfirst: Why can no one make a good Yorkshire pudding any more?  Victoria Moore fears for the future of her favourite dish
fields.trailText: Why can no one make a good Yorkshire pudding any more? Victoria Moore fears for the future of her favourite dish.
fields.body:
There are things I remember about childhood Sunday visits to my paternal grandma that I can still only see from the waist-high perspective of a six-year-old. The bottle of Robinson's lemon barley water in the cupboard under the drawer with the old tennis balls I played with on the drive. A copy of the Beano that tradition dictated would be "hidden" under the middle cushion of the coffee-coloured sofa. And the Pyrex jug, opaque with age and scratches, holding creamy Yorkshire pudding batter, standing beside the sprouts (already cooked half to death) on top of the stove.

Grandma was the queen of Yorkshire pudding-making and understandably proud. By contrast, my mother's tasted good but they always turned upside-down in their tins so they ended up looking like dumplings and there was no hole into which to pour your gravy.

In retrospect, I can see that this pleased grandma immeasurably: the secret of the successful Yorkshire pudding was passed down from generation to generation, mother to daughter, and so my grandmother was able to assume a proprietorial superiority over her daughter-in-law. Just as well, then, that she is no longer around. She would be appalled - and no doubt wickedly delighted - at my utter ineptitude when faced with the task of producing anything approaching an edible Yorkshire pudding.

I tried to make Yorkshire pudding last weekend and it was a disaster. One hundred phone calls home and fevered consultations with every recipe book on the kitchen shelf could not help me mix the batter to the consistency I recollected from grandma's kitchen. But I did get some things right. The roast beef was resting gracefully on top of the oven and the fat smoking in the tins when I poured in the mixture. Not enough of the mixture, as it turned out. I squatted on the floor and peered excitedly through the oven door, the better to observe the small miracle of the rising of the batter. Slowly, it coloured around the edges to a pale gold. Then, as I watched expectantly, each would-be pudding frazzled within seconds to a brittle, blackened disc. And that was that.

Which got me thinking that, in this ready-cooked age, there might be a danger of the ability to make such an irreplaceable and delicious part of our culinary heritage as Yorkshire pudding dying out. When my mother was my age - 26 - she had a one-year-old daughter and had been cooking a weekly family roast with all its accoutrements for the past four years.

I, on the other hand, have spent the past four years getting out of bed late at the weekend and rustling up bacon sarnies. In any given six months I eat more restaurant dinners than my parents have enjoyed in their entire lives. I practically have a degree in ordering from Indian takeaways. Of course, I cook too, but it tends to be "assemblage" food, hastily thrown together when I arrive home at 8.30pm after a depleting slog across London on the Tube. Pan-fried salmon steaks; caesar salad fresh from its cellophane bag; spaghetti alla puttanesca; carpaccio of beef and warm potato salad; marinated chicken kebabs ... this is what my generation mean by cooking. No one, repeat no one, of my age and acquaintance has ever even tried to make a Yorkshire pudding.

I first began to fear for the future of the Yorkshire pudding when I ordered it at the Mirabelle, Marco Pierre White's elegant London restaurant. Marco Pierre White's fiery brusqueness and his Yorkshire pedigree are well-documented. So it seems fair to suppose that he, of all people, would not struggle to make a fine pudding. For, as Jennifer Stead writes in her essay Yorkshire Pudding and Parkin: "The fact that they require spanking-hot fat, explosions as the batter hits it, fierce heat, and crisp results, may explain why it has often been said that only Yorkshire folk - those possessing the Yorkshire temperament - can make a true Yorkshire pudding."

Alas, the Mirabelle's Yorkshire pudding was a grave disappointment. Its first sin was to come on the plate alongside the meat and vegetables. Sacrilege! The whole point of Yorkshire pudding when it was originally made in the 18th century was that it was a cheap way of taking the edge off hearty appetites before they fell to devouring the meat. It also tastes better that way.

Jesiah Oakroyd, in JB Priestley's The Good Companions, puts it best: "A Yorkshire pudding is eaten by itsen and not mixed up wi' meat and potaters, all in a mush." Even worse, the Mirabelle's Yorkshire pudding was yellowy and rich-tasting, as if extra eggs and extra milk had been used. Someone in the kitchen seemed to be trying to spruce up a centuries-old pauper's recipe to make it more appealing to toffs. And it was as pale and soft as they are. What folly! As Jesiah explains: "If you've mixed right and your oven's hot, pudding'll come out as light as a feather, crisp and brarn, just a top and a bottom, you might say, wi' none o' this custardy stuff in t'middle." Quite obviously the Mirabelle's designer version will do nothing to preserve our Yorkshire pudding heritage. Still, I optimistically put it down to the Mirabelle being rather an effete, southern sort of place.

Then, the other week, returning to my favourite Leeds pub at the start of the football season, I ordered Yorkshire pudding as I always do. How I looked forward to its arrival, slopped over with onion gravy, almost burned on top and just-soft on the underbelly. But a stealing dread set in when I saw that it had trebled in price since I last ate it and that it was chalked up with a range of four fillings. It had stopped being an ordinary Yorkshire meal and become an olde pubbe gimmick. My worst fears were realised when the plate was set before me. It wasn't properly cooked. Its pale and doughy bottom filled most of the plate. I couldn't eat it.

But if I, a true-born Yorkshire woman, and Marco Pierre White, a trueborn Yorkshire chef, and the Whitelocks pub in Leeds cannot make a decent Yorkshire pudding, then who can?

It is time to go back to basics. Early Yorkshire puddings were baked underneath the spit-roast and drenched in the rich juices that fell from the cooking meat. They were also made in a vast rectangular tin and cut into squares to be served. The batter is made from a milk, water, eggs and flour (no one should be tempted to replace water with luxurious milk). It goes without saying that a northern recipe must be used. (For what would a southerner know? I have even heard of some who fondly imagines that Yorkshire pudding is always served with jam.) Even then don't expect it to be easy. Prise a recipe from any northerner and you will find it full of words like "by guesswork" and "you just know" and "when it's ready". Not very helpful.

My grandmother's recipe is no more obliging. She used one heaped tablespoon of plain flour per person, plus one extra, and one egg per person (quite generous on the eggs, this recipe). Put the flour into a bowl or jug and stir in a little salt. Make a well in the flour and crack in the eggs. With a fork gradually beat in the eggs, slowly gathering up more flour from the sides and bottom of the bowl. When the mixture is smooth slowly beat in "some" milk and "a little" water (I told you it wouldn't be precise) until the batter achieves the "right" consistency.

The right consistency is when it just coats the back of a spoon. Beat hard for five minutes. Now leave the batter to stand for a good half hour at least. When you've done this you might find it needs a little more liquid (a little more guesswork required here). Next skim the fat, or beef dripping, from the juices that have collected round your roast and use it to grease the Yorkshire pudding tins. Put the tins on the top shelf of a belting hot oven until the fat is really smoking hot. Pour in the batter, pop them in the oven "until they're ready".

If all this still sounds like too much trouble, and if you really have to, the supermarket shelves are piled with ready-made versions - testament to the fact that we like to eat but cannot make Yorkshire puddings. The ubiquitous Aunt Bessie's simply requires a little reheating. Sainsbury's own-brand ones come, uncooked and frozen, in individual little foil saucers, and you have the pleasure of watching them puff up into perfectly shaped puddings in the oven. And I don't want to be too complimentary but they don't taste bad either. Good enough, at least, for southerners.

webTitle: Vaz blames press for dislike of EU

fields.headline: Vaz blames press for dislike of EU
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Keith Vaz, the minister for Europe, will today attack Britain's rightwing press, accusing newspapers of turning voters against the European Union with a stream of scare stories.
fields.body:
Keith Vaz, the minister for Europe, will today attack Britain's rightwing press, accusing newspapers of turning voters against the European Union with a stream of scare stories.

In a speech to business leaders in Cardiff, Mr Vaz will warn that the Sun, the Daily Telegraph and others are among the main obstacles to reversing the decline in public support for the EU.

"All too often we see articles and opinion pieces that either misrepresent policy or deal with fiction rather than fact," he will tell the Cardiff chamber of commerce.

"By politicising straightforward issues or even spreading anti-EU propaganda, they are clouding the debate."

Mr Vaz, who will be speaking as part of the government Your Britain, Your Europe campaign to promote the EU, highlights a spate of press reports that the EU's proposed charter of rights would spell disaster for businesses in Britain.

"The story goes that the charter will introduce a raft of rights for workers which will undermine one of our key economic strengths, our flexible labour market.

"Let me set the record straight. EU leaders agreed that the fundamental rights currently enjoyed by EU citizens should be written down in one place in a charter.

"But the [British] government will not agree to incorporate [additional] new rights or rights that would damage business."

His speech echoes an attack on the rightwing press earlier this summer by the prime minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell.

Ministers believe that they will find themselves struggling to make the case for joining the euro in the face of a Eurosceptic press.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, will reinforce Mr Vaz's message this weekend when he tells his European counterparts that Britain wants to join the "grown-up" debate about the future of Europe, despite hostile media coverage in the UK.

webTitle: UK ad agencies in global consolidation drive

fields.headline: Advertising industry rides wave of global consolidation
fields.standfirst: Following in the footsteps of agencies' international clients, the past year has seen the face of the UK's advertising industry change rapidly with a fresh round of mergers and acquisitions
fields.trailText: Following in the footsteps of agencies' international clients, the past year has seen the face of the UK's advertising industry change rapidly with a fresh round of mergers and acquisitions. Claire Cozens reports
fields.body:
Not since Saatchi & Saatchi launched its ill-fated bid for Midland Bank has the advertising industry been seen to embrace consolidation so enthusiastically. Having lagged behind the companies they serve for more than a decade, ad agencies have in the past year rushed to buy, or be bought, in an often bewilderingly rapid feeding frenzy.

This activity is a belated mirroring of what has been happening among their multinational clients. As global industries consolidate, they are looking increasingly for a single company that will cater for all of their ad requirements worldwide. It means there are fewer, but much larger and more lucrative, ad accounts in play, so smaller agencies will find it more difficult to survive as global clients seek to work with the biggest global agencies.

According to Paul Richards, a media analyst at stockbroking firm WestLB Panmure, the other major factor behind the drive to consolidate is a desire for economies of scale. "Each of the big groups wants to have two, maybe even three, global ad agencies. It's not just ad agencies - economies of scale are particularly important to media buying agencies. And there's a whole range of below-the-line activities - healthcare, PR, direct marketing - that clients now expect their agencies to offer."

But until recently, ad industry efforts to consolidate have been severely hampered by conflicting client interest. Advertisers do not like to use agencies that work for rivals in their sector, just as they rarely employ professional advisers who work for direct competitors. A proposed merger between the French group Publicis and Young & Rubicam of the US was scuppered recently when Y&R's biggest client, Ford, objected on the grounds that Publicis handles ads for rival car manufacturer Renault.

Perhaps the most notorious example is Procter & Gamble. As the world's biggest advertiser, it wields enormous power over its agencies. Until recently, P&G refused to allow its four main agency networks - Saatchi & Saatchi, Grey Advertising, Leo Burnett and MacManus - to belong to the same holding company as an agency handling competitor's work. The most extreme illustration of P&G's draconian rules came when Saatchi & Saatchi demerged from Cordiant Communications in 1997 because its status as a P&G roster agency meant Bates Worldwide - Cordiant's other agency network - could not pitch for any household product advertisers.

But early last year P&G, realising that its rules meant it no longer had the world's biggest and most powerful agencies on its roster, let it be known quietly that any moves towards expansion would be looked on favourably. This has acted as a catalyst to industry consolidation and, in the past year alone, the balance of power has changed dramatically.

The first P&G agencies to oblige were the US groups MacManus (owner of the UK's D'Arcy and IMP agencies) and Leo Burnett, which owns the UK agency Bartle Bogle Hegarty. Last November, the two of them linked up with Japan's largest ad agency, Dentsu, to form the oddly-named B Com3 (according to its founders, the name is derived from "beacon"). B Com3 is now the world's fourth-largest ad organisation, behind Britain's WPP and Omnicom and IPG of the US, and it is expected to use its forthcoming flotation to bankroll further acquisitions.

It was assumed that Saatchi & Saatchi would follow suit and merge with Grey Advertising, which is publicly quoted but controlled by its 73-year-old chairman and chief executive, Ed Meyer. But in June Publicis, having lost out on a deal with Y&R, surprised the industry by launching a $2bn (£1.3bn) friendly takeover of Saatchi & Saatchi. The move created the world's fifth-largest ad company, with substantial media buying interests in the form of Publicis' Optimedia and Saatchi & Saatchi's 50% stake in Zenith Media.

Earlier in the year, Publicis scored a coup when it bought the privately-owned US ad hot shop Fallon McElligott - known for its award-winning creative work. But this proved to be a mere hors d'oeuvre for the French group's acquisition-hungry chairman, Maurice Levy, who has seen Publicis leap up the global agency rankings - from tenth to fifth - in less than a year.

But the most dramatic shift in the global agency rankings came in May when the London-listed WPP group added Y&R to its two agency networks: J Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather. The $4.7bn (£3.2bn) deal meant WPP leapfrogged its two US rivals, Omnicom and IPG, to become the biggest ad services company in the world. The merger created a gold standard by giving WPP many of the biggest names across all marketing disciplines, including direct marketing and media buying.

WPP is now expected to merge its media arm, and the world's largest media specialist, MindShare with Y&R's the Media Edge - ranked fourth. For the year to December 31 1999, the combined group had revenues of $5.2bn (£3.5bn).

In addition to bringing three of the world's leading ad agencies under one roof, the deal united four of the biggest public relations agencies: WPP's Hill & Knowlton and Ogilvy Public Relations, and Y&R's Burston-Marsteller and Cohn & Wolfe, as well as Y&R's below-the-line agency, Impiric, and WPP's OgilvyOne.

So, after contenting itself with two agencies for years, WPP has fallen into line with the US trend of having three. Both of the other ad super-groups - Omnicom and IPG - adopted the three-legged model in the 1990s. IPG departed from the norm last year when it merged Ammirati Puris Lintas with Lowe, but that was in anticipation of acquiring another agency.

The multi-agency structure makes sense because it allows companies to take on conflicting business by keeping their agency subsidiaries separate. But even this system has its limitations. Even though P&G has softened its conflict policy, any links between its agencies and those that handle work for its biggest rival Unilever are still out of the question. And car manufacturers, particularly in the US, still insist on the rigorous demarcation of agency groups, with General Motors using Interpublic, Ford employing Y&R and Daimler Chrysler using True North Communications.

Nevertheless, WestLB Panmure's Richards believes there is considerable scope for further consolidation. He says: "It's still a very fragmented industry. WPP, the biggest player, still has only a few per cent of the total market, so there is room for a lot more consolidation. Cordiant and True North is a likely deal. They are two medium-sized agencies and, geographically speaking, they are a good fit. Cordiant is strong in Europe but weaker in the US, whereas True North is strong in the US but needs to improve its European capability. Grey is a good match for Publicis Saatchi."

Cordiant chairman Michael Bungey admitted recently that he had held talks with True North, and a string of recent acquisitions suggest he is fattening up the company for a sale. Cordiant executives are thought to be holding out for the £1.2bn Publicis paid for Saatchi & Saatchi - a company of a similar size. The group is also thought to have held talks with IPG, which has been seeking a major acquisition since its attempts to buy MacManus failed last year. Either way, Cordiant is unlikely to remain independent for long. And once it has been snapped up, only one top 20 UK agency - M&C Saatchi - will remain independent.

It is a far cry from 15 years ago, when the UK top 20 was dominated by home-grown independent agencies such as Dorland Advertising (now Bates UK) and BMP, now part of Omnicom's DDB network, and the UK outposts of US ad giants such as JWT and O&M.

The Saatchi brothers, following their unceremonious ousting five years ago from Saatchi & Saatchi, the agency they built up from scratch, are expected to think carefully about ceding control of M&C Saatchi. But, realistically, their attempts to build a global network are unlikely to succeed in the face of competition from the new super-groups. Recent press reports suggest M&C would consider joining the new Publicis/Saatchi grouping, although this theory seems to owe more to the famous Saatchi spin than good commercial sense.

Ironically, it was Saatchi & Saatchi that started the trend towards industry consolidation when, more than a decade ago, it embarked on an ambitious buying spree aimed at turning it into a global one-stop shop for business services. The agency expanded from ads into direct marketing, sales promotion and PR, before coming unstuck when it tried to move into financial services. Now it seems Martin Sorrell, former finance director at Saatchi & Saatchi and now chairman of WPP, is showing them how it is done.

This has acted as a catalyst to industry consolidation and, in the past year alone, the balance of power has changed dramatically. The first P&G agencies to oblige were the US groups MacManus (owner of the UK's D'Arcy and IMP agencies) and Leo Burnett, which owns the UK agency Bartle Bogle Hegarty. Last November, the two of them linked up with Japan's largest ad agency, Dentsu, to form the oddly-named B Com3 (according to its founders, the name is derived from "beacon"). B Com3 is now the world's fourth-largest ad organisation, behind Britain's WPP and Omnicom and IPG of the US, and it is expected to use its forthcoming flotation to bankroll further acquisitions. It was assumed that Saatchi & Saatchi would follow suit and merge with Grey Advertising, which is publicly quoted but controlled by its 73-year-old chairman and chief executive, Ed Meyer. But in June Publicis, having lost out on a deal with Y&R, surprised the industry by launching a $2bn (£1.3bn) friendly takeover of Saatchi & Saatchi. The move created the world's fifth-largest ad company, with substantial media buying interests in the form of Publicis' Optimedia and Saatchi & Saatchi's 50% stake in Zenith Media. Earlier in the year, Publicis scored a coup when it bought the privately-owned US ad hot shop Fallon McElligott - known for its award-winning creative work. But this proved to be a mere hors d'oeuvre for the French group's acquisition-hungry chairman, Maurice Levy, who has seen Publicis leap up the global agency rankings - from tenth to fifth - in less than a year. But the most dramatic shift in the global agency rankings came in May when the London-listed WPP group added Y&R to its two agency networks: J Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather. The $4.7bn (£3.2bn) deal meant WPP leapfrogged its two US rivals, Omnicom and IPG, to become the biggest ad services company in the world. The merger created a gold standard by giving WPP many of the biggest names across all marketing disciplines, including direct marketing and media buying. WPP is now expected to merge its media arm, and the world's largest media specialist, MindShare with Y&R's the Media Edge - ranked fourth. For the year to December 31 1999, the combined group had revenues of $5.2bn (£3.5bn). In addition to bringing three of the world's leading ad agencies under one roof, the deal united four of the biggest public relations agencies: WPP's Hill & Knowlton and Ogilvy Public Relations, and Y&R's Burston-Marsteller and Cohn & Wolfe, as well as Y&R's below-the-line agency, Impiric, and WPP's OgilvyOne. So, after contenting itself with two agencies for years, WPP has fallen into line with the US trend of having three. Both of the other ad super-groups - Omnicom and IPG - adopted the three-legged model in the 1990s. IPG departed from the norm last year when it merged Ammirati Puris Lintas with Lowe, but that was in anticipation of acquiring another agency. The multi-agency structure makes sense because it allows companies to take on conflicting business by keeping their agency subsidiaries separate. But even this system has its limitations. Even though P&G has softened its conflict policy, any links between its agencies and those that handle work for its biggest rival Unilever are still out of the question. And car manufacturers, particularly in the US, still insist on the rigorous demarcation of agency groups, with General Motors using Interpublic, Ford employing Y&R and Daimler Chrysler using True North Communications. Nevertheless, WestLB Panmure's Richards believes there is considerable scope for further consolidation. He says: "It's still a very fragmented industry. WPP, the biggest player, still has only a few per cent of the total market, so there is room for a lot more consolidation. Cordiant and True North is a likely deal. They are two medium-sized agencies and, geographically speaking, they are a good fit. Cordiant is strong in Europe but weaker in the US, whereas True North is strong in the US but needs to improve its European capability. Grey is a good match for Publicis Saatchi." Cordiant chairman Michael Bungey admitted recently that he had held talks with True North, and a string of recent acquisitions suggest he is fattening up the company for a sale. Cordiant executives are thought to be holding out for the £1.2bn Publicis paid for Saatchi & Saatchi - a company of a similar size. The group is also thought to have held talks with IPG, which has been seeking a major acquisition since its attempts to buy MacManus failed last year. Either way, Cordiant is unlikely to remain independent for long. And once it has been snapped up, only one top 20 UK agency - M&C Saatchi - will remain independent. It is a far cry from 15 years ago, when the UK top 20 was dominated by home-grown independent agencies such as Dorland Advertising (now Bates UK) and BMP, now part of Omnicom's DDB network, and the UK outposts of US ad giants such as JWT and O&M. The Saatchi brothers, following their unceremonious ousting five years ago from Saatchi & Saatchi, the agency they built up from scratch, are expected to think carefully about ceding control of M&C Saatchi. But, realistically, their attempts to build a global network are unlikely to succeed in the face of competition from the new super-groups. Recent press reports suggest M&C would consider joining the new Publicis/Saatchi grouping, although this theory seems to owe more to the famous Saatchi spin than good commercial sense. Ironically, it was Saatchi & Saatchi that started the trend towards industry consolidation when, more than a decade ago, it embarked on an ambitious buying spree aimed at turning it into a global one-stop shop for business services. The agency expanded from ads into direct marketing, sales promotion and PR, before coming unstuck when it tried to move into financial services. Now it seems Martin Sorrell, former finance director at Saatchi & Saatchi and now chairman of WPP, is showing them how it is done.

fields.headline: Shaft Collection, by Armani
fields.trailText: Long the designer of choice for the more stylish Los Angeles crowd (Michelle Pfeiffer, Jodie Foster and Matt Damon, to name but a few), Giorgio Armani is the true king of Hollywood.
fields.body:
Long the designer of choice for the more stylish Los Angeles crowd (Michelle Pfeiffer, Jodie Foster and Matt Damon, to name but a few), Giorgio Armani is the true king of Hollywood.

His designs are not just to be spotted on the backs of actors strolling along red carpets but on the screen itself. Movie-loving Armani has designed the wardrobes of such credible and aesthetically pleasing films as The Untouchables, Batman (though not the batsuit) and The Grifters. He even managed to turn Richard Gere into a style icon in the 1980 film, American Gigolo. In fact, his wardrobe attracted so much attention that Gere was prompted to ask: "Who's acting in this scene, me or the jacket?"

The appeal of the original Shaft film lay mainly in its quality of cool, so who other than Armani could better design the wardrobe of the update? To coincide with the film's release on September 15, he has launched a Shaft collection for men and women, available at Emporio Armani in London, Glasgow and Manchester for a limited time from September 8. Even better, all Shaft collection customers get a free CD of the film's soundtrack thrown in for a good measure, and images of the New York City skyline will adorn the shopfront windows.

Fulfil those dreams of being Richard Roundtree or Samuel L Jackson by sporting clothes inspired by the film - a men's full-length leather coat (£750), perhaps, or a beanie hat (£39), or maybe a mohair rollneck (£169). Just try to walk down the street in these babies without a strut in your step and a click in your fingers, especially when you are grooving to your new CD. Enquiries: 020-7823 8818.

fields.trailText: Sharon Stone's vanity cases: Ice cream: Charlie's Angels flicks
fields.body:
Most wanted: Sharon Stone's vanity cases

Vanity cases are strange objects. Carrying your beauty products separately in an indestructible feminised toolbox is a bit like having "high maintenance" henna-tattooed on your forehead. Especially since you can't carry those cases without bruising your shins, and therefore require a porter.

Of course, Joan Collins et al would insist they are strictly practical - must keep the caviar eye cream away from the Oscar de la Renta mink stole - and they are nothing short of essential for that luxury travel vibe. Now Sharon Stone, not a woman who turns right when she gets on a plane, has designed a collection of vanity cases for Louis Vuitton.

Stone's luxurious creations come in hard-sided and soft tote versions of Vuitton's signature monogram canvas, with all proceeds going to the American Foundation for Aids Research. When the beauty cases reach the stores this month, prepare to gush over the lush design details: glass trays for mixing foundation or lipstick, soft red leather storage drawers and make-up bags that double as evening bags with the help of an additional strap. So you had better make sure you put the right lotions and potions inside: no supermarket own brand shampoo, please. Prices start at £5,300 for the small hard case and £385 for the soft tote bag. Enquiries: 020-7399 4050.

Most popular: ice cream

Best selling Häagen-Dazs flavours at The Odeon, Leicester Square (020-7930 6111) 1Vanilla 2Strawberry Cheesecake 3Cookies & Cream.

Most everywhere: Charlie's Angels flicks

The film version of Charlie's Angels isn't even out yet, but girls all over town are already looking like a walking, talking trailer for the return of their jumpsuit-wearing childhood heroines, thanks to the revival of the flick hairstyle. Last seen on Grange Hill's Michelle about 15 years ago, the flick will forever be associated with Farrah Fawcett, although the currently modish version has been subtly reworked for the 21st century. This is the look Fawcett would have gone for had she made a living selling fringed leather belts in Spitalfields market.

A masterpiece of elegant structural engineering, the flick is the Golden Gate bridge of hairdressing: awe-inspiring, gravity-defying and often terrifying. Not so much a wave as a tsunami.

But while Farrah's wind-machine flick was, in its way, a sensible way of keeping hair out of the eyes while karate-chopping baddies, 2000 version, as modelled by pop princesses Britney Spears and Billie Piper in their new videos, sweeps down to rest on the eyelashes.

It also involves an exaggerated side-parting, not dissimilar to the kind sported by men misguidedly trying to hide their bald patch with a few sad strands of hair, which has to be maintained by crooking the head to the side in the manner of a lead singer in a New Romantic pop band. Don't come moaning to me when you have to make a running leap on to a moving helicopter and can't see through your fringe.

webTitle: Retirement no bar to model riches

fields.headline: Retirement no bar to model riches
fields.trailText: If you want to make money out of modelling, get off the catwalk. That is the surprise finding of a new survey of the world's richest models, which places Cindy Crawford at the top of the supermodel rich list for the first time - despite having bowed out of catwalk and editorial modelling years ago.
fields.body:
If you want to make money out of modelling, get off the catwalk. That is the surprise finding of a new survey of the world's richest models, which places Cindy Crawford at the top of the supermodel rich list for the first time - despite having bowed out of catwalk and editorial modelling years ago.

With a personal wealth estimated at £23m, Ms Crawford has overtaken Australian supermodel Elle Macpherson (£22.3m), according to Business Age magazine.

Ms Crawford, who once said she "has to work all the time for the Cindy Crawford brand", epitomises the trend of supermodel turned superbusinesswoman. After cutting back on catwalk commitments a decade ago to raise her profile as a presenter on MTV, she has enjoyed lucrative contracts with Revlon cosmetics, Omega watches and Pepsi, and in January of this year landed £5m to be the face of Special K cereal. The 34-year-old has also made a series of successful fitness videos.

Most of the names on the list have made the bulk of their wealth through advertising campaigns, endorsements and investments rather than on the catwalks of New York or Milan.

German supermodel Claudia Schiffer, third with £19.5m, earns £300,000 a year from her swimsuit calendar alone and has appeared in advertisements for Citroen cars.

Ms Macpherson, known as "the Body", has her own lingerie line and has enjoyed some success as an actress, while Christy Turlington, seventh with £13m, has launched clothing and skincare ranges.

Kate Moss is the wealthiest British model, fifth with a fortune of £14.8m. She is one place ahead of Naomi Campbell, who is worth £14m. Ms Campbell once said she earned £5m a year, claiming the figure would be twice that if she were white. Linda Evangelista, the Canadian-born model whose comment that she "wouldn't get out of bed for less than $10,000" came to define supermodels in the early 90s, is fourth with £16.7m.

fields.trailText: Southampton manager Glenn Hoddle has scrapped a bid for Vegard Heggem after Liverpool put a £4m price tag on the out-of-favour defender, reports the Sun.
fields.body:
Southampton manager Glenn Hoddle has scrapped a bid for Vegard Heggem after Liverpool put a £4m price tag on the out-of-favour defender, reports the Sun.

Everton are "in the frame" to sign Inter Milan defender Cyril Domoraud, according to Planet Football's "sources in Italy". Walter Smith is believed to have made contact with the 29-year-old Ivory Coast international, but faces stiff competition from Spanish side Celta Vigo.

Manchester City have taken Nigerian international defender Godwin Okpara on trial. The 28-year-old is out of favour at Paris St Germain and is available for £1m."We are talking to Godwin to have a look at each other," admitted the City manager, Joe Royle.

Arsene Wenger is expected to travel to Latvia this weekend to watch Andrejs Rubins and Igor Stepanov play against Scotland.

Newcastle are ready to sign Chilean Clarence Acuna when he ends a four-month drugs ban later this month, reports the Sun. Acuna is currently on a 10-day trial at the club in the hope of clinching a £2m move from University of Chile.

And the Sun also claims that IFK Gothenberg midfielder Par Karlsson will join Wimbledon on a Bosman free transfer when the Swedish season ends next month.

Charlton have opened talks with Leicester City striker Tony Cottee.

webTitle: Transcript: The last two minutes of agony

fields.headline: The last two minutes of agony
fields.trailText: 13.58 Crew contacts control tower to plan pre-flight sequence.
fields.body:
13.58 Crew contacts control tower to plan pre-flight sequence.

14.07 Controller gives permission to start, confirms runway 26 right as requested by crew.

14.34 Ground controller gives the plane permission to taxi toward the runway.

14.42 and 17 seconds Controller. "Air France 4590, runway 26 right, wind zero 90 knots, authorized takeoff."

14.42.21 Co-pilot: "4590 taking off 26 right; (sound of switch).

14.42.24 Pilot: "Is everyone ready?;

14.42.25 Co-pilot: "Yes."

14.42.26 Mechanic: "Yes."

14.42.26 Pilot: "Up to 100, 150; (followed by unclear words, sound of switch).

14.42.31 "Top; (noise similar to engines increasing power).

14:42.35 Unidentified voice on radio channel: "Go on, Christian."

14.42.43 Mechanic: "We have four heated up; (sound of switch).

14.42.54 Co-pilot: "100 knots."

14.42.55 Pilot: "Confirmed."

14.42.57 Mechanic: "Four green."

14.43.03 Co-pilot: "V one; (Low-frequency noise).

14.43.11 Pilot: (unclear)

14.43.13 Co-pilot: "Watch out."

14.43.13 Controller: "Concorde zero ... 4590, you have flames (unclear) you have flames behind you."

14.43.16 Unidentified voice (simultaneously on radio) "Right; (background noise changes, sound of switch).

14:43.16 Mechanic: "Stop (unclear)."

14.43.18 Co-pilot: "Well received."

14.43.20 Mechanic: "Breakdown, eng, breakdown engine two; (two sounds of switches, followed by fire alarm).

14.43.22 Unidentified voice on radio: "It's burning badly, huh; (Gong)

14.43.24 Mechanic: "Cut engine two."

14.43.25 Pilot: "Engine fire procedure; (sound of switch, end of ringing).

14.43.27 Co-pilot: "Warning, the airspeed indicator, the airspeed indicator, the airspeed indicator; (sound of switch, gong).

14.43.28 Person in control tower: "It's burning badly and I'm not sure it's coming from the engine; (Switch sound similar to fire extinguisher handle being activated).

14.43.30 Pilot: "Gear on the way up."

14.43.31 Controller: "4590, you have strong flames behind you."

14.43.32 Mechanic: "The gear; (alarm, similar to toilet smoke alert).

14.43.34 Controller: "Beginning reception of a Middle Marker.

14.43.34 Co-pilot: "Yes, well received."

14.43.35 Mechanic: "The gear, no; (Gong).

14.43.37 Controller: "So, at your convenience, you have priority to land."

14.43.37 Mechanic "Gear."

14.43.38 Co-pilot: "No; (two switch noises).

14.43.39 Pilot: "Gear (unclear), coming up."

14.43.41 Co-pilot: "Well received; (fire alarm, gong, three switch sounds).

14.43.45 Co-pilot: "I'm trying (unclear)."

14.43.45 Mechanic: "I'm hitting."

14.43.46 Pilot: "Are (unclear) you cutting engine two; (end of smoke alarm).

14.43.48 Mechanic: "I've cut it."

14.43.49 Controller: "End reception Middle Marker."

14.43.49 Co-pilot: "The airspeed indicator; (sound of switch, end of ringing).

14.43.56 Co-pilot: "The gear won't come up; (fire alarm rings).

14.43.59 Aircraft instrument: "Whoop whoop pull up; (GPWS alarm, gong).

14.44 (4.44 pm) Aircraft instrument: "Whoop whoop pull up; (GPWS alarm).

14.44 Co-pilot: "The airspeed indicator."

14.44.02 Aircraft instrument: "Whoop whoop pull up; (GPWS alarm).

fields.headline: Dot.gones and not gones
fields.standfirst: Many City analysts predicted that the demise of Boo.com would put a chain dot.com collapses in motion. But as weaker players teeter on the brink, big-name dot.coms remain defiant. By Dan Milmo.
fields.trailText: Many City analysts predicted that the demise of Boo.com would put a chain dot.com collapses in motion. But as weaker players teeter on the brink, big-name dot.coms remain defiant. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Dot.com doom-mongers have been predicting a website clearout ever since the spectacular collapse of online fashion retailer Boo.com in May. But big-name companies have held their heads above water and defied the circling stock market vultures.

The much-slated Lastminute.com disappointed many sceptics in August by displaying signs of vitality when it bought French rival Degriftour for £58m. But venture capital funding has dried up and left bigger companies with enough money to run for, at best, one more year, so further casualties are inevitable. In the meantime, Boo has only a few companions in dot.com oblivion.

Boo.com: the Titanic of dot.com start-ups Boo spent investors' money with zeal but generated little revenue. The company folded in May after Swedish co-founders Ernst Malmsten and Kajsa Leander spent £115m in 18 months, leaving debts totalling £25m. The much-vaunted website was crammed with complex data that jammed customers' computers, while money was lavished on transatlantic flights for senior management and numerous other perks. Not surprisingly, some staff said they had the most enjoyable year of their life at Boo's Carnaby Street offices.

Dressmart

In August, Dressmart joined Boo in the Swedish online retailer scrapyard. The Stockholm-based company went into administration with debts of £2m and let down backers rumoured to include the king of Sweden and a former Swedish prime minister. The company was founded in April 1998 and raised more than £13m in funding. Swedish fashion company New Wave was poised to buy Dressmart's trading system, but the deal was scuppered by sceptical shareholders, who clearly knew better.

Clickmango.com

John Cleese was the celebrity face of Dressmart, but Clickmango.com's choice of Joanna Lumley might not be enough to save the online health and beauty retailer. Atlas Venture provided most of the £3m funding to start the company, but decided to bail out when the e-retail market failed to take-off. Clickmango had a turnover of only £2,000 a week, although loyal investors and staff have made it possible for the company to operate into September. It has struggled against rivals such as the heavily backed ThinkNatural.com.

LeisurePlanet.com

This travel site called in the receivers in August, offering the convoluted excuse that it was a "direct consequence of the changed market conditions whereby capital is no longer available to fund ambitious business-to-consumer plans that incur losses". In other words, investors refused to bail it out.

Worldsport

This ambitious company is restructuring under voluntary administration after struggling to raise money without advertisements or subscriptions. Its business plan was to produce a series of websites for a host of sports federations. These organisations were paid about £50,000 a year for the rights, while Worldsport raked in money from the webcasts. But it turned out there were not enough badminton or water polo fans, while the site has lacked support from a big-name federation such as Uefa.

The company was beset by problems, including inadequate server capacity and a main computer that sometimes went down for up to five hours a day. The monthly salary bill for the company's London office was rumoured to be close to £600,000 (half of its staff were laid off in July). The much-anticipated surge in interest in the qualifying competition for the Olympic Games' women's water polo never materialised.

NEWS NETWORKS

Arch internet sceptic Rupert Murdoch avoided the start of the web gold rush, and his experiences with News Networks probably make him wish he had stayed away altogether.

Murdoch has broken up News International's new media division just eight months after its birth. The subsidiary controlled the online editions of the Sun, News of the World, Page3.com, the Times and Sunday Times. These sites are now back under the remit of their parent newspapers, as Murdoch's corporation struggles to take its brands online without cannibalising paper sales.

Online auction site FiredUp.com, which is backed by an expensive advertising campaign featuring Bruce Willis, is also in turmoil, with about 30 staff having either been made redundant or walked out. The saga is a minor glitch for News International, but embarrassing nonetheless.

Urwired

This video games and DVD site collapsed in August after ploughing through most of its £1.8m start-up fund. The company was set up by Mattias Lamotte, who used money provided by his father - a senior City fund manager. Lamotte ensured effective communication with his backers by continuing to live with his parents at the age of 29.

Living.com

The Texas-based furniture seller left coffee titan Starbucks with egg on its face after filing for bankruptcy in August. Starbucks put £14.2m into Living.com, but wrote off its investment after the company laid off 275 staff and began to liquidate its assets. Amazon.com was another high-profile investor and saw its £6m stake wiped out, although for some reason it still plans to sell furniture through its site.

SAVED BY THE BELL

Netimperative

The news service went into liquidation in May, but was then bought by a consortium for £1m. It was pulled back from the brink in dramatic fashion after staff prevented bailiffs from seizing vital assets, allowing time for a rescue deal to go through. The company hit the rocks when key shareholder and venture capital firm Durlacher refused to provide an £800,000 financial lifeline. Netimperative's excuse for its troubles was the cost of moving offices. Bright Station, which bought Boo's technology assets for £250,000, is one of its new owners.

Cdnow

The music retailer was once a bright star of the internet, but German media giant Bertelsmann snapped it up for £79m in July after its funds ran out. At the height of its fame, the company was valued at £660m. It is now part of Bertelsmann's e-commerce division. The website sells CDs, DVDs, videos and T-shirts to about four million customers. It was set up in Pennsylvania in 1994 by twin brothers Jason and Matthew Olim. Cdnow has racked up losses of £142m.

Drkoop.com

The US-based health website was hours away from collapsing this summer when a group of investors gave it a £14m cash injection. Analysts remain sceptical about the company, which will again run out of money in March, and believe it is ripe for a takeover bid. Drkoop made spectacular strategic errors, such as paying AOL £60m to feature prominently on its websites. The deal had to be scrapped, given that this sum is more than Drkoop earned from its flotation. Last year, the company lost £38m, on a turnover of £6.3m. It is not a picture of perfect health.

webTitle: Ad agencies wake up to digital dilemma

fields.headline: Ad agencies wake up to digital dilemma
fields.standfirst: Far from sounding the death knell for the advertising industry, the dot.com revolution has breathed new life into agency coffers with hefty ad spends. But how well prepared are agencies for the digital age?
fields.trailText: Far from sounding the death knell for the advertising industry, the dot.com revolution has breathed new life into agency coffers with hefty ad spends. But how well prepared are agencies for the digital age? Claire Cozens reports
fields.body:
One of the more wildly inaccurate predictions about the internet was that it would spell the end of the advertising industry as we know it. Digital communications would, so the theory went, render obsolete all those lumbering old media forms of promoting your brand.

Well, anyone who believed that must be feeling pretty stupid now. From Amazon.com and Egg.com to Jungle.com and Lastminute.com, the e-commerce industry is ploughing millions into advertising agencies' coffers in an attempt to build up all-important brand recognition. And while the popularity of the internet as an advertising medium is growing rapidly, most of the new e-brands are spending the bulk of their venture capitalist millions on good old-fashioned press, poster and television advertising.

For any remaining doubters, the moment of truth came when the US networks unveiled their advertising schedules for last autumn's Super Bowl, the advertiser's Holy Grail. Almost half the 30-odd companies that had bought airtime at a rate of around $2m (£1.3m) for a 30-second commercial had dot.com at the end of their names.

So far, then, the internet has been just about the biggest gravy train the advertising industry could have hoped for, with multi-million-pound advertisers falling into their laps. But how well prepared are advertising agencies for the digital age? And with a new breed of digital specialists snapping at their heels, are agencies being too complacent about their hold on their clients' marketing budgets?

While most industry observers agree that the advertising industry was slow off the mark, many of the top 10 UK advertising and media buying agencies now have a specialist digital division. But the fact that the function of these divisions varies wildly from one agency to the next shows how confused the advertising industry remains about its precise function in the digital age.

In some agencies, such as WCRS, they have a fairly traditional role, handling advertising campaigns for the main agency's IT and e-commerce clients and creating internet advertising campaigns for its mainstream clients.

One agency, BMP DDB, has even opened a shop dedicated to creating interactive television ads for its clients - although the number of interactive ads that have run in the UK so far could be counted on the fingers of one hand.

Other agencies, though, have been more ambitious. eMC Saatchi, an offshoot of the Saatchi brothers' agency, M&C Saatchi, is billed as a digital consultancy, and offers strategic advice to clients about how they should be using digital media. J. Walter Thompson offers a similar service.

But many advertising agencies - including the UK market leader, Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO - still have no such specialist operation. The argument these agencies use is that advertising agencies should stick to what they do best, rather than trying to be jacks of all trades. They also believe that what the digital consultancies call 'new media solutions' should be integrated into the main agency, rather than hived off into a separate division where clients may not have access to the best creative talent.

Andrew Robertson, chief executive of AMV, points out that no two interactive units are doing the same thing. "The internet impacts to some degree on everything Abbott Mead Vickers is doing," he says. "If this thing becomes as important as everyone is predicting it will, then the last thing in the world we would want to do is to take it out of the main agency."
