fields.headline: Transfer fees to be scrapped
fields.standfirst: Small clubs count the cost
fields.trailText: Professional football took one of the most revolutionary steps in its history yesterday, when Fifa, the game's governing body, announced that it is to abolish the transfer system, a move which could give players unprecedented power over clubs.
fields.body:
Professional football took one of the most revolutionary steps in its history yesterday, when Fifa, the game's governing body, announced that it is to abolish the transfer system, a move which could give players unprecedented power over clubs.

The decision by Fifa and other football organisations in Zurich yesterday means that players like Manchester United's David Beckham and Roy Keane, as well as other high-profile footballers, stand to benefit from a massive wages increase.

Players aged 24 or over will have the right to terminate contracts and choose which clubs they want to play for, giving them the opportunity to negotiate even larger salaries.

Under plans agreed by football officials, players will be allowed to change clubs once a year during a specific period lasting a few weeks, while contracts would be no longer than a year.

The new rules, which will not come into effect immediately, will have serious implications for small clubs and lesser known players. Clubs will no longer receive transfer fees for players, although some compensation might be paid, while clubs will be able to terminate players' contracts if a period of notice is served, giving them limited job security, pension rights and insurance cover for injuries.

Fifa officials were meeting to discuss a response to the European Commission's competition commissioner, Mario Monti, who claims that the transfer system restricts free dom of movement, enshrined in the Treaty of Rome.

The European Commission (EC), which has given football until September 20 to respond, claims that professional footballers should be like employees of any other organisation and should have the right to change clubs, provided they serve a period of notice. This means that any footballer could leave a club after three months notice, for example, if he received a more lucrative offer elsewhere.

In an attempt to settle the dispute with the EC and limit the damage it could have on football, Fifa agreed to end transfers for players over 24, while compensation will be paid to clubs for players between 18 to 24.

Fifa's president, Sepp Blatter, who met representatives of players and the European leagues in Zurich yesterday admitted that the transfer fee system was at an end. He asked the EC for time to work out a system of compensation for players aged 24 and over. It has not been decided whether this will be based on length of contract, remaining sum of salary or football experience.

Mr Blatter added: "In our minds we have already taken the position that we have to look at a new system. It is the freedom and liberty of all people to be where they want to be but we need time to give a more balanced response."

One football source said yesterday: "Some top players are seeing this as some sort of corporate opportunity to increase their wages, while their less well-off brothers are facing the dole queue."

Football officials also agreed yesterday to end international transfers of players under 18 in an attempt to prevent youngsters from developing countries being lured to Europe and then dumped if they do not match expectations.

fields.headline: Vocalis left speechless
fields.trailText: Speech technology group Vocalis enjoyed a spectacular 18% share price rise yesterday after signing a deal with a US-based internet service provider.
fields.body:
Speech technology group Vocalis enjoyed a spectacular 18% share price rise yesterday after signing a deal with a US-based internet service provider.

The deal with WorldShare.net will allow its customers to access and reply to emails over the phone. It means the Vocalis SpeechMail product will be supplied to more than 200,000 people nationwide, the firm said.

Vocalis shares soared as a result. Late in the day they were trading at 312p - a rise of about 50p - but later slipped back to 307.5p.

SpeechMail, which translates emails into speech, is used by more than 70 ISPs in Britain. The company has previously marketed this product to consumers, but is now preparing to target business customers.

Analysts have questioned whether Vocalis is still waiting for a market for its technology. The defining day is expected to arrive if consumers readily embrace mobile internet.

Late in the day they were trading at 312p - a rise of about 50p - but later slipped back to 307.5p. SpeechMail, which translates emails into speech, is used by more than 70 ISPs in Britain. The company has previously marketed this product to consumers, but is now preparing to target business customers. Analysts have questioned whether Vocalis is still waiting for a market for its technology. The defining day is expected to arrive if consumers readily embrace mobile internet.

fields.headline: At this price?  BSkyB
fields.trailText: The threat of Germany's Kirch shedding its 3.1% stake in BSkyB has been hanging over the stock for months. Yesterday it finally happened and the company placed some 58m shares with investment banks Credit Suisse First Boston and Goldman Sachs, netting £583m in the process.
fields.body:
The threat of Germany's Kirch shedding its 3.1% stake in BSkyB has been hanging over the stock for months. Yesterday it finally happened and the company placed some 58m shares with investment banks Credit Suisse First Boston and Goldman Sachs, netting £583m in the process.

The shares were placed at £10.05 each and sold to institutional investors at £10.25.

Kirch acquired a 4.3% stake in BSkyB at the end of last year and sold part of it in June. The pay-TV company, in which BSkyB has a 24% holding, will use the cash to help fund the roll-out of its digital services.

As a consequence of the sale the price of BSkyB shares fell back 44p to a three-month low of £11.25, comfortably, or rather uncomfortably, below their March peak of £21.58, the inevitable effect of a large tranche of shares hitting the market at once. That could, however, make this a good time to step in.

It is worth remembering that some recent block sales of shares have not got away easily and, although the BSkyB sale was at what one dealer described as a "thumping discount", the appetite is clearly there for the shares.

"In the past few months a lot of uncertainties have been removed," said one media analyst. "BSkyB has retained the Premier League football broadcasting rights, taken control of [interactive service] Open, which has been a huge success, and now the concern over the Kirch stake has been removed. With those three things resolved, BSkyB is a much cleaner story."

The view was echoed by Paul Richards at ABN Amro who described the shares as a strong buy.

"It has the leading position in pay television in the UK by a country mile and taking full control of Open was a very smart thing to do. They also have a significant stake in the only digital satellite player in Germany, which is pretty valuable."

webTitle: Croat PM acts after killing of key witness

fields.headline: Croat PM acts after killing of key witness
fields.standfirst: Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: The Croatian prime minister, Ivica Racan, ordered an immediate inquiry yesterday into the murder of a key witness in war crimes investigations into the murder of Serb civilians in Croatia in 1991.
fields.body:
The Croatian prime minister, Ivica Racan, ordered an immediate inquiry yesterday into the murder of a key witness in war crimes investigations into the murder of Serb civilians in Croatia in 1991.

Milan Levar, 46, was killed by a bomb outside his home in Gospic, central Croatia, on Monday. It was the third attempt on his life.

"Those who are responsible for crimes committed in Croatia will not manage to thwart, by terror, blackmail or murders, Croatian authorities in efforts to punish all those liable for war crimes," Mr Racan told a cabinet session.

But it emerged yesterday that a request for protection for Levar and his family from the international criminal tribunal for the former Yugoslavia in the Hague had been mislaid.

According to a Croatian interior ministry statement, a letter was received from the Hague tribunal in April 1998, but the promise of protection was never passed on to county police covering Gospic.

Levar had twice given evidence at a time when the nationalist government of Franjo Tudjman was refusing even to allow war crimes investigators to enter Croatia. He was the first and so far only Croat to testify against his compatriots.

Levar had been offered protection by the Hague tribunal, but chose instead to stay in Croatia, believing that the publicity surrounding his allegations would protect him.

Levar's murder may seriously hamper future investigations of the tribunal, but Graham Blewitt, the deputy prosecutor, said that the organisation would continue to do "everything possible to provide adequate protection for all our witnesses".

Some 41 people are currently either on trial or awaiting trial in the Hague - the majority Bosnian Serbs. Many victims and witnesses of atrocities have already given evidence.

The tribunal has yet to issue any indictments for crimes against Serbs in Croatia, but has indicted three Serbs suspected of massacring patients at Vukovar hospital in November 1991, when the town fell to Serb forces.

Milan Levar was a local official in Gospic when the Serb rebellion against Croatian independence began in the summer of 1991. He participated in the defence of the town, but was so appalled by the atrocities committed by his own forces that he felt compelled to speak out.

Croatian forces have been accused of atrocities against Serb civilians in three instances: during the 1991 war, when Croatia lost a third of its territory to the Serbs, and during two rapid and successful campaigns to retake that territory in 1995.

Levar named high-ranking Croatian army officers in a series of press articles in 1997, and accused them of the "systematic murder" of Serb civilians. The revelations caused shockwaves in a country whose population see themselves as the victims, not the perpetrators of the war.

But more revelations about war crimes in Gospic followed, this time from Miroslav Bajramovic, another soldier involved in the defence of the town, who described how he took part in the torture and murder of dozens of Serbs.

Last year a Zagreb court convicted Bajramovic and several others of lesser crimes, but dropped the more serious charges for lack of evidence.

The possibilities open to the Hague tribunal widened enormously in January, when a new Social Democrat-Liberal government was elected, pledging full cooperation with investigators.

In April this year, those investigators began to search for the graves of an estimated 120 Serbs in the Gospic area. In the Obradovic Varos suburb of Gospic, they exhumed the remains of 10 bodies, under close police protection.

At the time, there were protest marches through the town, organised by veterans' associations, with banners reading "Where were you in 1991?" and "Don't humiliate us".

"How could Croatians have committed crimes when the town was besieged and took over 5,000 shells a day?" one of the participants, Ante Djapic, leader of the extremist Croatian Party of Rights, said to reporters.

webTitle: Spring in step of tech stocks

fields.headline: Spring in step of tech stocks
fields.trailText: Technology stocks continued their revival yesterday, driving the Techmark growth index to its highest level since April.
fields.body:
Technology stocks continued their revival yesterday, driving the Techmark growth index to its highest level since April.

The index, which dropped to 2,802.56 points earlier this year when the internet bubble burst, is enjoying a return to favour and by last night's close had risen 162.5 points to 4,119.75.

The FTSE 100 index was also in good form, running up to its best level in five months, once again thanks largely to technology, media and telecoms stocks.

The lead index gained 57.6 points to 6,672.7, with about 1.9bn shares changing hands. Gainers outnumbered losers five to four.

The European Central Bank's widely expected announcement to raise interest rates by 25 basis points did not have a serious impact as dealers said the increase had already been priced into the market.

The surge in telecom stocks, which added 45 points to the FTSE 100, appeared to surprise the City where analysts were at a loss to explain the explosion in interest. One said: "It's been mayhem. It's across the board and there doesn't appear to be any particular reason."

The biggest risers included Colt Telecom, which leaped 359p to £23.20, and Telewest Communications, which rose 23p to 172p.

Vodafone, which was subdued for most of the day despite typically heavy trading, eventually helped the cause with a 5.5p rise to end the session at 278.25p.

Continuing its good run was CMG, the computer services group, which had delighted analysts with better than expected results on Wednesday.

The stock had risen 83p last night at £13.65, representing an increase of just over 4%.

Internet service provider Freeserve, which has been tipped to fall out of the FTSE 100 after the next constituents' meeting, enjoyed a revival, closing 31p higher at 270p.

Bookham Technology, which rose 275p to £41.35, and ARM Holdings, which went up 85p to 920p, were the other key performers in the sector.

Dealers pointed to the recent rally in the Nasdaq composite index as one of the reasons behind the surge. In fact the early rises on Wall Street were credited with bolstering the British markets. At one stage the Nasdaq had put on 71 points and the Dow Jones industrial average was up 165 points.

Pearson was among the leading chargers in the media sector with a 6% increase to close up 120p to £19.90.

Shares in 365 Corporation, the digital media company, also rose on the back of healthy revenues. Increased losses were ignored. The stock rose 11p to 82p, although it remains a long way off its 305p year high.

On the downside, British Sky Broadcasting was the FTSE 100's biggest percentage faller after Germany's KirchPayTV sold its remaining stake in the firm. The shares had dropped 4%, or 47p, to £11.21 as the market closed.

Oil and gas stocks also had a damaging effect on the index, wiping out 15 Footsie points, as BP Amoco and Shell fell away from the highs enjoyed on the back of soaring crude oil prices.

CFS Group, the software firm, which announced first-half results, shed 14% as dealers highlighted rising costs despite an improved outlook.

This took the stock's value down to 187.5p, a fall of 32.5p.

Also taking a tumble was QSP Group, the financial software maker, which fell 29.5% to 103.5p on the back of dull first quarter trading.

However, Redstone Telecom was among the key performers in the mid caps with an impressive jump of 30%, or 63.5p, to 277.5p. Analysts praised the move to accelerate the roll-out of its British broadband network.

Elsewhere in the markets, the FTSE Small Cap index rose 41.4 points to end at 3,557.9 points - not far off its all-time high of 3,568.2 achieved earlier this year.

fields.headline: Porsche's patriotism looks outmoded
fields.standfirst: This is no time for parochialism
fields.trailText: As a manufacturer of sports cars Porsche is one of the world's top names. In corporate terms it is hardly a titan, however - merely a German middle-sized capitalisation company with a market value of around €3.3bn (£2.02bn). Yet its intervention in the battle over the future of the planned merger of the London Stock Exchange and Deutsche Börse could prove as important as it is unfortunate.
fields.body:
As a manufacturer of sports cars Porsche is one of the world's top names. In corporate terms it is hardly a titan, however - merely a German middle-sized capitalisation company with a market value of around €3.3bn (£2.02bn). Yet its intervention in the battle over the future of the planned merger of the London Stock Exchange and Deutsche Börse could prove as important as it is unfortunate.

Porsche's opposition to the London-Frankfurt merger - already under threat from OM's hostile offer for the London Stock Exchange - is based on what it calls "a healthy dose of local patriotism" which suggests a merged exchange would weaken Frankfurt as a stock market location.

Setting aside what Dr Johnson had to say about patriotism, Porsche's backward looking comments - coming as they did on a day when Clearstream and Crest came up with one of the most practical proposals for the development in pan-European trading through their plans for cooperation in the areas of settlement and clearing - can only be regarded as particularly disappointing.

Porsche's argument is based on the outmoded premise that stock markets are somehow dependent on their geographical location.

Technology has made that nonsense. The days when the intermediaries could mistake themselves for the real principals of stock market life - the listed companies and the investors - are fading, even if the reaction of some of the UK's broking community suggests they have not entirely disappeared.

The trouble with the Porsche intervention is that it may reflect what others have thought but have been reluctant to express. The best that can be said is that it will force the main players to confront the issue of "patriotism" which they have been sidestepping since the merger plan was announced.

Hard work

Punch Taverns' outspoken boss, Hugh Osmond, has been keeping a low profile since he won last year's bitterly contested bidding war for Allied Domecq's 3,500-strong pub estate.

At the time he promised he could work wonders with the pubs by applying a few fashionable retail techniques he learned as a director of Pizza Express.

He finally came out of hibernation yesterday, with the same taste for juicy soundbites but a few more grey hairs, betraying the stress of being one of Britain's most powerful landlords.

Mr Osmond trumpeted a 20% increase in turnover at pubs where Punch had completed refurbishments. However, this figure requires closer examination. Under questioning, Mr Osmond admitted there were only 80 pubs in the portfolio where refurbishments were finished, after total spending during the year of £90m.

Figures for the rest of the estate are much more modest: the company managed a 1% increase in overall sales against a 0.5% decline under Allied Domecq's final year of ownership.

These numbers are not bad - they show things have begun to move in the right direction. But they serve as a reminder that Punch will have to work long and hard to achieve growth, in a market that is generally considered to be mature.

It will take more than a few brightly coloured carpets, large-screen televisions and clean toilets to swim against the industry's tide. Staff who accept the invitation to buy shares in Punch should be prepared for a long haul.

Eidos impasse

A year ago the computer games company Eidos was the toast of the City with a high-flying share price and a confident management.

Today it is almost impossible to find anyone who will say a nice word about the firm in the wake of successive profit warnings.

Yesterday analysts, brokers, fund managers and legions of small shareholders were still none the wiser about the state of the takeover talks first announced almost three months ago. Even many of the company's own advisers seemed nonplussed.

Chief operating officer Mike McGarvey was saying nothing. Even chief executive Charles Cornwall - briefly back in the UK having flown in from his Los Angeles home - wasn't talking, despite his firm being at such a crucial point.

Some in the City doubt the "talks" are that serious. They want a resolution to the Eidos saga as soon as possible; they say that uncertainty surrounding the firm is having a negative effect on the whole of the quoted computer games sector - which is having a rough time in any case: a cyclical downturn in the market means not as many games are being bought.

Mr Cornwall, a confrontational former investment banker, has other interests. He should put everyone out of their misery and get on with pursuing those interests instead.

fields.headline: Clear-out at SmithKline
fields.trailText: In an attempt to satisfy American regulators, SmithKline Beecham has cleared out its drugs cabinet ahead of its merger with Glaxo Wellcome by selling rights to three products for $2.9bn (£1.9bn).
fields.body:
In an attempt to satisfy American regulators, SmithKline Beecham has cleared out its drugs cabinet ahead of its merger with Glaxo Wellcome by selling rights to three products for $2.9bn (£1.9bn).

The pharmaceuticals group sold Kytril, which is used to treat nausea, to Swiss rival Roche for $1.23bn. Kytril is prescribed for cancer patients who feel sick while having chemotherapy and radiotherapy.

It is also selling anti-viral products Famvir and Vectavir for $1.63bn to Novartis. These treat shingles, genital herpes and cold sores.

The sale is an attempt to pre-empt an order from the US federal trade commission, concerned about the merged groups dominating the market for certain types of medicine. Glaxo has products for similar conditions - its portfolio includes Zofran for nausea and Zovirax for herpes.

The widely expected disposals raised more money than some analysts predicted. Peter Laing, of SG Securities, said: "They've got rather better terms than we thought. These are all reasonably mature products."

SmithKline said it would use the proceeds for "general corporate purposes", although industry experts described the cash as "small change for something the size of Glaxo SmithKline". SmithKline's shares rose 12.5p to 897.5p.

As part of the same reshuffling of products, SmithKline is paying Roche $400m for the north American rights to a drug for heart failure, Coreg. SmithKline already has an agreement to co-promote the treatment, which had US sales of $196m last year.

Directors of Glaxo and SmithKline are hoping the sales clear the way for their merger to be complete by the "target date" of September 25.

The deal has already been delayed by a month and another hold-up would be an embarrassment to the groups.

There has been speculation that the FTC could raise concerns about conflicting research and development projects.

Glaxo tried to avert one potential problem yesterday by paying £5.75m to biotech firm Cantab Pharmaceuticals to exit a development tie-up for a genital herpes vaccine. Cantab's shares edged up 5p to 300p.

fields.headline: CSFB bonus bill for six months totals £1.8bn
fields.trailText: Bonuses for investment bankers at Credit Suisse First Boston cost the Swiss bank some SFr4.3bn (£1.8bn) in the first six months of the year.
fields.body:
Bonuses for investment bankers at Credit Suisse First Boston cost the Swiss bank some SFr4.3bn (£1.8bn) in the first six months of the year.

The figure is in addition to the £800m which Credit Swiss, the parent company, is setting aside to retain important staff at Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette, the American investment banking group it bought this week for $11.5bn.

The bonuses for CSFB investment bankers, 6,000 of whom are based in London, were 51% higher than in the same period last year and represented the main reason for the 28% rise in operating expenses at the bank.

Overall the Swiss bank, which has private banking and fund management operations, reported a 35% rise in net profits to Sfr3.6bn, boosted by the strong performance of stock markets in the first three months of the year - particularly in the race to buy internet shares before the dot.com bubble burst in mid-March.

While it anticipated a "good overall result for the year as a whole" the bank warned that the "favourable" market conditions in the six months to the end of June might not continue in the second half of this year.

Investment in new business areas and technology might also dent the total results.

With 2,000 jobs expected to be cut as a result of the takeover of DLJ, Lukas Muehlemann, the chairman and chief executive of Credit Suisse, described the deal as "a merger in spirit".

The bank also played down the possibility of any acquisi tions to further bolster its investment banking position on the European continent.

The analyst community remained concerned about the price tag attached to the DLJ acquisition and expressed disappointment that the group's fund management operation had not grown as rapidly as anticipated.

 ING Barings, the investment bank acquired by ING bank of the Netherlands for £1 five years ago, reported an 89% rise in pre-tax operating profits to €293m.

fields.headline: Galen reaches £1bn landmark
fields.standfirst: Healthcare firm claims a first for N Ireland
fields.trailText: Galen Holdings, the Drumcree-based healthcare group which specialises in intra-vaginal rings, has become Northern Ireland's first £1bn public company.
fields.body:
Galen Holdings, the Drumcree-based healthcare group which specialises in intra-vaginal rings, has become Northern Ireland's first £1bn public company.

Galen's shares edged up 2.5p to 802.5p yesterday, valuing the business at £1.01bn. The company narrowly beat the electricity generator Viridian to the milestone - Viridian's market capitalisation has slipped in the past few days to £910m.

John King, Galen's chief executive, gave a low-key welcome to the news: "We noticed that we'd gone over the billion mark. I suppose it is a bit of a milestone but you won't see champagne corks popping or anything.

"Clearly, we've come a long way in a long time. It's a lovely point to cross but we just have to look on to the next battle."

The group floated on the London Stock Exchange three years ago, valued at £180m. Since then its shares have rocketed amid enthusiasm about the group's drug delivery technology.

The firm's leading products are tiny rubber loops called intra-vaginal rings which can be used for the gradual delivery of hormone replacement therapy. Galen believes these could become very popular as a convenient alternative to taking daily pills or having cumbersome surgical implants.

Galen's success has made Mr King and chairman Allen McClay into two of Northerrn Ireland's richest men - they have a combined stake of 54%, worth £545m. Mr McClay, a former drugs salesman for Glaxo Wellcome, founded the company in 1968. He recruited Mr King, then a pharmacy researcher at Queen's University, Belfast, in 1979.

Galen is in the final stages of purchasing an American drugs company, Warner-Chilcott, for £190m.

Few other Northern Irish companies have approached a £1bn stock market valuation. Among the province's other leading public companies have been packaging firm Boxmore International, which was taken over for £190m last year, and engineering group Powerscreen, bought for £180m by Terex Corporation of the United States.

fields.headline: Simply sold
fields.standfirst: Bid scramble for Hucknall-founded hotel chain
fields.trailText: Malmaison, the hotel chain co-founded by Simply Red singer Mick Hucknall's management firm, So What Arts, has been sold for £76m, writes Mary O'Hara .
fields.body:
Malmaison, the hotel chain co-founded by Simply Red singer Mick Hucknall's management firm, So What Arts, has been sold for £76m, writes Mary O'Hara .

The entire stock was bought by property development group Marylebone Warwick Balfour from its US owner, hotel group Wyndham International.

A new company jointly owned by Marylebone and a subsidiary of Scandinavian Airlines System has bought the Malmaison brand with expansion rights for £11m. The sale was concluded after a bidding round in which at least 80 firms competed.

Marylebone secured £83m from Société Générale for the sale, £55m of which is going towards the cost of the acquisition with the remainder directed at the refurbishment of existing hotels.

Marylebone's Clive Hillier said the chain had the potential for at least 10 new hotels in Europe and that work would start "immediately" on a London site. Malmaison's 1999 turnover was £16.3m, with a net profit of £6m.

webTitle: Business: Farewell to the irksome Firkin

fields.headline: Farewell to the irksome Firkin
fields.trailText: The Firkin pub brand is to disappear from the high street as part of a revamp of Punch Taverns' portfolio outlined yesterday by chairman Hugh Osmond.
fields.body:
The Firkin pub brand is to disappear from the high street as part of a revamp of Punch Taverns' portfolio outlined yesterday by chairman Hugh Osmond.

The distinctive chain of pubs, many of which have a miniature brewery inside, was sold by Allied Domecq last year and is split between Punch and Bass. However, Punch has the rights to the name and Bass has agreed to rebrand its outlets by October 2001.

Mr Osmond said the Firkin chain had moved too far from its roots as a student offering. "Ten years ago it was a good brand but it's knackered now."

Since buying Allied's portfolio, Punch has been developing a selection of "discreet" concepts.

These include Q's, which are largely sports bars, and the Great Local concept of neighbourhood bars. It is rolling out a chain of fashionable Japanese-style bars called Cane's.

Mr Osmond attacked the quality of some of the outlets Allied had sold. Punch refurbished the White Hart in Hammersmith, which was "a complete hole where the windows hadn't been cleaned for five years, you stuck to the carpet when you went in and there was a fight every Friday night".

Punch spent £90m in its estate over the past year, and saw sales rise 20% at pubs where refurbishment has been completed.

fields.headline: Hemmings back at Pontins
fields.trailText: Trevor Hemmings, the leisure entrepreneur behind the recent £161m takeover of Littlewoods Pools, is on the brink of buying back the Pontins holiday business from Scottish & Newcastle.
fields.body:
Trevor Hemmings, the leisure entrepreneur behind the recent £161m takeover of Littlewoods Pools, is on the brink of buying back the Pontins holiday business from Scottish & Newcastle.

The multimillionaire, whose interests include Blackpool Tower and Lingfield and Folkestone racecources, sold Pontins to the Scottish brewer for about £80m in the late 1980s.

Yesterday S&N said it was in exclusive negotiations to sell a slimmed-down Pontins business to Manor Parcs, a Hemmings family firm. The deal is expected to be completed by the end of September.

S&N also said that it was close to selling the British operations of its Centre Parcs holiday business to DB Capital Partners and the European operations to Pierre et Vacances.

Under the proposed Pontins deal, Mr Hemmings will take over the Pontins name and headquarters at Chorley, Lancashire, together with eight holiday centres spread around the country.

Pontins had 22 holiday camps when it was acquired by S&N in a two-stage deal in 1988 and 1989.

Since then S&N has reduced Pontins to a shadow of its former self by selling or closing sites.

Of the seven sites not included in the deal with Mr Hemmings, three are being transferred to the Centre Parcs holiday business, one is subject to a sales contract, two are under offer and one in Ireland is about to be brought to the market.

Pontins started when Sir Fred Pontin set up his first holiday camp at Brean Sands near Weston-super-Mare in 1946. Holiday camps, especially Butlins and Pontins, had their heyday during the 1950s and 1960s. They lost their popularity when affluence and cheaper air travel opened the way for charter holidays in Spain. But Pontins still attracted 700,000 visitors last year.

S&N's motive for buying Pontins was to get out of the capital intensive hotel business with its poor cash flow into a faster-growing, less capital intensive leisure business.

It has now decided that it can deliver more shareholder value through the international expansion of its beer and pubs business.

webTitle: David McKie: Commissions reports are rejected

fields.headline: Taskforces are dead and buried
fields.standfirst:
Commissions reports are rejected. Whither consensus politics?
Special report: proportional representation
fields.trailText: Commissions reports are rejected. Whither consensus politics?
fields.body:
More in sorrow than in anger, Lord Jenkins of Hillhead has conceded defeat. The Alternative Vote-Plus, the ingenious scheme which he and his colleagues on the Electoral Reform Commission devised two years ago as a potential alternative to first-past-the-post, will not now happen. It was clear from Labour's national policy forum in July that the party would not swallow it. Jenkins has served in the highest reaches of government. He knows how the system works. Which is no doubt why he is said to be "disappointed, but not surprised".

He is not alone in his present predicament. At least three others share it with him, and where he has learned of his fate with sorrow rather than anger, with some of them it sounds like the other way round. Professor Sir Stewart Sutherland chaired a royal commission on long-term care. Lord Rogers of Riverside and the former Tory minister David Mellor headed taskforces - Rogers on urban renewal, Mellor on the regulation of football. Like Roy Jenkins, they now discover that little has come of their labours.

All commissions of inquiry are faced with the same hard choice. Do they recommend what they believe best reflects the broad interests of the nation? Or do they temper their findings in the hope of getting them implemented? A majority on the Sutherland team found it unacceptable that people in long-term care should have to sacrifice life savings to pay for it. They concluded that while it was reasonable to have people meet living and housing costs, personal care was different: the state ought to pay. Two members dissented, arguing that the this solution would create what one called "a Niagara of public expenditure". After 16 months of silence, the government answered at last, in its national plan for the NHS. Surprise, surprise: it preferred the minority view. The state will pay for nursing care, but not for the rest.

Lord Rogers's taskforce produced a report called Towards an Urban Renaissance: 300 pages, more than 100 recommendations, and costs running into billions. Some called it visionary; others, counting the cost, thought it pure fantasy. The Treasury inclined to the second view. So as Rogers, far less resigned to his fate than Roy Jenkins, keeps complaining, much of what he signalled as urgent continues to be ignored. Mellor and his team wanted quite tough regulation through a Football Audit Commission. The government is expected this month to propose a seriously watered-down version to be called the Independent Football Commission. Mellor's fears that this creature would have no teeth were confirmed when reports appeared that its chairman would be the former Labour cabinet minister Jack Cunningham, hardly the man, he thought, to get stuck right in and start banging football heads together. "The whole thing stinks," he wrote in the Evening Standard.

You won't catch Lord Jenkins of Hillhead saying the whole thing stinks, but his nostrils must be wrinkling a little. His fate is all the more disappointing because, unlike Rogers and Sutherland, he clearly tailored his findings to make them politically acceptable. His appointment resulted from Labour's manifesto commitment to appoint a commission "to recommend a proportional alternative to the first-past-the-post system." What he recommended however, was not a proportional system, but a blend of the notoriously disproportional Alternative Vote with a top-up designed to make the end result somewhat more equitable. This was less PR than LDR: Less Disproportional Representation. But even this was too much, as the national policy forum showed, for the Labour party. Calculations suggested the forum was set to vote unequivocally for sticking with first-past-the-post. To avert that outcome and keep some hope of change alive, party managers resolved to sacrifice Jenkins's top-up element and focus on AV pure and simple - a solution quite clearly incompatible with the manifesto pledge to offer a proportional alternative in the promised referendum on change.

These various modes of inquiry were born at that time, decades ago as it now seems, when New Labour was out to create a new kind of politics, in which boring old ideology was banished, and Labour would govern not in accord with the party's ancient beliefs but pragmatically, in line with what the electorate wanted. And to guarantee that reform would proceed from a base of consensus rather than party doctrine, a host of commissions arose, open minded in pursuit of the truth in a way politicians were no longer trusted to be.

And now we see the result. Some recommend what the Treasury, as powerful as ever, judges the country cannot afford. Others run into the road blocks of political institutions (the democracy of the Labour party, for instance) which had seemed in the dream days no longer to matter. It is part of the nation's political re-education; perhaps also of Tony Blair's.

fields.headline: Going up in smoke
fields.standfirst:
Little action will be taken to combat climate change while oppositions offer people an excuse to do nothing

Special report: the weather
Special report: Renewable Energy
fields.trailText: Little action will be taken to combat climate change while oppositions offer people an excuse to do nothing.
fields.body:
Yesterday Michael Portillo inadvertently raised the key question of the century. Can western democracies ever deliver the politics necessary to save the world? To stop global warming as it is now - just to halt it - world emissions of carbon dioxide have to be cut by between 60% and 80% according to the intergovernmental panel on climate change: targets set at Kyoto which some countries won't reach were a pathetically modest first step. But outside wartime, no democracy has ever asked its voters for such savage belt-tightening or such radical lifestyle change as would be required to get anywhere near that goal.

Will it have to wait until citizens can see for themselves that climate change threatens them now, not in the future? Dying polar bears, water at the north pole, fires blazing across great tracts of land or even tropical diseases like West Nile fever breaking out in Boston make interesting newspaper stories, but they don't scare the people into a wartime frame of mind: presumably that will take water flooding over the spire of the Empire State Building.

Michael Portillo yesterday said the Conservatives would abolish Labour's climate-change levy, a pollution tax that after three years of negotiation finally comes into force in April. It will create energy savings worth about a third of the Kyoto cuts Britain has to make in carbon emissions. It is not draconian, adding only 0.45p per unit to business energy bills. It will raise £1.1bn, all of it to be recycled back to business. (It is not a Treasury money-maker). All employers will get the money back as a reduction in National Insurance contributions they pay for employees. The idea is an incentive to cut energy use, coupled with an incentive to employ more people.Ten per cent of it will be used for energy saving capital grants for business.

This policy was led by Lord Marshall, then head of the CBI. It has undergone years of delicate negotiation to ensure it is fair. Industry persuaded Gordon Brown to halve the size of his original levy, making special agreements for 80% rebates for sectors that use vast quantities of energy but employ few people - steel, chemicals, engineering. Yesterday John Cridland, deputy director-general of the CBI, said it was not opposing the climate-change levy.

The one and only supporter of Portillo's surprise announcement was the Institute of Directors. (Small business stands to gain from the NI cuts). Portillo's rousing rhetoric at the breakfast for business included these thoughts: "There is no justification for an energy tax which is going to be particularly harmful to manufacturing industry. Business can no longer be the fall guy." He called the idea of taxing manufacturing industry "ill-conceived", "counter-productive" and "crazy". (Both he and the institute talked of manufacturing industry's dire plight due to the high pound, apparently shameless about their own part in Britain's failure to join the euro and rescue British manufacturing).

But most important of all, Michael Portillo took no account of global warming. He simply criticised the levy as a tax on business. It is politics as usual, no change. At least, unlike the Republicans in America, the Conservatives don't deny the existence of global warming, nor the need to do something about it. But as oppositions do and always will, they deny the need for a particular belt-tightening measure the government of the day proposes. It's "crazy", needless, could be done better or in any other way but the one proposed. There will be a great array of methods governments choose to apply carrots and sticks to drive down energy use to hit their targets. But if oppositions always offer the people an excuse for not doing it, a reason for voting against any particular tax, quota or limit, nothing will be done.

Portillo's "alternative" suggestion is typical weaselling. Instead of a tax, he said, his party would introduce "emissions trading" whereby companies are given carbon quotas they can buy and sell. It gives them a financial incentive for switching to more expensive clean energy sources such as wind or solar power that fall outside the quota. Good idea. Except that the government is already planning to do this and has a taskforce in place drawing up just such a scheme. So is the EU. But it will be needed side by side, not instead of, a climate-change levy because it wouldn't work without that incentive. It will take several years to introduce, during which time Portillo proposes nothing should be done. The danger is that in democracies people are easily seduced by apparently pain-free alternatives offered by oppositions, ensuring governments never quite dare take measures as tough as they know they should be to hit their targets. And that's the way the world ends.

Consider the sort of lifestyle change we in the west will have to make to meet the 60-80% cut: a one-way flight from London to Miami uses up half the carbon emission a person would be allocated for a whole year's heating, cooking and transport. Will it require authoritarian national governments to introduce those kinds of severe changes, or can oppositions behave more responsibly and sit down with governments to agree global-warming measures? The Conservatives' desperate thrashing around at the moment for any vote-catcher, however disgraceful, doesn't bode well.

Must it all be hard sacrifice? There's always a glint in the eye of the Greens that suggests they really relish anti-materialist, back-to-nature lifestyle cuts as a puritanical good thing in its own right. However, it is possible that a mixture of good government and new technology will mean nothing too drastic has to hit general standards of living. But as Michael Portillo must know, the longer action is delayed, the harsher the cuts that will need to be made later.

The climate-change levy is an excellent tool to start large energy users thinking again about ways to convert their supplies to clean sources and to use less. For example, it will tip the balance in making it financially worthwhile for a new office building to invest in solar panels as a cladding that would give the building 30 years free electricity at no greater construction cost than most ornamental but useless cladding. (It looks like blue marble). The levy would tip the balance in encouraging any large energy user to invest in solar panels. The government is to use 10% of the levy for grants to help companies install this and other clean electricity supplies.

The difference in cost between clean and dirty electricity is shrinking all the time, so that relatively small extra taxes can change energy use dramatically. How high do oil prices rise before electric cars look attractive? Maybe we shall fly less often, but then trains will improve to take up the international long-distance trade. But carrots and sticks will have to start the whole process. And oppositions that try to capitalise shamelessly on what all responsible governments must do deserve to be kept out of office indefinitely.

Dying polar bears, water at the north pole, fires blazing across great tracts of land or even tropical diseases like West Nile fever breaking out in Boston make interesting newspaper stories, but they don't scare the people into a wartime frame of mind: presumably that will take water flooding over the spire of the Empire State Building. Michael Portillo yesterday said the Conservatives would abolish Labour's climate-change levy, a pollution tax that after three years of negotiation finally comes into force in April. It will create energy savings worth about a third of the Kyoto cuts Britain has to make in carbon emissions. It is not draconian, adding only 0.45p per unit to business energy bills. It will raise £1.1bn, all of it to be recycled back to business. (It is not a Treasury money-maker). All employers will get the money back as a reduction in National Insurance contributions they pay for employees. The idea is an incentive to cut energy use, coupled with an incentive to employ more people.Ten per cent of it will be used for energy saving capital grants for business. This policy was led by Lord Marshall, then head of the CBI. It has undergone years of delicate negotiation to ensure it is fair. Industry persuaded Gordon Brown to halve the size of his original levy, making special agreements for 80% rebates for sectors that use vast quantities of energy but employ few people - steel, chemicals, engineering. Yesterday John Cridland, deputy director-general of the CBI, said it was not opposing the climate-change levy. The one and only supporter of Portillo's surprise announcement was the Institute of Directors. (Small business stands to gain from the NI cuts). Portillo's rousing rhetoric at the breakfast for business included these thoughts: "There is no justification for an energy tax which is going to be particularly harmful to manufacturing industry. Business can no longer be the fall guy." He called the idea of taxing manufacturing industry "ill-conceived", "counter-productive" and "crazy". (Both he and the institute talked of manufacturing industry's dire plight due to the high pound, apparently shameless about their own part in Britain's failure to join the euro and rescue British manufacturing). But most important of all, Michael Portillo took no account of global warming. He simply criticised the levy as a tax on business. It is politics as usual, no change. At least, unlike the Republicans in America, the Conservatives don't deny the existence of global warming, nor the need to do something about it. But as oppositions do and always will, they deny the need for a particular belt-tightening measure the government of the day proposes. It's "crazy", needless, could be done better or in any other way but the one proposed. There will be a great array of methods governments choose to apply carrots and sticks to drive down energy use to hit their targets. But if oppositions always offer the people an excuse for not doing it, a reason for voting against any particular tax, quota or limit, nothing will be done. Portillo's "alternative" suggestion is typical weaselling. Instead of a tax, he said, his party would introduce "emissions trading" whereby companies are given carbon quotas they can buy and sell. It gives them a financial incentive for switching to more expensive clean energy sources such as wind or solar power that fall outside the quota. Good idea. Except that the government is already planning to do this and has a taskforce in place drawing up just such a scheme. So is the EU. But it will be needed side by side, not instead of, a climate-change levy because it wouldn't work without that incentive. It will take several years to introduce, during which time Portillo proposes nothing should be done. The danger is that in democracies people are easily seduced by apparently pain-free alternatives offered by oppositions, ensuring governments never quite dare take measures as tough as they know they should be to hit their targets. And that's the way the world ends. Consider the sort of lifestyle change we in the west will have to make to meet the 60-80% cut: a one-way flight from London to Miami uses up half the carbon emission a person would be allocated for a whole year's heating, cooking and transport. Will it require authoritarian national governments to introduce those kinds of severe changes, or can oppositions behave more responsibly and sit down with governments to agree global-warming measures? The Conservatives' desperate thrashing around at the moment for any vote-catcher, however disgraceful, doesn't bode well. Must it all be hard sacrifice? There's always a glint in the eye of the Greens that suggests they really relish anti-materialist, back-to-nature lifestyle cuts as a puritanical good thing in its own right. However, it is possible that a mixture of good government and new technology will mean nothing too drastic has to hit general standards of living. But as Michael Portillo must know, the longer action is delayed, the harsher the cuts that will need to be made later. The climate-change levy is an excellent tool to start large energy users thinking again about ways to convert their supplies to clean sources and to use less. For example, it will tip the balance in making it financially worthwhile for a new office building to invest in solar panels as a cladding that would give the building 30 years free electricity at no greater construction cost than most ornamental but useless cladding. (It looks like blue marble). The levy would tip the balance in encouraging any large energy user to invest in solar panels. The government is to use 10% of the levy for grants to help companies install this and other clean electricity supplies. The difference in cost between clean and dirty electricity is shrinking all the time, so that relatively small extra taxes can change energy use dramatically. How high do oil prices rise before electric cars look attractive? Maybe we shall fly less often, but then trains will improve to take up the international long-distance trade. But carrots and sticks will have to start the whole process. And oppositions that try to capitalise shamelessly on what all responsible governments must do deserve to be kept out of office indefinitely. polly.toynbee@theguardian.com

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Ford shares hit by tyre fears
fields.body:
Ford shares hit by tyre fears

Shares in Ford slumped more than 5% in the United States yesterday as Venezuela declared that the company was partly responsible for road deaths linked to faulty Firestone tyres.

The news coincided with comments from US officials who said they were raising their estimate of fatal accidents involving the problem tyres.

Venezuelan authorities said Ford shared responsibility with Firestone for 40 deaths in 35 accidents linked to problems with tyres fitted to Ford Explorer vehicles.

Venezuela's Institute of Defence and Consumer Protection alleged the relationship between the two firms "could be called a conspiracy" and it was recommending criminal prosecutions.

PVC-free smart card arrives

The world's first "environmentally friendly" smart card for banking was launched yesterday. EarthCard, developed by specialist Gemplus, is PVC-free, totally recyclable and releases no harmful gases into the atmosphere when burned, said the company. The raw material for EarthCard is based on polyester, and it is said to last considerably longer than ordinary cards. A spokesman said the new card overcomes a problem that arose with biodegradable prototypes - a tendency to start decomposing before people had finished using them. Gemplus is based in France and has offices worldwide including one in Havant, Hants.

Dye considers comeback

Fund manager Tony Dye, well known for his bearish views, is considering a comeback after retiring from Phillips & Drew earlier this year.

He is quoted on Sharecast.com, an internet news site, as saying: "At the moment our plans are not concrete and we are going through a long process to begin authorisation."

Mr Dye, who predicted a stock market crash four years ago, which failed to materialise, is to work with former Foreign & Colonial fund manager Ed Knox.

BT agrees £150m sell-off

BT is selling three of its business units that provide remote phone services to maritime, oil and gas, banking and aeronautical companies, to a Canadian specialist, Stratos Global. Inmarsat, Vsat and the aeronautical division will together fetch £150m.

webTitle: Business: Osmond warns on Interbrew acquisition

fields.headline: Osmond warns on Interbrew acquisition
fields.standfirst: Punch Taverns chief calls for DTI action on 'anti-competitive' move
fields.trailText: The boss of Punch Taverns, one of the UK's biggest pub companies, has called for "very serious" government intervention to prevent the Belgian group Interbrew from dominating Britain's beer industry.
fields.body:
The boss of Punch Taverns, one of the UK's biggest pub companies, has called for "very serious" government intervention to prevent the Belgian group Interbrew from dominating Britain's beer industry.

Punch's chairman, Hugh Osmond, said Interbrew's proposed purchase of breweries from Bass and Whitbread would lead to higher beer prices and the demise of traditional ale brands.

"This is effectively a merger of Bass and Whitbread. If that ain't anti-competitive, nothing ever will be," he said.

Punch is among Interbrew's largest customers, with 5,150 pubs. Mr Osmond has told the office of fair trading that he thinks the acquisitions are "a pretty dubious thing to allow to happen without some very serious conditions".

There has been speculation that the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, will order Interbrew to sell some lager brands - the group will own Stella Artois, Carling and Tennent's, with a 32% share of the entire beer market.

Mr Osmond said that even after the sale of brands Interbrew and rival brewer Scottish & Newcastle could control the availability of beers through their distribution networks.

Lorries from the two big groups supply a range of drinks to 80% of Britain's pubs and, although they carry products from other manufacturers, Mr Osmond claimed they favoured their own beers.

"Selling a brand is not enough unless you sort out the distribution issue. For the average pub company the only distribution option is one of the big brewers but mostly, whatever they say, they're not keen on distributing their competitors' products.

"This is doing exactly what the Beer Orders and the European commission have been trying to stop - it's preventing access to the market."

Mr Osmond added that prices were bound to rise: "We can't make Interbrew's numbers stack up unless they increase their market share and increase their prices.

"We're not going to sit by and let that happen."

Interbrew's £2.3bn deal with Bass is being considered by the office of fair trading, which will advise Mr Byers on whether to order a full inquiry by the competition commission. An Interbrew spokesman described Mr Osmond's remarks as premature, saying: "With all due respect for this person, let's just wait and see what the OFT thinks."

Interbrew argues that the biggest brewers in other European countries have higher market shares, and that the sheer number of different beers available in Britain makes it one of the most competitive markets in the world.

Punch and the Japanese bank Nomura are the country's biggest pub owners, each with just over 5,000 houses. Punch became a major player last year when it paid £2.7bn for Allied Domecq's 3,500 pubs after a vitriolic bidding battle against Whitbread.

Mr Osmond announced plans yesterday to allow more than 5,000 employees to buy shares in Punch, ahead of a possible flotation in "two to three years' time".

The shares, in either the group's tenanted or managed pubs business, are on offer at 30p each. This values the business at £364m, although it has debts of more than £2.5bn.

Mr Osmond and his management team own about 30% of the company, with the balance held by venture capitalists. Employees will be offered a total of 4%.

fields.headline: Editor questioned over Diana letters
fields.trailText: The editor of the Mirror, Piers Morgan, was questioned by police yesterday over the alleged theft of intimate letters sent by the late Diana, Princess of Wales, to her former lover James Hewitt.
fields.body:
The editor of the Mirror, Piers Morgan, was questioned by police yesterday over the alleged theft of intimate letters sent by the late Diana, Princess of Wales, to her former lover James Hewitt.

Mr Morgan was interviewed for 30 minutes under caution by Scotland Yard's organised crime group at Charing Cross police station in London; in an unusual co-incidence, the interview was given on the third anniversary of the princess's death.

Mr Hewitt, a former Life Guards officer who had a five-year affair with the princess, accuses the Mirror of plotting to steal the letters. His former fiancee, Anna Ferretti, took 64 notes from his home in Devon two years ago.

Mr Morgan said he had told detectives there was no evidence to substantiate Mr Hewitt's allegations, and questioned why it had taken so long for them to be made. "It seems a curious use of public money to deploy high-ranking detectives from the country's most important crime unit in such a matter," he said.

"I have no criticism of the officers concerned, who were very professional and courteous. But they had no explanation as to why it had taken so long for this interview to be conducted, and, frankly, the evidence they presented to me was thinner than William Hague's hair."

He had asked the detectives if they were investigating Mr Hewitt under the 1351 Act of Treason [yet to be repealed] for committing adultery with the wife of a future monarch; they had said they were not.

Ms Ferretti offered the letters to the Mirror in 1998 for £150,000. It went along with the deal, intending to pass the letters to Kensington Palace without paying any money, he said.

Michael Gibbins, the princess's former private secretary, later informed him that the Mirror's conduct would have accorded with her wishes, Mr Morgan told the officers. After a legal battle with Diana's estate, Mr Hewitt won back the letters.

Yesterday a spokeswoman for Scotland Yard would say only that a man in his mid-30s had appeared by prior arrangement - Mr Morgan is 35.

webTitle: Martin Woollacott: The dangers of sea power

fields.headline: Dangerous dragons are lurking under the sea
fields.standfirst:
Submarines are risky and expensive, but everyone wants them
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Submarines are risky and expensive, but everyone wants them.
fields.body:
The fate of the Kursk cast a fitful light on a drama beneath the waves to which we normally give little thought. The 500 or so submarines of many nations that ply their stealthy way through the oceans may not seem a large number. But submarine competition between countries is a cause of problems and dangers worthy of sustained attention.

This is an undersea world in which new technologies are barely under control at the same time as old technologies decay and collapse. It is also a world in which largely untested theories of offence and defence drive hugely expensive developments which could engender the very conflicts governments seek to avoid through the maintenance of naval strength.

Submarines represent at the same time the least vulnerable way of carrying and launching nuclear weapons and the most effective way of limiting a nuclear strike by destroying some of the other side's ballistic missile submarines. Apart from their deterrent function, they are a vital element in maintaining control of the high seas. They are also vital in sea-based intervention - in the so-called "expeditionary" strategy to which most navies now subscribe, whether they see their job as mounting such expeditions or defeating them.

The submarine, in other words, underpins deterrence, sustains sea control, and is critical in intervention. But one has to pause here to question the logic of all this.

What was the Kursk doing in the Barents sea? It was presumably practising its main job, which is to protect Russian ballistic submarines from American attack submarines - perhaps also to attack American ballistic-missile submarines, if the balance between the two navies were ever to permit that. When you render down what the Kursk's captain wrote to the mother of one his young sailors, with its impressive phrases like "battle capable", this is what was meant: the Kursk's job was to ensure that Russia's ballistic submarines could launch as many nuclear missiles as possible at North America and western Europe.

Why is Russia still doing this, when a nuclear war between the west and Russia has become inconceivable? The Russian navy has been run down to the point where its surface fleet is about the same size as Britain's, but it still has a large submarine force with deterrence as its main function.

In part, Moscow goes on with this because submarines are something it was good at in the cold war. The new Akula class, extremely difficult to detect and powerfully armed, was giving western admirals nightmares as that conflict ended. In part, Moscow goes on with it because the United States' approach to nuclear arms control is lackadaisical and compromised by the recent infatuation with national missile defence. Those policies almost force Russia to continue to deploy nuclear weapons to which it is "entitled," and which can be seen as bargaining chips in negotiations with America. Finally, of course, there is Vladimir Putin's desire to reform and strengthen Russia's military forces as a means of restoring its prestige, influence, and national pride.

Reasons in plenty - but are any of them good enough, singly or altogether, to justify not just sending young men and boys to the bottom, but the risks run by the whole world when a nation at an economic and technological low attempts to keep a superpower navy at sea?

There is a dangerous irrationality here, but it is not just Russian. Nuclear submarines are on the technological frontier. They are not easy things to keep going, as the Royal Navy has found: one of our submarines has been languishing unrepaired in Gibraltar since May, and some believe that nine of 12 of our non-ballistic boats are out of service at any one time. The French probably have similar problems. Chinese nuclear submarines rarely put to sea. When they do, fingers are crossed. Other countries, some of them even less capable of controlling the technology, are beginning to hanker after nuclear submarines.

It is probably true that the only navy that can run a fleet of nuclear-powered submarines efficiently and safely is that of the US, but even there accidents have happened. When we thought we all had to do these things, such risks could be defended with a degree of plausibility that is lacking now. The costs, meanwhile, are large. The next generation of American nuclear submarines will cost $2bn each. Then there is the cost of disposing of obsolete craft. The terrible scale of the Russian problem is known, but the problem is not confined to them.

Acquisition of submarines by countries which previously had few or none goes on. In most cases, governments seek to buy conventional submarines - but they do so in part to counter the advantage of countries which have nuclear-powered submarines. Developments initially to do with deterrence are thus closely linked with those to do with conventional conflicts.

The strategy, or rather strategies, that have emerged divide the globe into two classes - those who can project power, and those who wish to frustrate that projection. Submarines are arguably the most important single instrument for both classes. For the supreme power projector, the US, the submarine is a valuable collector of intelligence, the safest platform for precision strikes against land targets and a vital protector of surface ships.

Those who aspire to some capacity to project power, like Russia, China, Britain and France, follow, at a huge remove, down this American road. But, equally, for those who want to offer effective resistance to a descent on their shores by the forces of the US, American-led coalitions, or other big countries, the submarine is the weapon of choice.

Improved propulsion systems for conventional submarines which give them more endurance and make them harder to detect, as well as better weapons and targeting techniques, mean that relatively weak countries can mount a serious threat to expeditionary forces, including the nuclear submarines that accompany them. Where such intervention depends on an assurance of low casualties, such threats might be effective.

As the cold war ended, a British naval officer wrote that "we are going to need a strategy that doesn't start with the Threat". There have been, and continue to be, ways in which sea power can enhance the security of the nations, stop or limit conflicts, rescue people in trouble or bring aid to them. But the pity is that we have held on to "the Threat" by maintaining, on both sides, submarine forces built around the deterrent. Even if those forces are somewhat reduced, they are surely still indefensible. At the same time we could face a new naval race between intervening powers and those who would resist them. There are indeed dragons under the sea.

webTitle: Tony Booth urges son-in-law Blair to boost pensions

fields.headline: Tony Booth urges son-in-law Blair to boost pensions
fields.trailText: The prime minister will today be told by his father-in-law to seize control of state pensions from the Treasury and offer a fairer deal to older people.
fields.body:
The prime minister will today be told by his father-in-law to seize control of state pensions from the Treasury and offer a fairer deal to older people.

Tony Booth, the actor, makes his intervention in the bulletin of the National Pensioners Convention, which is led by Jack Jones, the former transport workers' leader. Mr Jones is planning to launch an offensive on pensions at the Labour conference later this month.

Although Mr Booth, Cherie Blair's father, has previously criticised the government's style and centralising tendencies, this is understood to be his first attack on policy. fields.headline: Herb 'can cure depression'
fields.standfirst: St John's wort matches drug in test on patients
fields.trailText: St John's wort, a herb used for thousands of years to treat nervous complaints, has been found to be just as effective in treating mild to moderate depression as a leading antidepressant drug.
fields.body:
St John's wort, a herb used for thousands of years to treat nervous complaints, has been found to be just as effective in treating mild to moderate depression as a leading antidepressant drug.

Hippocrates, Pliny and Galen all described St John's wort, which has the Latin name hypericum perforatum, as a treatment against possession by demons in ancient Greece.

It is available over the counter in high street pharmacies. A paper in the British Medical Journal says doctors should give it to depressed patients in preference to imipramine, the most commonly used tricyclic antidepressant medicine.

There have been small studies of St John's wort's effect on depression before, but this research compared the herb with the full dose of imipramine that would normally be prescribed for mild to moderate depression.

The study involved 324 out patients at 40 clinics in Germany, half of whom were given St John's wort and half the antidepressant. The patients did not know which they were receiving. Their decreasing depression was measured using standard psychiatric tests.

The scientists, led by Helmut Woelk, medical director of the Akademisches Lehrkrankenhaus der Universität Giessen, found that St John's wort was just as effective in alleviating the depression of the patients as was the conventional drug, with fewer side-effects.

"In view of the mounting evidence of hypericum's comparable efficacy to other antidepressants and its safety record, hypericum should be considered for first line treatment in mild to moderate depression," they write.

There may be reluctance among some GPs in the UK to begin prescribing a herbal medicine in preference to tricyclic antidepressants, but there is likely to be enthusiasm among patients. Herbal medicines have become increasingly popular, causing concern in medical circles because herbs can interact with conventional medicines. Patients who take them often do not tell the doctor, either because they do not see the need or for fear of scorn.

There have been warnings that St John's wort can affect transplant patients by countering the anti-rejection drug cyclosporin. The medicines control agency has also warned that the herb can interfere with the contraceptive pill.

The study found, however, that taken by itself for depression, it did not cause the side-effects typical of the tricyclics - dry mouth, sweating, dizziness, nausea, asthenia and headache.

In the imipramine group, 41 (25%) had one or more of these side-effects. In the St John's wort group, 13 (8%) reported side effects, the most common of which was a dry mouth. Four patients on St John's wort dropped out of the study because of side-effects, compared with 26 on imipramine.

The biggest worry over the tricyclic antidepressants is the possibility of fatal overdose. The Prozac class of drugs, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), have become more popular because there is no such risk, but there have been other concerns about their safety.

The report says: "Patients seen in general practice frequently prefer to bear the symptoms of depression rather than sustain the side-effects of treatment with antidepressants. An effective antidepressant with no (or comparatively few) side effects would be an optimal treatment. Hypericum seems to meet these criteria."

Alternative cures

Herbal medicine aficionados say thousands of years of use prove effectiveness; doctors demand scientific proof. Few clinical trials have been done, but some herbs have shown promising results

Garlic Shown to reduce high blood pressure

Gingko biloba The leaves of this Chinese tree are used to improve blood circulation to the brain, improving memory - possibly for Alzheimer's sufferers

Hawthorn Popular in the middle ages, berries are used to increase blood flow to the heart, reducing angina symptoms

Saw palmetto North American berries. A small study has shown they can shrink a benign prostate swelling

Valerian Used as a sedative since Roman times.

fields.headline: Scoot.com 'vulnerable' to Vivendi
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Scoot.com is a takeover target for its largest shareholder, Vivendi, analysts claimed yesterday, as the online publisher announced it would move into profitability next year.
fields.body:
Scoot.com is a takeover target for its largest shareholder, Vivendi, analysts claimed yesterday, as the online publisher announced it would move into profitability next year.

Scoot.com released its third-quarter results yesterday, which saw losses grow from £13.9m to £19.9m. The substantial increase was blamed on a change in the group's pricing model for its directory service, which saw it shift from charging customers a fixed price to a variable fee.

The company said it would be in profit in 2001 - a year earlier than expected.

Robert Bonnier, the chief executive, said the firm's subscriber base had grown by 16% in the quarter and that he expected that rate to be higher in the present three-month period. An increase in sales staff led to a rise in the number of new subscribers.

The churn rate - the measure of Scoot.com customers who transfer to a competitor - fell from 9.6% to 8.4% during the same period.

Analysts welcomed the improving results but said the weak share price was making Scoot.com vulnerable to being mopped up by Vivendi. The French group recently increased its stake in Scoot.com from 11.5% to 22.4%.

Shares in Scoot.com rose by 2% to 127.25p yesterday.

"Scoot.com is a company with a history of underachievement," said Nick Bubb, an analyst at SG Securities. "Vivendi will buy it - or someone else will buy it". Mr Bonnier declined to comment.

webTitle: Rodents keep falling on my head

fields.headline: Rodents keep falling on my head
fields.trailText: Obese mice are raining on to the streets of Palermo after losing their ability to jump from rooftop to rooftop.
fields.body:
Obese mice are raining on to the streets of Palermo after losing their ability to jump from rooftop to rooftop.

Residents of the Sicilian capital erected barricades around the Via Papireto in protest after some pedestrians were hit by falling mice and the street became littered with scores of bloody corpses.

The mice had been fed and sheltered by an elderly woman who lived alone in the top flat of a block in the street. Thanks to her efforts, their numbers swelled to several hundred.

Last week she was moved to a nursing home, and it is assumed that her pets grew hungry and went searching for food. But fattened by coddling, they lost the ability to scale drainpipes and leap on to window sills, skills retained by mice in other parts of city.

Unfortunately, the Via Papireto - situated between a 12th-century Norman cathedral housing the tomb of Frederick II and the Piazza Vittorio Emanuele Orlando - is popular with tourists and is near where the Sicilians will host a UN conference on organised crime in November, so the problem had to be tackled.

Residents were persuaded to take down the barricades after the council promised to help.

"They are orphans, there is no one to feed them now so they have been forced to go wandering. It is not funny, it is sad," said one council official.

Exterminators moved in yesterday, but many of the mice were fit enough to run and hide. The job was due to be completed at dawn today.

Italy's animal rights activists, who have succeeded in establishing colonies for cats and sex entitlements for dogs, have not objected.

fields.headline: Watchdog warns of net monopolies
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance

Net news
fields.trailText: E-commerce firms could exploit monopoly powers to rip off consumers, the office of fair trading warned yesterday.
fields.body:
E-commerce firms could exploit monopoly powers to rip off consumers, the office of fair trading warned yesterday.

"Competition authorities worldwide are facing the challenge of ensuring e-commerce flourishes in a competitive environment," said John Bridgeman, director general of fair trading. "The balance to be struck is that of protecting consumers without stifling innovation."

Setting-up costs on the internet are comparatively low, which should promote competition, but the OFT said firms that grab the limelight by being the first to enter an area of e-commerce might gain an entrenched position.

"Reputation, branding and customer loyalty will become increasingly important and may create significant first-mover advantages," the OFT said. It also noted that many online markets tend to be natural monopolies.

The good news for consumers, according to the OFT, is the internet will make it easier to compare prices in a global market place and buy from the cheapest supplier. It was examining existing rules to ensure it was monitoring e-commerce effectively.

"Whether existing competition law is up to the task of dealing with this new and constantly evolving market is an issue being considered by many competition authorities."
