webTitle: Britain faces fight to keep Serb sanctions

fields.headline: Britain faces fight to keep Serb sanctions
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: France will exploit its current position as EU president this weekend to push for sanctions against Slobodan Milosevic's Yugoslavia to be watered down or even dropped, a move which Britain opposes strongly.
fields.body:
France will exploit its current position as EU president this weekend to push for sanctions against Slobodan Milosevic's Yugoslavia to be watered down or even dropped, a move which Britain opposes strongly.

The timing of the initiative is particularly sensitive since Yugoslav parliamentary and presidential elections are due to be held on September 24 and supporters of the sanctions believe that any change in policy now risks boosting Mr Milosevic's popularity.

Britain's foreign secretary, Robin Cook, is likely to find himself virtually isolated, however, when he meets his European counterparts this weekend for a meeting in the French resort of Evian.

Only the Netherlands and Denmark are said to back Britain's hard line and other countries have made no secret of the fact that they believe the sanctions are flawed and ineffective.

Although the Evian meeting is informal and is not expected to yield any concrete decisions, the Foreign Office will be aware that such meetings are often used to pave the way for formal decisions shortly afterwards.

Consensus on the sanctions - which include an oil embargo, a ban on doing business with most Yugoslav firms, and travel restrictions on government officials - crumbled in July at a similar EU meeting.

Hubert Védrine, the French foreign minister, said in a recent letter to European foreign ministers: "It's obvious that our action (towards Serbia) has not yielded the desired results and that several of us are of the opinion that some of the measures we have imposed like the sanctions remain ineffective and even counter-productive.

"It will be indispensable to evaluate our policy on the eve of these very important elections."

The stated aim of the sanctions was to undermine Mr Milosevic but many countries are convinced that they have served only to impoverish ordinary Serbs and have allowed the Yugoslav strongman to portray himself and his country as the victim of international bullying.

Britain begs to differ, however, and believes that the current "carrot and stick" approach which is designed to hurt the Milosevic regime while simultaneously promoting democracy should be continued.

Foreign Office officials played down the prospect of confrontation on the issue and said they had no problem discussing different scenarios for action after the elections. They acknowledged, however, that they were still "firmly" opposed to any move to lift the sanctions.

"You've got to play this incredibly carefully because Mr Milosevic has made a career of pretending that Yugoslavia is being bullied," one official said.

Serbia is not the only subject on the agenda this weekend. France is expected to float for the first time a controversial idea to hold yet another landmark EU summit to reform the 15-nation bloc. A major summit is already planned for Nice in December with the aim of preparing for enlargement, and the French are keen to start thinking about further reforms afterwards.

There are fears in Britain that the idea of yet another summit would be to make progress on the contentious idea of a two-speed Europe. There is also speculation that such a summit might be used to draw up a European constitution, the stuff of nightmares for Britain's eurosceptics.

The EU's highly criticised £7bn a year programme of external aid is also up for review. Slammed by the commissioner in charge of it, Chris Patten, and dubbed the worst aid system in the world by Clare Short, it is in need of an overhaul. Ministers are pushing for a greater say in deciding its priorities and are likely to get their way.

The final topic on the agenda will be the Middle East. With a Palestinian threat to declare an independent state on September 13 if the peace process does not produce an agreement, the EU must consider how it would respond to such a dramatic development.

webTitle: Schröder lays flowers as race victims hide

fields.headline: Schröder lays flowers as race victims hide
fields.trailText: As the chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, paid his respects yesterday to the immigrant whose murder ignited an international scandal about Germany's neo-Nazi right, it emerged that the dead man's widow had fled her home in fear of her life and was living in hiding under police protection.
fields.body:
As the chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, paid his respects yesterday to the immigrant whose murder ignited an international scandal about Germany's neo-Nazi right, it emerged that the dead man's widow had fled her home in fear of her life and was living in hiding under police protection.

Three young men set upon the Mozambique-born Alberto Adriano in a park in the eastern city of Dessau on June 11 and kicked him for so long and so hard that he died from his injuries three days later.

His murder helped jolt Germany's political leaders into a new assessment of the threat posed by the extreme right.

Adriano's German-born wife Angelika was not in court on Wednesday for the sentencing of her husband's murderers. The eldest of the three racist thugs who attacked him was given a life sentence. His two 16-year-old accomplices got nine years each.

John Greene, an American who represents an anti-discrimination group in Dessau, said yesterday that Ms Adriano left her home on Saturday. "I know that she planned it after receiving threatening telephone calls. Then a letter came threatening her life and the lives of her children," he said.

A leader of the immigrant community in Dessau said the writer of the letter had threatened to blow up the flat she shares with her three children, the youngest of whom is six months old.

The letter also abused her for having married an African and said her children would be infected with Aids as a result.

Against a background of spreading European concern about the far right, Mr Schröder was joined yesterday by the Finnish prime minister, Paavo Lipponen, on a visit to Dessau. The visit was intended to highlight the German government's determination to curb neo-Nazism.

Mr Schröder laid a wreath of yellow flowers at the little monument which local officials have erected at the site of the murder. But, astonishingly, no arrangements were made for the chancellor to meet Mrs Adriano.

Nor did he have any but the most fleeting contact with those working against racism in the city: he shook hands with the head of the city's multi-cultural institute.

Nobody doubts his determination to tackle far-right violence, but he will have his hands full: xenophobia seems to be entrenched in many regions of Germany, particularly in the east.

Heinz Wolf, a retired man, who watched Mr Schröder lay his tribute of flowers, said he had little respect for the gesture.

"This won't change anything," he said."Why do we bring so many foreigners here when we have enough problems ourselves?"

Today Mr Schröder will reach the end of a marathon tour of eastern Germany which has been dominated by the issue of far-right violence. Yet not a single meeting with race-relations workers has figured on his itinerary.

Nor is there any evidence of his having discussed the issue with members of the immigrant community.

As he visited Dessau, a new race row erupted in the state parliament in Hesse, the region which includes Frankfurt.

The local leader of the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) made a formal apology after Green party members claimed that a Christian Democrat MP had told a foreign-born Green MP to go back where he came from.

They said that during a heated debate Tarek al-Wazir, who has German citizenship and a Yemeni father, was told to "go back to Sana'a".

CDU members said that the phrase had been misheard, but the leader of their parliamentary group made an unconditional apology.

Elsewhere, police in the eastern town of Cottbus reported that a group of youths shouting "Sieg Heil" and giving the Nazi salute had tossed two crude Molotov cocktails on to the footbpath in front of a building housing a youth club called "Multi-cultural Europe". There were no injuries and no damage.

Near Stuttgart, in south-west Germany, three skinheads, ages 18 to 21, faced charges after confessing to lighting a fire in a home for asylum seekers on Wednesday. Two of the 79 residents were slightly injuring during the evacuation.

Near Stuttgart, in south-west Germany, three skinheads, ages 18 to 21, faced charges after confessing to lighting a fire in a home for asylum seekers on Wednesday. Two of the 79 residents were slightly injuring during the evacuation.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 When a grand old institution finds itself in trouble, it must reconnect with its public, just as the Queen sought to do three years ago when she returned to London to address a rebellious nation about Diana's death. It's a lesson Marks & Spencer might do well to study. Beverley King writes to report that although BHS, C&A and many others are on this year's list of stores accepting Working Families Tax Credit school uniform vouchers, her preferred supplier M&S has vanished. Knowing the firm to be a signatory to the Children's Promise and to claim a heightened awareness of children's needs, she was baffled and emailed asking for an explanation. Customer relations replied that the process is too difficult and time-consuming. "I am so upset," Beverley writes. "It is awful going into a shop anyway with these vouchers... Now I feel even worse because M&S say that low income families aren't worth the effort." Three efforts to discuss the matter with M&S have failed, so all we can say for now is shame on you Marks, shame on you Spencer. Poorest of shows.

 I am upset to note in a Sunday Mirror report that Diary vicar the Rev Steve Chalke gave the blessing ("brought to this congregation by Cadbury's Time Out," apparently) at Anthea Turner's elegant wedding to Grant Bovey. Like M&S, Steve fails to return messages, and it just won't do. A little less celeb blessing, a little more Diary sermonising... that's the ticket for the media conscious Baptist minister of today.

 A press release arrives from Norfolk and Norwich NHS Trust. "Mr Reggie Kray: Mr Kray had a comfortable night," it reads, "and his condition remains unchanged." This is fine as far as it goes (although "Mr Reginald Kray" is more respectful), but isn't it time to do things properly and start posting hourly bulletins outside the Blind Beggar? We'll have a word in the shell-like of Tory candidate for Henley, Boris the Jackal Johnson, and see if he can't do something to put this right.

 On Wednesday, as part of its splendid National Cleavage Week, the Sun bought its bouncing Cleavage Bus to our offices, and yet nowhere in its two-page report is there mention of the bus smashing into that great modern Sun icon, a white van. Furious Clive Tiernan leapt out of his van and gesticulated at the bus driver before swapping insurance details. "I dunno if I'll press charges," fumed Clive to Diaryman Richard Adams. "It's up to my company, see what they think." But what, as a White Van Man, do you think of the driver? "He should be looking at the road and not at the f***ing cleavage."

 Gerald Kaufman Month is over, alas, for another year. There are a couple of loose ends (one involves an ad campaign for new Cadbury's Snowflake) which we will tie up on Tuesday... when we will also bid farewell to that doughtiest of August space-fillers, the amusing tourist attraction.

 Perhaps predictably, meanwhile, the special report on our trip to Leeds in the Rolls-Royce convertible RR1 provided another triumph for our fact-checkers. The ex-Labour councillor featured is Garth Frankland, not Gareth. He was not expelled from the Labour party, but left to join the Left Alliance. Cowper St School is in Chapeltown, not Middleton. I could go on. But I won't. I haven't the strength.

 For all those sneerers who believe that Lottery Commission chair Dame Helena Shovelton appeared confused about what to do with the franchise, there is an explanation. One of the quango queen's other gigs is as a member of the Competition Commission, former Monopolies and Mergers. Half the time she's trying to break monopolies, in other words, the other half she's trying to award the juiciest monopoly of them all. Poor old thing, no wonder she doesn't know whether she's Arthur or Martha.

webTitle: Business: London Bridge makes rapid recovery

fields.headline: London Bridge makes rapid recovery
fields.trailText: Financial software group London Bridge has reported a 40% increase in turnover for the six months to June 30 - despite what proved to be a difficult first quarter of trading.
fields.body:
Financial software group London Bridge has reported a 40% increase in turnover for the six months to June 30 - despite what proved to be a difficult first quarter of trading.

The company said that while business in the first quarter of the year was affected by clients taking their time over the implementation of major IT decisions, the second quarter had seen a rapid recovery.

Chairman Gordon Crawford said: "In common with most financial software product suppliers, the first quarter of 2000 was relatively slow as clients began to consider new projects following the completion of year 2000-related projects."

Mr Crawford, who became one of the country's wealthiest e-millionaires during the boom in hi-tech stocks earlier this year, said a surge in new orders throughout March and April had helped produce the strong second quarter.

Orders for fulfilment after the report period were, he said, at their highest level in the company's history.

The group, which specialises in the development of credit risk management software, had enjoyed a strong full year in 1999, when profits rose by 30% to £11m.

Revenues for the first half of 2000 totalled £27.2m, up £8m from the same period in 1999.

However, adjusted profits rose by just £200,000 to £5.7m. The small increase was attributed to investment in product development and restructuring of the company's US operation.

Chief operating officer Jon Lee said increased investment in research and development would continue and the group was on course for a strong second half.

London Bridge Software recently bought a 10% stake in US private software firm Aspen Grove and is "evaluating the potential acquisition" of banking software company Phoenix International. The firm has also announced partnerships with Sema and NTL.

Analysts reacted positively to the results and shares were bouyant yesterday, gaining 105p to close at 985p.

An interim dividend of 0.35p will be paid.

webTitle: A Country Diary: Mind those leeks

fields.headline: Mind those leeks
fields.standfirst: Northumberland
fields.trailText: The Romans introduced the leek to the north-east, where soldiers patrolling Hadrian's Wall must have been glad of the vegetables' sustenance during harsh winters. Leeks provided vitamin C, which prevented scurvy. Today, doctors, teachers, redundant miners, butchers and the retired, succumb to gallium proem "exhibition", which means growing pot leeks to gargantuan proportion.
fields.body:
The Romans introduced the leek to the north-east, where soldiers patrolling Hadrian's Wall must have been glad of the vegetables' sustenance during harsh winters. Leeks provided vitamin C, which prevented scurvy. Today, doctors, teachers, redundant miners, butchers and the retired, succumb to gallium proem "exhibition", which means growing pot leeks to gargantuan proportion.

In early January the monsters start and they reach the show bench in September. "A show leek increases its weight 9m times within a nine-month period," said a man who is the doyen of our local leek club. "Leeks need warmth, water, fertilisers, fungicides and pesticides in varying amounts at critical times."

The idea is to have them in peak condition on show day. The champs must be edible, no hard woody centres run to seed are permitted. An ideal leek should be 14 ins (30-35 cm) long, with no bulbing and white for 2/3rds of its length with dark green foliage. Success can come from a chance seedling showing size and quality whose progeny will emulate it, more often it is a process of years of reselection to obtain the exhibitors desired qualities.

The leek has provided an important pastime here from the time of the industrial revolution. Depressed wages and long working hours under harsh conditions, especially in the pits, created their own problems and gardening provided an escapism. Nurturing flowers and vegetables helped give purpose to life in colliery villages, providing both solitude and a measure of companionship. Money-raising events are held during the months leading up to the show in order to swell the purse and a feature is that every entrant receives a prize corresponding to his leeks position in the show so the total prize money available is important for everyone.

Feelings run high, theft and vandalism may not be as endemic as leek viruses, but overnight decapitation is not unknown. "We'll swop ideas and drop hints on the right strain of seedlings," said my friend. "But on show day it is every man for himself. I never take a holiday in the summer now, I can't leave my leeks."

webTitle: Bullish 365 ready to snap up ailing rivals

fields.headline: Bullish 365 ready to snap up ailing rivals
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Shares in 365 Corporation, the internet content firm best known for its irreverent sports websites, received a much needed kick yesterday after it reported a strong set of first-quarter results.
fields.body:
Shares in 365 Corporation, the internet content firm best known for its irreverent sports websites, received a much needed kick yesterday after it reported a strong set of first-quarter results.

The shares climbed 15% to 81.5p after 365 revealed that revenues for the quarter had jumped 37% to £10m and gross profits had risen by the same margin to £4m. Pre-tax losses widened from £2.9m to £3.4m as a result of investment in new products, chief executive Dan Thompson said.

"These are quality revenue figures and we are starting to talk quite substantial figures," he said, pointing to the 2.1m users of the service.

Shares in 365 are languishing at less than a third of their year's high of 305p, however.

Mr Thompson believes that, with £45m in the bank, 365 is well positioned to drive consolidation in its sector. Several privately owned sports and entertainment content companies are struggling to raise funds and many have approached 365 about possible sales.

The company is thought be examining about 10 possible acquisitions across its telecoms, business and content divisions.

Management is also thought to be prepared to hive off the business division into a separately listed entity if the group's share price does not improve soon.

Analysts expect the unit to generate around £22m in sales this year and value it at around £110m. The value of 365 is put at £163m.

webTitle: Financiers have stars in their eyes

fields.headline: Financiers have stars in their eyes
fields.standfirst: Spacey sales pitch makes dramatic converts in City
fields.trailText: Actor Kevin Spacey has won over audiences as a serial killer, a hostage negotiator and an American suburbanite going through a mid-life crisis. Now he is repeating the trick in his new real life role as a business consultant.
fields.body:
Actor Kevin Spacey has won over audiences as a serial killer, a hostage negotiator and an American suburbanite going through a mid-life crisis. Now he is repeating the trick in his new real life role as a business consultant.

Instead of treading the boards on Broadway in front of the New York cognoscenti, Mr Spacey was earlier this month in the basement presentation room of Bloomberg's London headquarters, addressing a selection of fund managers from institutions including Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley and UBS Warburg.

Mr Spacey was trying to convince them to buy shares in Old Vic Productions, a new company being set up by the London theatre to fund plays and other theatrical events. It is looking to raise more than £1m from 200-350 investors. The Hollywood actor has already put in his own cash.

According to one observer it was an other Oscar-worthy performance. "I don't think the fund managers knew what to expect when they turned up and at first they just sat there, arms folded and looking pretty sceptical," said the source. "By the time Kevin had done his bit a lot of them were ready to invest."

Demand for shares since Mr Spacey's star turn has been phenomenal, according to Old Vic managing director Michael Morris. The share offer is due to close at 5pm on Sunday but it might be extended to cope with the level of interest.

Old Vic Productions is a relaunch of Criterion Productions, which was set up in 1994, raised some money through one of the last Business Expansion Schemes and is still going strong. Last year it made a post-tax profit of £71,514 on turnover of £108,876.

About eight out of every 10 West End productions lose money. Criterion Productions has a better hit rate than most, having co-produced The Weir, and invested in recent hits The Graduate, The Blue Room and De La Guarda.

While there might be no financial bonanza, for those who want to rub shoulders with theatreland's great and good the benefits in kind are immediate and increase in line with the size of the sum stumped up.

Investing the minimum sum of £2,000 earns a free ticket to all of the company's first night performances, regular newsletters and priority bookings. For £25,000 or more the investor receives 10 complimentary tickets for all the first night productions, a dinner party at The Ivy with stage stars and champagne receptions backstage.

It is the latter package and the corporate entertainment that come with it that the big City institutions are particularly excited about. Investors will also qualify for tax relief of 20% under the Enterprise Investment Scheme (EIS). Old Vic Productions plans to invest in a variety of shows so the fate of the investment does not hang on the success of a single play.

Some of the biggest hitters in the West End are backing the venture. Lord Attenborough is chairman, with Dame Judi Dench, Jeremy Irons and David Suchet as directors.

Associate directors of the Old Vic theatre itself include Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson, Talk magazine editor Tina Brown and advertising chief Charles Saatchi.

Old Vic Productions' fund-raising comes during a period of renewed financial interest in the West End. Audience levels are high, management of theatres is becoming more sophisticated and ownership of venues is rapidly consolidating.

In the past year or so Lord Lloyd Webber, the force behind some of the most successful musicals in history including Phantom of the Opera, Cats and Starlight Express, has built up his portfolio of London theatres to 13. His Really Useful theatre group has bought the Stoll Moss business, ownerof the Theatre Royal Drury Lane and several other properties, with the backing of private equity group Bridgepoint Capital for around £87m.

SFX, the sports and entertainment operation recently bought by Clear Channel, has taken over the Apollo group. Producer Cameron Mackintosh has expanded his portfolio while Howard Pante and Peter Beckwith's Ambassador Group now owns nine theatres.

Adam Maidment of Bridgepoint Capital believes West End theatres are an increasingly sound investment. "West End theatre audiences over the past 20 or 30 years have always remained at reasonably consistent levels," he said. "Audience levels seem to be insensitive to economic upswings and downswings."

Bridgepoint believes theatres can also be put to better use - for concerts and conferences - during quiet times when live performances are not taking place. "Venues like the Theatre Royal and the Palladium are spectacular, unique assets known the world over and yet historically they have been largely underutilised."

Players - Who owns the West End

Really Useful Group Apollo, Adelphi, Cambridge, Duchess, Drury Lane, Garrick, Gielgud, Her Majesty's, New London, London Palladium, Lyric, Palace, Queen's

Ambassadors Theatre Group Albery, Comedy, Donmar, Duke of York's, New Ambassadors, Phoenix, Piccadilly, Whitehall, Wyndham's

SFX Apollo Victoria, Dominion, London Apollo Hammersmith, Lyceum

Cameron Mackintosh Prince of Wales, Prince Edward. Deals also in place for the Albery, Gielgud, Queen's, Strand. Wyndham's to come under Mackintosh's control over the next five or six years

Sir Stephen Whalley-Cohen, impresario Savoy, St Martin's, Vaudeville, Victoria Palace

Individually owned Aldwych, Criterion, Fortune, Old Vic, Peacock, Playhouse, Shaftesbury, Strand, Theatre Royal

fields.headline: GM crops threaten skylarks
fields.standfirst: Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: Genetically modified crops could spell trouble for skylarks on farms, according to a study published in the US journal Science.
fields.body:
Genetically modified crops could spell trouble for skylarks on farms, according to a study published in the US journal Science.

Andrew Watkinson and his colleagues, from the University of East Anglia, fashioned a computer model of what would happen as farmers sowed herbicide-resistant crops, such as sugar beet, and then sprayed them to wipe out the weeds that lower farm yields. They found that the introduction of such crops could reduce weeds by more than 90%.

The drawback is that farmland birds such as the skylark depend on weed seeds such as fat hen, especially in winter. The more weeds in a crop, the greater the number of skylarks in the vicinity.

"For a variety of social, ecological and economic reasons, some farms contain much higher seed densities than others. If farms such as these opt to grow GM crops, the impact on birds could be particularly severe," said Professor Watkinson.

Although there have been claims that GM foods could present a hazard to human health, most of the objections to their introduction in Britain have been based on their effect on wildlife. Researchers in the US have twice proposed that some genetically modified crops could affect monarch butterfly populations.

In Britain, farmland seed-eaters have been in trouble for decades. The linnet has dwindled by more than 40%, the skylark and the yellowhammer by 60% and the tree sparrow by 87% in 25 years.

Field trials for GM crops are about to begin, with the aim of answering questions about their effects on biodiversity. Prof Watkinson believes that valuable as these trials are, they will not reveal much about bird populations.

He said: "They are carried out on too small a scale. One considerable advantage of the methodology we have adopted is that it enables us to make predictions now rather than wait for the results of a three year trial."

fields.headline: Eidos stays silent
fields.trailText: Eidos, the computer games group, yesterday failed to give an update on its long-running takeover talks but insisted that it was well positioned to weather the downturn in the games market while negotiations rumbled on.
fields.body:
Eidos, the computer games group, yesterday failed to give an update on its long-running takeover talks but insisted that it was well positioned to weather the downturn in the games market while negotiations rumbled on.

Analysts expressed disappointment that almost three months after the talks were first announced the company was not able to give them more concrete information. French rival Infogrames has admitted an interest.

Eidos chief operating officer, Mike McGarvey, speaking after reporting first-quarter results, said he understood the market's disappointment but he was "not in a position at this juncture to give any further details".

Analysts believe Eidos is trying to attract other bidders, even though several of the most obvious suitors have said they are not interested in joining an auction.

Mr McGarvey pointed to a strong schedule of forthcoming releases as evidence that the one-time star of the British computer games sector can climb out of the trough it has found itself in after issuing two profits warnings.

New games based on the films Chicken Run and 101 Dalmatians plus a movie version of its Tomb Raider franchise should help, he said. Sales across the games sector are down as players await the new generation of consoles.

Mr McGarvey hinted that none of the 40 new titles under development was likely to match the success of Tomb Raider, which has become one of the biggest selling games of all time. "As much as we'd like two or three more, I'm not sure they exist."

Mr McGarvey was speaking after reporting a pre-tax loss of £18.4m and revenues of £16.8 m for the three months to June 30. The figures were in line with what analysts had been expecting, following Eidos's profit warnings, and unchanged on a year ago.

Shares in Eidos fell almost 5% in early trading on disappointment at the lack of bid news but recovered to close up 6.25p at 495p.

fields.headline: Cheapskate ... where to eat out for under £15
fields.standfirst: Quick bites ... where to eat out in under 15 minutes
fields.trailText: Quick bites ... where to eat out in under 15 minutes
fields.body:
Simply Spice, 53 Calthorpe Street, London WC1. Tel: 020-7833 9787

Classy Indian restaurants are not as common as they might be. Classy Indian restaurants in hotels are virtually unheard of. Simply Spice in the Holiday Inn brightens up the no man's land between King's Cross and Farringdon. Focus on regional dishes, especially those of Goa, home region to the chef. You get the real, incendiary pork vindaloo, sublime imlidaar batak (duck in tamarind sauce) and a classic chicken xacutti with its 21 spices. Vegetarians get serious consideration (try the chole bhatura or paneer shaslik). The dining room is large, but it is comfortable and the service is considerate.

Mangiare, 4-6 Theobalds Road, London WC1. Tel: 020-7831 9268

The latest concept in fast street eats. Actually based on Italian original of pizza a taglio - a big square pizza, cut into portion sizes and served up on napkins to eat on the street. Here put into slick concept boxes to make a desktop statement when you eat it in the office. The pizzas are part cooked beforehand and then finished off to order to ensure freshness to the max. And they taste it. Spicy chorizo, quattro formaggi and pulcinella among the regulars. Cost: £2.25-£2.95. Easy to spot by its eye-searing mustard yellow corporate colour. Will roll out through London in time.

fields.headline: Nurses reject elderly care bill
fields.standfirst:
Fees for personal care unworkable, says RCN

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The government is facing an embarrassing revolt by nurses against the health bill to reform care of the elderly in residential homes.
fields.body:
The government is facing an embarrassing revolt by nurses against the health bill to reform care of the elderly in residential homes.

Ministers hoped the legislation, due to be announced in the Queen's speech later this year, would be a good advertisement for Tony Blair's national plan for the NHS and would particularly appeal to older voters in the run-up to a general election.

Yesterday the Royal College of Nursing said the government's hybrid scheme, to offer free nursing but charge for personal care in residential homes, was unworkable.

Christine Hancock, the college's general secretary and hitherto one of the NHS plan's staunchest supporters, said the college would lobby against "an artificial distinction" between nursing and personal care that would "create perverse incentives and inequities".

In a letter to Alan Milburn, the health secretary, she urged the government to consider the consequences for nearly 300,000 elderly people in residential care homes.

"We acknowledge the pressure for urgent action, but believe it unwise to move on legislation until these issues are properly resolved," she said.

The problem arose because of the government's rejection last month of one of the main recommendations of the royal commission on long term care, chaired by Sir Stewart Sutherland. In 1998 the commission proposed changes costing £1.1bn a year that included abolition of means-tested charges in residential homes for personal care, such as bathing, changing dressings and assistance with eating.

Mr Milburn said that he had rejected such free personal care because it would "consume most of the additional resources we plan to make available for older people through the NHS". He plans to spend £1.4bn a year to improve health and social services for the elderly, but most would go on "intermediate" care for older people, to reduce time spent by them in hospital.

His decision last month provoked anger from groups representing older people, some of whom have to sell their homes to pay for personal care in residential homes that would be free if they were in hospital.

Ms Hancock's objection yesterday focused on the health of these elderly people, rather than their wealth. "The plan states that 'in the future the NHS will meet the costs of registered nurse time spent on providing, delegating or supervising care in any setting'.

"But clearly, nursing care is not provided by registered nurses alone - a large amount of nursing care is delegated to health care assistants. Therefore the plan would create an artificial divide between nursing and personal care based on whether the care is provided by a registered nurse or healthcare assistant," she said. Perversely, this would discourage delegation of work to care assistants, as the government wanted.

Ms Hancock said the college was encouraged by most of the proposals in the NHS plan and supported the principle of extending free nursing care. "However, we are concerned that flaws in the approach to long term care funding will continue to undermine the potential benefits of such measures for the health and wellbeing of all older people," she said.

The Department of Health said ministers had not yet received the college's letter. They were proposing a broad definition of nursing care that would for the first time be free in all care homes. The college would be involved in drawing up a framework for assessing every resident's nursing needs, a spokeswoman said.

webTitle: Two-thirds of motorists ignore speed limits

fields.headline: Two-thirds of motorists ignore speed limits
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Most drivers exceed speed limits on clear roads, and two out of three ignore 30mph signs, according to a survey by the Department of Transport.
fields.body:
Most drivers exceed speed limits on clear roads, and two out of three ignore 30mph signs, according to a survey by the Department of Transport.

It found that 56% of car drivers surveyed exceeded 70mph and 19% exceeded 80mph.

On urban roads with a 30mph limit, two-thirds broke the limit, with almost a half of these going faster than 35mph.

The report, Vehicle Speeds in Great Britain: 1999, used data collected at 92 sites for the national traffic census.

On 40mph roads, a quarter of cars exceeded the limit, with 8% exceeding 45 mph. Motorcycles were the vehicles most likely to speed on 40mph urban roads, with 38% breaking the limit. Lorries were also identified as a problem. On urban 30mph roads, 45% of articulated heavy goods vehicles exceeded the limit.

Transport 2000, which accused the government recently of "wimping out" by refusing to impose 20mph limits in 30mph areas, commented yesterday that the survey proved there was a need for stronger enforcement by police and awareness from motorists that speeding was as unacceptable as drink-driving.

The group pointed out that 5,000 non-drivers - children, pedestrians and cyclists - were killed each year. "The first priority has to be to get drivers to realise they must not break the limit and that, if they do, they will be stopped and fined," said spokesman Steve Hounsham. "That 67% of drivers deliberately ignore limits is totally unacceptable. That's why we have such huge carnage on Britain's roads."

The RAC said the survey suggested there was a need to rethink speed limits. "I think 80mph would be a more reasonable limit for motorways, given that modern cars are much safer," said spokesman Jonathan Simpson. "In terms of urban roads, there's an argument for looking at limits more intelligently rather than just blanket speed reductions. Perhaps we could have 20mph limits around areas where there are vulnerable people such as schools.

"We need to educate the motorist to respect limits in specific areas, rather than following up knee-jerk reactions from organisations that call for massive crackdowns."

Yesterday, Denise van Outen, 25, pleaded guilty to driving at nearly double the speed limit in her VW Beetle and was warned she faced a driving ban. She admitted the offence by letter, and did not appear before magistrates at Beaconsfield in Buckinghamshire. Sentencing was adjourned for one month for her to appear in person. The former host of Channel 4's Big Breakfast was stopped on the M40 this year on her way to London from her £2m home at Horsenden Manor. Police recorded her doing 73mph past roadworks with a 40mph limit in place.

webTitle: Can I have a platonic marriage and a fulfilling sex life on the side?

fields.headline: Can I have a platonic marriage and a fulfilling sex life on the side?
fields.standfirst: Next week: Six years ago, I learned via an anonymous letter that my husband was having an affair with a woman 30 years his junior
fields.trailText: Private Lives: Next week: Six years ago, I learned via an anonymous letter that my husband was having an affair with a woman 30 years his junior.
fields.body:
My partner and I have been together for 15 years and still love each other deeply (I am 31 and he is 37). He was my first, and remains my only, sexual partner. But for the past five years we have not had a sexual relationship We have no children and are unlikely to ever have any, which makes us both sad. We have tried therapy to no avail. We have admitted that we no longer have sexual feelings for each other but we wish to stay together. My partner recently had a fulfilling sexual relationship with another woman, without wanting to leave our relationship. This aroused no jealousy in me. For the past two years I have been attracted to a friend, and he is aware of my feelings. I long to have a fulfilling sexual life, as well as my partnership with the man I love. My partner and I are also business partners and we enjoy running our small firm together. Is a platonic marriage, perhaps with adopted children, possible, or are we hopelessly deluded?

Leave your partner

What has happened is that your relationship has staled and you've fallen in love with someone else. It happens - enjoy it!

Your present partner is now your best friend, not your lover. He doesn't want you in bed, he doesn't want your children and he was probably amazed and relieved to note your tolerance of his adultery.

Haven't you got the message yet? It's over. Only convenience, mainly his, is keeping you together. Separate your business and personal lives, and move out. Mr Other-Bloke will be watching with interest. Ask him round to help you decorate.

You are still a young woman and you are entitled to a fulfilling sex life and the possibility of children with a man you love. It's a big step, I know, but you're strong enough. Believe me, you'll be happier than you ever dreamed possible. Good luck!

Jill, Crewe

Set sail and enjoy

You and your partner have been together a long time, and it seems that love and attraction have turned into cosy familiarity.

Although sex isn't the most important element of a relationship, it forms part of a solid foundation. Therefore when sex is non-existent in a previously fullfilling relationship, the whole structure of the relationship is apt to become very unstable or is undermined.

You have admitted to each other and a therapist that you no longer have sexual feelings towards one another yet still love one another and want to stay together. This seems to me the action of someone scared to let go of the safe and familiar. Why don't you open yourself to the possibilities of a whole new life?

You both yearn for a fulfilling sex life, and your partner has even experienced this. You admit sexual feelings for a friend. Are you really sure you felt no jealousy towards your partner's dalliance?

I do not believe that this is a good basis for a marriage and that it could be held together by friendship alone. What if one or both of you fell in love with anybody else?

As far as children are concerned, assuming you are both fertile, if you wanted them that badly and truly loved each other, you would have sex. If you both enjoy running your business then you could continue to do so without being married or even together, but just as friends and business partners with no other ties.

Everything you have experienced in your formative late-teenage years and young adulthood has been under the aegis of your partner. Suddenly to leave this safe, familiar harbour may seem like madness. But you know in your heart that it is something you must do. Set sail and enjoy.

Name and address withheld

Platonic is possible

You ask if a platonic marriage is possible. Well, yes, I think it's definitely possible for some people. What you need to find out is whether you and your partner are among those people for whom it works.

If it's any help, I can say how it works for me and my second husband. At the start, we were sexually very adventurous. But we realise now that this was mostly a reaction to the chilling sex lives we had with our first partners and also because it was novel to be free of our teenage children's cruelly condemming gaze on our previous marriages.

I have three children and he has two. They're all great but mercifully no longer part of our everyday lives.

Now, after six years together, we turn out to be not terribly interested in sex. But we have a rich, tender, romantic, funny, warm emotional and intellectual life together and we mean to preserve it.

We've often talked about how we reached this happy state and agree on two main requirements. Firstly, it won't work if you're not both reasonably confident, secure people who aren't needing more attention, love or approval than you're already getting from each other and from life in general. It's a good sign that you weren't jealous of his lover.

Could he say the same if you have an affair with the man you're attracted to? It would be best to discuss this first.

Secondly, there has to be absolute trust, honesty and respect between you - no lies, no deceptions, no point-scoring.

We've found that a platonic marriage can't cope with games-playing - it's too insulting. This is a lot to ask of any relationship but it sounds as if you're halfway there anyway. My best wishes.

J Walters, Sussex

Six years ago, I learned via an anonymous letter that my husband was having an affair with a woman 30 years his junior. Some detective work on my part turned his denials into a reluctant acknowledgement of a series of long-standing relationships with leading ladies at the amateur theatre where he acted and directed. After receiving counselling, I decided to stay with him and asked him to leave the theatre, which he did. It was at this time that redundancy in his lecturing post led to his taking retirement at 55. I continued to teach fulltime.

Since then, he has done nothing more than attend a 20-week recreational course in philosophy, deal with the supermarket shopping and cut the grass. In spite of my suggestions about voluntary work, a structured course of study, part-time work and travel, he spends his time in bed and reading. He is bored, and thoroughly bad-tempered, partly because of a sleep deficit resulting from the early stages of prostate cancer diagnosed three years ago, and partly because my work prevents my being lively, witty company to divert him in the evenings. He claims that my request for him to leave the theatre has "fettered his mind" and rendered him incapable of wanting to do anything beyond return to the amateur theatre to play King Lear. Is this really the only future for a childless, 61-year-old left-leaning liberal? If it is, how can I accept calmly his return to temptation?

Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. Write to Private Lives, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, fax 020 7239 9935, email private.lives@theguardian.com (please do not send attachments).

He is bored, and thoroughly bad-tempered, partly because of a sleep deficit resulting from the early stages of prostate cancer diagnosed three years ago, and partly because my work prevents my being lively, witty company to divert him in the evenings. He claims that my request for him to leave the theatre has "fettered his mind" and rendered him incapable of wanting to do anything beyond return to the amateur theatre to play King Lear. Is this really the only future for a childless, 61-year-old left-leaning liberal? If it is, how can I accept calmly his return to temptation? Private Lives appears every Friday. Each week we publish a letter to which readers are invited to respond. Replies, giving an account of your personal experience, should reach us by Thursday. Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. webTitle: Shayler states terms for helping police on Gadafy plot

fields.headline: Shayler states terms for helping police on Gadafy plot
fields.standfirst: Special report: David Shayler
fields.trailText: David Shayler, the former MI5 officer, has told the police special branch he is willing to help their investigation into the alleged involvement of MI6 in a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader Colonel Gadafy, but only so long as they are given full access to security and intelligence service files.
fields.body:
David Shayler, the former MI5 officer, has told the police special branch he is willing to help their investigation into the alleged involvement of MI6 in a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader Colonel Gadafy, but only so long as they are given full access to security and intelligence service files.

Commander Roger Pearce, head of the Metropolitan police special branch, said this month that he wanted to interview Mr Shayler about the allegation.

Yesterday, John Wadham, Mr Shayler's lawyer and director of Liberty, the civil rights group, wrote to Cdr Pearce saying they needed to ensure "first, that the security service (MI5) and the secret intelligence service (MI6) have already agreed that they will both make relevant officers available for interview; secondly, that both those organisations have agreed to make all relevant records, documents and other materials available to you".

In separate letters, Mr Wadham has asked Jack Straw (home secretary) and Robin Cook (foreign secretary) for their assurances that special branch officers would be given "proper and unrestricted access" to MI5 and MI6 files.

Details of alleged MI6 involvement in the Gadafy plot of 1996 - including the names of two MI6 officers - were sent to Mr Straw by Mr Shayler last November. Five months ago, they were handed to Scotland Yard by Annie Machon, Mr Shayler's girlfriend, also a former MI5 officer.

A secret MI6 report, dated 1995, confirming one of the plotters had approached an MI6 officer about the conspiracy and containing details of it was posted on the internet earlier this year.

Mr Shayler has been charged with original allegations he made about MI5 to the Mail on Sunday in August 1997 and with disclosing MI5 documents. He has not been charged in connection with his Gadafy plot allegations.

Scotland Yard said the inquiry into the allegations was at an "early stage".

fields.headline: Clampdown on tax dodge
fields.trailText: I heartily agree with C Mowat (Letters, August 28) on the removal of untaxed vehicles from the roads.
fields.body:
I heartily agree with C Mowat (Letters, August 28) on the removal of untaxed vehicles from the roads.

Two years ago I was run into from behind by an uninusured driver. I have paid inflated premiums for two years and have just had the repair excess refunded from the insurance company which has abandoned the case. Myself and the insurance company have paid on behalf of criminals.

Frances Barker
Ruddington, Notts

 The upset of a driver leaving an accident without giving details must also sometimes be due to them not being insured. Perhaps if magistrates didn't impose such small fines (in some cases one-tenth of a year's insurance) there would be less hit and run incidents.

Richard Chandler
Caldicot, Gwent

 The responsibility for vehicle excise duty enforcement rests primarily with the Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency. The DVLA has operated a nationwide scheme to wheelclamp and impound unlicensed vehicles since 1997 to help deal with evasion. It has proved to be very successful and has encouraged an additional 269,000 motorists to relicense their vehicles, bringing in over £30m in increased revenue. Relicensing also means compliance with insurance requirements as a certificate must be produced.

Sue Prest
Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency

 How about also improving driving to reduce accidents. In the US there are traffic police that keep traffic moving, fine motorists for speeding, crossing red traffic lights etc. This type of police could be easily paid from fines.

JA Breslaw
London

fields.headline: UN backs cyber pickets
fields.trailText: The UN's global compact initiative (Getting into bed with big business, August 31) is not a sinister deal with "the world's biggest and most controversial corporations", but incorporates business, international unions and civil society groups based on the universal declaration of human rights, the International Labour Organisation's fundamental principles and rights at work and the Earth Summit's agenda 21 principles on the environment.
fields.body:
The UN's global compact initiative (Getting into bed with big business, August 31) is not a sinister deal with "the world's biggest and most controversial corporations", but incorporates business, international unions and civil society groups based on the universal declaration of human rights, the International Labour Organisation's fundamental principles and rights at work and the Earth Summit's agenda 21 principles on the environment.

George Monbiot's suggestion that Kofi Annan allows multinationals to deflect "pressure from single-issue groups" will be of interest to such naive organisations as Amnesty, Human Rights Watch and the ICFTU global trade union confederation which also support it. They accept the global compact's recognition that voluntary agreements "are no substitute for action by governments". But such groups believe the compact can initiate meaningful dialogue on developing global rules for a global economy.

The global compact website provides access to agreements between unions and multinationals incorporating core labour standards as well as details of disputes and allows activists to take part in "cyber pickets" of firms violating labour rights. Hardly a corporate front organisation. Multinationals are not omniscient, monolithic and malevolent. Monbiot's view promotes a false dichotomy between passive resignation and the facile oppositionalism of recent "anti-capitalist" indulgences. The more productive route is through the tedious, demanding long slog of constructive engagement.

Michael Allen
Centre for Strategic Trade Union Management Cranfield University M.Allen@cranfield.ac.uk

webTitle: Letters: Euro campaigners and the vision thing

fields.headline: Euro campaigners and the vision thing
fields.trailText: The problem with Labour's document (Labour to force pace on euro, August 30) is the lack of a political case for joining. How can an electoral campaign on the Euro take place without reference to the politics of European unity?
fields.body:
The problem with Labour's document (Labour to force pace on euro, August 30) is the lack of a political case for joining. How can an electoral campaign on the Euro take place without reference to the politics of European unity?

As Larry Siedentop has argued in his recent book (US politics made a nation, July 29) there has to be a public debate about our future in Europe and the future of Europe in the world - or, to put it bluntly, about the "vision thing". The media (and especially Greg Dyke's revamped BBC) must not allow New Labour to get away with setting the limited and reductionist agenda signalled by their internal document.

Hugh Chignell
Bournemouth University hchignel@bournemouth.ac.uk

 It is untrue that the euro would eliminate transaction costs for holiday-makers and travellers. Most holiday-makers do not choose only to take cash with them. Any other method of taking or spending money abroad - credit card, travellers cheques or money transfers - will remain as expensive it is now.

According to European Commission figures, cross-border transactions, even within the euro zone, remain approximately 17 times more expensive than domestic ones. This is because there is no European-wide clearing system, nor is there any prospect of one being set up. The commission recently admitted to the European parliament it saw no prospect of the charges being substantially reduced.

Theresa Villiers MEP
Conservative European economics spokesperson tvilliers@europarl.eu.int

 I'm surprised to read how many Britons are still undecided or prefer to adopt a wait-and-see policy on UK membership of EMU, with the implementation of the single currency only a few years away (Euro choice, August 29). Let's hope the fence-sitters will eventually decide to join the euro. Europe's goal is the creation of a single strong currency capable of competing with the US dollar, whose strength and ever-increasing buying power has dominated the world's markets.

Despite the current weakness of the euro against the US dollar, in a long-term perspective, all the Euroland countries will undoubtedly benefit from the single currency, both in the economic and financial markets.

Giulio Cicconi
Teramo, Italy g_cicconi71@hotmail.com

fields.headline: Cojoined in twobicles
fields.trailText: Without intending to detract from a serious issue (Labour hit by race row, August 31) may I ask how many of these 28 black and Asian MPs should be female?
fields.body:
Without intending to detract from a serious issue (Labour hit by race row, August 31) may I ask how many of these 28 black and Asian MPs should be female?

J Brown
Leeds

 Surely it is time we referred to "conjoined twins" rather than Siamese twins (Twins must have fatal surgery, August 26)?

Margaret Morgan
Worcester

 I'm sure those who were maimed or lost loved ones in such atrocities as Enniskillen and Omagh will be interested in Charli Langford's claim (Letters, August 30) that republican terrorists always hold the moral high ground.

Frank Bray
Dundee

 It's a bare-faced cheek, falsely claiming a first (Two-person toilet cubical installed, August 30; Letters, August 31). Without any fuss and nonsense a twobicle has been available in The Works, Kingston-upon-Thames, for some time; not that anyone even uses it, mind.

Amy Christie
New Malden, Surrey

 Years ago many rural dwellings in Norway had two-hole earth closets and a camp site in southern Norway had one with three seats. Detailed study showed the holes were usually of different sizes.

T Hall
Manchester

 Among the culture shocks Chelsea Clinton might have to cope with at Oxford (Inside story, G2, August 29) could be devotees of Steve Bell calling her Wandsworth.

Henry Wickens
Luxembourg

 Is the discovery in an Australian cannery of a severed human head inside a fish (Report, August 30) the only reported instance of a cod eating battered human?

Christopher Head
Harpenden, Herts

fields.trailText: Gary Younge's piece on the question of genetic factors in black people's success in athletics should be susceptible to dispassionate debate, based on objective evidence (Comment, August 28). But it is currently unacceptable to allow that there might be a genetic factor involved. Why?

Gary Younge's piece on the question of genetic factors in black people's success in athletics should be susceptible to dispassionate debate, based on objective evidence (Comment, August 28). But it is currently unacceptable to allow that there might be a genetic factor involved. Why?

David Nelson
Dunfermline

 It's not racist to say black people are the best athletes; for socio-economic reasons it seems to be their turn. But it's so sad that when your closest and most open-minded friends say it, they think they are paying you a compliment.

South Ockendon, Essex

 At last! A black man who reassures me that as a white man I really can sing soul, play blues and move as well as a black man. Cheers, Gary.

Gareth Phillips
Llangoed, Ynys Mon

fields.headline: Put children first
fields.standfirst: They proclaimed the rule - then broke it
fields.trailText: Wave goodbye to the dream of a five-term school year. Say hello to the continuation of six-week summer holidays, bored kids and serious regression of learning. As so often, teachers' interests have been put ahead of pupils' by the local government association's independent commission on the school year.
fields.body:
Wave goodbye to the dream of a five-term school year. Say hello to the continuation of six-week summer holidays, bored kids and serious regression of learning. As so often, teachers' interests have been put ahead of pupils' by the local government association's independent commission on the school year.

Chris Price, formerly Labour chairman of the Commons education select committee and principal of Leeds Metropolitan University, who chaired the commission, was adamant at its launch that the status quo was not an option and that children's interests must come first. Yet, although the commission's proposals were yesterday dressed up as a radical overhaul of the academic timetable with a six-term school year, that is what we have already: three terms, each with a half-term holiday, are to be replaced by six terms with no half-term holidays.

There is one radical shift. School exams - GCSEs, AS levels and A-levels - will be taken in the fifth term, late April/early May, rather than in June. This will certainly help pupils who suffer from hay fever and open the prospect of universities offering places on A-level results, rather than projected results. Both would be welcome. It could even lead to wider access to higher education by persuading pupils from non-academic homes with good results to apply. The vice-chancellors are in favour, but will it get the support of their staff, who will have to remain in post in July?

The serious downside is the continuation of six-week summer holidays. Research in the US has shown a critical regression in reading and maths with such long breaks. And the sixth term, with exams already over, could exacerbate the problem. Teachers' leaders are adamantly opposed to losing their summer perk, even though total holiday time would remain the same. Given a teacher recruitment crisis, it may be a pragmatic package, but it is not in children's interests, and that is what matters most.

webTitle: Letters: How to feed the world

fields.headline: How to feed the world
fields.trailText: George Monbiot (Biotech has bamboozled us all, August 24) is correct on one point - feeding the world's population will require political and social change in addition to technology.
fields.body:
George Monbiot (Biotech has bamboozled us all, August 24) is correct on one point - feeding the world's population will require political and social change in addition to technology.

However, his statement that "organic farming is the key to feeding the world" is selective with the facts.

He mentions trials in Hertfordshire "where wheat grown with manure has produced higher yields for the past 150 years than wheat grown with artificial nutrients". This is the Broadbalk experiment at Rothamsted, where the yield of winter wheat grown on plots receiving different fertiliser treatments has been recorded since 1843. But his interpretation is wrong.

An annual application of 35 tonnes per hectare of animal manure is required to match the yields of wheat (about 7 tonnes per hectare) achieved by annual applications of 144kg per hectare of "artificial" inorganic nitrogen. This rate of manure application is about three times what would be considered sensible for practical agriculture and is unachievable on any scale. To produce this much animal manure requires 5.5 cattle for every hectare of wheat cultivated (hardly a practical prospect either here or in the developing world).

Nevertheless, since the average world yield of wheat is a pitiful - 1 tonne per hectare - any increase in fertiliser inputs, organic or inorganic, is much needed and will surely reap a benefit.

Monbiot is also incorrect to regard the Broadbalk experiment as a test of organic farming. Although it contains a treatment receiving organic manure, this alone is not organic farming. Organic farming also depends on a rotation of crops which, in the UK, is normally three years or more of pasture containing clover (to "fix" nitrogen from the atmosphere into organic matter). The pasture is then ploughed up and wheat or other crops grown - these rely on the nitrogen previously fixed being released through the action of soil microbes. The yield of an organic crop will typically be 60-80% of one given fertilisers and pesticides, but it cannot be grown every year: at most three years of arable crops can be grown following three years of fertility building. It is misleading to compare yields in a single year.

Reference is also made to studies on the control of rice blast disease in Yunnan Province, China recently reported by Youyong Zhu and colleagues (Nature, August 17). The highly effective disease resistance of modern hybrid varieties was clearly demonstrated in this work which also confirmed how well-favoured ("sticky") but highly disease susceptible varieties can be "protected" by growing them as a mixture with specifically selected resistant ones.

We can indeed exploit to greater benefit than hitherto the wealth of biodiversity represented by the natural disease resistance genes in our crop varieties. This is particularly the case now that genetic engineering technologies will allow such genes to be readily isolated and moved from poorly adapted, low-yielding varieties or wild relatives to the highly productive varieties that a hungry world requires.

We echo the views of the Chinese scientists when they observe: "The current world population does not allow us to return to agricultural practices of the past - we need to maintain the benefits of modern agriculture while addressing its drawbacks."

Prof Ian Crute
Director, Prof David Powlson
Head of soil science,
Institute of Arable Crops Research, Rothamsted, Herts

Prof Christopher Lamb
Director,
John Innes Centre, Norwich

Organic farming also depends on a rotation of crops which, in the UK, is normally three years or more of pasture containing clover (to "fix" nitrogen from the atmosphere into organic matter). The pasture is then ploughed up and wheat or other crops grown - these rely on the nitrogen previously fixed being released through the action of soil microbes. The yield of an organic crop will typically be 60-80% of one given fertilisers and pesticides, but it cannot be grown every year: at most three years of arable crops can be grown following three years of fertility building. It is misleading to compare yields in a single year. Reference is also made to studies on the control of rice blast disease in Yunnan Province, China recently reported by Youyong Zhu and colleagues (Nature, August 17). The highly effective disease resistance of modern hybrid varieties was clearly demonstrated in this work which also confirmed how well-favoured ("sticky") but highly disease susceptible varieties can be "protected" by growing them as a mixture with specifically selected resistant ones. We can indeed exploit to greater benefit than hitherto the wealth of biodiversity represented by the natural disease resistance genes in our crop varieties. This is particularly the case now that genetic engineering technologies will allow such genes to be readily isolated and moved from poorly adapted, low-yielding varieties or wild relatives to the highly productive varieties that a hungry world requires. We echo the views of the Chinese scientists when they observe: "The current world population does not allow us to return to agricultural practices of the past - we need to maintain the benefits of modern agriculture while addressing its drawbacks." Prof Ian Crute Director, Prof David Powlson Head of soil science, Institute of Arable Crops Research, Rothamsted, Herts Prof Christopher Lamb Director, John Innes Centre, Norwich

webTitle: Leader: They are not taking over

fields.headline: They are not taking over
fields.standfirst: Robots are not going to boss us. Not yet
fields.trailText: Box office hits such as Terminator, Robocop and Blade Runner have all played on fears of robotic intelligence running amok and mastering their human creators. In two separate developments yesterday, the nightmare appeared to inch closer to realisation.
fields.body:
Box office hits such as Terminator, Robocop and Blade Runner have all played on fears of robotic intelligence running amok and mastering their human creators. In two separate developments yesterday, the nightmare appeared to inch closer to realisation.

Research published in Nature claimed to have made the first steps towards "artificial evolution" - by which robots are able to mutate and reproduce themselves - at Brandeis University in the US. In Bangkok, a security device was revealed which could be controlled through the internet: a robot primed to fire a gun when sensors detect an intruder. The reality is much more mundane. Self-replicating robots are still decades away; the Brandeis robot requires an element of human intervention in its construction. As for gun-toting robotic security guards, experts are sceptical; sensor technology is famously erratic and the notion of control by the internet is absurd, given the net's time delay.

We have a great taste for robots - both the facts and the fiction. Robot Wars, the DIY build a robot in your garage craze, has been a surprise hit on television, notching up impressive ratings to watch Dead Metal, Sir Killalot and Shunt put "the scrap back into metal". But on any sober assessment this branch of scientific research faces huge limitations. Yes, it is useful when given a very narrow, specific remit and has been used in everyday appliances such as washing machines. It might prove useful in electronic commerce, where considerable research is now being done on "intelligent agents", software able to negotiate with suppliers. But there is still a major obstacle to its application in many fields - it cannot deal with unpredictability. That limits its uses in medicine, for example, and ensures its reliance on some level of human manipulation. For the most part, as one expert ruefully admitted yesterday, "artificial intelligence is a technology in search of an application".

The difficulty is that our bid to create artificial intelligence is an attempt to copy the human brain before we have come to understand it. This is where research into artificial intelligence spills into philosophy and psychology in an area of inquiry likely to be one of the most fascinating of the century. So, anxieties about being mastered by the technology we have created are premature: until we understand ourselves better, artificial intelligence may create clever machines, but not independent life.

webTitle: Jenkins says Blair will never accept PR

fields.headline: Jenkins says Blair will never accept PR
fields.standfirst: Special report: proportional representation
fields.trailText: The man responsible for devising a voting system for 21st century Britain has admitted for the first time that Tony Blair will never concede to Liberal Democrat demands for proportional representation in general elections.
fields.body:
The man responsible for devising a voting system for 21st century Britain has admitted for the first time that Tony Blair will never concede to Liberal Democrat demands for proportional representation in general elections.

Lord Jenkins of Hillhead said he recognised that the Labour party had effectively ruled out adopting the "AV-plus" system proposed two years ago by the electoral reform commission, which he chaired at the personal request of the prime minister.

The Liberal Democrat peer and former SDP leader said he was disappointed but not surprised that his proposal had been given a lukewarm response at Labour's national policy forum last month.

But it was a lesson of history, he said, that political parties rarely had the courage to do anything that might damage their electoral prospects "when they have the power to do so".

His comments sparked fears that the Liberal Democrats' policy of collaboration with the government on issues of constitutional reform would come under fire at next month's party conference from activists who believe the party is reaping little in the way of rewards in return for cooperating with Labour.

Under a deal brokered by the cabinet office minister Lord Falconer at the policy forum meeting, Labour's official policy document says that further electoral reform should be delayed until the new voting systems in Scotland and Wales have been "thoroughly examined" and stresses the party's belief in the direct link between MPs and their constituencies.

But the Lib Dem peer Lord Russell insisted that Lord Jenkins's remarks would not damage relations between the two parties, which at present collaborate on the joint cabinet committee on constitutional reform.

He said: "At the moment, the anti-PR faction in the Labour party is clearly on top but the wheel of fortune never stops turning. I don't think anything will happen unless Tony Blair has a serious fear of losing office. Charles Kennedy [the Lib Dem leader] must not burn any boats."

Despite Labour's continuing commitment to a referendum on electoral reform, there is speculation that voters will be asked whether they are in favour of adopting the alternative vote, or "AV", a system which requires voters to mark their ballot papers in order of preference and redistributes second and third preferences until one candidate has 50% of the vote.

If AV had been in place in 1997, it would have given Labour an even larger majority than the landslide which it actually won.

Under Lord Jenkins's AV-plus system, however, most MPs would represent particular seats, but up to 100 MPs would be elected on a proportional vote without specific constituencies.

A spokesman for Mr Kennedy said: "We have always said this is a matter for the Labour party to decide. They have clearly not come to a decision yet and we have every confidence that they will not renege on their promise."

The Labour MP Stephen Twigg, a member of the pro-PR group Make Votes Count, said: "These comments don't change anything. Ordinary Labour party members are evenly divided and nothing is settled yet."

fields.headline: Heart of darkness
fields.standfirst: Colonel Kurtz - the insane renegade in Apocalypse Now - is one of film's legendary creations. So when David Herman heard rumours of a soldier who really had gone mad in the jungle, he embarked on a mission to track him down... By  Danny Leigh
fields.trailText: Colonel Kurtz - the insane renegade in Apocalypse Now - is one of film's legendary creations. So when David Herman heard rumours of a soldier who really had gone mad in the jungle, he embarked on a mission to track him down...
fields.body:
Somewhere up the Mekong river, long past the last vestiges of urban civilisation, a fat man has gone mad. There's been strange stories coming out of the jungle, stories of adulation and decadence, barbarism and insanity.

You're probably thinking of Apocalypse Now, Francis Ford Coppola's addled Vietnam epic. Martin Sheen smashing mirrors, Dennis Hopper ranting about physics, and there, at the bloody, hallucinatory end of it all, a monstrously bloated Marlon Brando as Kurtz, the inhuman logic of war made flesh.

Which is understandable; that, after all, was what went through David Herman's mind when he heard about Tony Poe. The result, four years and three continents later, is The Search For Kurtz, an absorbing portrait of America's greatest military folly, and the psychotic who took its execution as his raison d'etre.

Back in 1996, the idea seemed preposterous: intriguing, but preposterous. Apocalypse Now was based on Joseph Conrad's Heart of Darkness. End of story. Except a pair of British journalists working in Asia, Adrian Levy and Cathy Scott-Clarke, had heard of a covert US operation in Laos spanning the Vietnam war, and a guy named Tony Poe - a decorated Marine gone psychically AWOL in charge of a tribal battalion and later, allegedly, the inspiration for Colonel Kurtz. Returning to England, they contacted producer Herman.

"They had no details," he recalls, "just a deeply shady ex-CIA operative called Jack Shirley." It was enough to convince Herman a film should be made, if not to persuade anyone to finance it. His proposal did the rounds, belatedly being co-financed by Channel 4. "And I'll tell you," Herman says, "we were blagging like lunatics. Because we had absolutely no idea whether he was even alive, far less where he was."

Ascertaining he was alive was one thing. Jack Shirley, whose tales of serving with Poe checked out, was certain of it. Where he was proved trickier. With Shirley in tow, Her man, Levy, Scott-Clarke and director Derek Jones travelled from Bangkok to the dirt roads of Laos, once a paradisical retreat, now the poorest country in South East Asia. With monsoon season underway, the one overland route into Nam Yu - Pope's last base - was waterlogged, leaving a helicopter as their sole option: only, with elections in neighbouring Cambodia imminent, all three of Laos' choppers had been seconded.

The story Herman tells of the solution - involving the Laotian Minister of Defence, a $5000 gratuity ("which I have a receipt for"), a provincial governor up to his neck in the opium trade and, ultimately, the gift of a Russian helicopter complete with armed guard - is as ludicrously Boys' Own as it is alarmingly plausible.

And there, beside the Mekong, was Poe's headquarters. Or, rather, it wasn't. With Nam Yu razed to the ground, all that remained were rusted machine-gun clips and the communist commander who took Nam Yu for the Vietcong. It seemed, at the time, like a brick wall. Just as the group despaired, however, a call came from San Francisco, from a former CIA nabob called Bill Lair, who was prepared to talk. Herman and company headed for California, where Lair told them about Tony Poe and his leadership of the illicit Operation Momentum, launched in 1962 to band the Hmmong people of the Laotian hillsides into anti-communist guerillas.

"I wouldn't say we lost control of him," sniggered Lair, as if referring to some over-enthusiastic rogue. "I don't think we ever had it." Which, stripped of romanticism, meant Poe arriving laden with M-16s for a decade of ungoverned mayhem. Paying the Hmmong per communist fatality, he asked for ears as proof; later, he demanded heads. And, when he eventually fled with his Hmmong wife and his drink problem as the Cong took over (to be napalmed by American troops), he left a bitter legacy: landmines still disabling Laotian children today.

He set up home in Bangkok, fighting with the locals, but an icon among what Herman calls the "pathetic old men," who followed his lead and never went home. Until the early 90s, that is, when the Thai police finally deported him back to the US. And there, living in San Francisco on a CIA pension, is where Herman and company found him. At last, the heart of darkness himself, his resemblance to Brando at his most grotesque extraordinary.

The subsequent interview is TV at its most compelling: "War is hell," Poe shrugs. "And, if you're going to do it, let's do it with gusto." Unshaven and hungover, he speaks of sending disembodied ears to nervous US ambassadors as if it was a schoolyard prank, and explains that his mission failed because "we didn't kill enough people" - a nightmarish echo of Kurtz's dictum that "we must kill them. Pig after pig. Cow after cow. Village after village."

"And I was so glad," says Herman, "because I realised he wasn't coming across as Indiana Jones, but the sick, evil bastard he is." Except, of course, some people will always see Poe not as an alcoholic war criminal, but as a role model. Back in Bangkok, among the ageing US émigrés who sit around in bars, impotent, their livers shot, they still love Tony Poe. David Herman shakes his head at the thought.

"They fete him as a great man. But these are the guys who saw Apocalypse Now and thought Kurtz was the hero. They thought he was the main man. The man who did things right."

The Search for Kurtz, 11.05pm, Channel 4, tomorrow; repeated at 1.05am, Monday September 4; Apocalypse Now, Channel 4, 10.15pm, Monday September 4.
