fields.headline: David Champernowne
fields.standfirst: Economist who held chairs at both Oxford and Cambridge
fields.trailText: David Champernowne, who has died aged 88, was one of the most colourful economists of the 20th century. At different times he held chairs at both Oxford and Cambridge: his starting-point was a gift for mathematics, and he retained a rather abstract air, even when drawn increasingly into economics. Modest, quirky and humorous, he was determined never to get into a rut, even to the detriment of conventional career considerations. Thus while his output was substantial and diverse, much of the value of his work lay in assisting others with theoretical and statistical insights, and he was an academic editor of outstanding distinction.
fields.body:
David Champernowne, who has died aged 88, was one of the most colourful economists of the 20th century. At different times he held chairs at both Oxford and Cambridge: his starting-point was a gift for mathematics, and he retained a rather abstract air, even when drawn increasingly into economics. Modest, quirky and humorous, he was determined never to get into a rut, even to the detriment of conventional career considerations. Thus while his output was substantial and diverse, much of the value of his work lay in assisting others with theoretical and statistical insights, and he was an academic editor of outstanding distinction.

The son of the bursar of Keble College, Oxford, Champernowne went to Winchester College and won a scholarship to King's College, Cambridge, which he entered in 1931. While still an undergraduate, he had a paper published - the number 0.1234567891011... is "Champernowne's constant". He obtained a first class degree in mathematics and economics, switching subjects on the advice of John Maynard Keynes, and won the prestigious reading prize.

Another of Champernowne's interests was walking, and our lifelong friendship developed from a tour of the Peak District. The Youth Hostel Association was an innovation of the late 1920s, and he and I were of the generation that was able to make the development of hostels more viable by swelling its ranks.

While an assistant lecturer at the London School of Economics from 1936-38, Champernowne worked with William Beveridge, the eventual architect of the welfare state, who, with Keynes, greatly influenced his approach to economics and applied statistics: social justice was always important to him. The thesis that Champernowne wrote in order to become a fellow of King's College, Cambridge (1937-1948) eventually saw the light of day as a book, The Distribution of Income Between Persons (1973); the decades elapsing before publication constituted modesty taken to a fault.

Trends in income distribution and wealth continued to interest him, and in 1998 he returned to the subject with Professor Frank Cowell of the LSE with their study Economic Inequality and Income Distribution.

Champernowne's appointment in 1938 as a Cambridge lecturer in statistics led two years later to his being drafted into the prime minister's statistical department. Churchill set his "think tank" searching questions about home and enemy resources, and the unit's head, Prof FA Lindemann (later Lord Cherwell) was in turn extremely demanding on his staff. Champernowne did not get on well with him, and in 1941 moved to the Ministry of Aircraft Production, staying there for the remainder of the war.

In 1944, Champernowne was involved with Keynes in the Cambridge economics faculty's establishment of its department of applied economics, but he then went to Oxford University, where he was director of the Institute of Statistics from 1945-48, and professor of statistics from 1948-59.

In 1948 he married Wilhelmina (Mieke): he and Alan Turing, another friend from undergraduate days, co-opted her to play against their chess-playing program. As a beginner, she had the good grace to lose to a simple system which none the less contained significant methods of evaluation.

However, Champernowne came to regret his change of university, and looked for a way of returning to Cambridge. This he could achieve only by a highly unusual step down to a lower rank, when he became a reader in economics at Cambridge from 1959-70 - a preference that he sustained for the rest of his life. Nicholas Kaldor, Dennis Robertson and Joan Robinson all benefited from his intellectual support, and an interest in Frank Ramsey's theory of probability from before the war led to his three-volume work, Uncertainty and Estimation in Economics (1969). This unique but now overlooked study of the role of uncertainty in econometrics attempts to integrate quantitative analysis with decision theory.

In 1970, Champernowne was made a fellow of the British Academy and given a personal chair at Cambridge: he defined his subject area as economics and statistics. At this time, I was offered the post of editor of the Economic Journal, but insisted that there be two joint editors: Champernowne to concentrate on articles with a mathematical flavour, and Phyllis Deane to take charge of book reviews. The three of us got on very well, both with each other and with contributors in the sensitive matter of advising on substantial changes in articles. The task ideally suited Champernowne's love of behind-the-scenes refinement of ideas, and his years with the journal, 1971-76, were very happy ones.

In 1978, Champernowne retired, though he remained an emeritus professor and a fellow of Trinity College. When he fell ill in his final years, he and Mieke moved from Cambridge to Budleigh Salterton, Devon, to be closer to one of his two sons, who, with his wife, survive him.

 David Gawen Champernowne, economist, born July 9 1912; died August 19 2000

The son of the bursar of Keble College, Oxford, Champernowne went to Winchester College and won a scholarship to King's College, Cambridge, which he entered in 1931. While still an undergraduate, he had a paper published - the number 0.1234567891011... is "Champernowne's constant". He obtained a first class degree in mathematics and economics, switching subjects on the advice of John Maynard Keynes, and won the prestigious reading prize. Another of Champernowne's interests was walking, and our lifelong friendship developed from a tour of the Peak District. The Youth Hostel Association was an innovation of the late 1920s, and he and I were of the generation that was able to make the development of hostels more viable by swelling its ranks. While an assistant lecturer at the London School of Economics from 1936-38, Champernowne worked with William Beveridge, the eventual architect of the welfare state, who, with Keynes, greatly influenced his approach to economics and applied statistics: social justice was always important to him. The thesis that Champernowne wrote in order to become a fellow of King's College, Cambridge (1937-1948) eventually saw the light of day as a book, The Distribution of Income Between Persons (1973); the decades elapsing before publication constituted modesty taken to a fault. Trends in income distribution and wealth continued to interest him, and in 1998 he returned to the subject with Professor Frank Cowell of the LSE with their study Economic Inequality and Income Distribution. Champernowne's appointment in 1938 as a Cambridge lecturer in statistics led two years later to his being drafted into the prime minister's statistical department. Churchill set his "think tank" searching questions about home and enemy resources, and the unit's head, Prof FA Lindemann (later Lord Cherwell) was in turn extremely demanding on his staff. Champernowne did not get on well with him, and in 1941 moved to the Ministry of Aircraft Production, staying there for the remainder of the war. In 1944, Champernowne was involved with Keynes in the Cambridge economics faculty's establishment of its department of applied economics, but he then went to Oxford University, where he was director of the Institute of Statistics from 1945-48, and professor of statistics from 1948-59. In 1948 he married Wilhelmina (Mieke): he and Alan Turing, another friend from undergraduate days, co-opted her to play against their chess-playing program. As a beginner, she had the good grace to lose to a simple system which none the less contained significant methods of evaluation. However, Champernowne came to regret his change of university, and looked for a way of returning to Cambridge. This he could achieve only by a highly unusual step down to a lower rank, when he became a reader in economics at Cambridge from 1959-70 - a preference that he sustained for the rest of his life. Nicholas Kaldor, Dennis Robertson and Joan Robinson all benefited from his intellectual support, and an interest in Frank Ramsey's theory of probability from before the war led to his three-volume work, Uncertainty and Estimation in Economics (1969). This unique but now overlooked study of the role of uncertainty in econometrics attempts to integrate quantitative analysis with decision theory. In 1970, Champernowne was made a fellow of the British Academy and given a personal chair at Cambridge: he defined his subject area as economics and statistics. At this time, I was offered the post of editor of the Economic Journal, but insisted that there be two joint editors: Champernowne to concentrate on articles with a mathematical flavour, and Phyllis Deane to take charge of book reviews. The three of us got on very well, both with each other and with contributors in the sensitive matter of advising on substantial changes in articles. The task ideally suited Champernowne's love of behind-the-scenes refinement of ideas, and his years with the journal, 1971-76, were very happy ones. In 1978, Champernowne retired, though he remained an emeritus professor and a fellow of Trinity College. When he fell ill in his final years, he and Mieke moved from Cambridge to Budleigh Salterton, Devon, to be closer to one of his two sons, who, with his wife, survive him.  David Gawen Champernowne, economist, born July 9 1912; died August 19 2000

fields.headline: Odette Joyeux
fields.standfirst: Behind the fragile facade was an ambitious and determined actress who loved to rebel
fields.trailText: In 1943, Claude Autant- Lara directed the film Douce. It told the story of an innocent young girl from a good family who fell in love with a young man not in her social class and refused to give him up. The controversy it aroused is long forgotten, but it shocked Marshal Pétain's collaborationist France. The part of Douce de Bonafé was played by Odette Joyeux, who has died aged 85.
fields.body:
In 1943, Claude Autant- Lara directed the film Douce. It told the story of an innocent young girl from a good family who fell in love with a young man not in her social class and refused to give him up. The controversy it aroused is long forgotten, but it shocked Marshal Pétain's collaborationist France. The part of Douce de Bonafé was played by Odette Joyeux, who has died aged 85.

Joyeux was the ideal actress to play the role. She was small, and appeared to be delicate; her features were those of an adolescent, sulking and grumbling. But this apparent fragility concealed determination, a readiness to revolt, and a capacity for refusal. And this was Joyeux herself. She was small, slim, apparently shy and reserved. But in reality she had a strong personality and was always determined to get her own way. She described herself as "very violent and bad-tempered".

She was ambitious, and one ambition succeeded another. She wanted to make her way as a dancer, then as an actress, both on the stage and in films. Without abandoning acting she turned to writing novels, then plays, and went on to produce books about dancing, her memoirs and a biography. Towards the end of her life she produced scenarios for television.

It was said that this ambition originated in the poverty of her origins. Born in Paris at the beginning of the first world war, Joyeux was the daughter of an unmarried washerwoman. But from the start she was irresistible, and at the age of seven she had persuaded one of her mother's acquaintances to help her gain admission to the Paris School of Opera. Thus she became what was called "un petit rat de l'Opéra".

She had talent as well as charm, and enjoyed a moment of glory when she danced a divertissement composed by Poulenc. She also had her rebellious streak, and this career came to an end when she was expelled because she refused to accept the school's strict discipline. Although re-instated, she decided to seek success elsewhere and determined to be an actress.

With characteristic boldness the 16-year-old Joyeux applied for an audition with Louis Jouvet, France's leading actor and producer. The play was Intermezzo by Jean Giraudoux. She was successful and played the demanding role of Isabelle, a school-teacher in a small town where strange things were happening - the poorest person wins the lottery, only the old and unpleasant die, people reply truthfully to official enquiries. It was remarkable that the young, inexperienced girl should be chosen to play in this sophisticated drama, and chosen both by Jouvet and by Giraudoux himself. But, recalling this, she was businesslike. Both men were useful, she said: Jouvet advised her to act and Giraudoux encouraged her to write.

Joyeux's film career began before the second world war and continued until 1955. Among her films are Marc Allegret's Entrée des Artistes (1938); several other films with Autant-Lara - Le Mariage de Chiffon (1941), Lettres d'Amour (1942), Sylvie et le Fantme (1946); Max Ophüls's La Ronde (1950); and Sacha Guitry's Si Paris m'était Conté (1955).

An episode in her life was made by Joyeux into a series of stories with which she regaled several generations. In 1935 the actor and playwright Pierre Brasseur was looking for a young girl to star in his new play, Grisou. He auditioned Joyeux and fell in love with her. They married, but their life together was very strange. She had many stories to tell about the eccentricities that accompanied the consummation of their marriage and the tumultous scenes that led to the violent breaking of crockery whenever they had a meal together. These stories resurfaced when the son by this marriage, Claude Brasseur, became a famous actor. Joyeux was well-known as the author of witticisms, not all of which were kindly.

Her first novel appeared before the war, a further 10 followed. They enjoyed a moderate success at the time. Her two volumes of memoirs, Cté Jardin and Le Beau Monde, were very successful and with the help of her second husband, Philippe Agostini, a cameraman and film technician, she adapted parts of them for a television feature film.

Her comeback was in 1987. She played the part of an old lady in Première Jeunesse by Christian Giudicelli. The old lady revolted and broke with her past, as had the young girls whom Joyeux had played many years earlier. As she said, she was "always of a piece".

For more than 50 years Odette Joyeux was the jewel of the French cinema and theatre.

 Odette Joyeux, actress and writer, born December 5 1914; died August 26 2000

webTitle: Leader: Fishers of menace in France

fields.headline: Fishers of menace
fields.standfirst: The French government has been routed
fields.trailText: The French fishermen's protest against soaring fuel prices must have seemed like a dream situation to some French people: industrial action in which only the British get hurt and the government capitulates at the first whiff of grapeshot. This is in the grand tradition of French confrontation: if the action is strong and disruptive enough, the government gives way and hopes the knock-on effects will not be too great.
fields.body:
The French fishermen's protest against soaring fuel prices must have seemed like a dream situation to some French people: industrial action in which only the British get hurt and the government capitulates at the first whiff of grapeshot. This is in the grand tradition of French confrontation: if the action is strong and disruptive enough, the government gives way and hopes the knock-on effects will not be too great.

In France, unlike Britain, wildcat strikes like this are often quite popular (this one was supported by 58% of the population in a poll carried out earlier this week), which may help to explain why the government conceded so soon. But this is not the end of it. The action has been bought off by offsetting the impact of the sharp rise in the price of diesel fuel against cuts in the fishermen's social security contributions. Ministers are trying to ring-fence this deal, but taxi drivers are already planning a day of action today in protest against the same increases in diesel fuel and private ambulancemen are also getting steamed up. No one should be surprised if the French farmers also use this opportunity to try to gain compensation.

Fortunately for the French government, this comes at a time when the economy is recovering strongly. In an unrelated exercise yesterday, the new finance minister, Laurent Fabius, unleashed FF12bn of tax reductions including (pre-planned) cuts in fuel taxes. But this will not forestall other demands for fuel tax cuts. And it certainly will not improve France's image in the United States as an economy where labour power is inhibiting productivity growth. If there is a villain in the piece it is not the French government but Opec, which has been keeping the price of oil much higher than it would be in a free market by organising itself into a cartel. Saudi Arabia, the world's leading producer and one of the few worried about the impact of sharply higher prices on western economies, recently increased its output by 500,000 barrels a day (though it is reported to have sold only half that amount). If fishing, an industry that is heavily subsidised and does not pay any taxes on its diesel, is compensated for higher world prices, then why should not other oil users claim the same munificence? The oil industry will always pose a dilemma for governments. High prices are needed to conserve a finite resource and encourage solar alternatives - but not so high that they trigger an international recession, as happened during the 70s. It has taken decades to escape from the inflationary consequences of that price explosion and no one wants to go down that road again. It is in the long-term interest neither of consumers nor producers, since they too felt the backlash from the 70s recessions.

The other problem is that most western countries (except the United States) want prices to be high so they can cream off huge tax revenues. They do not want them high as a consequence of artificially inflated Opec prices. This week Saudi Arabia called for a coordinated strategy involving both consumers and producers which would take into account the effect of taxes on petrol prices. That seems a fair approach. But it must also take into account the monopoly status of Opec. It may have suited western governments , concerned about political stability in the middle east, to turn a blind eye to Opec, especially when prices were lower. But the fact is that it is a monopoly of the kind that would have been broken up long ago if it existed in the US. That too must be taken into consideration during any future talks between consumers and producers.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Asterix - By Toutatis/Check Up
fields.body:
Tony Robinson pays tribute to the Gallic symbol who burst on the comic scene 40 years ago. Asterix - By Toutatis (11.0am, Radio 4) celebrates the indomitable Gaul whose struggle against Julius Caesar's legions continues unabated. The Roman forts of Tototum, Aquarium, Laudanum and Compendium may surround him but Asterix keeps his puns constantly primed. Albert Uderzo and René Goscinny invented the strip to counter the American cartoons swamping Europe in the 1950s. Translated versions now appear worldwide, including scripts in Tibetan and Welsh.

If your hypochondria has gone into decline over these summer months, relief is again at hand. Barbara Myers and her experts are back for the new season of Check Up (3.0pm, Radio 4). New clients are being brought into the fold with a gentle examination of headaches and what may cause them. Not that an aspirin is necessarily the answer. The programme's associated web site offers ten alternative ways of handling the trauma.

fields.headline: You've got males
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Rupert Smith
fields.trailText: Men Down Under/EastEnders/Safe as Houses
fields.body:
Not content with sending our convicts to Australia, we are now transporting our sitcom stars. For crimes unspecified, Martin Clunes and Neil Morrissey were packed off to be Men Down Under (BBC1), and spent 50 minutes driving around the north-eastern corner of the continent in search of the legendary Australian male. They didn't find him. A show that set out to examine masculinity in its antipodean form came up with precious little material, and instead of insights or even discussions we were treated to an extended Clunes/Morrissey holiday video. This was not unpleasant. Clunes has that kind of easy, clubman's repartee that would make him the perfect travelling companion, while Morrissey seems to be the kind of lad who likes a drink or two. They got on well with the locals in such unpromising spots as Cairns and Alice Springs, and didn't try too hard to live up to their Men Behaving Badly personae.

But after 30 minutes or so in which nothing had happened, the novelty was beginning to wear off. We saw Martin Clunes playing golf very badly for an agonising five minutes, while Morrissey visited a swimming pool that was hilariously closed. We saw some camels, and learned that they have smelly breath. We met a man who has made a lot of money from running a diving club, despite getting bad school reports. All of this could have been achieved a good deal closer to home.

Clunes and Morrissey are lovely blokes and great actors, but without a script they don't make very exciting television. It's not enough simply to take a couple of familiar faces and send them somewhere hot - they have to be able to do something once they're there. Paul O'Grady's recent travels round the Far East worked because he was liable to blow a gasket at any moment - besides which, O'Grady is a great improvisational raconteur. Clunes and Morrissey aren't, and seemed for much of the time to be lost for words. They redeemed themselves in the show's final five minutes by getting slurringly drunk at a tent fight, during which we were treated to the edifying sight of two ageing tattooed men sitting on each other's faces. Were these the legendary "real Australian men" we'd been promised? Our hosts were too pissed to care.

Much more exotic fare came in the final part of EastEnders' Spanish trilogy (BBC1). Walford's love-crossed seniors returned to Albert Square, but not before treating us to some of the best soap of the year. Pat and Frank's erotic reunion was interrupted by Irene, sending the two fun-sized lovers scrambling into their clothes in a muck sweat of guilt. So flustered was Pat that she lost one of her earrings, and spent the next few minutes looking strangely denuded with her unadorned lobe. The tell-tale trinket turned up on the back of Peggy's pashmina, whence it was retrieved by Frank in a fake embrace. The scene, like the whole episode, teetered just on the right side of farce, and never more so than when Frank attempted to follow Pat into an aeroplane toilet. "Don't even think about it!" said Pat, but not before we'd all had a vision of two very large people squeezed into a very small cubicle.

Irene, of course, rode off into the sunset in a nifty red jeep, having chosen a life of economic uncertainty in Spain over domestic misery with Terry. "Please, make a choice ..." begged Terry, while the viewing nation bellowed "Take the jeep!"

Ricky Tomlinson and Paterson Joseph made a promising double-act in Safe as Houses (ITV), a one-off drama that would be welcome back as a series. Tomlinson, his hair longer and more luxuriant than ever, was in muted mood as Lawrence, a former master butcher now ekeing out a living as a home security rep. Joseph was his odious boss Gabriel, a salesman who had fallen for his own patter and lost his wife as a result. Together they visited a series of unlucky householders - one of them Dora Bryan in the funniest cameo of the week - until they found themselves inexplicably bound and gagged at the mercy of a gun-wielding maniac. It was up to Tomlinson to talk his way out of that one, which he did, in an impressive set-piece that just proves that the art of TV-acting is alive and well and only waiting for some decent material.

webTitle: Mike Ellison on Rev Richard Butler

fields.headline: A racist on the ropes
fields.standfirst: The Rev Richard Butler, head of the notorious American white supremacist group Aryan Nations, is being sued for assault in a case that could ruin him and his organisation.  Mike Ellison reports
fields.trailText: The Rev Richard Butler, head of the notorious American white supremacist group Aryan Nations, is being sued for assault in a case that could ruin him and his organisation.
fields.body:
Take away the anti-semitic "literature", the white supremacist flag and the fact that he is railing against blacks and Jews, and it might be possible to believe that Shaun Winkler cares about nothing so much as the state of your lawn.

Sheltering in the shadow of a court building against 80 degrees of afternoon sun, the young landscape gardener certainly looks the part: his T-shirt torn and dirty, his work boots heavy, his combat trousers slack and baggy. But this week Winkler is proud to abandon his career on the land for a holiday spent standing up for what he believes in. And what he believes in, above all else, is his mentor, the Rev Richard Butler, founder of the Aryan Nations and an all-round racist, bigot and hate-monger. This, should there be any misunderstanding, is a description borrowed from Butler's lawyer.

Business is going well enough for the God-fearing Winkler, though fear is probably an emotion stirred more readily when the church you attend every Sunday has as its centrepiece a bust of Adolf Hitler. "I go to people's houses, they call me up and ask me to come back again," he says. "I must be doing something right." Any non-white customers might not agree, but that is beside the point: he doesn't have any. Non-whites are statistically negligible in Coeur d'Alene, Idaho, and if it were otherwise Winkler would not choose to live in this town.

Business for Butler, on the other hand, has never been worse. Then there is nothing to do but wait until Butler, whose original calling was as an aeronautical engineer in California, is driven to the hearing in an aged Ford truck spewing toxic fumes and bearing licence plates proclaiming Idaho's motto: "Famous Potatoes." Inside, the case proceeds, often assisted by evidence from tattooed former members of Butler's posse despite the high price he places on the virtue of fidelity.

This would not be enough to cover his liability, but would deprive the white supremacists of their core and rallying point.

Butler at first had trouble at first finding a lawyer. But now his defence is in the hands of Edgar Steele, who argues that the civil rights squad is attempting to turn a trivial matter into an assault on liberty: "It is still legal in this country to be a bigot. "Here we have a case involving two people whose presence at the entrance to the Aryan Nations in the dead of night is at least questionable, who get chased and given a good fright by rowdy members of the Aryan Nations, acting well beyond the scope of their authority, who sustain no physical and highly questionable psychological injuries."

Outside in the street, Winkler the gardener is enjoying the attention and reflecting on his creed. "I came here because there were too many non-whites in Pennsylvania. I saw non-whites commit crimes against our people and I decided to take a stand for what I think is right. It's not because they're black; it's their culture. They're animals. They're savages."

Winkler explains how he became involved with white power groups at the age of 15 when he was taken to a Ku Klux Klan rally. "There was this nigger state trooper and he told us to take off our hoods and the guy I was with said to the nigger: 'You try to take off my hood and I'll punch you out.' Yeah, they took him away.'"

The gardener was arrested himself two years later. "That was just because of the communist police we have in this country." Still, it could be worse. "I heard that in German now you can't even give a Sieg Heil salute without being arrested." But now the small talk has to stop because the court is about to adjourn for the day and that means it's time to put on a show. First there is a hunt for some bagels, which are torn into pieces so that they may be thrown at the Jewish civil rights lawyers. Then more skinheads arrive and a small corridor is formed. Above it are the Aryan Nations banner and three Confederate flags.

A man in his late 30s appears on the scene to give the zealots a pep-talk. He tells them: "I don't want to see you guys yelling and screaming and getting arrested because we're better than that." Out comes Butler with his cropped white thatch, shuffling his way towards the arthritic Ford, his right hand raised towards his supporters. The old man with the complexion of dried orange peel is helped into the truck and off he goes back to the compound, which is guarded by his three German shepherd dogs, Fritz, Nazi and Hans. They are there to protect the church with the Hitler bust, his offices lined with extremist tracts, the watchtower, the men's and women's barracks and the shower area with a red swastika on the roof. His followers are left to trail across the car park opposite the courthouse, chanting a ragged anthem. Four of them get into a new green Buick and drive away, pausing only to wave pedestrians across the road in front of them.

It is easy to see why Butler's lawyer wants to make much play of his contention that his opponents are trying "to paint this rag-tag band of borderline derelicts as a highly organised, well-trained and disciplined military organisation". But Aryan Nations is taken seriously enough by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms: seven "photographers" covering the case had their media credentials removed after it emerged that they are actually federal agents.

And Steve Judy, the town's mayor, cannot bear the image of Idaho as a playground for racists as well as the more innocent outdoor types drawn to its 18m acres of protected wilderness. "Human rights groups outnumber hate groups here 10 to one," says the mayor. "Richard Butler is not that big a deal. We're talking about nine people living there full-time. The biggest problem is the message of hate he sends out and the link to our region."

It is true that until this point nothing has been pinned on Butler personally. But moonlighting Ayrans were among members of the Order, another far-right group, which murdered a Denver talk-show host and conducted a string of violent robberies in the 80s; members of the Aryan Republican Army, responsible for 22 bank raids 10 years later to finance a white revolution, were linked to Butler; and Bufford Furrow, who is accused of wounding three children and two adults at a Jewish community centre in Los Angeles last year before murdering a postman, is a former Aryan Nations security guard.

Whatever the outcome of the court case, no matter the future for Butler, buffoon or soldier for a caucasian nirvana, Winkler the gardener is not going to go away. "They can take our land, but they can't take Aryan Nations from our hearts."

webTitle: What the Levi's ad says about you

fields.headline: Who are you? What the Levi's ad says about you
fields.standfirst: What the Levi's ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Levi's ad says about you
fields.body:
The ad: A groovy young chap strolls onto an underground train. He is clad in Levi's new twisted jeans. A pretty girl sitting opposite, who is similarly attired, eyes him up and down, and a silent game ensues. He bends his head slightly to reveal his parting is "twisted", just like his pants. She responds by showing him her front teeth which follow the same bendy line. He raises a "twisted" eyebrow, then she shows him her "twisted" tummy button. Not to be outdone, our hero moves to undo his jeans, just as the lights flicker out on the train... The ad ends with a shot of the girl looking suitably startled.

The jargon: Levi's introduced their new "ergonomically sculpted" engineered jeans (complete with twisted side seam) back in March, and this ad is part of the second-wave of communication. It builds on the launch product message by making an icon out of the twist and depicting a, well, twist on the traditional, flirty, boy-meets-girl scenario.

Personality: The denims are billed as "the definitive jeans for young people today". Hence you are 15-19 years old, male or female, probably urban rather than living out in the sticks and, of course, extremely fashion-savvy, says agency Bartle Bogle Hegarty.

Financial status: LEJ's retail at around £55, which is probably a standard price for a pair of good-quality jeans. The target market might have to save up a bit, but it's the sort of price they are used to paying.

Telling lifestyle detail: You do all the right stuff - eg go clubbing and gigging, read Dazed & Confused and i-D, wear all the latest trainers and T-shirts and are generally "up there" fashion-wise.

Other relevant data: Typically for Levi's commercials the music is paramount, and talks are underway to release the track (The Second Line by Liverpool band Clinic) as a single. In case you didn't know, Clinic specialise in "retro futuristic millennium psych-rock", says their label.

fields.headline: No: 1712
fields.standfirst: Kerry Packer
fields.trailText: Kerry Packer
fields.body:
Age: 62.

So what's the big deal? Packer just blew £13.6m in a three-day Las Vegas baccarat extravaganza.

Hey, big spender! One of the biggest. Last September he blew £11m at Crockford casino in London - the largest single loss in British gambling history. Packer gambles as much as £100,000 per hand, and may have two hands going at the same time. He once, famously, lent the actor George Hamilton £125,000 in chips, then refused repayment.

A generous man then. Packer is Australia's richest man, worth some £3bn. His media empire, Publishing and Broadcasting, owns Nine Network television station as well as, coincidentally, Australia's largest casino. £13m? Peanuts to Kezzer.

And is he also a king of hearts? In a manner of speaking. Packer has suffered eight heart attacks and claims to have been declared clinically dead on October 7 1990, following a cardiac arrest.

But is his a heart-warming rags-to-riches story? You bet. Once upon a time, old grandfather Packer found a 10 bob note on a Tasmanian street. He bet it on a horse, paid his boatfare to Oz with the winnings, and started the family business.

So he's hardly one of life's losers. Oh, no. Packer makes three or four trips to Vegas each year, and once won £13m at the MGM Grand. Friends allege that his photographic memory gives him the edge ... We can only assume that this time he was out of film.

And does Packer play with the big boys? Kerry is reputedly numero uno on the world's list of 150 "whales" - players who regularly win (and lose) obscene amounts of money. Other big cetaceans include the Sultan of Brunei and arms dealer Adnan Kashoggi. For these whales, perks include free use of the casino's presidential suite and private jet, plus an instant credit line of £3.5m. Drinks are probably on the house too.

Do say: Family Fortunes.

Don't say: Play Your Cards Right.

webTitle: UK's 'unknown' master painter dies of cancer

fields.headline: UK's 'unknown' master painter dies of cancer
fields.trailText: The artist Euan Uglow, known for his haunting nudes and vibrant still life paintings, died yesterday after a short battle against cancer, aged 68.
fields.body:
The artist Euan Uglow, known for his haunting nudes and vibrant still life paintings, died yesterday after a short battle against cancer, aged 68.

Uglow's work was exhibited in museums and galleries in the UK, including the Tate, and abroad during the past four decades. He was known for the quality of his observation and the meticulousness of his technique.

Each of his paintings took months or often years to complete and he rarely did more than two a year.

David Sylvester, an art critic, last night paid tribute to his friend, saying: "He painted for 50 years and more without losing intensity. He painted from nature in a way that was somehow remarkably literal yet never banal. Also, the work was extremely austere yet wonderfully lyrical."

Born in 1932, Uglow studied at Camberwell and Slade schools of art. He later became one of the most distinguished postwar British painters, even though his name is still unfamiliar to the wider public.

"Euan's work is vastly underestimated, both nationally and internationally," Catherine Lampert, director of the Whitechapel art gallery, said. "He depicts the human figure in bold new poses and haunting forms. The result sends shivers down one's spine."

Sir Nicholas Serota, director of the Tate, said: "Euan Uglow was a distinguished and distinctive painter in the long tradition of painting from the model. His carefully constructed nudes and still life paintings were the products of rigorous observation of objects in the studio. Euan was much admired by other artists and he was an influential teacher at the Slade."

Richard Morphet, former keeper of the modern collection at the Tate, added: "Euan Uglow was an outstanding painter. Unusually ordered, purposeful and concentrated, his method itself becomes part of the content of each image he created. Paradoxically, its effect is animating."

A perfectionist, Uglow was known for working slowly, and some of his works took up to seven years to complete. He once said: "No one can be perfectionist enough. I've just got to go to a great deal of trouble. What's the point of being slack about painting if it's the most interesting thing you do in your life? Pointless."

Using a painstaking method of measurement, he marked every inch of the canvas and left the marks in place.

"The positions I ask my models to sustain are difficult, emotionally and physically," he said. "They may only come once a week. While I am painting they often go through a cycle of personal events. When one model first arrived, she had a boyfriend. Later she married, and by the time I was done, she was divorced."

Guarding his time fanatically, his days were strictly regimented. Everything was sacrificed to work. He did not have a television and listened to the news only twice a week.

Uglow's talent was recognised at 16 when he attended Camberwell school of arts and crafts, where he was taught by Tom Monnington, later president of the Royal Academy. Hating to be pigeon-holed, Uglow refused to join the Royal Academy in 1961. In 1990, however, he agreed to become an artist/trustee of the National Gallery.

Neil MacGregor, director of the National Gallery, said last night: "Euan Uglow was a distinguished trustee and appropriately his last completed work, Nuria, is on show in the gallery in the exhibition Encounters."

webTitle: Big disparity in waiting times for operations

fields.headline: Big disparity in waiting times for operations
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: NHS patients in south-east England are waiting up to two months longer for operations than their counterparts in the west Midlands, according to a regional analysis of health service delays published yesterday by the independent Centre for Economics and Business Research.
fields.body:
NHS patients in south-east England are waiting up to two months longer for operations than their counterparts in the west Midlands, according to a regional analysis of health service delays published yesterday by the independent Centre for Economics and Business Research.

In the second quarter of this year patients were waiting 201 days on average from seeing a GP to getting in-patient hospital treatment. This was 3.6 days quicker than in the first quarter, it said.

But the national average masked big regional variations. In the south-east the average wait across all types of operation was 215.5 days, compared with 184.4 days in the west Midlands, and 188.7 in Trent.

The gap was even greater in some medical specialities. The average wait for ear, nose and throat operations was 169 days in the west Midlands and 238.6 days in the south-east.

The average delay for a typical hip replacement operation in England was 255.6 days, varying from 232.9 days in the west Midlands to 277.7 days in the eastern region. The shortest average waiting times were for gynaecology patients in the north-west, averaging 141.2 days.

Ian Bogle, chairman of the British Medical Association, said: "The BMA has always stressed that what matters to patients is not the numbers on waiting lists but the time the individual has to wait for treatment."

But the Department of Health said the figures in the report were wrong. "First, not all patients who see a specialist doctor for an outpatient appointment need to have an operation.

"Secondly, the outpatient waiting times figures used in this survey measure people who have already had their appointment."

But the Department of Health said the figures in the report were wrong. "First, not all patients who see a specialist doctor for an outpatient appointment need to have an operation. "Secondly, the outpatient waiting times figures used in this survey measure people who have already had their appointment."

webTitle: Call for more investment in research

fields.headline: Call for more investment in research
fields.standfirst: Special report: the comprehensive spending review
fields.trailText: Extra government money is needed to support new "seed corn" research ventures in British universities, a report by the higher education funding council for England said yesterday.
fields.byline: Will Woodward and Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
Extra government money is needed to support new "seed corn" research ventures in British universities, a report by the higher education funding council for England said yesterday.

The report pointed to a survey which showed that per million pounds spent, British research was the most widely read and used among industrialised countries. The council expected more departments to win top ratings in the next research assessment exercise. To fund those departments and protect existing top rated research an extra £60m needed to be found, the council estimated.

"We have said that our priority is to protect top rated units. Unless there is extra money from the government to reward the improvement that is expected to be demonstrated in the 2001 research assessment, funding will have to be even more selective," the report said.

"Such a move would also be at the expense of the enormous strengths shown in the rest of the sector, as it would choke off essential seed corn funds for developing research groups, developing research areas and collaborative research endeavours."

The report said Hefce's present funding arrangements for distributing its annual £1bn research grant should stay "broadly intact".

But a new capability development fund should be established to allow universities to start researching new areas.

Research grants are already heavily concentrated in universities. The most recent figures for all contracts and awards showed that the so-called "golden triangle" of institutions in the south-east - made up of Oxford, Cambridge, University College London, and Imperial College London - secured a quarter of all research funds received by UK universities in 1998-99.

The report welcomed the £675m earmarked for research by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, in the comprehensive spending review last month.

fields.headline: UN troops 'collaborate' with West Siders
fields.standfirst:
Peacekeepers seen standing by as renegades rob at checkpoints
Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: UN peacekeepers responsible for security in the area where the West Side Boys abducted 11 British soldiers and a Sierra Leonean officer a week ago continue to jointly man checkpoints with them, at which civilians are robbed and abused.
fields.body:
UN peacekeepers responsible for security in the area where the West Side Boys abducted 11 British soldiers and a Sierra Leonean officer a week ago continue to jointly man checkpoints with them, at which civilians are robbed and abused.

The seizure of the British troops, five of whom were freed on Wednesday night, has also raised questions about the fate of hundreds of Sierra Leoneans held by the West Side Boys, who have robbed and raped with virtual impunity in recent months.

Human Rights Watch accuses the UN of appeasing the renegade soldiers and former prisoners who make up most of the West Side Boys fighters while entire villages are depopulated by civilians fleeing in fear.

At least five UN checkpoints in the Masiaka area continue to be manned by Jordanian peacekeepers while armed West Side Boys are present or in control. A taxi driver described roadblocks at which UN soldiers sit in the shade while drunken or drugged young men wielding machetes and guns rob drivers and abuse civilians.

"If you see the West Side Boys at the checkpoint it is very bad news," he said.

"They just point their guns in your face and ask what you have in your pockets and the UN soldiers don't do anything.

"I don't think they could just kill you there, because that would be too much, but you know that if they want to kill you a mile down the road the UN won't do anything, because they are so friendly with these guys."

The West Side Boys are what is known in Freetown as "self-provisioning". They are notorious for robbery, extortion, abduction and rape. They are believed to be holding several hundred civilians, some of them wealthy businessmen snatched from their cars on the main road into Freetown and held for ransom.

Many women and girls are raped and held as sex slaves.

Last month the UN sent Nigerian troops and Indian helicopter gunships to clear the West Side Boys from the road and press them to demobilise. Despite a heavy bombardment of the Occra Hills, where the renegades are camped, the abuses began again almost immediately.

Some in the UN believe the West Side Boys were tipped off that the attack was coming and withdrew to a safe area.

"I do not think collaboration is too strong a word to describe what is happening," a UN official who regularly drives the road to visit refugees said.

"The Jordanians are feeding those guys and socialising with them without thinking that these are the same ones who are killing people and raping girls. Some of us have commented on this inside the UN and said we can't just have our soldiers stand by and let it happen, but we are told that we have to build confidence so [that] they give up their guns and join the demobilisation process."

A UN spokesman, Lieutenant Commander Patrick Coker, declined to comment beyond saying: "It's not true."

The British have had close contact with the group in recent months.

When the war flared up again in May, British officers were so desperate to find fighters to defend the government that the West Side Boys were supplied with large amounts of ammunition, and food and medicines.

During a crucial battle at Rogberi Junction, a British lieutenant-colonel directed the West Side Boys attack on the rebels.

But relations soured as the renegades showed little enthusiasm for putting themselves under the direct command of the government's new army.

In June, West Side Boys fighters turned their guns on government troops during a battle for another town, Lunsar. The dispute was about rank: the renegades wanted to keep the grand ranks - they have a lot of "brigadiers" - they had awarded themselves in the bush.

The hostility and suspicion grew when two of their leaders were arrested last month after a gun battle in Freetown over the ownership of a car which once belonged to the captured Revolutionary United Front leader, Foday Sankoh.

A number of the West Side Boys have been accepted for training by the British as soldiers in Sierra Leone's new army, despite the gang's catalogue of human rights abuses.

Before the war restarted, Britain had made plans for carefully screening recruits for the new force.

With the upsurge in fighting, they felt it necessary to recruit any willing soldier, particularly those with experience, and that included many from groups such as the West Side Boys and the kamajor militias, as well as members of the former government army who were responsible for an array of atrocities, such as amputations and murdering children.

webTitle: Traffic fumes 'kill 20,000 people a year in Europe'

fields.headline: Traffic fumes 'kill 20,000 people a year in Europe'
fields.trailText: About twice as many people are killed each year in Europe by air pollution as die in road traffic accidents, according to research sponsored by the world health organisation published today in the Lancet.
fields.body:
About twice as many people are killed each year in Europe by air pollution as die in road traffic accidents, according to research sponsored by the world health organisation published today in the Lancet.

Analysis of deaths in France, Austria and Switzerland shows 6% of all deaths - around 40,000 a year - stem from air pollution, around half due to tiny particles in vehicle exhausts, particularly diesel.

In addition, traffic causes 25,000 new cases of chronic bronchitis in adults, 290,000 cases in children and more than 500,000 asthma attacks.

The research says motorists do not pay for the true cost that driving imposes on society.

The Lancet says in an editorial that if the cost of motoring on the health service was taken into account, spending on better public transport would appear far more reasonable, with taxes and laws to reduce driving more publicly acceptable.

Estimates by the Department of Health have put deaths from air pollution in Britain at 10,000 a year.

Yesterday, as a result of the paper, Friends of the Earth said that the number of British deaths was probably 19,000 a year.

In most of Europe because of the high traffic levels tiny particles, 100th of a millimetre across, called PM10s, are always present in the air and are far worse in towns where there is a high population and density of traffic.

On average, including country areas, people are breathing in up to 10 micrograms per cubic metre of these particles, but in city areas it can be three times as much.

The Lancet paper says that life expectancy is shortened by six months for each extra 10 micrograms (100th of a gram) of particles in the air. This means that in cities people die 18 months earlier than they would otherwise.

The research concentrates on the death rates of older people but says there is increasing evidence that air pollution kills babies and infants.

The WHO commissioned the research because it is concerned about the affect on human health of air pollution and its economic cost.

Nino Künzli, from Basle university in Switzerland, the lead author, says the true costs to public health of air pollution are still being studied.

Traffic creates costs to the public health system that are not paid for by the polluters, he says, such as the loss of clean air, silence and clean water.

"The project emphasises the need to consider air pollution and traffic-related air pollution as a widespread cause of impaired health."

Tony Bosworth, air pollution campaigner for Friends of the Earth, said: "These startling figures show that road traffic is having a dreadful toll on our health.

"If the impacts are the same in the UK, then nearly 19,000 deaths every year are due to pollution from road traffic. That's equivalent to a jumbo jet crashing every 10 days. The government must take tougher action on traffic levels to reduce this appalling death toll."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Rapist stays in police station
fields.body:
Rapist stays in police station

A convicted rapist who was freed from Walton prison last week is voluntarily living at a police station in Merseyside for his own safety, police said. Steven Beech, who has a total of 115 convictions for rape, affray and lewd behaviour, is being monitored around the clock.
Helen Carter

Emergency op on stabbed man

Two doctors were yesterday flown by air ambulance to a flat in Lavender Hill, south London, to perform emergency heart surgery on a stab victim. The man underwent further surgery at St George's hospital, Tooting, where he was said to be in critical condition. A man was last night being questioned by police.

Finucane widow to see Blair

The widow of Belfast solicitor Pat Finucane is to meet the prime minister Tony Blair on Monday to demand an independent inquiry into the murder of her husband who was shot dead by loyalists in February 1989.

Scout leader jailed

Trevor Claridge, 43, a Luton scout leader who preyed on boys in his troop over 25 years, was jailed for six years yesterday. Claridge pleaded guilty at Luton crown court to two offences of buggery with young boys. He also appeared for sentence on 13 offences of indecent assault and one of possessing indecent pictures.

Give a dog a phone

An operator in Kelty, Fife, alerted police yesterday after hearing nothing but barking when she answered a 999 call. Police found the house empty except for a dog next to a phone.

webTitle: US Presidential candidates warned off Bible-thumping

fields.headline: Candidates warned off Bible-thumping
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The unprecedented politicisation of religious issues in this year's US presidential election has provoked warnings to the candidates that they should avoid religious zealotry and "messianic delusion".
fields.body:
The unprecedented politicisation of religious issues in this year's US presidential election has provoked warnings to the candidates that they should avoid religious zealotry and "messianic delusion".

The New York Times warned them in an editorial yesterday against "political appeals that are so zealous that they unsettle Americans with different religious views [or can] lead to policies coercive toward non-believers".

Meanwhile the veteran Democrat Eugene McCarthy, who sought the presidency in 1968 on an anti-Vietnam war platform, said it was "unhealthy" for this year's candidates to present themselves as moral or spiritual leaders.

"Religious belief, privately held, may well be good for democracy," he said. "Its politicisation is not."

The debate on the role of religion in the presidential election took off a month ago when the Democratic candidate, Al Gore, chose the Orthodox Jew Joseph Lieberman as his running mate. They made a point of revealing that they shared a prayer before agreeing to run together, and when they made their campaign debut in Nashville the next day they both made repeated references to God. Mr Lieberman said that his selection was a "miracle".

The Republican candidate, George W Bush, and his vice-presidential nominee, Dick Cheney, have been more reticent, but when Mr Bush was asked earlier this year to say which philosopher or historical figure most influenced his thinking, he said Jesus.

Last weekend Mr Lieberman went further still, saying: "We need to reaffirm our faith and renew the dedication of our nation and ourselves to God and God's purpose." Later in the same speech he said: "George Washington warned us never to indulge the supposition that morality can be maintained without religion."

The speech led the Anti-Defamation League, which monitors American anti-semitism, to warn Mr Lieberman openly against "almost hawking" his religion and risking a backlash.

"We believe very strongly that appealing along religious lines or belief in God is contrary to the American ideal," the league said in a letter.

The issue of where to draw the line between religion and politics - or if there should be such a line - is by no means confined to Mr Lieberman. Even in the strongly religious US, the growth of political religiosity in recent years as been striking. This year Mr Gore and Mr Bush have both actively encouraged interviewers and voters to see them as highly religious figures.

Warning against this trend Mr McCarthy, now 84, said that such tactics "mock God and muddle politics".

"The president is not the moral leader of his people, no matter how often he prays or mentions God's name," he said.

"He was never intended to be the moral leader, and it is unhealthy when candidates for president present themselves or are regarded in this way, especially when they think they have a pipeline to God.

"Morality, compassion, decency and good manners are not the province merely of religious - or 'deeply religious' - people. There may be more than a few secular humanists out there who are good neighbours and better citizens. Religifying politics tempts politicians to messianic delusion."

The New York Times struck a similar note, saying that there "should never be any compromise" with the constitution's ban on government establishment of religion. Those who made such points "should not be denigrated as immoral or anti-religion."

In the past decade Republicans have been to the fore in making religious faith a political issue. Black Americans apart, Democrats have traditionally played cooler on religious themes.

But the influential opinion pollster Stanley Greenberg, who has worked for Bill Clinton and Tony Blair and now works for Mr Gore, wrote recently that the party "needs to honour" its religious traditions.

webTitle: Churchill spirit powers hi-tech Pig Command

fields.headline: Churchill spirit powers hi-tech Pig Command
fields.trailText: Eat your heart out, Winston Churchill. If only he had two internet sites, emails and computerised mailing when Britain faced its darkest hour. These are the latest hi-tech weapons being used at Pig Command - the Whitehall nickname for the Ministry of Agriculture's emergency control headquarters aimed at containing the swine fever that threatens pig exports.
fields.body:
Eat your heart out, Winston Churchill. If only he had two internet sites, emails and computerised mailing when Britain faced its darkest hour. These are the latest hi-tech weapons being used at Pig Command - the Whitehall nickname for the Ministry of Agriculture's emergency control headquarters aimed at containing the swine fever that threatens pig exports.

Like the cabinet war rooms - visited by thousands of tourists - a war command has been set up in an unused Westminster basement near MI5 headquarters.

Forty or so civil servants man a nerve centre overseeing life and death for some 12,000 pigs. The three room centre has three crisis desks; a kitchen cabinet table; a map room and an operations centre to check the disease has not spread. This is run by Gary, more usually overseeing the checking of passports for pets at Dover. But his reports will eventually lead to the all-clear to end the crisis.

The map room contains large ordnance survey maps of East Anglia, with infected areas marked out.

All that is missing is a bed so the cabinet minister in charge, Nick Brown, can sleep overnight if the crisis got out of hand. But so far this has proved unnecessary. Yesterday was the 19th consecutive day when no new outbreak had been confirmed. So far five outbreaks have been confirmed and 69 others checked out - with 44 cleared and restrictions lifted.

The politically incorrect slogan on the board in Pig Command is "Get 'em off" - a phrase referring to the seven days it took to lift restrictions on farms outside the five original outbreak areas.

The areas suffering the worst restrictions are in the constituencies of three Tory ex-agriculture ministers -Gillian Shephard; John Gummer and John Macgregor.

The fourth area takes in the constituency of Tim Yeo, the shadow agricultural spokesman.

Mr Brown - who with his department's chief veterinary officer and many of his civil servants cancelled their summer holidays at the last moment - is pleased that the issue has not become the main "silly season" story. "By stamping on the problem at once we seem to have stopped it, touch wood, from spreading and turning it into a crisis.

"If someone had not taken charge Whitehall would not have known what to do and the whole thing - because it is highly infectious among pigs - could have spread everywhere."

He said he had obtained millions of pounds of government cash - £35 per infected pig and £10 per piglet - to compensate farmers in the five infected areas from today.

webTitle: Fears that Briton may be 'sex slave'

fields.headline: Fears that Briton may be 'sex slave'
fields.trailText: The father of Lucie Blackman, the Briton who disappeared in Tokyo two months ago, said yesterday she may have been drugged and smuggled to Hong Kong to work as a sex slave.
fields.body:
The father of Lucie Blackman, the Briton who disappeared in Tokyo two months ago, said yesterday she may have been drugged and smuggled to Hong Kong to work as a sex slave.

Tim Blackman, whose daughter should be celebrating her 22nd birthday today, said the hotline set up in Japan by her family had received an anonymous tip that she had been taken out of the country with four other western women.

He feared his daughter, a former British Airways steward who disappeared after arranging to meet a client she met while working as a nightclub hostess in the city's Roppongi district, may have been drugged and had her hair cut off to disguise her.

An Englishman who wishes to remain anonymous has donated a £100,000 reward for information leading to her discovery, said Mr Blackman, who flew back to Britain from Tokyo last week.

The 47-year-old property developer from Ryde, Isle of Wight, added: "I believe it is quite credible that she is no longer in the country. The police have not been able to pinpoint where she is even though her image is well known in Tokyo and she has become a household name."

Miss Blackman's family hope the Japanese police will contact their counterparts in Hong Kong.

webTitle: Drug trials offer prospect of longer life

fields.headline: Drug trials offer prospect of longer life
fields.trailText: Hopes of developing an anti-ageing pill have been boosted after it emerged yesterday that scientists increased the normal lifespan of a creature using drugs.
fields.body:
Hopes of developing an anti-ageing pill have been boosted after it emerged yesterday that scientists increased the normal lifespan of a creature using drugs.

The test animal, a tiny nematode worm, lived between 50% and 100% longer than normal, according to research published in the Science journal. The work could lead to a revolution in the treatment of human age related diseases, and trials with the drug could start in the next five years.

The scientists - from Manchester University, Buck Institute in California, Emory University in Georgia and the biotech company Eurkarion Inc - focused on the natural chemical warfare that goes on all the time in living tissue. The targets were the toxic free radicals, substances produced in the cells as a by-product of the body's use of oxygen. Free radicals damage proteins and DNA, and are implicated in cancer and other diseases such as Alzheimer's and Parkinson's. The effect of free radicals can be lessened by anti-oxidant vitamins but only for a limited time.

For their experiments, the British-American team chose drugs which acted as catalysts - substances which provoked a change without themselves changing. These catalysts turned the harmful free radicals into harmless water and oxygen, permitting the worms a long life with normal growth and reproduction.

"We were amazed by what we were seeing down the microscope as these experiments progressed," said Gordon Lithgow of Manchester University. "As the untreated worms began to die, the drug-treated worms were swimming around full of life.

"Every time we repeated the experiment, it worked. We realised we were on to something pretty significant."

Simon Melov of the Buck Institute said: "The results are the first real indication we have had that ageing is a condition that can be treated through appropriate drug therapy."

The nematode's lifespan is measured in days, which makes it suitable for research into the ageing process. Research based on the creature has already yielded an awareness of genes, probably common to many living things, which affect longevity.

Ageing itself is a puzzle. Researchers can see why creatures die, but not why they get old. Skin becomes inelastic, bones weaken, muscles atrophy and blood flow becomes sluggish. Free radicals have been under suspicion for decades but, until now, nobody had though their effects could be countered by drugs from the pharmacist. The drugs used were synthetic versions of the natural enzymes superoxide dismutase and catalase. Wild nematodes treated with the drugs lasted on average 50% longer than those not treated. The scientists also treated a mutant strain of nematode with a shorter than normal lifespan. The process kept them alive 67% longer than normal.

The findings mean that scientists can begin to look at ageing as a solvable biological problem.

Average lifespans have nearly doubled in the past century, and some believe that the new understanding of genetics could extend the human lifespan by another 50 years in the future.

The thrust of much modern medicine, however, is not so much to keep people alive for longer as to keep them healthy and active for longer.

"Here you have a class of compounds that are perhaps affecting the ageing process. We are coming at this without any idea of what ageing is," said Dr Lithgow.

"Ageing is a big black box. We don't know what is going on. We know that ageing processes are causal to a whole host of age related diseases. Here is a common factor - not a cause, I would say, but a factor - in a bunch of different age-related diseases and potentially, here is a route to investigate."

Dr Lithgow said he did not see the drugs as being used to stave off the process of growing old. He said biotech companies could be testing the drugs on specific diseases over the next five years, "but that could be on things like radiation burns - a long way from interfering with ageing".

The experiments were backed by the charity Research Into Ageing. "This is a significant piece of work," said the director, Elizabeth Mills.

"The focus is on preventing disease in old age, not on extending life for its own sake. This is about making the years that are available to us all as healthy, active and independent as possible."

fields.headline: Stalking 'a product of isolation'
fields.trailText: The increasing incidence of stalking is the result of the isolation of modern urban living and a fear of other human beings, according to a report published in The Psychologist today.
fields.body:
The increasing incidence of stalking is the result of the isolation of modern urban living and a fear of other human beings, according to a report published in The Psychologist today.

The study, by Paul Mullen, a professor of psychological medicine at Monash University at Victoria, Australia, argues that "aloneness, both as valued privacy and feared loneliness," draws the stalker to shadow his victim, the watcher to the window and cyberintruder to the internet.

The report, based on a number of sample studies throughout the western world, found that 80% of stalkers were men and 70% of victims were women.

Those stalkers who had appeared before the courts were mostly from lower socio-economic backgrounds and many suffered from minor personality disorders, and occasionally from schizophrenia or delusional disorders.

Gareth Hughes, a research fellow at the Institute of Criminology at Cambridge University, said the report was one of the best descriptions of stalking to date, but cautioned against describing the intrusion as a modern phenomenon.

"DeClembault syndrome was afflicting middle-class women in 18th century France," he said. "They were falling madly in love with the media celebrities of their day - the minor aristocrats - and pursuing them fanatically."

A Home Office spokesman said that, under stalking laws introduced three years ago, 4,304 people were charged with causing harassment in 1998, with 175 sentenced to a maximum of six months. 1,505 people were charged with the more serious offence of putting people in fear of violence, with 576 sentenced to a maximum of five years.

But some of these harassment cases were not related to stalking, he added.

webTitle: Carnival out of control, say police

fields.headline: Carnival out of control, say police
fields.trailText: Attendance at future Notting Hill carnivals on bank holiday Monday should be restricted to help prevent violence, police leaders suggested yesterday.
fields.body:
Attendance at future Notting Hill carnivals on bank holiday Monday should be restricted to help prevent violence, police leaders suggested yesterday.

The Metropolitan Police Federation, which represents rank and file officers, said crime figures were played down for political reasons, and that attendance should be cut by a third from the notional 1m total this year.

It said officers were forced to turn a blind eye to crime because they were afraid of provoking violence.

Two men were murdered this year in separate incidents. Police estimate 1m people crammed the streets of the west London district on Monday, traditionally the busier of the two days.

Glen Smyth, chairman of the federation, said: "For a number of years, the level of reported crime is far below that which really happens.

"There is a significant criminal minority who exploit it in full knowledge that the police will tread extremely lightly."

The vice-chairman, Dave Rodgers, suggested that barriers be put round the route to regulate the number of visitors.

The Notting Hill Carnival Trust, which organises the parade, said: "Realistically, there is no way of stopping people coming to Notting Hill for the carnival. The carnival is run on public roads and people have a right of way."

webTitle: Erosion tips RAF shells on to beach

fields.headline: Erosion tips RAF shells on to beach
fields.trailText: Children collecting seashells on a beach in Yorkshire have been warned to be on their guard against shells of the exploding variety.
fields.body:
Children collecting seashells on a beach in Yorkshire have been warned to be on their guard against shells of the exploding variety.

Bomb disposal teams clearing unexploded ordnance from the disused RAF Cowden base on the coast near Hornsea say erosion is now so bad that old practice shells from the clifftop bombing range are falling on to the sand more quickly than they can clear them.

"Each time the tide comes in it's depositing a bit more ordnance on to the beach," said Chief Technician Paul Duckworth of RAF Wittering in Cambridgeshire, who is overseeing clearance of the 600 acre bombing range. "The locals are well aware this is a danger area, but it's the tourists we're worried about. We've had reports of people picking these things up and taking them home as souvenirs, and we're pleading with anyone who has done so to call the police."

He said it was impossible to say what proportion of the shells, which are mostly 60cm long and weigh more than 11kg, were unexploded.

The remote two mile stretch of beach remains open to the public but warning signs are clearly displayed and Mr Duckworth said controlled explosions were taking place at a safe distance from holidaymakers.

The range was used by army tanks during the second world war and, since 1959, by the RAF to train pilots. Erosion forced its closure in 1998.

The cliffs at RAF Cowden are falling into the sea at the rate of around 1.5m to 2m each year, making the erosion among the most drastic in Europe.

fields.headline: California now a 'minorities' state
fields.trailText: America's historic march towards the racial melting pot has passed a milestone with the publication of official figures showing that ethnic minorities are now collectively the majority in California, the US's most populated state.
fields.body:
America's historic march towards the racial melting pot has passed a milestone with the publication of official figures showing that ethnic minorities are now collectively the majority in California, the US's most populated state.

The census bureau estimates for 1999 show that white non-Hispanics make up 49.9% of California's 33.1m residents while Latinos make up 31.6%, Asians 11.4%, blacks 6.7% and American Indians 0.6%.

The figures reflect a dramatic rise in its Latino and Asian inhabitants in the past 10 years. The Asian population has risen by 36% and the Latino by 34.5%. The black and American Indian populations have grown only slightly and the white non-Hispanic population has fallen by 3.3%.

"It is my hope that we can all see our state's diversity as a cause for celebration and not consternation," the deputy governor, Cruz Bustamente - a Latino - said.

"If there's no majorities, then there's no minorities. Maybe we'll off be able to call each other Californians."

California is not the first state in the US to have a majority of minorities. Hawaii's population is 71% ethnic minority, mainly Asian and Pacific islanders. The District of Columbia, though not a state, also has a population in which minorities, mainly black Americans, add up to 71%.

The shift in California is a harbinger of one of the most profound changes facing the US as a whole this century.

Minorities account for 28.1% of the present population, but the bureau estimates that minorities will overtake the white non-Hispanic mbetween 2055 and 2060. A hundred years from now minorities will amount to 60% of the total: a third of Americans will be Latinos, compared with 12% today.

As they have been for most of US history, black Americans are the biggest minority at just under 13%. Asians account for 4% and American Indians 1%. But this order is projected to change as soon as 2005, when the proportion of Latinos overtakes the proportion of blacks.

The last time California did not have a white non-Hispanic majority is thought be 1860.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Two quit over soldiers' deaths
fields.body:
Two quit over soldiers' deaths

Two senior Israeli officers have tendered their resignations after an army inquiry found that three soldiers killed during a raid on the West Bank on Saturday were hit by friendly fire.

The chief of staff, Lieutenant-General Shaul Mofaz, did not say whether the army had accepted the resignations of the forces commander on the West Bank and the commander of the Duvdevan undercover unit. AP, Jerusalem

Estonia expels Russian 'spies'

Estonia moved yesterday to expel two Russian diplomats accused of spying, prompting Russia to retaliate by kicking out two Estonian diplomats it accused of similar activities.

Relations between Russia and its Baltic neighbours, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, have occasionally been tense since the former Soviet republics regained independence in 1991. AP, Tallinn

Fears grow on volcano island

The mayor of Miyakejima, the Japanese island hit by a series of volcanic eruptions, yesterday urged most of its remaining residents, especially women and the elderly, to leave. Schoolchildren have already been evacuated to Tokyo, 113 miles to the north, and more than half the island's 3,850 residents have left of their own accord. Reuters, Miyakejima

Bus station bomb injures 13

At least 13 people were injured when a bomb exploded in a mini-bus terminal in the southern Philippines yesterday.

No group has claimed responsibility for the blast in Kabacan, according to a television report. It is the tenth bombing in the country in three months. Previous explosions have been blamed on Muslim extremists. Reuters, Manila
